The cyclist trusted a man that didn't know much about the world. He naively thought that the guy would know how to get to the place he was looking for. The cyclist took his advice without hesitation. He assumed that he would be there really soon, so he started to drink his water really fast. Soon enough, he realized that he was out of water and the park he was going to was nowhere near. The cyclist got extremely frustrated and angry. He was now crossing the desert, which was making him terribly tired and dehydrated. He passed this rough road filled with tumbleweeds and snakes, yet he kept on going until he saw the “@CAPS1 Juice” company. He quickly hurried there, went into the bathroom, and drank some water. When he got out, an old man asked if he needed directions, but the cyclist, still annoyed, said no. In conclusion, the cyclist's trust in the wrong person and his hasty actions led to a difficult and frustrating situation during his journey.

During the passage “Do not exceed speed limit,” the cyclist endures many hardships. One of those countless hardships was the unforgiving setting that he was in. While he was lost, extremely thirsty, and completely exhausted, he remained all the while in “The high deserts of California in June”. This clearly shows that the temperature must have been unbearably high. This intense heat would cause the cyclist to tire out and dehydrate much faster than usual. Also, the surface he was riding on had many steep hills, as it is specifically said when he says “over one long, crippling hill”. This shows that the hills took a great deal of energy to get up. And finally, the author says that “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This shows that if he needed help, there was absolutely no one around to lend him a hand. That is how the setting affected the cyclist in a negative way. In conclusion, the harsh desert setting, the steep hills, and the lack of help all combined to make the cyclist's journey extremely difficult.

It affects the cyclist because in the beginning, the talk is about the old man. It also talks about basically saying their information is out of date. In other words, the cyclist should have just followed his map in the first place. This oversight influenced the cyclist's journey, making it more difficult than it needed to be.

In the stories, “Don’t exceed posted speed limit,” there are some very descriptive settings. In the stories, these settings have a great effect on the cyclist. Through these settings, the effects change, with some being good and some being harsh. The first setting that is described to you is, “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” This setting gives you a vivid picture of where the cyclist is heading. It also establishes a happy sort of mood. However, the pretty picture is about to change. Not much further into the cyclist's ride, he noticed a change of terrain: “the flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” At this point, the cyclist is short on water and is becoming very tired. Seeing this just crushes his spirit. Riding hills is hard, but riding hills without the knowledge of something good waiting for you on the other side of the hills is even worse. Both of these very different settings give off very different feelings. The first one makes you think he is going to have an easy, enjoyable bike ride. But this all changes when he hits those horrible hills. Just the thought of having to ride over miles of hills makes your legs hurt. Overall, the features of the setting imposed an intense bike ride for the cyclist, followed by a reward of a beautiful place.

The author had to bike through extremely hot weather. This made him feel sweat a lot. The narration states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt” (@NUM1). Due to the excessive sweating, this caused him to drink water until he ran out. The narration states, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips” (@NUM1). Left with no water, he then had to suck on pebbles, which was a risky move as he could have choked on them. The narration states, “With any luck, I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat” (@NUM1). This desperate situation shows the harsh impact of the hot weather on the author's biking experience.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” there were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. The most challenging problem faced by the author was the lack of water. “I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn't come out. Nor did I get more than a drip or two, and it had the flavor of battery acid.” When the cyclist set out for the next train, they came to a road that read “Rough road ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The terrain got more bumpy and hard to cross. This affected the determination the cyclist had left. They regretted not listening to the old men, thinking they didn't know what they were talking about because they never left their porches. As you can see, the setting definitely affected the cyclist in physical and mental ways.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. One way it affects the cyclist is by being hot, like it says in the text “I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June” (@CAPS1). The sweltering heat makes the cyclist's journey extremely difficult and uncomfortable. Another way it affects the cyclist is by being bumpy, like it says in the text “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT.” The bumpy terrain not only slows down the cyclist but also adds to the physical strain. That is how the setting affects the cyclist, both physically and mentally, making the ride a challenging one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist through the mood it instills in the cyclist and the events that unfold as he makes his way from the desert to a town. For instance, his mood undergoes a shift when an old man approaches him asking for a map. His attitude transitions from cautiousness upon venturing onto a new road to sheer terror when he fears for his life, thinking “I was gonna die and the birds would pick me clean.” Then, it shifts to pride when the old man asks for a map, and the author states “I own a very good map”. As he continues his journey towards Yosemite, the setting changes; he first traverses a desert - like area and then stops at a bait shop to rest before likely continuing merrily towards his destination.

Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit’ by Joe Kurmaskie clearly demonstrated that the features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. Initially, the cyclist was pedaling through the desert on a bicycle. This had a significant impact because if they had been traveling in a car or on a bus, a lot less energy would have been used up. Moreover, the cyclist started to run out of water. This was a problem as being on a bike in the desert required proper hydration. Another crucial setting factor was the deserted towns. If these towns had not been deserted, the cyclist could have found supplies and support, making the journey much better. All these features combined had a profound and negative effect on the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist such that it influenced his determination to continue. For example, after @NUM1 miles of cycling, he looked upon a “ramshackled shed, several rusty bumps and the corral…”. This sight deeply troubled him. In the scorching desert, his water tasted as unpleasant as “battery acid”. The text also describes this journey as “a test for my inner spirit”. It further states that he struggled on with just a few drops of water as he cycled through the tumbleweeds. This passage clearly shows the numerous obstacles he had to overcome. Despite the difficulties, he persevered and managed to make it with a small boost in confidence. Although his situation was extremely unbearable at times, he still kept pushing forward, demonstrating great resilience.

The setting of the story affects the cyclist throughout most of the narrative. The intense heat made him feel hot and extremely thirsty, while the long - distance travel depleted his energy and increased his need for water. In paragraph @NUM1, the writer describes one of the hills as “long and arduous”. This hill was wearing him out, gradually draining what little energy he had left. The setting of the story was a major factor; the road conditions, whether flat or bumpy, along with the temperature, played a crucial role in determining the cyclist's experience. All these elements combined made the cyclist's journey a challenging one.

The setting easily can affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The area where the cyclist found himself seemed to be completely abandoned, which did not bode well for him. When a town or a road is abandoned, there are no noticeable building structures for quite a while, leaving the cyclist without any shelter or resources. Additionally, the condition and shape of the road were very dangerous for the cyclist. Not only was the path narrow and rocky, but the presence of wildlife also posed a threat. In the text, it describes how a poisonous diamond - back snake was directly in front of the cyclist. This example shows that there could be even more dangerous creatures in the area. Finally, the temperature, whether it was swelteringly hot or freezing cold, limited the cyclist's water supply. The risk of complete dehydration was a huge concern for him. Overall, the conditions of the setting the cyclist was in put him at a significant disadvantage.

The different settings that the cyclist had to encounter were mountains or hills with winding roads and the scorching California desert in June. As well as facing these challenging settings, he was running out of water, which made his journey even more arduous.

How the features of the setting affect the cyclist by taking into account that he did not have the right setting. The features are simply not appropriate, and they could be adjusted slightly while still retaining about the same meaning of the essay. So, I firmly think they should change it around to better suit the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting have a significant affect on the cyclist. He is embarking on this bike ride through the desolate deserts of California in June. This obviously is going to have a profound impact on him because the cycling conditions will be very harsh. At one point he says, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed.” Additionally, the setting of having all these ghost towns was deeply troubling to him because no one else was around and he was beginning to run out of water. The sweltering weather outside was starting to take a toll on him, and he said, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage…” When you're pedaling through the desert on a blisteringly hot day it is going to have detrimental effects on you. If he was in a different setting this feeling of despair would not be present in the story. That is how the setting affects the cyclist.

There are many ways the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One crucial feature is the weather. When a cyclist is on a long - distance trip the weather could affect the setting greatly. For example, if it suddenly started to rain the roads could become extremely slippery and extremely dangerous to ride your bike on. The cyclist and his bike could crash, and in the worst - case scenario, he could die. All just because of the adverse weather. Another important feature is the animals. Animals are significant because wherever you go there are different animals that can behave in various ways. If the cyclist knows the types of animals around the area that he is traveling through, he could keep himself safe and not be harmed. It's far better to know the area and feel secure rather than not knowing what's going to happen next.

As the features changed in the setting it becomes harder for the cyclist. At first, the cyclist started off pretty easily. He had flat, smooth roads to traverse. He set out before the sun could fully bear down on him. “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over it,” he thought. He kept his mind off the sun and this helped him maintain his momentum. Then, he got to a highway that made the journey a bit more difficult. “I noticed the terrain changing. The flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” he noted. So he had to pedal much harder and would tire himself out faster. “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path. Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state was a real struggle.” By the presence of tumbleweeds, it was clear that he was in the desert during a hot period of time. So he had little water left and he was becoming severely dehydrated. This was a tough task for him to overcome. By the terrain changing it became much harder for him to continue his cycling journey.

The setting in this short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is a sweltering, sunny desert expanse, where all towns have been completely abandoned. As described, “The sun was beginning to beat down” (@NUM1). When the cyclist “arrived at the first town, it fit the definition of a ghost town” (@NUM1), a desolate and eerie place. At this point, the cyclist is not only tired but also deeply worried about the dwindling supply of water. The desolate setting and the cyclist’s anxious state run side by side, creating a tense and foreboding atmosphere.

In the story, there are numerous challenges the cyclist has to deal with. He has to endure a series of bad situations just to complete the race. The cyclist must constantly watch out for the rough and uneven road he is traversing. Throughout the entire race, he also has to be vigilant about diamond - back snakes lurking in the area. Water is the cyclist's biggest problem during the whole race. He runs out of water very quickly. When he spots a factory and stops, he puts rocks in his mouth to distract himself from the intense thirst and to make his saliva circulate. The cyclist overcomes all these problems, which clearly shows his strong determination.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. He was riding along on a route that he had little confidence would lead to a proper destination. Since it was the first time he had ever been on that road and he had only outdated knowledge about it, the cyclist felt quite uneasy. The temperature was extremely hot, with very little shade available, and the sun was relentlessly beating down on him. The route was highly discouraging. All the cyclist desired was water, yet the route kept taunting him with false hope. At the first town, he noticed a water pump, but all he could draw from it was sludge and water that tasted like battery acid. Next, he came across a deserted old building that turned out to be an old bottling factory for Welch’s grape juice. The cyclist would seem to be getting close to something to drink, but he was always left empty - handed, highlighting how the setting continuously thwarted his efforts.

During the cyclist's bike ride, the unbearable conditions significantly changed his attitude. When he first starts, the reader can sense his frustration because of the old - timers and their rather vague directions. Then, as he realizes that he might have enough water, his attitude begins to shift. The cyclist goes from being frustrated to appreciating and loving the scenery, as he says, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” However, as the conditions change to even more unbearable heat, he decides to just give up. But then he gathers the courage and continues, “slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” When he finally sees Gary and Wilber’s fish camp, he realizes he is safe, and his long - suffering journey is coming to an end.

The cyclist from “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit” was affected in many ways by the environment. The most frequently mentioned feature in the environment was the severe lack of water. The cyclist was on the verge of death because there was no water available and he was severely dehydrated. Another prominent feature was the intense heat. It was extremely hot in the area where the narrator was cycling. When it's that hot, the heat rapidly dehydrates you. So, the narrator was being pushed to the limit due to the heat. Moreover, all the towns were deserted, and every town he came to had a haunting effect on him until he got angry at the lodgers he talked to and was extremely frustrated. The initially smooth flat road gradually gave way to rolling hills, which made it much harder for him to ride. Lastly, the snake on the road affected him as he had to carefully avoid it. All of these environmental factors combined had a profound impact on him, testing his endurance and resolve.

Do not exceed posted speed limit" by Joe Kurmaskie is truly a story of man against nature. Here is a man who is completely alone, with only his bike, the barren landscape, and the relentless sun for company. First, he notices the sun directly overhead, a common sight in a California June, yet it still bears down on him mercilessly. Then come the rolling hills and the incline in elevation. Going uphill means his body has to work harder, burning calories and quickly depleting his much - needed water supply. Then there is the man's great torture. A speed limit of @NUM1, while he is struggling to go at a tough 12. And worse, there is a billboard showing “a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth”. This truly hits his emotions, clearly showing him what is out of his reach. In this story, every element of his surroundings contributes to his hopelessness, making his journey an almost insurmountable challenge.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. Firstly, the conditions of the road are truly awful, with potholes and uneven surfaces that make every pedal stroke a struggle. Secondly, the cyclist encounters a huge snake blocking his path, a terrifying sight that makes his heart skip a beat. Along with that, the occasional tumbleweed rolls across his way, adding to the desolate and unpredictable nature of the journey. The biggest impact on the cyclist is the lack of water combined with the unbearable heat, and he is extremely tired. All these factors combined wear him down both physically and mentally. These are the effects the features of the setting have on the cyclist, making his ride a difficult and arduous experience.

If I had a choice to ride a bike in California or Vermont, it would be a no - brainer to bike in Vermont. The temperature in Vermont would be much cooler than in California. In the story, the cyclist complains about the “wide rings of dried sweat” on his clothes and the looming possibility of heatstroke. It is well - known that when temperatures rise, the body tends to lose more water through sweating. Had the cyclist gone to a cooler place like Vermont at a different time of year, he wouldn't have struggled with dehydration on his bike ride. Biking in a cooler climate would have made the journey more enjoyable and less of a physical challenge.

The features of the setting in the story affected the cyclist a lot. In the morning when he began his trip, he was full of eagerness and determination to reach his destination. Although it took him forty miles to reach the first “town”, he didn't seem to mind at all. “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them,” is what crossed his mind once the sun began to beat down. This means that he wasn't troubled by the distance or the initial heat at that time. But as his trip progressed, it got hotter, and his water supply dwindled. Once he passed a couple of “troubling sights” that were abandoned with no one around, a sense of unease crept over him and he began to worry. The cyclist got so desperate that he started to suck on pebbles to circulate the last bit of spit he had in his mouth. In his desperation, he finally saw a sign for hope that gave him the strength to carry on. When he arrived at GARY AND @CAPS1’S FISH CAMP, his emotions and state of mind changed from being lugubrious to becoming thankful, relieved to have found a safe haven.

During his cycling trip, the author had to endure extreme heat, face snakes, deal with little or no shade, and survive a dire lack of water, all problems directly related to the setting of Yosemite National Park. The author, cyclist Joe Kurmaskie, writes about becoming dehydrated, describing, “the sun was beginning to beat down and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June”. One of his greatest struggles was crossing the path of a “ridiculously large snake” while trying to keep his balance in his dehydrated state. Kurmaskie runs out of water due to the extreme heat. Upon reaching a water pump, he finds the water to be unfit for drinking and “in the neighborhood of zoo degrees”. Another setting - related issue for Kurmaskie is that the area seems deserted, and he has to continue for miles until he is able to find a spot with clean water where he can rest and rehydrate. These challenges make his cycling trip in this setting a harrowing experience.

The features of the setting were very affective in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” It affected the cyclist because in one part of the setting, the terrain changed to rolling hills. Pedaling a bike on such hilly ground is going to be extremely challenging as it requires a great deal of physical effort. Another way the setting affected the cyclist is that at one point, tumbleweeds were in his way. If a tumbleweed gets caught on the bike, it could disrupt the cyclist's balance and cause him to fall, which might result in harm to him. Lastly, the road started getting rough up ahead, filled with potholes and other irregularities. Riding over these obstacles can be difficult and may even damage the bike. Therefore, the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist throughout his journey.

The features of the setting keep affecting the cyclist because first, the situation seems hopeful, but then he realizes it's hopeless. Initially, he was laughing when people told him the right directions, full of optimism. However, later on, as described in the story, “It was sad, hopeless laughter, mind you, but at least I still had energy to feel bad for myself,” the cyclist reflected on the first town with a sense of despair. The reason this affects the cyclist is that at first, he was making good progress on his journey. Then, he started to get thirsty, and a series of bad things happened. This shift in the setting's influence from hope to despair clearly shows how it impacts the cyclist's state of mind and his overall experience.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” written by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affected the author in many ways. One prominent feature was the hills. The speed limit on these hilly terrains affected the author because he felt that he was moving too slowly. The hilly landscape made it difficult for him to maintain a faster pace. In the story, when it says “I was doing a water - depleting 5 miles an hour,” it serves as clear evidence of how the combination of hills and the speed limit was hindering his progress. This shows that the setting's features, like the hills and the speed limit, had a notable impact on the author's cycling experience.

This is how the setting affects the cyclist. One significant factor is the hot, dry California desert heat. The intense heat was making him extremely hot and constantly thirsty, which led to a rapid depletion of his water supply. The hot desert heat had made the water in the well seem like an unattainable substance, perhaps due to its poor quality or inaccessibility. The water bottle he carried only contained a few tantalizing sips, which were far from enough to quench his burning thirst. The sweltering heat was so intense that it felt as if even the birds would pick him dry. All of these examples illustrate how the harsh desert setting made it difficult for the cyclist to follow the old - timers' advice. It made him realize that wisdom comes with time and that youth can sometimes make silly mistakes. The heat had turned this journey into a test of his inner soul's survival. That is how the setting significantly affects the cyclist.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist mainly because he was in a desert. In this desolate desert environment, there were no stores where he could replenish his supplies, no rivers or lakes to quench his thirst. The heat was scorching, making it extremely uncomfortable for him to ride. The roads were long and stretched out as far as the eye could see, adding to the physical and mental exhaustion. To make matters worse, there were even snakes on the road, which posed a real threat to his safety. All these factors made it much harder for him because he didn't have much water to drink. With limited water and a harsh desert setting, the cyclist faced numerous challenges that made his journey an arduous one.

Many features in the desolate setting profoundly affect the cyclist. Several main features include the car - laden "towns" that are no longer really towns in the traditional sense, and the water pump. Both of these examples gave him a glimmer of hope, but unfortunately, none gave him the much - needed relief. The town he first saw had the potential to give him water, but it was all run down and its resources weakened. “I arrived at the first ‘town’. This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time... refer the @NUM1 word war.” He is saying that the town could’ve provided him with more water and energy, but it appeared that its days of being useful were over. Additionally, he biked across a water pump that was desperately needed. He tried to pump water with great effort but got no success. “I pumped the handle for several minutes but the water wouldnít cool down.” A working water pump wouldíve been a huge boon for him, giving him more strength to continue his bike journey. However, once again, it was very misleading, leaving him in a state of continued hardship.

This is how the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. Another example would be “high deserts of California in June.” This description is clearly saying it's swelteringly hot outside and very tiring. I think it means that because in California, it's really hot, and in June, which is the peak of “summer time,” the heat makes cycling an extremely tiring task. The features affect the cyclist because of how the road is specifically made. If the road is a smooth downhill ride, the cyclist might ride much faster, taking advantage of the natural slope. On the contrary, the road might be going up a steep hill, so he has to go very slow, expending a great deal of energy. There could also be a possibility that the road might have bumpy rocks or patches of thick grass on it. These obstacles can be something really tough to ride through, as they require extra control and effort. So, the effect on the cyclist is clearly depending on how the roads are made, which can either ease or complicate their journey.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist because the worse the features get, the more he desperately wants water. For example, in the essay it said at some point, tumbleweeds crossed his path and a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement in front of him. When I think of tumbleweeds, I immediately think of dryness because it is like dry grass blowing in the wind. And when I think of snakes, I think of the intense heat because that is the time for snakes to come out when it gets scorching hot. So, the cyclist was constantly thinking about the dryness of his throat and the aridness of his surroundings, making him yearn for water even more. Another feature is when he saw a sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth. This sight was like a cruel tease, probably making the cyclist desperately wish he could have that cold, refreshing drink to quench his thirst. In “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclist was significantly affected by the features of the setting. She was first affected by the old men who told her a so - called “shortcut” to her ride to Yosemite National Park. This supposed shortcut led her into unforeseen difficulties. Then she was affected by ghost towns which, to her great disappointment, had no water to give her. As she continued, she was almost dehydrated when she came to a rickety road which had a few tumbleweeds and a huge snake. This situation was quite difficult to get by, as she had to be extremely cautious. Then at the end, she came upon “Gary and Wilberís fish camp” where she finally decided to make decisions herself. All of these things in the setting affected the cyclist in a negative way except “Gary and Wilberís fish camp” which saved her from dehydration, highlighting the importance of a fortunate encounter in an otherwise challenging journey.

In the short story, “Rough Road Ahead”, the cyclist was faced with many problems. One of these is the feature of the setting. I believe it has a big effect. The setting is in a desert, which is extremely hot, with no water around and usually no one living in it. One thing is that he was running out of water. In the text it says, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Another aspect of the setting of the book that affects the cyclist is that it is in June. June is a very hot month, especially when the cyclist is in a desert traveling many miles. This harsh setting not only challenges the cyclist physically but also mentally, as he has to constantly worry about his water supply and the intense heat.

The settings of a cyclist affect the way the cyclist performs. If the weather is too hot, then the cyclist might slow down because of the sun beating down intensely on them. The scorching heat can cause fatigue and make it difficult for the cyclist to maintain their energy. If it's too cold, the cyclist has to put on more clothes, which might weigh them down and prevent them from achieving the speed they need to obtain. The bike also has to be stable. Riding on rough roads requires the cyclist to be more cautious, and the brakes, speeding ability, and the chains being in good conditions are crucial. The area where the cyclist rides sets the mood. If it's a nice scenery, with beautiful landscapes and fresh air, the cyclist might be in a wonderful mood. In contrast, if the scenery is dark and gloomy, with nasty weather behind it, the cyclist might not be as happy as they could be. These types of things clearly help determine how settings can affect the cyclist.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead” the setting greatly affects the cyclists. The arid desert climate bears down upon the cyclist. For example, the further route he takes is not only in a desert, but also has no place to get water. The intense heat and lack of water combine to cause deadly dehydration upon the cyclists. The setting now forces the cyclist to become more determined if he wants to live. He must continue pedaling and pray for a town to come up, so he can restock on water and become hydrated once again. This shows how the setting can be a life - threatening factor for the cyclist and how it tests their willpower.

Many different things affected him on his way to Yosemite National Park, but the environment he was in played the biggest role in his journey. The cyclist was in a dry, desert area where tumble weeds were more common than people. The desolate landscape added to the sense of isolation. When the cyclist came across the old men and asked them for directions, they led him to a “ghost town”. There was no water for the dehydrated cyclist who had been baking in the extremely dry, hot weather. The heat was so intense that it seemed to sap his energy with every passing moment. This caused a problem where the cyclist thought that he would die in the desert because of the weather, the directions he was given, and the lack of water. When the cyclist came across the bait shop he knew he was saved. He became rehydrated and declined directions from an old man because these features of the setting are what caused his problems in the first place: unreliable old men, dry weather, and the scarcity of water.

There are a couple things that affect the cyclist in the story. One of the ways he is affected is dehydration. In the story about dehydration it says “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” The description vividly shows the cyclist's desperate situation. A good affect on the cyclist was that there was no one in sight to slow him down on his bike ride. He could pedal freely without any interruptions. A bad affect on him was not to ask directions from a guy when he was suffering from heat strokes on a gorgeous day in June. The cyclist, not knowing where he was going, received wrong information and blindly followed it. He was oddly excited upon thinking that he finally knew where he was heading. Along his journey, he was confronted with a plethora of challenges, such as the scorching sun. The weather conditions of the area were extremely harsh, and he even came across a big snake. The sun took a toll on him as he was rapidly dehydrating, and he almost had no water left. The intense heat made the journey incredibly difficult and put him in a strange mood. While following the directions, he was startled by a big snake he encountered. He was scared that he was going to be attacked and had no one to help him make his way through. These features affected him because he was lost and ill - prepared for the journey. Since it was summer, the heat was unbearable, and he was riding a bicycle instead of a car. In the end, his lack of knowledge and the tough conditions made his journey a real struggle.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist's train of thought. On page @NUM1, it clearly states, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” This description gives a strong sense of the intense heat and foreshadows the possible lack of water he'll face later on. As he passes a snake, he mentions “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” So, it's quite evident that the cyclist is most likely starting to feel dizzy and is beginning to lose hope. On page @NUM2, he says, “...I could drop from heatstroke...” This shows that he's starting to think of the worst - case scenarios. This affects him deeply as he's beginning to lose hope and believes he might not make it. On page @NUM3, he says, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean...” By this point, the rough conditions are clearly making him worry. In conclusion, the features of the setting had a profound and negative impact on the cyclist throughout the story.

With little water, the setting was extremely unhelpful to the cyclist. Joe @PERSON1 said, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind” (@PERSON1). In such a desolate situation, if there were people passing by in cars or nearby stores, it would probably have been a great help to the cyclist for asking directions. @PERSON1 also mentioned, "working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength" (@PERSON1). Having no water to replenish the body will make a person weak and unstable, which is a huge problem in the middle of nowhere. @PERSON1 further stated, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (@PERSON1). With little water left and a weak body, going up and down those hills must have been excruciating. Additionally, he said, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (@PERSON1). The dust in the lungs and the intense heat from the sun made it even harder for his body to function. All these factors combined made the cyclist's journey extremely difficult.

The setting in the story had a significant impact on the cyclist. The story takes place in June, a time when the heat is at its peak. The cyclist is getting severely dehydrated due to the sweltering conditions. You can vividly imagine how hot it was when the text says, “wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage.” It also gives the impression in the story that it felt like two hundred degrees when the sun was beating down relentlessly. The intense heat not only made the cyclist physically uncomfortable but also added to his mental stress. In conclusion, the hot setting in June was a major obstacle for the cyclist during his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. For example, it was June, and he was in the @CAPS1 of California. The weather was extremely hot, which rapidly dehydrated him. Moreover, he had no idea where he was going, so he had to rely entirely on the directions given by other people. This reliance on others was not always reliable, and he continued to get dehydrated as he struggled to find his way. The combination of the heat, his lack of knowledge of the area, and the need to keep moving in the harsh conditions took a heavy toll on him. In summary, these features of the setting were the main factors that affected the cyclist during his journey.

The features of the settings in “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie were rough and challenging. A biker rides through Todi, California, an area known for its rough terrain that makes cycling a real test. The ride was extremely hot and long under the scorching sun. He was so dehydrated that thick rings of dried sweat were visible around his neck. The solo cyclist says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” He had nowhere to get water or food. The place was completely deserted. He thought that if he died, no one would find him quickly and the birds would pick him clean. The essay “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie shows that solo cyclists are very independent as they have to face such harsh conditions on their own.

In the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist faced many obstacles. For example, he needed to get directions to Yosemite National Park. He asked a couple of elder men, but the information they gave was out - of - date. In addition, when there was a fork in the road, the cyclist had to make a decision. He chose a path that the old men said would have a town nearly eighteen miles down the road. Furthermore, the cyclist encountered flat roads that gradually turned into rolling hills. He also had snakes blocking his path and reached a severe dehydration state that could have easily killed him. In conclusion, this determined man overcame all these obstacles to finally reach Yosemite National Park, showing his perseverance and willpower.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects the cyclist in various different ways. First of all, he listened to the old man's advice and ended up on the wrong path. So he travels on a sweltering hot June day in the California deserts. The odds are against him from the start. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I needed a drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). From his haggard appearance, you can clearly tell that he is tired and almost out of water. The harsh setting puts a great deal of physical and mental strain on the cyclist, but he manages to keep going, showing his resilience.

The setting clearly has a huge effect on the cyclist. The flat roads are easy and smooth to ride on, providing a relatively effortless cycling experience. But as the road changes to short, rolling hills, the biking becomes more difficult. This is supported by the sentence that reads, “Over a long, crippling hill...” This shows that the hill is a very challenging obstacle that requires a lot of physical effort. He is also affected by the things that come with the change in terrain. For example, one sentence reads, “...tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake, it really did look like a diamondback, blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” This stresses how remote the area in which he is biking really is, and shows how it mentally and physically affects his trip, making it both arduous and nerve - wracking.

The effect of the setting is two old timers sitting on their front porch out in the desert. They've been there since Carter was in office. It was starting to become daylight, and he had to walk @NUM1 miles to get to the next town. So he gets on his bike and starts riding towards the next town. The speed limit on the road is 55 miles per hour, but he is going at a mere 12 miles per hour, as slow as a gentle waterflow. He is riding up and down the rolling hills, struggling with each ascent and enjoying the brief respite of the descents. After a long and tiring journey, he finally gets to the next town and is able to continue living his life, having overcome the challenges of the desert setting.

The setting of the essay affects the cyclist because when he asked the old people for directions, he got lost. This shows how the interaction within the setting led to an unexpected and difficult situation for the cyclist, ultimately influencing his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in a lot of ways. In the essay, the author describes how the setting is extremely hot, with the sun beating down relentlessly. The road is bumpy, filled with uneven patches that jolt the cyclist with every pedal stroke. This makes him sweat profusely, drenching his clothes. The heat and the constant physical exertion make him incredibly tired. He is also running out of water due to his intense thirst. The road gets very rocky at one point, making it even more challenging to navigate. The narrator states “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). There is also a photograph that shows how rough the terrain is. It is barren with nothing around it, adding to the cyclist's sense of isolation and struggle. All these aspects of the setting combined had a significant impact on the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the cyclist is severely dehydrated and has to ride on the horrible conditions of a road filled with snakes and hills. All of these features act like obstacle courses, which makes it hard to do what he's trying to do, which is receive water. Also, with the cyclist being hot and in desperate need of water, at this point he is delirious and most likely doesn't know what's going on. In the story, the author's main feature of the setting is the road. “Rough road ahead.” This clearly explains the cyclist having to go on a rough road, and doing that while dehydrated is very dangerous. These are some of the features of the setting that affect the cyclist, highlighting the harsh challenges he faces in this environment.

The settings have a huge affect on the cyclist. When he first comes to the “@CAPS1 town,” he isn't really worried. He is kind of laughing and thinks he's funny by saying, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time - say, before the last world war.” Then after he says that, it says he chuckled. When he gets to the dark part of the road with the risky pipe of water, he begins to switch into conservation mode and starts to get scared. He says, “I would confront water - a test at my inner spirit.” This shows that he was scared. After he sees the abandoned Grape juice factory, he says something like birds are going to pick him clean and leave behind some expensive biking gear. This definitely shows that he is giving up. Another thing that would back this up is when he talks about writing in his diary about the old men who gave him these directions. When he finally reaches the bait shop, he is relieved and goes to the bathroom and drinks water. He also says that he will buy bait even though he doesn't have a rod. These examples clearly show the many ways the setting affected the cyclist, from his initial nonchalance to his growing fear and eventual relief.

In the story, "Do not exceed posted speed limit," the features of the setting affect the cyclist. To keep cool on a sweltering hot summer day, it might be necessary for one to find shade. Just to add to the misfortune of the story, there was no one in sight, not a single building, car, or structure of any kind. This desolate factor does not help the cyclist at all. In fact, all it does is make the cyclist more exhausted as there is no relief from the scorching sun. Another element in the story that affects the cyclist is the lack of water. Early on in the story, the author explains, "The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips." With many more miles to go, the cyclist starts to lose hope of making it to his destination alive. The feature of rolling hills also affects the cyclist. The cyclist is already tired enough, and just to add to his misfortune, "flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills." Even though the hills are short, they still could have a significant impact on him because of the repetitive nature of the hills. Many features of the story affected the mood of the story, creating a sense of despair and struggle for the cyclist.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist. It affected him because the distance indicator was showing @NUM1 miles, and then they reached the first town. The cyclist was getting excited as he thought he was almost done and that he was going at a fast pace. When the cyclist finally got to the first town, he observed that it looked completely dead. After that, as he kept moving forward, he gradually realized that he wasn't really getting anywhere. Then, upon reflection, he noticed that he had listened to some old folks who had never even been off their porch. So, right after hitting the first town, he knew that he should never listen to old folks ever again because that first town seemed like nobody had been in it for years. This experience taught him to be more discerning about the advice he takes.

The features of the setting on the way to Yosemite National Park greatly affected the cyclist. On this long - journey to the park, the cyclist had to face the intense heat of the desert in California. The sun beat down relentlessly, making the air feel like an oven. Besides the heat, the cyclist also had to overcome the rough terrain of the short, rolling hills. The uneven ground made each pedal stroke a struggle, which made the cyclist tired and weary. Adding to his weakness, and with the extreme heat sapping his energy, he also ran out of water, causing him to become dehydrated. “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke...laugh.” This arduous trip through the California desert greatly affected the cyclist by causing great exhaustion and dehydration, but it also likely gave him a newfound respect for the power of nature.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the climate could be hot, making the air thick and stifling. The road could be bumpy, with potholes and uneven surfaces that jolt the cyclist with every turn. And the town could be deserted, with empty streets and silent buildings. For example, “Rough Road Ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit.” This warning sign would be especially challenging for a cyclist who is already thirsty. If he is running out of water and there is no water source in sight, he probably could barely make it up the hills. And with no town nearby to get water, his thirst would only grow. “First 'town'” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one point, but another warning sign indicated that it fit the description of a ghost town. There was no water to be found, leaving the cyclist in a desperate situation.

Hot, lack of water, lost - all are how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, it was hot. In one sentence, he mentioned that the sun was beginning to beat down with full force. The heat was so intense that the water in his bottle felt around two - hundred degrees. Sweat was pouring all over him, drenching his clothes. So, he had to be really hot, and the heat was sapping his energy. Next, the lack of water affected him and his performance. He was dying in need of water. The conditions the cyclist has to face are always either problems or helpers. Say there is a rocky up - hill part. The large rocks and uneven incline will most definitely slow him down. The cyclist can relax his legs as the bike glides effortlessly down the slope, and it takes a lot of the work of pedaling off his hands. This shows that the cyclist must adapt to different conditions on the road, and these conditions can significantly impact his journey.

The cyclist lost all hope as he found himself in the vast California deserts in the scorching month of June. The situation grew even more dire when he came across a rusty water pump. With great effort, he managed to pump out some water, only to find that it had the taste of battery acid. When he saw the sign “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, he became extremely cautious. The cyclist was certain that he was going to die out there in the desolate desert. He also felt a deep sense of loneliness as described in the text, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” Being in the California desert made him firmly believe that his end was near.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, he vividly describes his arduous biking trip through the diverse landscapes of California. In the essay, he mentions the setting with “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” While this doesn't directly characterize the weather, the reader can easily conjure up a clear image of the sweltering heat that typically engulfs a desert in the summer. When the author first stumbles upon the “ghost town”, followed by the dilapidated shack, and finally spots the sign that read “Rough Road Ahead”, all hope of finding Yosemite Park vanished from his mind. The overwhelming hopelessness of the situation made the author seriously consider giving up. He started to think that he was going to die out in the desert, succumbing to dehydration and exhaustion. This experience can be related to anyone who has ever been lost in unfavorable conditions, along with the accompanying feelings of helplessness and fear. It feels as if everything is conspiring against you, with nothing working in your favor, and this is precisely what the author goes through in his detailed description of his trip in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”.

The setting had a profound impact on the cyclist as the physical exhaustion was gradually taking its toll on him. What made the situation even worse was that he was out in the blistering heat, constantly sweating. This excessive sweating led to dehydration, further weakening his body and spirit. In such a harsh environment, the combination of exhaustion and dehydration made his journey extremely difficult and put his well - being at risk.

To begin with, a crucial feature that affected the cyclist was a severe lack of water. This is clearly shown when the speaker says, “When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” The fact that the only available water source was undrinkable was one of the biggest factors that put him at great risk. As the reader listened and followed the directions of the old - timers, he encountered many issues and also learned an important lesson. As he began to ride into the daybreak of morning, he had strong legs and even a wide smile on his face, full of energy and optimism. However, as time went on, he soon found himself running dangerously low on water and experiencing a significant loss of energy. The sweltering summer day made him sweat profusely, and he began to have disturbing thoughts that the birds would peck at his body as if he were going to die on his ride to Yosemite. When he finally reached a town, he quickly refreshed himself. He then realized that he should start to follow his own way of getting to places, rather than blindly relying on others' directions.

The features of the setting in the essay “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” affected the cyclist in a negative way. As he continued to ride further and further, his negative thoughts grew more and more prominent, and he was filled with a great deal of doubt. As the long - drawn - out journey continued, it seemed that the cyclist was losing all hope. “It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary.” The more he rode in the desolate middle of nowhere, with only “Rough Road Ahead” signs to be seen, the less likely he thought he was to finish this arduous journey. The features in the setting are very effective in influencing the cyclist. He finds himself in a vast desert area of California, where the sun beats down relentlessly. He has a severely limited water supply, with just a meager amount that can barely quench his thirst. It is extremely hot and dry, and the air is thick with the heat. He has to cover a long distance in this hot and humid weather, which is extremely taxing on his body. The deficiency of water puts him at a high risk of becoming dehydrated, as his body loses fluids rapidly through sweating. Another major obstacle that he encounters during this biking trip to Yosemite National Park is the series of hills that he has to face. At the start of his journey, he was on flat terrain, which was relatively easy to pedal on. But now, these steep hills require him to put in a lot more effort to pedal up, making the ride a lot harder. One other unexpected obstacle that he faced was running into a snake on the way. That setting presented numerous challenges for this cyclist. If it wasn't for the intense heat and the lack of water, he might have been able to make it through the journey a little more easily. In conclusion, the harsh setting with its various obstacles made the cyclist's trip to Yosemite a very difficult one.

The features of the setting strongly affected the cyclist. The long and crippling rolling hills were the cyclist's most challenging problem. These hills seemed to stretch on endlessly, and maneuvering down them would demand a great deal of energy and unwavering determination from the cyclist. Considering that the cyclist was already exhausted and sweating profusely from riding on the rough roads and having the scare of passing a large snake, riding on these rolling hills would be an extremely tough task. The features of the setting were not conducive to the cyclist's well - being. However, the cyclist maintained a positive attitude and refused to give up. His strong determination saved him, and he felt a great sense of relief when he finally came across the “Gary and Wilbells fish camp.” In conclusion, the features of the setting affected the cyclist because they forced him to work extra hard and put forth more effort. But it is evident that with determination, one can overcome even the most difficult of challenges and accomplish anything!

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist in the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit.” The cyclist's mood appears to change in tandem with the changing road and setting. The narration states, “A large highway sign jumped out at me. I read: Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit … sometimes life can feel so cruel (Kurmaskie).” As the terrain gradually becomes more and more difficult, the cyclist's spirits sink lower and lower. In conclusion, the harsh setting in the story plays a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's emotional state and his perception of the journey.

Some features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the signs that displayed speed limits. These signs directly influenced the speed at which the cyclist could ride. The incline required him to use more energy, and his body was working hard to overcome the resistance. In conclusion, these features of the setting, the speed - limit signs and the hill, had a notable impact on the cyclist's ride, making it more difficult and tiring.

The setting had a huge impact on the cyclist. One significant impact was the severe lack of water in the arid desert area he was traversing. Also, the intense sun beating down on him made his body increasingly warm, causing him to feel dizzy and making it harder for him to focus on what he was trying to do. In the setting of “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is greatly affected. From his point of view, “they'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing off at landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy route.” So, the cyclist, trusting their confidence, used that information. Unfortunately, it was not for the better. Instead of a smooth journey, he found himself facing unforeseen challenges due to the inaccurate directions.

How the features of the setting affect the cyclist becomes evident when the old guy asked him, “Do you know where to go?” And the other guy replied, “Yes sir! I own a very good map.” So, how did it change for the man riding the bike? In the story, the cyclist faced many problems. One of the biggest problems was the terrain that he had to maneuver through. The terrain was extremely hilly, with steep inclines that made going up a hill on a bike incredibly tiring. It wore him out much faster than cycling on flat land would have, and it made him use a great deal more energy. Each pedal stroke up the hill was a struggle. In the end, his will and determination got him through the harsh landscape, so he could finally get the water he needed to finish his trip.

In this essay, the features of the setting cause the cyclist to become irritated toward the old men. The setting of where you are riding has a great deal to do with the cyclist. In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting greatly affects the cyclist and his mindset. The features of the setting have a significant impact on the cyclist because the setting changed so drastically. In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist faces many hardships on his way to Yosemite due to the features of the setting. The terrain in “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie presented the cyclist with many difficulties. In the story “Rough road ahead,” the detailed setting significantly affects the cyclist. The cyclist has it extremely hard in the given conditions. The lack of water, the intense heat, and the rough terrain are all factors that made his ride much harder. In this, I will tell you precisely how the cyclist was being affected. One way is that the intense heat caused him to drink more water than he had planned, and then he quickly ran out of water. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in numerous ways. It was a truly dangerous journey for him as he had to face the elements and the isolation alone. But despite all the difficulties, he made it through, showing great determination and resilience.

The features of the setting do indeed affect the cyclist. One example is the condition of his jar. If the jar was damaged or leaking, it could lead to the loss of his precious water supply. This would then make him more vulnerable to dehydration during his ride. The state of the jar, as a part of the overall setting, can have a significant impact on the cyclist's journey, either facilitating or hindering his progress.

The features of the setting can significantly affect the cyclist. For instance, imagine a scenario where the surroundings are completely empty, with no cars, buildings, water, or people in sight. This kind of desolate setting might make you want to go faster and unleash your inner speed demon. That’s all I can really tell you. Because personally, I don’t think the setting of where you ride your bike actually matters. Possibly for a professional bicyclist, it can have an impact, but to me, I just don’t think so. In conclusion, while some might believe the setting plays a role, I remain unconvinced of its real significance for the average cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. There are no cars, buildings, water, or people visible anywhere. The terrain changes from a flat road to rolling hills, presenting a more challenging ride. Even though he had no water, he was determined to keep pedeling. A sign reads “Rough road Ahead, do not exceed posted speed limit”. At this point, he had no water left and was pretty much in the middle of nowhere. If I was in his situation, I would feel utterly hopeless as there was no sign of hope. All he could see were endless rolling hills. Then, when he saw a building over the hills, he thought he was home free. So he pedaled up to the building, only to find that it, along with all the others in the area, was abandoned. The cyclist thought he was going to die. In conclusion, the features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist because the sight of nothingness gave him no hope. If there had been cars and buildings on both sides of him, that probably would have given him some confidence, but that was not the case. He was stuck in the middle of nowhere. Finally, he came to a bend and said, “Then, as easily as rounding a bend my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.” This shows how the setting can both torment and then relieve the cyclist.

There are many features of the setting that affect the cyclist. His dehydration started when the scorching sun beat down on him, intensifying his thirst for water. He was particularly affected when he was out of water and rode by an abandoned Welch’s grape juice factory. “A sand - blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head.” Then, when he had almost nothing left in terms of energy and hope, he spotted a bait shop. “Somehow I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” Then, as easily as rounding a bend, his troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind him. It was when he saw “Gary and [Name] Fish camp – If you want bait for the big ones, we’re your best bet”, thus revealing his troubles were over. In conclusion, the various elements of the setting, from the sun to the abandoned factory and the eventual sight of the fish camp, had a profound impact on the cyclist’s experience.

The features of the setting that the author cycled through definitely affect not only his mood but also his physical condition. To start, it is mentioned that he is in “the high deserts of California in June”. From this, it is clearly implied that the weather is extremely hot, causing the author to sweat profusely as he bikes along. Next, there is a significant change in terrain, and he soon approaches “rolling hills” which are much more difficult to bike on, requiring more effort and energy. Finally, the author sees a sign that reads “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT”. He becomes discouraged because his bike is not even capable of reaching the speed limit, yet he still has to manage getting past the rough road. After passing this road, he approaches a picture of a boy drinking juice that is posted on a juice factory. Seeing this sign most likely exacerbates his thirst and leaves him more exhausted and frustrated than before. Such features of his surroundings played a large part in the author’s change in mood. In conclusion, the setting, with its hot weather, difficult terrain, and teasing signs, had a substantial negative impact on the cyclist’s well - being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. First, the beating sun is a major factor. The intense heat dehydrates him and almost takes his life. The sun’s rays are relentless, sapping his energy and making every pedal stroke a struggle. The rocky road is also a significant factor. Navigating the rough surface takes up a great deal of the time and energy he has to perform. Each bump and jolt on the rocky road slows him down and wears him out. Another key ingredient of the setting was the desert. In the vast expanse of the desert, there was no one to help him, and there wasn’t a place to get water. He was completely isolated and at the mercy of the harsh environment. In conclusion, the setting, with its scorching sun, rocky roads, and desolate desert, was a big factor in the story as it tested the cyclist’s limits and survival instincts.

The setting affects the biker in numerous ways. For one, he is riding through the vast high deserts of California during the sweltering month of June. It is naturally hot in the summer, but in the arid desert, the heat is twice as intense. This extreme heat means he will dehydrate at a much quicker pace, and thus will need a significant amount of water. The only water the biker can find is from an old, rusty pump, but he couldn't drink it since it was scalding hot and had a truly nasty taste. “When I tried a drop it had the flavor of battery acid” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). His route was completely deserted, so there was absolutely nobody who could come to his aid. Also, the terrain was extremely bad. The steep hills caused him to exert far more of his energy, which he desperately needed to stay alive. “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke caused me to laugh,” (@NUM1). He also encountered dangerous animals like the menacing diamond black rattlesnake. The setting also affected him mentally because he was silently berating himself since he took directions from a couple of old men. He knew he should have taken the right way, instead of trying a short - cut that he now realizes is abandoned and perilous. The biker is being affected in many ways, both mentally and physically, making his journey an extremely challenging one.

The setting causes major problems for the cyclist in the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The cyclist was faced with a vast, barren desert, traveling in extremely humid and sweltering temperatures with no access to water. He encounters venomous poisonous snakes and areas where there are no buildings or any signs of civilization all together. The effect on him was the main conflict of the essay. He had no water during some stretches of the trip and lost all hope. He told himself that it was no use. In the story it says, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die…” The extreme measures of the setting caused the cyclist to lose control, even putting stones in his mouth to try and stop thinking about his intense thirst. Overall, the harsh setting caused the cyclist major problems, both physically, as he suffered from dehydration and exhaustion, and mentally, as he battled despair and hopelessness.

The ways that the setting of the place can affect the cyclist are how the road is shaped, such as riding up steep hills and the roughness of the road surface. There was a weather - beaten sign where it said “rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit.” That sign was crucial because if he didn't see it, he might have gone over the speed limit or not known what speed he was supposed to maintain as a cyclist and could have gotten seriously hurt. The road was primarily made for cars, so adhering to the speed limit is quite difficult for a cyclist. This shows how the setting, in the form of the road and its signage, can have a significant impact on the cyclist's safety and journey.

In the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects the cyclist. One setting that affected him was the first setting. In this setting, under the blazing sun, he used up his water supply and it was oppressively hot. This affected the cyclist because he was starting to feel extremely dehydrated and began to think he was going to die. The text shows this when it said “I could drop from heat stroke.” Later, when the cyclist came to an abandoned juice factory, he couldn't help but think about how incredibly thirsty he was. This affected him because usually when you think about thirst, you become even thirstier. This also made him deeply disappointed. The final setting affected him because he had finally managed to get water and was no longer thirsty. That is how the different settings affected the cyclist, altering his physical state and emotional well - being throughout the journey.

On that long and arduous bike ride, the cyclist was affected by the setting in multiple ways. He was affected by the lack of water, the scorching heat, and the bad directions. Throughout the story, the cyclist ran out of water due to bad directions from some old men. “Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” He ran out of water and became severely dehydrated during his trip. The intense heat played a major part in his dehydration during the bike ride. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” I have been to California and I know it can be extremely hot. The trip was made even longer due to some bad directions from some old men. “Because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh.” The gentlemen gave him wrong directions because in their time that was the correct information. But now the land has changed and the directions were completely wrong. When going on bike rides, the setting of the rides can be a great help or a terrible hindrance. The cyclist experienced firsthand how the setting of a bike ride can affect him a great deal, making his journey a struggle filled with challenges.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist very much. For example, the intense sun was beginning to beat down relentlessly. Another example, I was hitting my water bottles pretty regularly to quench my thirst. The setting was hot and dry, with the heat making the air feel thick. It affected the cyclist very much. It was to the point where it felt like he was on the verge of dying, but somehow he kept going.

The cyclist in this essay was a very brave man. He had many obstacles in his long and arduous journey but he still made it. Nature was most definitely not on his side that day. He had to ride his bike up and down steep hills several times, which wears you out very quickly. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills that seemed never - ending. After he got through the hills, he came to a sign that read “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT”. Now he has to go through bumpy roads that jolted him with every turn. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed his path and a ridiculously large snake - it really did look like a diamondback - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of him. Now the poor guy had to deal with snakes bigger than him! Thankfully he got by the snake, alive. Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. The man thinks he found someplace to get water, but it's an abandoned building that, by the looks of it, had once been a Welch’s grape Juice Factory and bottling plant. Despite all these hardships, his determination saw him through to the end.

The setting affects the cyclist because it is extremely hot, and the scorching heat makes the air shimmer. Therefore, he gets thirsty as his body tries to cool down. That's one of the reasons why he was tired and dehydrated, as the heat sapped his energy and fluids. In such a setting, it was a real struggle for the cyclist to keep going.

The feature of the setting affects the cyclist as old - timers gave him wrong information about taking this short - cut he was going to take. He was doubting himself and on the verge of giving up on the race. As he struggled on, the wrong advice from the old - timers seemed to haunt him, but he still had a glimmer of hope deep inside that he could somehow finish.

In the piece, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist felt black humor, despair and then relief due to the features of the setting. The cyclist felt black humor, due to the features. This was because it was very ironic where he was. This sparked his black humor as he thought about the irony of the situation. The cyclist felt despair due to the features. In the essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by @PERSON1, many features of the desolate setting significantly affect the cyclist. First, when he pedaled into the first “town,” the once - perhaps - bustling place now stood as a silent relic. He mused, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time – say, before the last world war.” This deserted ghost town, with its crumbling buildings and overgrown streets, was like a dark joke. Yet, at the start of the day, with a decent water supply in his bottles, it had only a minor impact on his spirits. However, when he reached the ramshackle shed surrounded by several rusty pumps, the effect was far from mild. He uttered, “The sight was troubling,” as the dilapidated structure loomed against the harsh sky. Then, as he got on his hands and knees, desperately working the pump, hope faded. All that trickled out was a drop or two of water that tasted like battery acid, leaving a bitter taste in his mouth and despair in his heart. Lastly, after cycling several miles under the scorching sun, he arrived at an abandoned Welch’s Grape juice factory. With his water supply running dangerously low and having faced disappointment after disappointment, this desolate factory had a very wearing effect on him. The setting in this essay seemed utterly abandoned and hopeless. It was only the cyclist's unwavering determination that got him through this arduous journey.

The story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” is about a cyclist who received bad directions to Yosemite National Park. In the extreme heat, his water supply is steadily depleting. The dehydration has made him dizzy, and every turn of the pedals feels like a Herculean task. With each passing mile, his hope fades a little more, but he still clings to the faint possibility of reaching his destination. Despite the overwhelming odds, he keeps going, driven by a glimmer of hope in the face of this difficult situation.

The setting in this story is of utmost importance because without a well - defined setting, the narrative would not make sense. The way I would set my affected cyclist is by having him ride through a landscape that is both intimidating and unexpected. The features of the setting in, “Rough Road Ahead” have a profound impact on the cyclist. The cyclist began his journey at a campground, chatting with some old - timers. This cyclist had to contend with the challenging conditions of the land. He didn't have an ample supply of water with him, and as far as he could see, there wasn't a reliable water source nearby. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. They have a profound impact on the cyclist's confidence and hope. The features of the setting have a notable impact on the cyclist. In the story, the cyclist says “I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June” so the setting, with its sweltering deserts and lack of shade, is obviously a hazard to his well - being.
