The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a very serious way. The features cause him to consider that he might die soon, as well as present a variety of challenges to him. The setting takes place in the deserts of California, in early summer. There are no other people in there, no establishments, towns, etc. A particularly dangerous feature of the setting, in addition to it being in a desert in summer, is the desolation. For example, the author mentions the town that “might have been a thriving little spot at one time - sat, before the last world war”. The cyclist is given almost a sense of hopelessness as well as determination to survive as he runs out of water. His throat is dry, and his energy is waning. For example, he says “I was going to lie… slowly gaining elevation while losing hope”. The author makes the trip to a fishing camp and survives. He learns, because the setting is now lifeless and deserted, to not listen to old people who remember the current setting only as it was many decades earlier. Because the features of the setting nearly kill the cyclist, the cyclist learns a valuable lesson about the power of the environment and the importance of being prepared.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the author was not accustomed to such conditions. As she was riding her bike, there was no suitable place for her to stop and fill up her water bottle, which made her journey quite challenging. This lack of a water - filling spot due to the setting's features had a direct impact on her cycling experience.

The road was completely deserted. There wasn't a single building, car, or house in sight. He was stuck right in the middle of nowhere, without any supplies of water or food. The presence of poisonous snakes and the scorching heat could easily make him collapse, leaving him in a very precarious situation.

The cyclist on her trips sees a lot of features that would discourage her. She is riding in the high deserts of California in June, as (Kurmaskie) mentions. We all know deserts are extremely steaming hot and dry, especially during the month of June. She also encounters numerous hills (Kurmaskie). To make matters worse, she was travelling on these hills in the extreme heat. Though the cyclist goes through many perilous obstacles, she makes it to a camp. As she said, “I could see the horizon, telling myself that I could make it that far, I'd be fine.” (Kurmaskie) This shows the author's dedication and that if you don't give up, you will be fine, as perseverance can help overcome difficult situations.

In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the setting is an all - important factor. The author feels the need to vividly describe the path that the cyclist is following and the details of each place he stops. For example, he describes “one ramshackle shed… and a corral that couldn't hold the lamest mule…” and “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite…” In a story such as this, the setting is of great importance, especially since it is so rapidly changing. The story itself would be of much different quality, likely of a lower quality, if the author never put emphasis on the areas that the cyclist rode past. This story would not be worth reading if the author were not as skilled a writer as he is, as the well - described setting adds a lot of value to the narrative.

The setting of the cyclist was harsh. The weather was so intense that it was extremely difficult to be cycling vigorously all day. The extreme conditions in the setting made the cyclist's task arduous, but it also tested their endurance and determination.

The features of setting can significantly affect cyclists. If you're a male cyclist, you need to be wary of falling off your bike or running out of water. When you maintain a fast pace without any water, you're at risk of getting dehydrated. In the essay, the cyclist ran out of water and thought he was going to die as he became dehydrated. Fortunately, he managed to find a place to get something to drink. Overall, cyclists should always be prepared for such situations to ensure a safe and enjoyable ride.

In the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit", the man's bike ride gets quite rough. Because he followed the old men's advice and took a shortcut, the once pleasant and enjoyable ride turned into a challenging and arduous journey. This shows that sometimes, taking advice without proper consideration can lead to unexpected difficulties.

The cyclist in the essay experiences different phases that are affected by the setting. At first, the cyclist is well - acquainted with his location and is brimming with excitement for his ride, eager to complete it. Then, he arrives at a "ghost town". Doubts start to creep into his mind about the advice the old men gave him. This desolate place has no water, which makes him feel extremely discouraged. When he passes the Grape juice factory, he seriously believes it's the end for him. However, his hope and enjoyment return after he spots the sign for the bait. Clearly, the cyclist's feelings and attitude change in tandem with the changing setting, highlighting the strong influence of the environment on his experience.

The features of setting affect the cyclist in multiple ways. Initially, when he sees the tall pines and the river, he is calm and relaxed. But upon seeing the abandoned "@PERSON1’s Grape Juice" factory, he becomes desperate and fears he will perish in the desert. A man travels to @ORGANIZATION1, where he meets "old timers" who offer him a "shortcut" to the park. He then sets off on his bike, taking this so - called "shortcut". As he travels, he starts to run out of water and begins to think he will die in the desert. The quote "It dinít really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean." reflects his despair as he realizes he has no water in the middle of the desert in June. This shows that the harsh desert setting makes him desperate for water. In conclusion, the setting has a profound impact on the cyclist's state of mind and survival concerns.

The features of the setting can have a significant impact on the cyclist, either positively or negatively. It all depends on the specific conditions. For example, the cyclist might fall during the ride. In such a situation, it's important to consider whether he has a traveling first - aid kit. Having a first - aid kit can be crucial in providing immediate care if an accident occurs, ensuring the cyclist's safety to some extent.

Setting is a very crucial element to the story “Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie. Kurmaskie encountered a harsh scenery featuring extremely high temperatures, a scarce low water supply, and wild animals roaming about. High temperatures, when combined with an inefficient supply of water, can lead to heatstroke, hyperthermia, dehydration, and in severe cases, even death. It is of utmost importance to always be well - prepared with enough food and water to sustain oneself, especially in a situation such as being lost. Dealing with wildlife can also pose a significant obstacle. You never know precisely how any wild animal is going to react to your presence, so you must be as cautious as possible around non - domesticated animals. In conclusion, the scenery and setting of a story can truly make all the difference in how interesting a story can be and how informative it is. For instance, if Kurmaskie had experienced mild weather with an abundance of food and water while riding through a flat small town in @LOCATION1, the story would not have been as captivating.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie. The setting impacts how fast, hard, and long the cyclist needs to pedal. For example, “…Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The cyclist was going at a mere 12 mph, while the speed limit on that road was a whopping 55 mph. The cyclist started to lose hope after reading the sign, but his determination kept him going. Furthermore, it's not only the uneven land that adds pressure to the cyclist; the intense heat from the sun also takes a toll. For instance, the cyclist says, “… and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke…” The heat begins to affect the author's health and wear down his perseverance. In conclusion, the setting significantly affects the mental and physical strain the cyclist has to endure.

This story was a great source of motivation for an older man, showing that he can still be healthy and feel like a teenager again. It vividly showed how much effort he put into achieving his goal and how he managed to survive. He pedaled for forty long miles, enduring the hardships of the journey, just to reach the same water source that the cyclist was headed for. It's an interesting story of perseverance and not giving up. In conclusion, it serves as an inspiring tale for anyone facing challenges in life.

It affects cyclists because the condition of the route, whether it's the terrain like hilly or flat areas, or the weather such as strong winds or heavy rain, determines the pace at which they can cycle and even how fast they could travel overall. For example, a steep uphill slope will slow them down, while a tail - wind can increase their speed. In conclusion, the condition of the cycling environment has a direct impact on a cyclist's speed and pace.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. For example, the cyclist was in California, a place known for its extremely hot climate, especially in the desert region during June. These environmental features made dehydration a much more likely and dangerous possibility. Another example can be found in paragraph ten. It explains how the rough, bumpy road, the tumbling tumbleweeds, and the sudden appearance of a large snake made it incredibly hard for the cyclist to keep his balance, and all this was compounded by the lack of water. Also, the essay describes a building with a poster of a small child happily drinking a refreshing glass of juice. This sight made the cyclist think more about water and he quickly became very thirsty. Although there were some positive effects of the setting on the cyclist. The small pebbles he found allowed him to keep his mouth slightly moist and not constantly dwell on his thirst. Also, the bait shop along the way provided him with an option to get something to drink, thus preventing him from dying of dehydration. In conclusion, the setting, with its mix of challenges and small opportunities, had a profound impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way it affects the cyclist is because of the weather condition. In the sweltering heat of the day, being that it is very hot outside, the cyclist rapidly loses fluids and does not have enough water to replenish what is lost. Another way it affects the cyclist is because of the condition alongside the road. For example, the tumbleweeds that roll across the path unexpectedly and the snakes lurking in the underbrush pose hazards. Being that there is little rainfall, most likely the desert is in the process of a drought, and as a result, the cyclist gets very dehydrated. I believe these are the reasons because it all makes a lot of sense and clearly affects the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the lack of water was the biggest thing. In the scorching heat of the high desert, without cool water, he had nothing to re - boost his energy. The intense heat made him fatigue quickly, and he would get tired out faster. Even if he does find water, it's hot, like when he says, “brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” This shows how in “the high desert of June,” the water is all very hot. Even after he pumped the well for several minutes, the water still would not cool down as the hot desert had baked everything above and below ground. So when you go to get something liquid, which heats and cools faster than solids, it will be hot. Also, the rough road made it difficult for the cyclist to travel. We know the road is rough when he says, “large highway signs dumped out at me. It read ROUGH ROAD AHEAD DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT.” This also shows you could not go fast, further hampering the cyclist's progress.

The cyclist is dehydrated. He has a lack of water for a significant distance before he realizes “that the old men would have been right, had he been riding,” before the last world war. As he pedals through the desolate landscape, any “town” he rides into is just a run - down, deserted, and abandoned piece of desert. He says, “It was a sad, hopeless, laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” It was evident that he was getting more and more dehydrated, but was not quite ready to die. He still had enough energy to keep going, but “hope was fading.” Then all at once, after climbing a large hill, he gains all hope back. He sees “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp.” The rider is safe now. He stumbles into the modern - looking bathroom and drinks greedily from the sink. He is now safe, ready to ride again, and determined to avoid all men who haven’t moved from their front porches in years.

The harsh setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie made the journey for the cyclist more difficult due to the hot weather and the inconsistency of the pavement. The very hot June day was a major cause of the cyclist slowing down. “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This proves that the cyclist is very hot due to the summer heat, sapping his energy and making each pedal stroke a struggle. Another factor of the cyclist slowing down is the inconsistency of the pavement on the road. “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” The uneven surface and changing terrain prove that the road could be slowing the cyclist also. It seems the cyclist has a lot against him. But if he keeps his head up and perseveres, he can make it to “Yosemite.”

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by the hotness of the deserts of California. In the blistering sun, the cyclist was sweating profusely and rapidly drinking his water bottles to stay hydrated. Also, when the cyclist saw the building in the distance, he thought he could rest and maybe get a ride to where he was going. However, upon closer inspection, the building was abandoned years earlier, so the cyclist couldn't stop and had to continue his arduous journey. These are some features of the setting that clearly affect the cyclist's experience and progress.

Several features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the specific time of year, the vast desert land, the notable lack of civilization, the scarce availability of resources – especially water, and the rugged and challenging characteristics of the land. The cyclist was traveling during the peak of summer, which was undoubtedly the hottest time of the year. He was also traversing through the deserts, which create an even more sweltering climate. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” was a quote from the selection that clearly tells us this. If he had been traveling in the cooler months, for example, he would have been more comfortable. Throughout his trip, the author never encounters any signs of desert civilization. He runs into a deserted factory and miles upon miles of land without a single person. The fact that he is traveling through desert terrain also clearly helps us realize that water is extremely scarce. He has great trouble finding a place to get water. This made the trip extra hard and incredibly discouraging. “I was going to die” he says in despair. As he travels farther, the land also becomes increasingly harder to travel on. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” – this characteristic of the setting, like the others, negatively affects the cyclist by making his already difficult journey even harder. In the end, these challenging settings tested his limits but also likely made his eventual journey more memorable.

The cyclist's surroundings did indeed have an impact. In paragraph two, the cyclist vividly describes how “I enjoyed the serenity of an early - summer evening.” To have such a wonderful day to begin with was perhaps an assurance that everything would be fine. Confidence was boosted by the beautiful weather, and he also knew a short - cut, which added to his sense of ease. In paragraph three, the cyclist mentions how some old men looked at his map and pointed out “this breezy jaunt.” The cyclist just thought his life got a little easier at that moment. Then in paragraph five, the cyclist comes upon the “traditional definition of a ghost town.” This setting was nothing like what the old men were talking about. “Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts.” In paragraph six, this caused significant confusion and worry. “This sight was troubling.” “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The cyclist was “hitting my water bottles pretty regularly” due to the intense heat. This setting made the cyclist extremely uncomfortable, especially with the sweltering “two hundred degrees” heat. The cyclist then began to feel puzzled and distraught. “I noticed the terrain changing” – in this quote, the cyclist's settings clearly could have caused confusion. But in the end, despite all the challenges posed by the settings, the cyclist succeeded, showing his resilience.

The features of the setting in Do Not Exceed Posted Speed limit by Joe Kurmaskie, significantly affect the cyclist because the cyclist is in a vast and desolate desert with no readily available water and is trying to find a town that is much further than he initially thinks. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This shows that the cyclist had very little confidence in this desolate area of the journey. The scorching heat of the desert, combined with the long - distance to the town and the lack of water, made the cyclist's situation extremely dire. Every pedal stroke was a struggle as he faced the harsh reality of his surroundings. In the end, the challenging setting truly tested his will to survive and complete the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the road could be severely damaged or there could be a large number of steep hills. That is how the condition of the road can have a significant and detrimental effect on the cyclist's journey. In conclusion, these road conditions made the cyclist's trip far more arduous and risky.

When the cyclist takes off on the road again, he starts with plenty of water, strong legs, and enjoys the sunny and warm day. The initial conditions seem perfect for a great ride. But as the day progresses and gets hotter, and the terrain becomes more like a desolate desert and the air becomes dry and dusty, the cyclist begins to lose his confidence. As he keeps riding, his water supply is steadily depleting, and he begins to firmly believe that he will die. At one point, talking about the terrain he says, “I toiled on at some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path.” It sounds as if he is struggling very hard to keep going without water and with no clear clue about where he is. When he is almost certain that he is going to die from the suffering, he says, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This clearly shows that by this time his confidence was completely lost because of the insane heat and the unbearable terrain. He begins to lose his sanity along with his strength because the setting around him was so incredibly terrible. However, despite these extreme challenges, his perseverance ultimately led him to keep going, and it's possible that he overcame these odds in the end.

The features of the settings affect the cyclist in many ways. When he starts off, he is bright and happy, just as the serenity of the surroundings is nice and calming. There is a gentle pace that makes him feel like nothing could go wrong. “I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” After about @NUM1 miles in the cold, his energy was getting low, and he came to his second promising place. He then felt a little disturbed and worried as he realized he needed to find a place with water. “This site was unpromising.” There he finds a water source, and his hopes rise a bit, until he discovers the water isn't good. “A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by murky water that felt as if it came from a place in the neighborhood of two hundred trees.” So he moves on and finally he reaches a life - saving spot! He is so relieved he can't believe his luck. “Then as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.” The setting affects the mood in a very big way; the cyclist feels as the setting looks.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist. One way it affects him is because it is extremely hot, and he realizes he has no water left. Also, because there are so many dilapidated buildings and ghost towns, this gives him a glimmer of hope that he will be able to get the water he desperately needs. Almost all of the cyclist's surroundings are old and barren. The weather is like a sweltering @CAPS1 climate. So his ride was a very rough and tiresome one, as he had to constantly battle the heat and the difficult terrain.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by influencing how much confidence he has in where he's going and how he's going to get there. The lack of water is a constant reminder of the harshness of the environment, and it chips away at his confidence, making each pedal stroke a struggle both physically and mentally.

If the sun had not been so blaringly hot and all the roads so treacherous, the cyclist's journey would have been much easier. Also, the “elevation” often bothers the author because he had to overcome the challenges of dryness and dehydration. The high elevation combined with the hot sun and difficult roads made it a real struggle for him to keep going, but he persevered through these harsh conditions.

When cycling or doing any outdoor sport, the setting matters greatly. If it's cold, you need a proper, insulated jacket to keep your body warm. When it's hot, you need an adequate supply of water to stay hydrated. Depending on how extreme the conditions are, it could be a matter of life or death. For instance, the terrain could be really hilly, and you might get tired quickly. And if you have no water, your body could start to shut down, and you could die. Also, it depends on whether the location is in a city, a suburban area, a small town, a desert, or a highway. All these factors play a huge role in cycling, and one must be well - prepared for them.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The cyclist was in California in June, a time when the weather is typically hot. If it wasn't so hot under the blazing sun, he wouldn't have needed water as badly. He wouldn't have been sweating as much, losing precious fluids from his body. Also, there weren't any buildings or cars around in that desolate area, so there wasn't anyone to help him in case of an emergency. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structures of any kind.” Clearly, such features of the setting could severely affect the cyclist's well - being.

In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” written by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One feature that affects him is that he is cycling “through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie). This extreme setting means that the intense heat would cause the author to be dehydrated faster. The cyclist, who is also the author, is dehydrated before he can make it to the next town. As evidence, he “gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in [his] mouth” (Kurmaskie), a desperate attempt to moisten his parched throat.

In the essay Do not exceed posted speed limit by Joe Kurmaskie, the surrounding setting affected the cyclist. The setting was somewhere outside Lodi, California in early summer, a time when the sun can be quite intense. The cyclist took advice from some old men that led him to difficult places to get out of, perhaps areas with rough terrain or long stretches without resources. As the sun beat down, making the air hot and dry, and his water started to deplete, getting to Yosemite was much harder. The cyclist was traveling through high deserts of California in June, a harsh environment. When the terrain started to change from a flat road to rolling hills, the cyclist pushed himself even harder to get to his destination. The sun and hot air dehydrated him faster, sapping his energy. After traveling over “a long, crippling hill,” the cyclist had to stop and even tried sucking on a pebble in an effort to take his mind off thirst. When he found a habited store, he was exhausted and relieved. Clearly, the features of the setting had a big effect on the cyclist. The weather dehydrated him while the terrain exhausted him, making his journey a real struggle.

The settings in the essay affected the cyclist mentally and physically. The fact that he was riding through the desert in June, with the scorching sun overhead, affected how long his water supply lasted. If he had been riding in the cooler @DATE1, then his water supply would've lasted longer and he would've had more energy to pedal. Since the town the old men had told the cyclist about was abandoned, that also affected the cyclist because he had to keep on going even though he was getting weaker with each passing mile. What affected the cyclist most, I think, was when he arrived at the bait store. If that had been abandoned like everything else in that desolate area, the cyclist would've died. Luckily though it wasn't, and he was able to drink water. The factory affected him mentally because the picture of the boy was haunting him in a way due to the fact he was drinking juice, something the cyclist couldn't do at that desperate moment. All in all, I think the conditions that the cyclist was in affected him greatly. Since I've fainted from dehydration before, I know how it feels to be without water. First, you get a throbbing headache; then your mouth dries up and a sense of desperation sets in, and finally you get dizzy. It's a terrifying experience, and the cyclist endured it all due to the unforgiving setting.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” significantly impacts the cyclist's physical and mental state. There are distinct negative and positive effects for each state. The physical effects of the cyclist due to the settings are all apparent throughout the story. For example, when the cyclist reaches @PERSON2 and @PERSON1’s Fish Camp, he is able to hydrate once again. This positive effect makes the cyclist regain his health and safety. The setting mentally influences the cyclist very substantially. This can be clearly seen when the cyclist is in the comfortable camp around in @LOCATION1. He feels a deep sense of happiness in this area. This positive effect well - prepares the cyclist to go on the trip to Yosemite. Also, when the cyclist reaches the “Ramshackle @CAPS2, several rusty pumps, and a corral,” he feels deeply troubled. He is negatively affected mentally by the scarce amount of available water. In addition, the cyclist felt “sad” and “hopeless” when cycling in the dry, arid terrain. The cyclist is in the worst mental state in this place. Finally, the cyclist felt relieved upon seeing the fish camp. He describes the feeling by saying that his troubles are now “behind” him. The setting's positive effect in this instance changes his mental state from negative to positive. Setting was the main factor in deciding upon the cyclist’s physical and mental state. Setting impacts the cyclist’s physical and mental state in positive and negative states almost equally in the story, highlighting its crucial role in the cyclist's journey.

The setting made the cyclist feel extremely lonely. The cyclist lost hope quickly because he never saw any people or water on the long, desolate way. The cyclist said they saw a “ghost town,” a place completely devoid of any signs of life. Before he got to the fish camp, the cyclist saw no one and was gradually becoming dehydrated. This severe dehydration caused him to lose hope rapidly, and at some points, he truly thought he was going to die. For example, he says, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” It is clear that the setting affected the cyclist in a very negative way, leaving a lasting and harrowing impression on his experience.

The features of the setting, specifically being in a forest, greatly affect the cyclist. This was a bumpy trip with a multitude of troubles along the way. The forest terrain was uneven, filled with roots and rocks that made cycling difficult. This was a long trip, with the cyclist having to pedal for hours on end. But he persevered through it all, making it tough with a remarkable story to tell in the end. His journey through the forest not only tested his physical strength but also his mental resolve, and he emerged victorious with a tale of endurance.

The setting of the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” significantly affects the cyclist's physical and emotional attitude. In the beginning of the essay, the cyclist, “rode into the morning with strong legs and a wide smile on [his] face.” It was not too hot yet in the cool morning air. So, the cyclist was extremely happy and full of strength. He was supremely confident he could conquer anything that came his way. As the day grew on, “the sun was beginning to beat down” mercilessly. He was beginning to drink lots of water but he was still confident and strong. “I came to a ramshackle shed [and] several rusty pumps; the sight was deeply troubling.” The cyclist was travelling in the hot deserts of California, where the heat was almost unbearable. He was becoming increasingly tired and thirsty. He had to save as much water as possible to survive. What started as a confident ride into the desert became a desperate survival ride. Once the cyclist finds water, he is immensely relieved. He feels more confident and can ride to his destination with new - found determination. The weather and setting can affect us emotionally and physically just like in the essay, the cyclist became tired both physically and emotionally as the hot, sunny day went on, clearly demonstrating the power of the environment on human experience.

As the cyclist begins his journey, he is highly confident and extremely excited to have been offered new directions from some “old wise men” which promise a shortcut. This water supply is mediocre, and his attitude is tested against the flat and hilly terrain, until he realizes the directions are way off target. The cyclist was making his way to Yosemite when he came to the first “town,” but it wasn't a town at all but more of a desolate ghost dwelling. As he continued, hoping the shortcut offered by the old “codgers” would actually materialize, he realized he was utterly alone in the scorching hot desert with a depleting water supply and a dwindling spirit. He was deeply disturbed that he had chosen to follow the advice from the older men. Through his pain and despair, he encouraged himself by deciding he would never listen to their type again. The cyclist felt completely cheated, yet through his strong will and determination, by carefully rationing water and mentally choosing to cycle for each hill one at a time, he endured his physical, emotional, and mental trials. He lived to learn the valuable lesson of never consulting old “codgers” on mapping issues, because their information would most likely be outdated, a lesson that will stay with him for future adventures.

The reasons why the setting affected the cyclist are that as the temperature got hotter, the more water he drank. Also, the farther he traveled, the more tired he became. This tiredness caused his body to heat up, which in turn made him drink more of his limited water supply. Eventually, this cycle of heat, tiredness, and water consumption significantly impacted his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly in his determined ride. At first, he seemed at ease, excitedly talking about the cool pines and rushing rivers he was going to encounter once he reached Yosemite. After a long and strenuous ride under the scorching sun, he started to get nervous and began to wonder if he was even going to survive. He was running out of water and thought he saw a diamondback snake, which only added to his anxiety. Once he reached the rolling hills, he saw a posted speed - limit sign saying not to exceed the speed limit of 55 m.p.h., while he was moving at a “water - depleting” 12 m.p.h., constantly wondering how he was going to make it. At the end of the rolling hills, he came to an old Welch’s grape factory, feeling that his life was so cruel. After that moment of despair, he was determined to survive and make it to his destination. He picked out some landmarks on the horizon and rode towards them, slowly making his way across the vast desert. Finally, he made it to “Only and Wilbers fish camp” where he knew he was safe and would survive this arduous journey.

The hot, dry, and barren setting affected the cyclist greatly. A barren place is a hot, dry, and abandoned area with little to no signs of life. The cyclist was trying to ride his bike to Yosemite National Park. He made the mistake of deciding to follow the directions of a couple of old men. As Kurmaskie said, “Simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades.” The hot and dry conditions made the cyclist's hardest obstacle staying hydrated. Without an adequate water supply in such a harsh environment, his journey became extremely challenging.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. One way was because of the hot and dry climate. With the cyclist having a limited amount of water, it affected him severely. The features of the setting affect the cyclist by presenting all the big hills and the roughness of the roads. As the essay says, "The flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. There are many ways in which the setting of “Rough Road Ahead” affects the cyclist. First of all, he is bicycling through the desert. This poses a significant problem because the desert environment is extremely dry and hot. At one point in the story, the author writes that he was “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” It is quite obvious here that the lack of water is affecting him in a major way. He almost collapsed due to being so desperately thirsty. Another part of the setting that affects the cyclist is that he is in a very remote area. He says that “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” Since there was nowhere to stop immediately, the cyclist had to keep cycling and rationing his limited water supply until he could find a place to rest. Lastly, the “rough road” affected the cyclist. The uneven and bumpy road made traveling even more difficult and caused the cyclist to have a very tough time. If I had to bicycle for a long period of time, I would much rather have a smooth road so that I could conserve and renew my energy. The heat, remoteness of the area, and the rough road all combined to affect the cyclist negatively on his journey. In conclusion, the harsh desert setting with its various challenges made the cyclist's journey a truly arduous one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly in the story. The arid desert climate takes a toll on the cyclist by rapidly depleting his water supply. The features in the setting affect the cyclist because there are different kinds of hills, some steep and some gently sloping. @CAPS1 the story shows that the condition of the problem often affects the mood of the cyclist. In the story, the setting greatly affects the cyclist. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in ways of feeling doubtful, confidence, determination, and relief. The features of the setting in which the cyclist is in change his outlook on the trip significantly. The features of California and the fact that the cyclist was near Yosemite made the terrain rugged and dangerous to the cyclist. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The long, winding roads under the blistering sun made him extremely tired. The cyclist in the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” took the advice of older gentlemen who offered him a shortcut they knew to get to the national park. The features of the setting affect the cyclist by instilling a glimmer of hope in the author. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, many challenging features of the setting test the cyclists. The dry, desert - like setting would severely affect the cyclist because under the scorching sun, he could easily become dehydrated due to the significant loss of water through sweat. The features of the setting affected the cyclist quite disastrously. First of all, he was “traveling through the high deserts of California in June”. In the essay, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit", the cyclist encountered several daunting problems. The main conflict the cyclist faced in this text is the acute lack of water. The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist, making his travel an arduous task. The sweltering weather, with the sun blazing down mercilessly, leaves him extremely thirsty. The story “Rough Road ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie is about a man traveling through some extremely difficult settings. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” there are many features that significantly affected the cyclist.
