As she skillfully biked around a sharp bend, the wind rushed past, and “my troubles, thirsts, and fear were all behind me.” The surrounding scenery seemed to blur as the cyclist left her worries in the dust, finding a moment of peace and freedom on the road.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist set out on a bike ride in the sweltering heat of summer in California, where he was staying. Along the way, he met some friendly old people who kindly gave him a “short cut.” As he continued on, he found out that most of the places he was told about were desolate, abandoned ghost towns, devoid of a single drop of drinkable water. If he were in a different setting, like by a clear, flowing river or a natural spring, he would simply stop and drink from it. Or even if he was in a more populated, industrialized area, he could stop in any building and ask for a drink. But he was in the dry, hot, abandoned hills of California, parched and without any water. Under these harsh conditions, he grew tired, thirsty, dehydrated, and desperate for a drink. Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, he came upon a small bait shop that had water there, offering him much - needed relief.

During the cyclist's journey, he was affected by the setting frequently. When he was cycling, the temperature started to rise, and it became very hot to him. At first, though, it wasn't so bad. “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.” This clearly proves that the cyclist was aware that it was getting hot, yet it did not have an immediate impact on him. Another factor that affected him was the time that he was traveling in. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts in California in June.” This shows that the cyclist was constantly drinking because of the time of day and the month of the year he was out cycling. All of this indicates that the setting had a significant influence on the cyclist during his journey.

I think that the features of the setting really do affect the way someone rides a bike because certain places have distinct types of terrain. Some types of terrain are not always suitable for a bike rider. For instance, if the ground is bumpy, with large rocks and uneven surfaces, then someone could easily fall off the bike. Also, if it is dark outside, you may not even be able to see where you are going, and you could hurt yourself very seriously. That’s why riding a bike in certain settings can be dangerous. On the other hand, if you are in an environment where everything is smooth, like a well - paved bike path, then you can have a nice, enjoyable bike ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in “Do not Exceed posted speed Limit” by changing him physically. He was in the arid California desert in the middle of June, with not a single drop of water left in his bottles. This harsh situation was taking a severe physical toll on him. The lack of water was making him weak, and his physical condition was also making him feel hopeless. He says, “It was a sad hopeless laugh mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” So, the way he was suffering from dehydration physically affected his emotional state because he felt as though there was nothing he could do to improve his situation. Had he been in another place, for example, a coastal area where it does not get nearly as hot as in California, he would not have been suffering from dehydration and would not have been in such an isolated place. His cycling experience could be compared to the climbers who were lost in the snow storm in the Rocky Mountains. Instead of dehydration and heatstroke, however, they suffered from hypothermia. Had they been on a different mountain, there would have been no snow storm, and they would be fine. The outcome of this story and the climbers' situation was clearly determined by their respective settings.

The conditions gave the cyclist no hope at some points because the intense heat of the land and the harsh features of the setting were so extreme. He had no hope, just like when the cyclist says, “I hope I make it to the horizon because there’s nothing else to compare.” He can’t say, “Let’s ride to the next building or mailbox” because there are none. The desolate desert features make the cyclist feel that it’s just him, and no one can help him. He fears he’ll die of dehydration. Then the features get even worse. He sees the Welch’s grapefruit building, giving him a glimmer of hope for survival. But then he finds out that it’s deserted, and that’s like the final straw. He gives up. The cyclist is almost unconscious when he runs into the fishing store where he has a sip of water. So, clearly, the features of the setting were the main reason the cyclist lost hope.

The features of the setting affect the author because it leaves him dehydrated. The scorching desert sun makes the sweat pour out of him, and he has no water to replenish the electrolytes he loses. Also, once the author gets into the hills, he loses a significant amount of his energy. So, pedaling up the hills is a strenuous task. If I were the author, I would also have gotten tired because water is essential for the body to function and survive. In such a harsh setting, the lack of water and the challenging terrain take a toll on the author's physical state, making it clear that the setting has a profound impact on him.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist greatly. In the cyclist's opinion, things began pretty well. He had a positive attitude as it states, “with strong legs and a smile on my face.” As the man moves on, he comes to a fort of sorts. To him, the sight was rather troubling. Though it was troubling, he still had the confidence that he could continue his journey. Next, he noticed the changes in the terrain. He explained, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This means that he would have to pedal harder and with greater force in order to get over the hills. The weather was sweltering, and the cyclist was running out of water. The possibility of heatstroke came to mind. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” as told by the man. His mind entered a state of sad and hopeless thoughts, but he persevered and cycled on. At this point, he was extremely thirsty and felt his death was near. He said, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” As he kept going, he spotted an old guy in sight. He regained a bit of hope and moved ahead. The features of this story affected the cyclist physically and mentally. Physically, he was exhausted and worn out. In this horrible state, mentally, he was becoming negative and pessimistic about his travel. Undoubtedly, the setting's features interfered with the cyclist's physical and mental state.

In this story, “No Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, I believe the setting greatly affects the cyclist. I believe this because when it’s a long, downhill, cool road, the cyclist is fine. But if it is a straight uphill road and extremely hot, he feels like he can’t keep pedaling. The cyclist gets very weary when the setting is out in the hot desert with no one around. The blistering heat and the isolation make the journey seem endless and arduous. So, the setting has a huge affect on the mood in this story. Another example shows how the setting can either make the cyclist's journey enjoyable or a struggle, clearly demonstrating its significant impact.

A cyclist is a bike rider. They can ride in groups with different people or they can be a solo cyclist. Some cyclists go for just a few miles when riding their bikes, while others can go for much longer distances, like @NUM1 miles. Some cyclists take on challenging terrains; they go over hills and through water. They do a lot with their biking adventures. They must have a good amount of free time on their hands to be able to ride a bike that far. Whether it's a short ride or a long - distance journey, cyclists are dedicated to their activity, and the various ways they experience cycling show their passion.

The setting is as hot as a sweltering desert, with not a soul in sight, and the air is extremely dry. The intense heat outside takes a toll on the cyclist as he is drenched in sweat and desperately needs water. The searing heat gradually wears him down. Having no one around means he has no one to turn to for water, which is essential for his long - distance journey. These adverse conditions make him weak and make it even more arduous for him to find a place where he can get a drink. In such a situation, his journey becomes an uphill battle, but he perseveres, hoping to find water soon.

The setting can significantly affect the cyclist, and it can be either a positive or a negative factor. If a cyclist is able to adjust his own settings according to the situation, such as adapting his speed, gear, or riding style, that is a good thing as it allows him to better cope with the environment. However, if someone else meddles with his settings without his knowledge, it could lead to problems. For example, incorrect gear adjustments might make pedaling too difficult or too easy, affecting his efficiency and comfort. In conclusion, the cyclist should have control over his settings to ensure a smooth and successful ride.

In this narrative of a cyclist riding in California and heading for Yosemite National Park, he faces numerous challenges. He encounters a shortage of water and gets bad directions from a group of old men sitting on a porch. The setting plays a crucial role in his “challenge,” ranging from the tall pine trees to the desolate barren hills. At the beginning of his trip, he passes through a “ghost town” that clearly has seen better days. The dilapidated buildings and empty streets present him with his first doubt, and he continues his journey with caution. Then, he comes across the pines that, “had my name written all over them.” The sight of these pines gives him hope and reassurance, making him feel more confident about his journey. However, the rusty pump and the “ramshackle shed” that follow take away that hope and reassurance, making him cautious once again. The steep hills that require him to work hard to get over, the snake that crosses his path and slows him down, and the abandoned Welch’s juice company all add to his troubles. Finally, he gets some water at a bathroom, and everything seems better. If the setting had remained the same throughout the journey, he wouldn't have experienced the rise and fall of hope, and the story wouldn't be as interesting. The changing setting keeps the story engaging and showcases the cyclist's resilience.

Winding hills, limited water sources, and poor directions are the main troubles faced by this cyclist. First, he approaches a group of old men sitting on a porch. These old men, who haven't been outside of their porch in a while, give him very bad directions. Then, he passes through the first town. In his haste or perhaps due to oversight, he doesn't fill his water bottles. As he continues, he gets lost and soon runs out of water. His situation seems dire until he finds a fishing store. There, he not only finds water to quench his thirst but also meets people who are kind enough to give him a better map. With the water and the new map, he is better equipped to continue his journey and overcome the challenges that lie ahead.

The lack of water and the absence of proper direction have a significant impact on the cyclist. Water is crucial for the cyclist, as he himself said in the essay “I could drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie). In the scorching heat, without an adequate supply of water, his body is at risk of overheating and succumbing to heat - related illnesses. Moreover, having no direction is another major issue. Without clear directions, he will end up riding aimlessly for a long time, wasting his energy and time. This aimless riding can also lead to increased stress and frustration. In conclusion, the shortage of water and the lack of direction are the primary problems that the cyclist faces in the story, and they make his journey a difficult one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he confidently thought he had packed enough water, so he set off on his way. As he cycled, the heat of the surroundings was taking a toll. He drank most of his water in less than half the journey to his destination. He didn't truly realize how hot it was until he was down to his last couple of sips of water. Soon, he started to become dehydrated. He then remembered that the old men had said the next town was about eighteen miles away, so he gritted his teeth and kept on going. When he finally reached the town, there was nothing to drink, just an old, run - down factory. In desperation, he took some rocks and started sucking on them for a bit of moisture. But then, as he went over a bump, he accidentally swallowed one. He said to himself that next time he would just go by what the map said, as everything he had passed on the way had been run - down and abandoned. Finally, he reached a bait shop and went inside the bathroom to get some much - needed water, relieved that his ordeal was over.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. For example, the terrain had no hills, but the heat made him get dehydrated quickly. He was cycling down this rusty, bumpy road, which jolted him around and didn't help his dehydration at all. The constant movement on the rough road made him lose more energy and water. And another example would be that he found a plane wreck on the side of the road. He thought it could be a place where he could take a short break and figure out the best way to get where he was going. In the end, it was clear that the features of the setting had a significant and mostly negative impact on the cyclist's journey.

The cyclist goes through many natural settings that affect him. First of all, he rides into a vast barren land. The desolate expanse seemed to stretch on forever. The cyclist portrayed this barrenness vividly by saying “it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This was in response to the first “town” he came across. The once - inhabited place was now empty, with broken buildings and overgrown weeds. Next, he speaks of a large snake that slithered close to him. The snake was a real danger, with its menacing eyes and sharp fangs. But luckily, he quickly and skillfully maneuvered out of its way. But the worst setting the cyclist had to deal with was the lack of water. In the hot and dry environment, water was scarce, and this is a threat to any living creature. But in the end, he found a small water source. After quenching his thirst, he was able to continue his journey, and the story ended fine as he overcame the challenges posed by the natural settings.

In the essay “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the setting relates to how the author is feeling. At first, when the author sees the abandoned first “town,” he is not too worried about it and moves on. “I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.” At this point, the author is okay, and still has enough water to keep him going. Next, as he pedals on, he starts to get low on water. The heat of the high deserts of California in June is intensifying, and he becomes more panicked. This panic in turn makes the day seem even hotter. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” Since the author is low on water, the day seems to get worse. Afterward, he continues on and runs into a rattlesnake. The sight of the dangerous snake makes him even more panicked. “And a ridiculously large snake. It really did look like a diamond back - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” However, when he got to the bait store and drank from the sink, things didn't seem so bad anymore. There was no more talk about water nor the heat. As a result, it's clear that the setting was closely related to the author's moods throughout the journey.

The features of the setting did affect the cyclist in this small story. In this story, the setting is a hot, dry terrain which can be better explained by the name California. The arid desert climate was like an oven. The heat of the desert climate seems to start having an effect on him about after he reaches the first town. I know this by his statement. “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time – say, before the last war – but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down. The summer heat was intense during this time of the day, and he was drinking lots of water to stay hydrated. So, this setting does affect him greatly. It causes him to use his water supply at a rapid rate and it causes him to begin the process of dehydration. I know how the summer heat can affect you during outdoor activities. At times it feels like you are going to die, but there's always hope around the bend, just like for the cyclist who eventually found a way to deal with the harsh setting.

In Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit, the features of the desolate setting are extremely devastating to the cyclist's condition. Cycling "@CAPS1 through the arid high desert of California" is surely never an easy task to begin with. Under the scorching sun, without proper hydration, people often suffer heatstrokes or pass out, and in some severe cases, even perish. It is entirely worse for this cyclist because of the strenuous effort he is exerting, pedaling laboriously over “short, rolling hills.” Even worse, the trail that a few very old, eccentric men set to run on does not do much in the way of helping with a depleted water supply. The first town the cyclist comes across easily splits “the traditional definition of a ghost town,” with dilapidated buildings and an eerie silence. The only other water pump he comes to emits only sewage and incredibly hot brackish water. Therefore, the intense heat is only made worse by the false look of water on the cyclist's path. This combination of harsh features in the setting causes a great deal of distress to the cyclist, almost pushing him to the brink of death.

There are many ways the setting affected the cyclist in this story, such as the sweltering weather, the scarce supply of food and water, the wrong estimation for old people, and the bumpy road. First off, the weather was extremely dry, and the temperature soared up to two hundred degrees. The searing heat made the cyclist sweat profusely and gasp for air as it was hard to breathe. The supply of water was extremely harsh, with very little water available around at all. When he tried to get water from the pumps, they would pump out not clean water but rather murky and undrinkable substances. The scorching weather and the scarce water supply were two major factors that had a significant impact on the cyclist, making his journey extremely arduous.

In the beginning of the story, the author is in high spirits, but towards the end, she grows increasingly upset. "I rode into the morning with strong legs and a bright smile on my face” (@NUM1). This clearly shows how the author is in a good mood and happy to be on this adventure. She is on a journey full of hope, feeling as if no one can dampen her enthusiasm. Then, the story takes an unexpected turn. “With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I carefully maneuvered down the steep hill,” (@NUM2). After getting lost in a desolate town that seems far removed from any signs of life, the author suddenly hears the voices of people! She is extremely relieved to have found anyone who can offer her help. She gets much - needed water and is forever grateful. The desolate setting is truly horrifying to her because it makes her feel as if she can't survive even if she were a local. She felt utterly alone and feared that she would die in this desolate place. If the setting was in a bustling city surrounded by tall buildings, the author would still feel some sense of security even without water, as there would be more chances of getting help.

The features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist. The main reasons are related to the water and the hills. One significant reason is the water situation. After he refilled his water bottles all the way up, the water was cooled down, which was a brief relief. However, as he continued his journey, the water quickly became scarce again. My last reason is the challenging rolling hills. These hills require the cyclist to exert a great amount of energy as he pedals up and down, making his ride much more difficult. Overall, the combination of the water issue and the rolling hills in the setting affects the cyclist's progress and well - being.

There are features such as the blazing heat radiating off the sun, “short, rolling hills” that seem never - ending, and a complete lack of water sources. There was also the fact that the rider felt as if he was in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by nothing but desolation. This has a great effect on the cyclist, both physically and emotionally. The intense heat saps his energy rapidly, the lack of water leaves him parched and weak, and the constant uphill riding against the slopes of the rolling hills can take a huge amount of energy out of someone, making it extremely hard to keep pedaling. Not to mention, with no sign of help or water in sight, there isn't much hope left, which eliminates the whole “mind over matter” thing. All the harsh features of the setting put together can lead to major trouble for the cyclist, endangering his life and making his journey a life - threatening ordeal.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. After about @NUM1 miles, as the cyclist's throat grew parched and he was in desperate need of water supply, he found a rusty pipe. First, a tarlike substance oozed out of it, followed by a brackish water substance. When cycling, clean water is an absolute necessity. Next, the terrain gradually changed from being flat to very hilly. When already in need of water, facing hilly terrain is the last thing a cyclist wants as it poses more challenges. Later on along the road, there were no cars passing by or any buildings in sight. When the cyclist was feeling at his worst, he would have wanted someone to be near in case he fell out, but the road was completely deserted. Lastly, seeing the old Welch's Grape Juice Factory would surely affect the cyclist. Having the image of a drink factory right in front of him but knowing it was out of business must have made him feel like he would never make it through this arduous journey. These features of the setting had to affect the cyclist, making his cycling experience extremely tough.

The features in the setting dramatically affect the cyclist. Initially, everything was going fine for the cyclist until he ran out of water and reached the hills. If he were in a more populated area like Callada, he wouldn't have become dehydrated so easily. However, the hills were not only a physical challenge but also played tricks on his mind. The most important setting element is the Welch's grape juice factory. He would have been able to quench his thirst with all the grape juice he wanted, but unfortunately, it was abandoned. He calls it an ironic twist. And the last significant setting is the bait shop that saved his life. There, an old man kindly offered him directions, which gave him a glimmer of hope in this difficult journey. Overall, the various features of the setting had a profound impact on the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist because he was in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by vast emptiness, with no water or direction. The man was extremely thirsty as there was no water left in his water bottle. As time passed, his thirst became more and more unbearable. I found an example to show that he was thirsty. “The speed limit was @NUM1. I was doing a water - depleting @NUM2. Sometimes life can feel so cruel”. By saying he was doing @NUM2 when it should have been @NUM1, he was clearly indicating that he was getting very exhausted and desperately needed water to get him feeling refreshed once again. Also, the fact that there was no one in sight to give him direction affected him too. He didn't know where the next refuge was. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind”. From the man's point of view, he probably thought civilization was many more miles away and he likely couldn't make it that far. The setting affected him by making him probably begin to stress or panic a lot for the most part, making his cycling journey a nightmare.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, he feels extremely dehydrated and tired because he is riding through the scorching desert under the blazing sun and has a severe lack of water. I often feel the same way when jogging for extended periods of time, so I can empathize with his situation. The men in the story “who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office” also add an interesting element to the story. Due to their advice, the cyclist takes an unmarked shortcut that turns out to be a horrible choice, filled with rough terrain and obstacles. The Welch’s factory affects the cyclist because it intensifies his thirst and makes him constantly think about getting a drink. The sign showing grape juice looks irresistibly appealing to him, driving him to keep moving forward in search of anything to drink. The terrain change also affects the cyclist because it forces him to work even harder to pedal up the hills now rather than just smoothly ride on flat terrain. All these setting features combined make the cyclist's journey extremely difficult.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, in paragraph @NUM1 it says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The intense heat the cyclist experienced, since he was in a desert during the hot month of June, made him dehydrate at a much faster rate. The sweltering heat made him drink more water, causing him to run out of water more quickly. Then, in an attempt to conserve water, he would try not to drink, but this would cause him to dehydrate even more as he was losing body fluid in sweat. Secondly, in paragraph @NUM2 it says, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” These hills affect the cyclist because he has to exert more energy to cycle up the hills. This extra effort causes him to become exhausted more quickly than he would on flat land. If the setting had been different, such as not being in a hilly desert, the cyclist would not have become as dehydrated and tired as he did. In conclusion, the features of the setting, including the heat and the hilly terrain, affect the cyclist in many ways, making his cycling journey a real struggle.

The features of the setting directly affect the cyclist. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” This affects the cyclist because in June, the high - desert climate is extremely hot. The arid desert environment exacerbates the heat, causing the cyclist to continuously drink water until his supply runs out. As he pedals, he expends energy, which makes him sweat profusely, further increasing his need for water. “One ramshackle shed. Several rusty pipes and a corral that couldn't hold the lamest mule greeted me.” This desolate scene presents a problem as there is no available water source. The cyclist has to conserve his remaining water and limit his energy expenditure. Clearly, cycling in a water - scarce desert setting has a far greater impact on the cyclist than cycling on a cold day.

The cyclist in, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” was affected greatly by the features of the setting. First of all, the weather was extremely hot, and this sweltering heat makes one feel completely exhausted, as if they have no energy to do anything. Moreover, there is no one in sight. The cyclist is all alone in this vast expanse, which makes her feel small and helpless. I can relate to this feeling; when I'm in an empty place, I tend to get scared. Finally, there is no water around. It's obvious that the author is dying of thirst. The lack of any visible resources around her makes her perception of thirst even more acute. All these factors in the setting combine to have a significant and negative impact on the cyclist.

The setting affected the cyclist in multiple ways. The rough roads made it extremely difficult for the cyclist to pedal. The uneven surface and bumps on the roads constantly challenged his balance and strength as he tried to move forward. Additionally, he encountered a snake during his ride through the “town.” The sudden appearance of the snake startled the cyclist, making his heart race and his hands tremble on the handlebars. To make matters worse, he was running out of water. When he finally found some water, it tasted like battery acid, which was not only unpalatable but also made him question its safety. Overall, the setting was very rough on the cyclist, presenting a series of hardships during his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him tired, scared, thirsty, and causing him to worry. The setting was a scorching hot California day in June. The cyclist was riding through the intense heat, struggling over the hills and difficult terrain. He describes the land when he says, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” These rolling hills required extra effort to climb, gradually wearing him down. He also mentions, “Over one long, crippling hill,” which shows the extreme physical challenge he faced. As the cyclist progresses further, self - doubt creeps in. Fear and thirst start to take over him. He says, “It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” expressing his despair. When the cyclist finds the bait shop, he has almost lost all hope. On his way to the shop, he says, “Slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” However, at the end, the sight of the bait shop makes the cyclist regain his strength. He says, “Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.” The features of the setting put the cyclist on an unsteady ride filled with fear, hope, and confidence.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by helping him get water to quench his intense thirst. After suffering from the lack of water for a long time, he finally finds a source that allows him to rehydrate. This enables him to get back on the road and continue his journey to wherever he is trying to go. However, one notable aspect is that he never mentions getting his bait for the fish. It seems that his focus was primarily on survival and getting water. Additionally, the cyclist was severely affected as he almost died from thirst and the lack of a proper road. The harsh setting put his life at risk, but the discovery of water gave him a new lease on his journey.
He is in a race, desperately trying to reach Yosemite while being close to some rushing river.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. Having desert stretches makes you want to just lay there and not try to go any further, because you don’t know where the end will be. The scorching sun and the endless expanse of sand can be extremely demoralizing. As for grassy, flowery land, it offers more of a scenic route, and makes you want to keep going and see many things. The gentle breeze and the colorful flowers create a pleasant atmosphere. Hills and terrain make it harder to keep going but more of a challenge, and a good workout at the same time. Clearly, the setting does affect the cyclist.

When the cyclist first receives directions to Yosemite Park from the “old timers” he met, he was pretty confident that they knew what they were talking about. He thought they had years of experience and local knowledge. To his dismay, these elderly men sent him through life - threatening conditions in a deserted area. As the cyclist begins his journey through the hot, June weather, he “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” He was full of enthusiasm at the start. As he continues forward, he notices that there are no buildings, cars, or people of any kind. The silence was eerie. He passes abandoned towns and creeps into the desert flat land. The flatland however, morphs into crippling hills with tumbleweeds and snakes awaiting. Not only is the terrain suddenly different, but the cyclist is rapidly deteriorating. Tiredness and lack of water make the cyclist think “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” It was amazing that through all this, the cyclist was able to reach a small fishing camp where he is quickly replenished. “Gary and Wilber’s Fish Camp” saved the cyclist from almost certain death and taught him to always just use his map.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed posted Speed Limit.” The features of the area the cyclists rides through affect him greatly. For example, when the narration says, “At some point, humble weeds crossed my path” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The presence of these unassuming weeds in the desolate landscape shows the tone of the cyclist with despair creeping into his mind. Also, another good example is when the narration says, “After a long, arduous hill, a building came into view” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The sudden sight of the building makes the cyclist sound more hopeful than before. That is how the area the cyclist enters affects his state of mind.

In the story the cyclist is affected by many features of the desert. The main feature is the heat. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The intense heat was almost unbearable. He’s also running low on water, “The water bottles only contained a few tantalizing sips.” The limited amount of water was a constant worry. He’s faced by extreme heat and lack of water. He’s tired and has a long way to go. So far, all of the towns have been deserted. The emptiness added to his sense of isolation. Finally he reaches a bait shop and refills his water and promised to stick to the map in the future, realizing that relying on others' directions can be risky.

In the essay, the setting affects the cyclist in different ways. For example, the course must have been tough because he was visibly dehydrated, with his lips parched and his energy waning. It is described that there are rolling hills and rough roads, which would have made pedaling extremely strenuous. Another example is that there were dangerous animals like snakes that he unexpectedly came across on the path. These slithering creatures added an element of fear and distraction. In conclusion, these are some reasons how the setting significantly affects the cyclist.

The terrain described in this essay adds a profound effect to the struggles of the cyclist. For example, when the author says “there were no cars nor buildings in sight,” it vividly adds to the effect that he is truly out in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by an empty expanse. Also, it adds a great deal of impact when he comes upon an abandoned juice factory. He is so desperately thirsty that he puts stones in his mouth to gather even a tiny bit of saliva. Moreover, when he finally finds water, an “old - timer” casually asks if he knows the best way to go, which further emphasizes his isolation and the challenges of the journey. In conclusion, the terrain and these encounters effectively illustrate the cyclist's arduous struggles.

In the essay, the cyclist is riding in the desert. It is extremely hot out because it’s June, and the sweltering heat causes a lot of problems for him. He said that since it was so hot, he was afraid of getting dehydrated, constantly worrying about his dwindling water supply. Also, he explains that the roads were getting hilly, with the inclines becoming steeper. This would have caused him to work much harder, meaning he was losing more water through heavy sweating. In conclusion, the combination of the desert heat and hilly roads poses significant challenges to the cyclist.

The features of the setting negatively affect the cyclist. When the cyclist arrived at the first “town,” he could immediately tell there’d be some issues. It was a deserted, run - down area with dilapidated buildings and a desolate atmosphere. The water was hot, making it unappealing and less effective in quenching his thirst. Down the road, the setting started to change from flat land to hills, which required more physical effort. There was a big snake in the road, startling him and causing a momentary loss of focus. He was becoming very dehydrated going through hilly areas with little to no water, his body gradually weakening. In conclusion, the various negative features of the setting severely hamper the cyclist's journey.

I think it explains because they did a decent job, showing some competence and effort. However, it was not entirely good either because they did the right thing in some aspects, but they also made the same kind of mistakes. For instance, they followed a correct procedure in part, but then repeated a wrong step that undermined their progress. In conclusion, their performance was a mix of right and wrong actions, which is why the situation is as it is.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the sweltering and desolate setting significantly affect the cyclist. Dehydration, caused by the intense heat and not having enough water, made the cyclist constantly sweat and feel nauseous. “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke, caused me to laugh.” In this quote, he is thinking about all the bad and horrible things that could happen to him because he is already in a bad physical and mental state. In conclusion, these features of the setting, like the heat and lack of water, have a detrimental impact on the cyclist.

The features of the harsh desert setting affect the cyclist in a big way. For one, the intense “heat beating down on him made him sweaty, extremely hot and utterly tired. The relentless heat had also made him extremely thirsty, which led him to drink a lot of water in a very little amount of time. As a result, he ran out of water before reaching the next town. Also, since he was in the vast desert, there were no trees to give him the shade that he could rest in. There were also no people around to help him or give him a much - needed drink of water. So, during the ride, he struggled more than he ever thought he could, facing the full brunt of the unforgiving environment.

Some of the things that affect the cyclist was the severe lack of water. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Water is of great importance to strong men. Your body needs water to function right. The extremely humid and dry weather of California was also an issue. “The high deserts of California in June.” “I could drop from a heatstroke.” The sun is unbearable, especially without shade and water, having a huge affect on the cyclist. The lack of human presence “There was No - one in sight.” It would have been a lot easier for the cyclist if a store or people would have been around. Another factor is the presence of animals. “A @CAPS3 large snake crossed my path.” “A diamondback blocked the majority of the pavement.” It was an added worry for the cyclist. These are all things that affect the cyclist and make his journey extremely difficult.

Rolling hills, open terrain, high deserts - all are prominent features of the setting that affect the cyclist. First, the long - stretching rolling hills could gradually take a great deal of energy out of the cyclist when having to travel for miles on end, constantly pedaling up and down. The open terrain exposes the cyclist to the unrelenting beating sun, which also puts a lot of physical and mental pressure on the cyclist. Lastly, high deserts would have a significant affect on the cyclist because he has to pedal for miles on end in the rough and dry terrain, putting a great strain on his body overall. In summary, these setting features make the cyclist's journey arduous.

In the case of the cyclist in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted speed limit,” the setting has an enormous affect on the biker. Predominantly, the scorching weather causes him to feel severely dehydrated. He says that he “had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly.” @CAPS1, he tries to get water from the old well, demonstrating just how desperately he needed water. The water in this pump, the owner said, was “somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” If the water has reached such a high temperature, the reader can infer that it must be extremely hot outside. The author implied this when he says he is in California in June, it is a sweltering day, and the sun was beating down mercilessly. Another aspect of the setting, the lane, dirty, “ghost town” infested land, had a large affect on the cyclist. As he begins to look around, he loses hope. He cannot see any signs of human life; “there was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind.” This empty land makes the cyclist himself feel empty inside. Most literally, the fact that the setting was unknown to the cyclist added to his confusion. He didn't know the best path to his destination and therefore relied on others for aid. Because of this, he ends up lost and in a difficult situation. In conclusion, the setting, with its weather, desolation and unfamiliarity, severely impacts the cyclist's journey.

There were many different conditions that affected the cyclist. He did not have the proper amount of water for the long and arduous journey, which made it extremely difficult. He states in the story, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Additionally, the rough terrain and numerous hills made it difficult. He ran into snakes and passed through very deserted country. But his unwavering determination led to success, and he finally arrived into a town, relieved to have overcome the challenges.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. When he arrives in the first “town” that the old men told him to go to, the cyclist “chuckled and moved on”, and acted just sort of indifferent, showing little interest to seeing this old and dilapidated town. As he reached “the fork of sorts” twenty miles up the road, "the sight was troubling to him as his water supply was somewhat deteriorating, so he became a bit uncertain. Finally when the cyclist read the sign that said “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the author continued to move on, but with a large chunk of his confidence gone. He was dehydrated, fatigued, and had lost a lot of hope after coming across all these desolate places. When he saw the sign for Gary and Wilber’s fish camp, he was as happy as could be, knowing he would drink some water, rest, continue his journey the next day, and not listen to old men’s directions again. Many people in stories or in real life are affected by the setting they are in. In the novel *The* Champions by *Author*, one of the characters named *Group* went on a journey to find an art exhibition, running into many problems on the way, which in many cases, gave him a lack of hope in reaching his destination safely. The influence of setting on characters is a common and significant aspect in both literature and real - world experiences.

Some features can affect the cyclist. The weather can slow them down. For example, if it was extremely cold outside, the cyclist's muscles could stiffen, and if it was swelteringly hot, they could quickly become dehydrated, both of which can slow the person down. If the person does not have proper gear to deal with such weather conditions, the impact on their cycling performance can be even more severe. In conclusion, weather is an important setting feature that can have a notable effect on cyclists.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by the road that he was on. He was on a road that had snakes slithering around, and the trees were all fallen across the road, creating obstacles. The road was like a snake because it was winding and waved. It had a huge hill that made you go fast when descending, and it was hard to start going up because the hill was steep and slippery. It was so challenging that no one would ride that hill casually. If it was a popular race, then it would have been easier to ride the hill because there would be more people around. There would be some people who could help you if you get hurt. There is also no lights there. If you ride at night, then you can’t see where you are going unless you put a light on your bike or helmet, and then you can ride the hill at night with more ease. These are the features of the setting that affect the cyclist going down a hill where no one is there to help you if you need it. In such a situation, the cyclist has to rely solely on their own skills and equipment to navigate the challenging road.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because there was a lot of detours and distractions where the cyclist rode. The detours could lead the cyclist off - course, and the distractions, such as unexpected wildlife or strange noises, could divert their attention. The cyclist had to pay full attention to the road or else the cyclist could have been seriously injured. The features of the setting also affect the cyclist because he has to go down steep hills and navigate through windy turns. Going down steep hills requires careful control of speed, and windy turns demand precise steering. In conclusion, the features of the setting have a huge affect on the cyclist, influencing their safety, speed, and overall cycling experience.

Setting can affect a cyclist in many ways. Just as I read in the story, being in a sweltering desert dehydrated him severely. The scorching heat was unbearable, the rough and bumpy road made the ride extremely difficult, and there were the lurking dangers of poisonous snakes. The cyclist could have died in many ways such as: heatstroke from the intense heat, falling off his bike on the uneven terrain, dehydration due to the lack of water, and a bite from a venomous snake. Say, if the cyclist was in the mountains of Colorado. There are many problems that face you there, like steep slopes, cold temperatures, and unpredictable weather. In conclusion, different settings pose various threats to cyclists.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by causing him to be hit with his water bottle regularly as he jolted along the rough paths. The high deserts of California, with their arid expanse and intense heat, affected him greatly. Also, “Not many miles into the next section of the ride, he noticed a significant terrain change.” For example, the previously flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills that required more effort to pedal. Then after overcoming that challenge, “A large highway sign jumped out at him saying or reading,” “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed Posted Speed Limit. And that was 55 miles per hour. This forced him to slow down and be more cautious. Last, the author says, “Sometimes life can feel so cruel.” In conclusion, there were many things that affected the cyclist, from the terrain to the road signs.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. One way is that they would drink up all of their water because it was extremely hot and they would get desperately thirsty from all of that strenuous cycling under the blazing sun. The heat made the water evaporate quickly from their bodies, leaving them parched and in need of constant hydration. In conclusion, the hot setting had a significant impact on the cyclist's water consumption.

In the essay entitled “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed the speed limit” the setting changes as does the mood of the essay as well as the mood of the cyclist. For example, towards the beginning of the essay, at the peaceful reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, the essay states, “At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early summer evening.” This shows how towards the beginning of the essay the cyclist is happy, just woke up feeling refreshed and getting ready to go on a nice, leisurely bike ride. However, this all changes when he gets directions from a couple of “old - timers.” From that point on, his trip goes downhill. The essay states, “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town,’ a desolate ghost town,” “The sun was beginning to beat down mercilessly,” This also shows that the setting of a ghost town and a setting with the sun beating down is affecting the mood of the essay and the mood of the cyclist. As he goes another twenty miles to a different ghost town with only a few rusty water pumps containing acid - flavored water. At this point, the cyclist is very worried because it's hot and he has no water, while knowing he has another thirty miles to go. Thirty miles of rolling hills and the hot sun while seeing a “A Rough Road Ahead” sign and a diamondback snake, he is sure he is going to die. However, it all changes when a different sign, one for a baitshop, offers a glimmer of hope. This is how the author, Joe Kurmaskie, uses the setting to affect the mood.

The dusty, dry setting has a serious effect on the cycling author. It got so long and hot that, “...a slow blues tune ‘summer time’ rattled around in...my deteriorating brain.” The author has spent so long cycling through the searing heat that his brain is starting to shut down. It’s also because there is very little water left for him, and what little water he has is warm and unpalatable. Another problem is that every building/town except the last building is deserted. So without any chance of being refueled and restocked with food and water, it’s the author v.s nature. Plus, as the author states, the directions came from old people who, “...haven’t left their porches since Carter was in office.” The world has greatly changed. Towns have become deserted, buildings rundown but the roads are kept in shape. The towns the old people mention are now ghost towns, and are no help to the author. In conclusion, the harsh setting and unreliable directions have put the author in a difficult situation.

As the cyclist continues on his ride, the once - familiar and pleasant surroundings gradually transform. These changes in the environment ultimately have a profound impact on the cyclist's attitude. When he first set out on his journey to Yosemite that morning, he started with strong, well - rested legs and a wide smile on his face. He had eagerly received travel information from a few of the older, local residents. They assured him that this advice would help cut down the time it took to arrive at Yosemite National Park. However, as he pedaled along, the cyclist began to realize that perhaps the older men's travel advice was a bit out of date. With only a tiny bit of water left to hydrate himself and being surrounded by seemingly endless stretches of road and desolate desert, the cyclist couldn't help but let out a laugh. "It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself." At this point, the cyclist was angry with himself for not just relying on the map he had brought instead of blindly listening to the locals. Although he remained determined to find water, his hope was steadily waning. Then, suddenly, he came across a bait store. Here, he was able to quickly rehydrate himself. With his spirits renewed, he continued on his journey, this time firmly relying on his map to guide him.

The cyclist was riding on a rough, bumpy, and extremely dangerous road. The uneven surface made each pedal stroke a challenge, and he constantly had to adjust his balance. He had to be constantly on the lookout for wild animals that might try to attack or even kill him. There were snakes slithering near the roadside and coyotes lurking in the distance. Since he had no water left in his bottles, he was rapidly dehydrating. His throat was parched, and his energy was draining fast. Also, the road was hot, and despite it being well - traveled, it seemed to soak up his energy. Every bit of effort to get through it was a struggle. In this harsh situation, he knew he had to find water soon to keep going.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly. It looks as if he is on a long, desolate highway in the middle of the desert, riding either his motorcycle or bike. The vast expanse of the desert around him gives an impression that he is either coming from or going on a vacation. The way he is riding, with the wind whipping through his hair and his body leaning forward, makes it seem like he is going extremely fast, almost on the verge of losing control and falling. The hot desert sun beats down on him, adding to the sense of urgency and danger in his ride. This setting not only impacts his physical state but also his mental state, making him more cautious and aware of his surroundings.

The cyclist is out in the vast, arid desert. The scorching sun has been beating down on him all day, and he has been pedaling for hours. As a result, he is extremely tired. His legs feel like lead, and his arms are sore from gripping the handlebars. Also, he is running out of water. The little water he had brought with him is almost gone, and he is getting severely dehydrated. His lips are chapped, and his throat is dry and scratchy. He knows he has to find water soon or his situation will become life - threatening.

The setting of the story affected the cyclist by significantly changing his mood. At the start, he had high confidence and enthusiasm, which gradually faded once he entered the barren desert. The desolate landscape, with its endless sand and lack of any signs of life, sapped his energy and optimism. However, his mood picked up when he rounded a rest stop. A prime example of his mood swings is how he went from "strong legs and a smile on my face" to "the growing realization that I could drop dead of a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their perch in decades" to "I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait." The overall mood of the story is closely based on how the author, through the cyclist's experiences, feels about the journey and the changing settings. It shows how the environment can have a powerful influence on one's emotions and mindset.

The features of the setting in this story, “Do not exceed Posted Speed limit,” affect the cyclist in a huge way. The cyclist was biking through a desolate, desert - like area in California. The sweltering heat in this region can be unbearable, just as the writer describes, “wide rings of sweat circled my shirt.” The fact that the area he was biking through was a vast desert and he ran out of water put himself into serious danger. Also, since the cyclist had no water, he was rapidly becoming dehydrated. The area he was biking through had barely any people around, which meant there was no readily available water for him. Therefore, if the setting had taken place in a cooler area with lots of people, the cyclist would have easily found water. Without this type of harsh setting, the story would have completely changed, as the cyclist's struggle and the tension of the story would have been non - existent.

The setting very much affects the cyclist. The statement “I maneuvered down the hill” clearly shows him navigating down a rather steep hill. If the hill wasn't there, it would have been a whole lot easier for him to get to his destination. He wouldn't have to carefully control his speed while going down and would have saved a significant amount of energy. Without the hill to slow him down or consume his energy, he could have maintained a steady pace and reached his goal more quickly. If there weren't any hills to get in his way, the journey would have been far less arduous, and he would have likely completed it with much less fatigue. In conclusion, the presence of the hill in the setting had a notable impact on the cyclist's journey.

The setting in this story was hot and filled with rolling hills. These factors greatly affected the cyclist. The hot weather was extremely bad for the cyclist because he had a very limited water supply. The text says, “The sun was beginning to beat down” (@NUM1), clearly showing that the temperature was steadily rising. As the heat intensified, the cyclist's need for water increased rapidly. Moreover, the text says, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (@NUM2). To make matters worse, the author's battery was leaking acid, which made it even harder for him to pedal and make it over the hills. It seems like everything went wrong for this man, but despite all these difficulties, he still persevered and made it to his destination, highlighting his determination in the face of a challenging setting.

In the start of the story “Do not exceed speed limit,” the time of year and place setting were the main things that affected the cyclist. This story takes place in the deserts of California in June. The fact that the story took place in June, and especially in a California desert, really is what caused the cyclist's dehydration. Anywhere in this country, June is summer, and summer means that it gets hotter and more humid than usual. In the California desert, the heat is even more intense. This extreme heat caused the cyclist to lose a large amount of water through sweating, leading to dehydration and the “growing realization that I (the author)” was in a difficult situation. Without this specific time and place setting, the cyclist would not have faced such a severe struggle with dehydration, and the story would have had a very different tone and outcome.

The settings in the story affected the cyclist throughout the story. With winding roads and hills, peddling can already be tough, tiring, and challenging. The cyclist had little to no knowledge of the roads, which made the journey ten times harder to deal with. Navigating the winding roads without prior knowledge required extra concentration and energy. And with no landmarks or places in sight, it was extremely hard for the cyclist to have confidence. There was nothing tangible to keep him going, no visible goal on the horizon. This lack of direction and motivation made the already difficult task of cycling on winding roads and hills even more demoralizing. In conclusion, the settings in the story significantly hampered the cyclist's progress and mental state.

Donít let anything stop you from achieving your goals. One such goal could be going to Yosemite National Park. Reaching there takes a journey that leads you away from the comfort of home. After traveling forty miles into the journey, you come to a small town. You stop at a water station but are disappointed as old men say, ìthe water taste like buttery acid.î Then you continue, leading towards the hills and desolate towns. You can ride on without anything to drink. People unfortunately die from heat - attacks because they donít take the time to rest and replenish with water and food. But donít let these challenges stop you from your goal.

Features in the setting of the cyclist do in fact affect him in many significant ways. The setting in the story affects the cyclist a great deal. It is June in the vast California desert. The scorching sun is beating down on him relentlessly. All of these factors together make him consume his water supply even faster. As he runs out of water, the setting is making him feel extremely desperate, and this desperation only worsens his situation. In the end, the harsh setting truly tests the cyclist's resolve.

Each person has a really remarkable ability that stands out prominently. Someone can be good - looking, highly intelligent, or exude confidence. There are those who never give up and do exactly what they wish to do. The cyclist in the story is a man with an incredibly strong will. He has a deep - seated desire to be alive. He has encountered too many difficulties on his way to reach the place he wanted to be. He listened to some old guys' advice and unfortunately lost his way. The sun was beginning to bear down with full force. He was completely out of water, yet he continued riding determinedly to reach his goal. As he rode on, he was gradually losing his strength. The weather was extremely hot. The water he found tasted like acid from a battery. But he firmly believed in himself that he could stay alive. He managed to gather more strength by believing in himself even though his physical strength was waning. Every place that he passed by was a new and valuable experience for his life. These experiences were like a challenging game that he managed to overcome successfully. He never gave up. He did everything within his power to not lose his sanity. He didnít want to lose the mental battle, and his unwavering spirit kept him going.

The features of the setting made the cyclist even more tired and extremely thirsty. The rolling hills presented a tough challenge where he had to pedal strenuously up and down. The desert stretched out before him, with no water in sight, just endless dry land. Everything in the setting was intensifying the conflict in his story. The old Welchís Grape Juice Factory was a taunting sight; it was as if drinks were right there but were now long gone. If it would have been Yosemite with its cool pines and flowing rivers, he wouldíve felt completely at ease. There were no people in sight, which made him lack a sense of security, and there was also a shortage of water and no buildings for shelter. The tumble weeds blowing around gave no hope of getting anywhere, and the sight of snakes and vultures waiting to feast after one died was terrifying. Everything in the story was the complete opposite of what he wanted until he finally reached his last hope, the bait shop. This bait shop became a glimmer of hope in his otherwise harsh journey.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the setting of the story majorly affected the cyclist. The story tells us “...I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” The extreme heat of the summer, with temperatures soaring high, definitely put a strain on the cyclist causing him to have to drink lots of water. Unfortunately, the “towns” were very far apart and many did not have good water, creating a dehydration problem. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or a structure of any kind.” None of this would have happened had he been cycling at a marathon with people handing him water when requested, or if he had been smart enough to follow a good map to avoid such difficult situations.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist significantly. For example, on page @NUM1, Kurmaskie said “I got down on my hands, laboriously working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength”. This vivid description shows his desperation due to the lack of water, highlighting how the setting's water - scarcity issue had a direct impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting have been a major affect on this cyclist in the story. On the normal road, the ground is smooth but it is also a lot like a maze, curvy and winding. The cyclist also comes across bumps and non - paved roads that make it extremely hard to maneuver through. Then, you add the fact that there are not really any towns nearby and he is in a blazing heat with little water. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is in the high deserts of California where it is very hot. In such high - temperature conditions, you need a lot of water to stay hydrated. Then he needs more water and finds a water pump but can't use the water because it was “somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees”, which is far too hot to consume. Then the terrain changes when he says “Flat road was replaced”. This change in terrain further complicates his journey, showing how the setting's various features continuously impact the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because I was talking about the exceed posted speed limit. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in that he or she should act, behave, or talk according to the specific settings. In the beginning, the cyclist was full of energy, ready to go, and extremely happy about the journey ahead. As time passed and he got half - way to his destination, he started “losing hope”. The weather was very hot, and he was completely alone on the road. By the end, he was greatly relieved because not only did he manage to find water to quench his thirst, but he also discovered an easier way to reach Yosemite. The first group of old men he met didn't offer any help, but the second man was kind enough to assist him. In the story “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting have a significant impact on the cyclist. This is evident as the cyclist gives us an insight into what's going on around him and how he feels about it. It describes, “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold the lamest mule greeted me.” The author further mentions that this troubled him. In fact, it made the author scared, thinking that maybe he was all alone in the desert with a ghost - town. An unplanned situation was that the roads were in a rusty condition where the speed limit was 55 mph, but since he barely had any water, he was only going 12 mph. This indicates that he was troubled and confused about the surrounding environment. As the desert stretched on, it seemed like the author was slowly losing hope as he traveled further. I think it's similar to how some people, as soon as trouble appears or seems imminent, start losing hope and their good judgment, making life seem much harder.

In this story, it seems as if every part of the environment is dry. The rider, continuously cycling under such conditions, would be getting extremely thirsty. He is all by himself on this journey, and this solitude could make any man feel vulnerable because if he were to have an accident, there would be nobody around to help. Moreover, he is going up and down steep hills. These steep slopes require him to be extra careful while cycling to avoid any mishaps. In conclusion, the dry environment, his solitude, and the hilly terrain all pose challenges to the rider.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For instance, if you were cycling in a very cold climate, your body wouldn't perspire as much, and you wouldn't need to drink as much water. However, in the story, the cyclist is in a very hot climate, and he quickly runs out of water. The quote “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, wide circles of sweat circled my shirt and the growing realization that I could drop from heat - stroke on a gorgeous day in June…” clearly explains that the setting of the cycling plays a huge role in the cyclist's experience. Also, the terrain can have a significant impact on the biker. If one were to ride on a flat terrain, there would be much less wear - and - tear on the cyclist's body, making it an easier ride. All of these reasons clearly show that the settings affect the cyclist in numerous ways.

The setting plays an important part in the author's mood. When the author stumbles upon the dilapidated ghost town, he is still full of high spirits and finds it quite amusing. He muses that it's a bit comical that the old men’s “town” has now been completely abandoned. “…(the town) fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled…” This clearly shows that the author is still in good spirits as he can still let out a laugh. When “a tar - like substance slowly oozed out of the water pump at the next stop, the author became a bit unsettled since he was running critically low on water. But he still clung to optimism. Once the rolling, expansive hills came into view, the author let out a “sad, hopeless laugh.” At this point, the author was depressed, severely dehydrated, and had almost given up. In the passage “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” the setting definitely affects the cyclist. When the cyclist first arrives at the abandoned “town,” he eagerly searches for water. On a scorching hot day in June, a cyclist was riding his bike in the desert. He rode off towards the sun, heading on his way to Yosemite National Park. Some old men gave him directions on the map, even though they hadn't been through that way in many years. When the cyclist started his day, he was full of energy and ready to go. He naively thought he would be able to stop and get water regularly. But soon he realized he was right in the middle of the desert with no water in sight. The man pushed himself hard and tried to stop thinking about water. He even put pebbles in his mouth to suck on so that he could keep his mind off his parched throat. The man showed great intelligence in this situation, and he knew exactly what to do to survive. This experience has made him stronger, both physically and mentally.

FLAT ROADS, HILLS, BUILDING - ALL ARE SETTINGS THAT AFFECTED THE CYCLIST. While the hills were flat, the cyclist was extremely determined. He firmly believed he could make it and was not going to give up on himself. He pedaled steadily, with a clear goal in mind. However, when the hills got bigger and it became harder to pedal, he began to feel the strain. His legs started to ache, and he grew exhausted and tired. Lastly, the buildings were what almost made him want to give up. When he sees the building of the Welch’s Grape Juice Factory and a young boy drinking, he “hung his head.” He was getting more and more tired as he went along. The land, with its changing terrains and the sight of the factory, was making him feel as if he didn't have the energy to keep moving along. But perhaps, deep down, he still held a glimmer of hope to overcome these challenges.

The setting affected the cyclist greatly. It think it means to truly be all that you are capable of being, to reach your fullest potential.
