With long, tiring rides on winding hilly roads and very little water to sustain him, the cyclist was surprisingly in good spirits. I mean, he could have been very angry about the challenging conditions, but he kept his cool and stayed calm throughout the ordeal. This shows his resilience in the face of a tough setting.

The towns, the rugged terrain, the dilapidated Welch’s Grape Juice factory - all are integral parts of the setting that affect the cyclist. “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time - say, before the last world war,” describes the cyclist with a hint of melancholy, “but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” The desolate town intensifies the cyclist's growing feeling of doubt. At this part, he is really regretting taking the old guy's advice in taking the “shortcut.” “Not two miles into the next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing,” reveals the cyclist. The cyclist is already very worried and very doubtful, and the rough, unforgiving terrain is making it worse. It mirrors the town in which the cyclist had stopped at earlier, again making his feeling of doubt increase. The cyclist exclaims, “By the looks of it - had been a Welch’s Grape Juice Factory.” The cyclist gets very excited when he sees this, and gets a great feeling of hope. So throughout the whole story, the setting of where the cyclist is at affects his mood by giving him doubt, but by also giving him hope, making his journey a roller - coaster of emotions.

The cyclist was biking through the vast California deserts during the warm summer months. The scorching heat and the long, uninhabited canal were the biggest struggles for the cyclist. For example, he thought there would be many convenient stops for water during his trip, but he was sorely mistaken. Also, he runs out of water very quickly because of being severely dehydrated in the blistering heat. The cyclist became irritated with himself for blindly trusting someone else to give him directions for a shortcut. The harsh setting affected the cyclist’s mood in a negative way, leaving him frustrated and disheartened.

There were many features in the setting of this bike race that affected the cyclist. It stated, “The previously flat road was replaced by short, steep rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist was pedaling smoothly and steadily until these big, challenging hills came into play, and his energy was gradually running lower as he labored up each incline. Also it stated, “At some point tumbleweeds randomly crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake slithered across” (Kurmaskie @NUM2). This debris and the menacing snake made him stop abruptly because he got scared and significantly slowed him down. There were a lot of features in the setting that affected the cyclist, causing him to slow down and lose precious energy, ultimately hampering his progress in the race.

Many things can affect a cyclist and how they ride. In this essay, several factors influenced the cyclist, such as the setting of the story. One of the problems with the setting was the absence of stores or even people. Another, and most crucial, was the lack of water around the cyclist. So, many things can affect a cyclist while they are riding, including their surroundings. These various elements combined to have a notable impact on the cyclist's riding experience.

The second photograph better communicates ideas similar to those expressed in the essay “A Sea Worry” because the story is about a boy who surfs as a job. In the second picture, a boy is clearly seen surfing. The author states, “My son body - surfs. He says it’s his ‘job’.” This quote clearly explains that he is a body - surfer and that surfing is his occupation. Due to this strong connection between the essay and the second photograph, it is evident why I chose the second photograph as it effectively mirrors the key idea from the essay.

The condition the cyclist is in affects a great deal of how they ride. One clear example of this is, “I was travelling through the high desert of California in June.” Due to this fact, the cyclist had entered a “dehydrated state” because of not having an adequate supply of water. When you are travelling in hot - weather areas without much water, your body will become dehydrated from sweating profusely. Cycling in different conditions will affect cyclists differently, and this example clearly shows how adverse conditions can significantly impact a cyclist's state and riding ability.

Many features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead.” First, the scorching heat of the desert in June was a major problem that pushed him to the brink of dehydration. In the text, it states, “I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This clearly shows the severe effect the exposure to intense heat had on the cyclist. Also, the challenging terrain posed a threat to his well - being during the story. In the text, it says, “I toiled on.” This illustrates the significant increase in effort and strain that the difficult terrain caused on the cyclist during his adventure. Overall, these setting features had a profound and negative impact on the cyclist's journey.

In the story “Do not Exceed Posted Speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The hot weather affected him because it made him extremely thirsty. Moreover, being out in the middle of the vast desert meant that he had no access to water. The steep hills further exhausted him, making him tired and weak. All of these features in the setting had a cumulative effect on him, leaving him feeling powerless and desperately thirsty. In conclusion, the setting played a crucial role in hindering the cyclist's experience.

The features that affect the cyclist are that he is riding his bike in the vast, arid desert and doesn't have any water left in his bottles. That affects his journey because he is severely dehydrated, feeling dizzy and weak. So he needs to find water fast. This is making him get to Yosemite slower because he has to constantly stop and search for water sources. That is a feature that significantly affects the cyclist's progress.

In the story, the setting has a large and detrimental affect on the cyclist. After taking the seemingly well - meaning advice from some old people in a small town, he ended up in a desolate desert area with no cars passing by, no buildings in sight, and not a single person around. He was running critically low on water and had absolutely no way of getting any more. He was really dehydrated, felt extremely tired, and his legs were giving out. He almost gave up because of the scorching heat and the lack of water. All this was caused by the harsh setting he was in, which clearly hampered his journey.

The setting of the place was a “ghost town” as the author said. It was a sweltering hot summer day in June, and the sun was beating down mercilessly. So, of course, the cyclist would be rapidly dehydrating, his throat parched and his lips chapped. There was no one around for miles, so he couldn't ask for help. It was like an old - fashioned town because he ran into some elderly men who were so out of touch that they knew nothing of the new world. They were so unfamiliar with modern directions that they told him the wrong way, further complicating his journey.

The setting affected the cyclist in a few different ways. At first, it helped him. “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed. The cool pines and rushing rivers” This is saying the refreshing pines and the gurgling rivers helped him forget about the intense sun, providing a pleasant and calming environment. Later on, however, the setting was against him. There was no place nearby to get water, and he was becoming increasingly dehydrated. The terrain was getting rougher, with more rocks and uneven ground. There were no people around to offer him a helping hand, but there was a slithering snake on the path, adding to his distress. All these features were working against him until he finally made it to a small bait store. This bait store gave him much - needed water and a reliable, detailed map to continue his journey.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe @PERSON1, it tells of a cyclist heading for Yosemite National Park, and the numerous problems he faced. For example, the intense heat was a major issue the cyclist had to face. In the story, it said “Drop from heatstroke.” This shows that the setting affected him in a very negative way. The blistering heat was a major part of the setting that made the cyclist's journey extremely difficult, sapping his energy and putting his health at risk. The heat in the setting clearly had a significant and adverse impact on the character's progress towards Yosemite.

The features of the setting affected the author’s story a great deal. It had an impact by making the trip appear even more difficult to the reader. This was achieved by vividly describing how sweltering hot it was and elaborating on how the road was replete with bumps and numerous hills. The story states “over one long, crippling hill.” This makes the reader perceive the trip as extremely arduous since the character has to pedal up so many steep hills. But if the road was not as hilly, then the trip would seem far less difficult. This would also give the impression that the old guys provided good directions. But the whole point of the story's setting is to create a challenging narrative for the reader to engage with.

As soon as the cyclist gained information about which way to go, he eagerly set off through the tall, cool pines. The thick foliage of these pines gave him a strong feeling of confidence, and at the same time, physically cooled his overheated body down. As he pedaled steadily down the road, he encountered various small towns, none of which looked promising at all. This lack of viable options gave him a deep - seated feeling of despair, especially in accordance with his dwindling supply of water. Even further into the journey, he found one last town and a rundown welche’s @CAPS1 factory. The sight of the factory increased his thirst and gave him a strong feeling of spite towards the old men who had given him advice. However, he soon chanced upon a bait house where he could get water and escape the scorching heat. For this fortunate discovery, he was thoroughly satisfied and extremely grateful to the kind - hearted owner. It made him realize that he should never again blindly trust the old men's advice.

The setting affects a great deal in a cyclist's experience. For example, if you are cycling in a bustling city, you feel rushed, tired, and overwhelmed by the constant noise and traffic. The honking horns and fast - paced environment add to the stress. But when you find yourself in a serene forest, surrounded by the sounds of nature, you are happy and a bit less stressed. The gentle rustling of leaves and the chirping of birds create a calming atmosphere. A setting not only sets the mood but also influences the attitude in the story, making it an important element in how the cyclist perceives and endures the journey.

The features of the setting affect the author's disposition as well as his ability to complete the journey, thus creating a significant obstacle that the author must overcome. At the end of paragraph five, the author writes that “I was traveling through the high deserts of California.” This particular setting is crucial because it adds a palpable sense of urgency to his trip when he starts to run low on water. In the arid desert, water is scarce, and the risk of dehydration looms large. This is similar to when I was backpacking and a bear got most of our food. Our normal, leisurely backpacking trip had suddenly become more of a game of survival. So, the water issue was clearly the main point of conflict that the author presented in the setting. He also writes that “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This aspect of the setting also affects the cyclist because it makes it much more strenuous for him to progress than if it was a downhill road. In short, the setting of the story presents the main points of conflict to the author and thus was essential to the essay as it drives the narrative forward.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the unbearable setting affects the cyclist with its harsh conditions. At first, in the cyclist’s own words, “things began well enough.” However, this soon changes. The road is long and filled with numerous obstacles, and the cyclist has hardly any water to take a sip from. He does not give up, though. In the text, it says, “got back on the bike, but not bothered gathered up a few peldder and stuck them in my mouth.” He does this in order to reduce his need for water and continues his journey, bravely ignoring the challenges that the unforgiving setting brings upon him. Despite the hardships, his determination shows that he is willing to push through the difficult circumstances presented by the setting.

The cyclist is affected by the setting in “Rough Road Ahead” because the road is a specific place. If it is rough or its conditions are unknown, it has a direct impact on the traveler, who in this case is the cyclist. For instance, if it is a hill, then the cyclist would have to exert extra effort to climb it. In the text, it said, “over a long crippling hill,” and the “crippling hill” part clearly stresses that the setting is a challenging hill, which makes the cyclist's journey more difficult. This shows how the setting can directly affect the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because there is no water, there are hills, and there are deserts. When the cyclists saw water, they had an intense urge to jump in. All they could think about was the water they lacked, which felt like battery acid in their throats. Then, the hills slowed them down on their way to the water. The desert, with its scorching heat, just made them want water even more. These are some of the prominent features of the settings that significantly affected the cyclist's journey and well - being.

There were many features in the setting that affected the cyclist. One was the extreme heat during the June heatwave in California. The speaker vividly said that he could have easily died from heatstroke due to the blistering temperatures. The rough road was also a major problem for the cyclist. The numerous bumps, steep hills, and unexpected wildlife along the way affected the cyclist’s journey. The thing that most affected him was the lack of water. It was such a severe problem that he had to suck on stones to distract himself from the intense thirst. As you can see, these problems in the story had a profound impact on the speaker’s journey to Yosemite National Park, making it a challenging and arduous one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. He is riding in the desert where there is little to no rain. This means that if he runs out of water, he can't collect any from natural sources to drink. Also, deserts are extremely hot. The searing heat will rapidly speed up the dehydration process, so he will need a large amount of water to survive. If he runs out of water, he will face a life - threatening situation. The cyclist finds a building, but unfortunately, it is abandoned and completely empty. All these features of the setting have a detrimental effect on him. Since he can't find water, he has to carefully conserve what little water he has. Also, the heat is taking a toll on his body. It doesn't help that the only building he finds is abandoned. During the whole time when the threat of death looms in the air, with the desert showing no signs of life, no water in sight, the cyclist is constantly thinking about his possible death. As long as he dwells on his death, the situation seems even more hopeless. But as soon as he puts the pebbles in his mouth to stop thinking about death and being thirsty, he sees a bait shop which saves his life. He starts thinking about his survival, and immediately, he finds a place where he can drink and replenish his water supply.

The setting affected the cyclist greatly throughout his ride. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke (pG @NUM1 kurmaskie).” This quote is clearly saying that because of the intense heat, the rough and uneven terrain, and the unexpectedly long length of his “shortcut,” he is rapidly running out of water. That’s when he has a terrifying realization that he could die from heatstroke because he heedlessly listened to a bunch of old men's advice. This shows how the setting can turn a simple ride into a life - threatening situation for the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He finds himself in the vast expanse of the desert, where the scorching sun beats down relentlessly, and he has a meager and dwindling supply of water. Without an adequate water supply, his body quickly succumbs to fatigue, and he tired very easily. On top of that, he had to pedal a bicycle through the unforgiving desert terrain. So, he was constantly thirsty and utterly exhausted from rambling in the desert. This is how the setting affected the cyclist, making his journey an arduous struggle.

The setting significantly affects the cyclist. The cyclist has to constantly worry about the road condition. If the road is full of potholes, uneven surfaces, or gravel, then the cyclist must reduce his/her speed to maintain balance and avoid accidents. The cyclist also has to be vigilant about whether it is day or night. If it is night, visibility is severely reduced, and they must be extremely careful as cars may not be able to see them easily. In the text, the cyclist was in extremely hot weather, with the sun baking the ground and the air filled with stifling heat. This is extremely dangerous to the cyclist if they are not prepared with essential things such as an ample supply of water. Overall, the setting presents various challenges that the cyclist has to face during the journey.

The setting affects the cyclist because the cyclist initially believes that he has a nice, short, flat distance to travel to get to Yosemite. He imagines a smooth and effortless ride, but instead, it turns out to be a long, hilly (rough), and sweltering journey. He only prepared himself for a quick ride, bringing only a small amount of water, just enough for what he thought would be a brief trip, and wasn't prepared for the harsh reality of his ride. First of all, he is riding in the middle of the day, which is the hottest part of the day, in the “high deserts of California in June”. I know when I go to camp here in @LOCATION1 during the summer, I drink six to seven liters of water to stay hydrated, but the author only mentions a “few bottles of water”, which clearly aren't going to be sufficient to sustain him in that intense heat. Secondly, the cyclist believed that the old men had given him a safe and reliable path to follow, but instead, he unexpectedly came across a “ridiculously large snake. It really looked like a diamondback”. That is a highly poisonous snake, and the cyclist has barely been able to “ease past” it because of his lack of water, which has weakened his physical state. Lastly, the cyclist expected the old men to give him an easy path on a flat terrain, but in fact, the flat stretch was replaced by short, rolling hills. This means he has to put in more physical effort, using up more water in the process, to climb the hills. The setting definitely affects the cyclist because it makes it much more difficult for him to reach his destination. However, without these unexpected challenges and bumps in the road, how is he to learn a valuable life lesson about being better prepared and expecting the unexpected?

The cyclist is affected by the features of the setting a great deal. For example, the dry and hot place creates an intense thirst in him as the heat causes his body to lose water rapidly through sweating. Then, the ghost towns he passes through are desolate and abandoned, making it extremely hard for him to get essential supplies like food, water, or spare parts for his bike. Also, the bad road, which is full of cracks, potholes, and loose gravel, slowed him down considerably. The rough surface of the bad roads even would probably hurt him and his bike. His body jolts with every bump, and the constant vibrations can damage the bike's components. The roads also would make him work harder as he has to pedal with more force to move forward on the uneven ground. In conclusion, the setting's features have a significant negative impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many bad ways. For example, in the text it says how “I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state”. This means that he had a great deal of trouble being in a place he didn't know well. The unfamiliar surroundings added to his stress, and he was also severely dehydrated, which further impaired his physical and mental abilities. His body was weak, and his judgment was clouded, making it difficult for him to navigate safely. In conclusion, the setting did affect the cyclist, presenting numerous obstacles and challenges that made his journey a difficult and perilous one.

First, the biker sets off on his journey. The bike smoothly encounters flat roads in the vast desert, where the lack of obstacles makes navigation through these areas very easy. When he arrives at his first town, he remains determined and keeps going, still focused on reaching Yosemite. As his water supply starts going low, he actively looks for some more water to keep himself going. Then he continues on his way and comes across a fork in the road. After choosing a path at the fork, he keeps pedaling forward and soon faces another problem. An old person tells him that it's @NUM1 miles to the next town, but he doesn't trust the guy. Despite his doubts, the biker decides to listen and goes on down the road. Next, he faces yet another challenge. The previously flat road starts to become quite uneven with short, alternating high and low hills. These hills gradually reduce his stamina greatly as he struggles to climb them. Then he has to deal with a rocky and bumpy desert road that jolts his bike and makes the ride uncomfortable. Suddenly, he has to face a snake on the road and quickly maneuvers to avoid it so that it doesn't attack him. Finally, the biker conquers his last long hill and is relieved to find a bait and tackle shop with lots of water. There, he can replenish his supplies and regain his strength for the rest of his journey.

In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist is significantly affected by the features of the setting, making him feel even worse than he initially does. The cyclist is lost in the unfamiliar area, has only managed to find dirty water, and is constantly moving on rough ground. The features of the setting are described as “cool pines and rushing rivers,” creating an idyllic image. However, the cyclist comes to find that the so - called “rushing river” is not as refreshing as it sounds. It might be dirty or difficult to access, leaving him disappointed. He also experiences a terrain change, transitioning from a flat road to short, rolling hills that require more effort to pedal through. There is a prominent sign, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” which is also the name of the passage, with a limit of 55 mph. In contrast, the cyclist is only going a slow 12 mph, highlighting the vast difference between his pace and the speed limit. Ironically, he stumbles upon a picture of a boy drinking grape juice at the factory. This sight makes him hang his head in misery as his intense thirst becomes even more unbearable. Finally, he comes to a fish camp. When he encounters the owner, the owner, in an ironic twist, tells him he’d be better off using his map, leaving the cyclist still in a state of uncertainty about his journey.

The features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist because he is destined to be on the road for a long time. The desolate setting, with no buildings in sight, no people around, and no cars passing by, affects the rider deeply. When he is running low on water, he feels utterly helpless in this empty expanse. The mention of a ghost town doesn't help his situation either. An old man told him about it, and he had high hopes of being able to get more water there. But when he arrives, he finds it just as barren as the rest of the area. The grape juice factory also affects him negatively. He thought he would finally get a refreshing drink there, but to his dismay, it is abandoned. There are no signs of activity or any available drinks. All these features combined create a difficult and discouraging situation for the cyclist, clearly showing how the features of the setting impact his journey and well - being.

Features of the setting would have a significant impact on me if I were the cyclist. Just like him, I would start thinking that I was going to die. There is absolutely nothing interesting to look at in this desolate landscape. There is no gentle breeze to cool me down, and no wind to provide any relief. The cyclist has already seen a snake, which adds to the sense of danger. And to make matters worse, he has no water. He has gone through three towns, hoping to find some supplies, but each town has been completely empty with nothing to offer. The sun is slowly setting down on him, and the heat is still intense. He has no hope left as he struggles to continue. Who knows, maybe if he would have just strictly followed what the map had said, he would have been fine and avoided all these hardships.

The features of the setting have a profound and multi - faceted impact on the cyclist. The cyclist is in a dire situation, running out of water and being exposed to the intense heat in “the high deserts of California in June.” The sweltering heat is relentless, sapping his energy and leaving him parched. The tumbleweeds that randomly cross his path add to his sense of desperation. They seem like a symbol of the desolation and isolation of the place. Not only do the features of the setting affect the cyclist physically by dehydrating him in the scorching heat, but they also take a toll on his mental state. The cyclist has to encounter various challenges along the way, such as rolling hills that make pedaling difficult, tumbleweeds that disrupt his path, rattlesnakes that pose a real threat, and ghost towns that offer no help. All of these factors gradually make the cyclist start to give up hope. He becomes more and more discouraged as he realizes the harshness of his environment. In conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist both physically, by weakening his body, and mentally, by eroding his will to continue.

The features of the setting greatly impacted the cyclist. First, the setting at the middle of the story was an empty expanse with no place to get water. The desolate landscape stretched as far as the eye could see, with not a single oasis in sight. This filled the cyclist with doubt and despair, and he/she thought they would die under the scorching sun. The setting also made the cyclist extremely thirsty because of the extreme heat that seemed to suck the moisture out of every pore. Finally, the cyclist was filled with regret because they regretted listening to the old men's advice. As a result, the cyclist didn't make it where he/she wanted to go, and the journey seemed like a wasted effort.

The author thinks that the setting means he is not getting any closer to his destination. As he looked around, the vast and barren landscape seemed to stretch on forever, making his progress feel like a futile endeavor. However, he found out that there was still people around. Their sudden appearance in the desolate setting caught him off guard, and he panicked, thinking he was going to die. The places were deserted, with broken-down buildings and overgrown weeds, and he thought they led nowhere. He was a little scared at the fact he might die because everything around him was in a sense dead, with no signs of life or hope.

The setting really affected the cyclist. Since he was in the desert on a bike, he was bound to be hot and tired. The relentless sun beat down on him, its rays like a furnace baking his body. The heat radiated from the sand, making the air shimmer and the ground feel like it was on fire. This exhaustion and heat would come from the sun coming down on him with full force. You know he was hot where it said “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt.” The dried sweat was a clear sign of the intense heat and the toll it was taking on his body.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they are extreme and do not change. The cyclist was riding on a narrow, dusty small road in the desert. The desert was a vast expanse of sand and rock, with no shade or relief from the blistering sun. In the desert, it was swelteringly hot, and because of this, the cyclist was sweating profusely and getting dehydrated rapidly. Also, because he was in the desert, with its featureless landscape and lack of landmarks, he had no sense of direction. He felt like he was wandering aimlessly in a sea of sand. Also, the towns were all run down, with dilapidated buildings and empty streets, with nothing in them. So, the cyclist couldn't get any water to drink to rehydrate himself. Only when he came to a small, shabby bait shop close by did he finally get water, which was a huge relief.

The setting really affected the cyclist a lot. The blazing sun and the sweltering hot weather dehydrated him quickly. His body was losing water at an alarming rate, and he felt weak and dizzy. He also had pretty much run out of water. In the story, he says "The bottles contained only a few drops," which clearly shows that he had drank almost all of his water. Then it says "the growing realization that I could drop from a heat - stroke" shows the heat was affecting him severely. His head throbbed, and his vision started to blur, making him fear for his life. The setting had truly taken a toll on the cyclist's well - being.

The setting was calm and peaceful as he started out riding his bike. With a wide smile on his face, he pedaled steadily, his strong legs propelling him forward. As he hit the @NUM1 town and saw a ramshackled shed, rusty pumps, and a corral, a sense of unease began to creep over him because he was running out of water. As the flat roads were replaced with short, rolling hills, his worry deepened. When he saw a building, his face lit up with hope, but when he found out it was run - down, he felt sad, thirsty, and utterly tired. When he finally saw an old man and told him he had a map, he became a little happier because he knew the map was going to help him reach Yosemite. As the setting became worse, with the landscape growing more desolate and the sun beating down mercilessly, his mood became worse as he had less and less water and felt very hopeless. But when he saw the man, the glimmer of hope returned, as he believed the map would guide him to his destination.

The setting of this story is very rigorous. At the beginning of the story, the boy was in good spirits. He had a bottle of water with him, which he carried carefully to ensure he didn't get dehydrated. When he was riding, he started to feel the sun getting higher into the sky, though he could barely notice it because of the tall pines that shaded the road and the cool feel of the nearby river. The cyclist got to the second town on his journey. He had been sipping his water all day and was almost out. He had found a water pump. He got down on his knees, his body tired from the long ride, and pulled hard on the handle. All that came out was blackish water. He just feared the water and stated that it tasted like battery acid. He began to ride again. Not two miles up the road, the terrain changed. Not only was it rolling hills, but it was also getting hotter. He was majorly dehydrated because he was out of water except for a few “tantalizing sips”. Dry sweat circled his shirt and he was afraid he could suffer from heat - strokes. Where he was at was in the middle of nowhere, with no buildings, cars or structures in sight. Over the tops of the hills, a building came into view. He wiped the sweat off his eyes to make sure it was not a mirage. By the looks of it, it had been a Welchís @CAPS1 @CAPS2 Factory. He was so dehydrated and tired that he could imagine a “Young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth.” The problem was that it was abandoned. This person was imagining things. He got back on his bike and stuck pebbles into his mouth to help take his mind off being thirsty.

I read “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” written by Joe Kurmaskie. In the story, the features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him accept advice from “old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches while @CAPS1 was in office”. These old - timers, with their local knowledge and experience, offer guidance that the cyclist takes to heart, as the challenging setting makes him rely on any help he can get.

In the essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. First, the sun is making the cyclist hot and dehydrated. He states “The sun was beginning to beat down,” clearly indicating that the sun was a big factor in its effect on the cyclist. The intense heat made him sweat profusely and drained his energy. Also, the hills of the country roads. Going up and down hills take a lot of work; you have to use a great deal of energy. The cyclist says “@CAPS2 were replaced by short, rolling hills.” Moreover, there were snakes in the road, which made the cyclist timid, constantly looking out for snakes so he would not get bit. Again, the cyclist states “diamond back - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” Additionally, there was an old factory that gave the cyclist hope and then crushed his hopes. The factory even made him more thirsty as he imagined the refreshment it could have provided. In conclusion, there were many affects on the cyclist due to the setting.

The features of the setting take their toll on the unfortunate cyclist. For example, “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” The deserts of California, especially in June, are extremely hot and dry. The scorching sun beats down on the cyclist, causing him to use much of his water supply very quickly. As he “toiled” on, the terrain features became even more trying, “over one long, crippling hill…” By this time, the cyclist was so exhausted that he barely had enough energy to make it over a hill. All the wear and tear his body was put through by the features of his setting, such as the heat, the dryness, and the difficult terrain, left him on the verge of collapse. In the end, the harsh setting had truly tested his limits.

The settings of this story have an encouraging impact on it, as the ride he undertakes is quite challenging. Such a setting for a really athletic ride can be truly devastating, making the outcome of the journey highly uncertain.

The features of the cyclist and the settings aren't that good. There are incidents that pose problems. One of them is the bad weather. The temperature is such that it makes it feel pretty close to @NUM1 degrees. He stops at a water pump, and although water comes out, it is far from cool. He takes two tiny sips, and it tastes like battery acid. If he were to drink a large amount of that water, it would probably either kill him or make him extremely ill. He desperately needs something because there is another town @NUM2 miles down the road, so he has to find a way to keep himself going. As he pedals down the road, he sees a sign: “Rough Road Ahead.” Even though he is going at 12 mph, he could still hit a hole and go flying over his handlebars. If he does go over his handlebars, he could run into the snake he saw earlier and then get eaten by the birds because he wouldn't have any energy to get up. Heat, water supply, energy – all are crucial features of the setting that can significantly affect a cyclist. First, there is heat. When it is overly warm outside, it not only makes the ride more difficult but also extremely inconvenient. The sweltering heat can sap a cyclist's strength and motivation. Second, water supply is vital. If you are in the middle of a ride and start to run low on water, you are in serious trouble. The author describes, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” This shows that if you aren't well - prepared for your cycling journey, it will be extremely inconvenient when you run out of supplies. Lastly, energy is the key. If you run out of energy while cycling, you have nothing. Your energy is what keeps you moving forward and motivated. “With what I believe, was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill,” the author describes. When you are out of energy, your ride comes to an end. All of these aspects are essential to consider and have in place before deciding to go on a cycling journey to ensure a successful and enjoyable ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in multiple ways. Firstly, the combination of the heat and the lack of water leads to dehydration and can even cause him to see mirages. The intense heat makes him lose a large amount of water through sweating, and with little water available, his body starts to suffer. Secondly, he loses strength as he goes over the many hills. The steep inclines and rough terrain require a great deal of physical effort, gradually draining his energy. Moreover, there is a very large snake that he has to ride by, which poses a real danger as it could have bitten him. All these factors together make the cyclist's journey extremely difficult and perilous.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because when there are hills to climb and only a small amount of water, dehydration is inevitable. The physical exertion of climbing hills makes the cyclist sweat profusely, and without enough water to replenish the lost fluids, his body starts to suffer. Also, the heat from the desert is so intense that it further exacerbates the dehydration problem. If you don't pace yourself and don't drink an appropriate amount of water, you will struggle to reach your goal. Taking breaks to rest is also a big factor. If you don't have enough energy due to lack of rest, you won't be able to cover much distance. Therefore, proper planning and management are essential for a cyclist to overcome the challenges posed by the setting.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. The steep hills made it extremely hard for him to ride his bike uphill as he had to exert a great deal of energy with each pedal stroke. Moreover, he was afraid of the grass because it was tall and had a rather scary - looking appearance, which made him cautious while cycling through areas with such grass. In the end, these setting features clearly hindered his cycling experience.

In the story “Do not exceed Posted Speed limit”, a determined cyclist embarks on a journey through the challenging terrain to reach the beautiful Yosemite. In that particular part of California, there are very few towns and the population is sparse. The road he is riding on is not only very dangerous but also incredibly long, with potholes and sharp turns. It is very dry and hot out there, and the lack of shade makes the journey even more arduous. Despite these difficulties, the cyclist perseveres in his quest to reach Yosemite.

The setting can affect a cyclist in a multitude of ways. One prominent way the setting affects a cyclist is when the weather is hot. In such conditions, it becomes notably harder to cycle long distances. I say this because in the story, the narrator vividly states “...and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke...” Another crucial part of the setting that impacts cyclists is the terrain they cycle on. For instance, it is much easier to cycle on flat, smooth ground where the wheels roll effortlessly than it is on rolling hills with rough, rocky ground that constantly jolts the cyclist. This is clearly shown with the quote “...ride down into distances I could see over the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine.” Setting can have a great deal of impact on a cyclist, depending on whether it's smooth or rocky, or hot or cool, ultimately influencing their cycling performance and experience.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed the Speed Limit”, the features of the setting affect the cyclist to a great extent. Each distinct feature causes the cyclist to take specific actions. For example, upon reaching the “ramshackle shed”, the cyclist discovers that the water there is unusable. This forces him to carefully conserve the little water he has left and attempt to head for the next town. That action leads him deeper into the sweltering high deserts of California during the hot month of June. Also, as the terrain gradually changes from a flat road to short, rolling hills, the cyclist must adjust his speed to better endure and continue in his dehydrated state. The scarcity of buildings in this dry and barren desert terrain compels the cyclist to check every “shack” or building he comes across in the hope of finding water. In this story, the features of the setting strongly dictate the actions of the cyclist in his desperate quest to survive in the desert.

The cyclist in the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, is on what starts as a great adventure but soon turns bad. He initially has everything he thinks he needs, yet somehow, things take a turn for the worse. He gets low on water, and the setting is truly horrible. He is on his way from a campground in @LOCATION2, @LOCATION1 to the Yosemite river. He receives bad directions from some old guys at the campground. On his way, he runs into two abandoned towns, and as he pedals on, he starts running out of water. Then he comes to a sign that says, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” He is pedaling over hills, and with each passing moment, he becomes more and more dehydrated. When he thinks he is going to die, he comes to a bait shop. There, he gets water and meets an old guy who offers to give him directions. However, he decides he better stick to the map. Even though the setting gets worse as the story progresses, he sticks it out and finally makes it to the end of his challenging journey.

Heat, hills, and ghost towns – all are prominent features of the setting that significantly affect the cyclist. First, the intense heat dehydrates and exhausts him, pushing him to the brink of a heat - stroke. As the sun beats down mercilessly, he starts drinking more often, and soon realizes he's nearly run out of water. Next are the hills. These steep inclines demand massive amounts of energy to climb, further adding to his dehydration as he pants and sweats his way up. Finally, the desolate ghost towns. Their empty streets and dilapidated buildings make his long journey seem hopeless, and there's a real risk that this could cause him to lose the will to carry on. Overall, these elements of the setting combine to make the cyclist's journey an extremely challenging one.

The cyclist is in the sweltering desert where the temperature soars to @NUM1 degrees. The water he has, which is his only relief, tastes like battery acid, making it a bitter necessity. The harsh desert environment plays tricks on his senses, causing him to see mirages. Meanwhile, the copious sweat pouring down his face keeps getting into his eyes, stinging and blurring his vision. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, these desert - induced hardships are integral to the cyclist's experience. All these factors combine to make his journey in the desert a truly arduous one.

In the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the author shares a tale of when he followed the advice of the “old folks” and ended up getting lost. The setting of his journey had a profound impact on him. For example, he describes how “tumbleweeds crossed my path, and a ridiculously large snake...”, which gives a vivid picture of the wild and unpredictable environment. He's in a very hot climate, specifically in a vast, arid desert. Due to the scorching heat, he needs large amounts of water to stay hydrated, but unfortunately, he has a limited supply. To make matters worse, he's riding on hilly terrain. The steep slopes and uneven ground make pedaling incredibly difficult, expending even more of his energy. As if that weren't enough, he can't find any towns that aren't abandoned. The desolate, empty towns offer no respite or assistance. All these factors combined create a very tough situation for him during his journey.

In the story, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. One significant way is time. The rough and uneven road forces him to go slower, meaning it takes him much longer to reach the town. Every pedal - stroke is a struggle on this difficult surface. Also, because the road is so hard to pedal on, he expends a great deal of energy and quickly gets thirsty. To make matters worse, the water he has is really hot, offering little relief from his thirst. In conclusion, the setting's features conspire to make the cyclist's journey both time - consuming and physically draining.

There were several notable features of the setting that held an impact on the cyclist in this story. For one, the cyclist was riding in a sweltering hot desert. The intense heat in this condition normally makes it extremely difficult for one to obtain water. Seeing as how water was an absolute necessity for the cyclist to keep going, the lack of it due to the arid desert created the critical conflict of dehydration. Additionally, the desolate and abandoned town that the cyclist passed through triggered a spark of deep - seated doubt in the cyclist’s mind. The cyclist now had to ride with his brain clouded in doubt and his body in a state of desperate hope. By the time he/she reaches the old, dilapidated factory, the cyclist is extremely dehydrated. Now his head is screaming with annoyance from the heat and exhaustion, and his body is screaming with an intense lack of water. This abandoned juice factory almost completely wiped out the cyclist's last shreds of hope. A man is little to nothing without hope. The setting had a profound and direct impact on the cyclist, because he didn’t know if he was going to die or live in this harsh environment. The scorching heat made him use up all his water at a rapid pace. As he pedaled on, the heat bore down on him like a furnace, and his mouth became as dry as a desert. Every breath was a struggle, and his throat felt like it was lined with sandpaper. With no end in sight and no immediate source of water, the cyclist was in a life - threatening situation. The setting, with its unforgiving heat, had put his very survival at stake. In conclusion, the harsh setting was a major factor that endangered the cyclist's life, and his fate hung in the balance.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, he shows that the features of the setting played a significant role in affecting the cyclist in many different ways. A prominent setting the cyclist faces is that it is so swelteringly hot that he keeps constantly taking (drinking) water, and he is constantly worrying that he is going to run out. Kurmaskie writes, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in the blistering heat. The sun was beating down mercilessly, and the dry air was sucking the moisture out of me.” This is what the cyclist gets affected by throughout the whole story as he realizes he could die of a dangerous heatstroke if he doesn't carefully watch how much water he's drinking. Also, this is what a lot of people normally face when traveling in such extreme conditions, which is a huge challenge because of the ever - present threat of dehydration. In conclusion, the hot desert setting in the story is a major obstacle for the cyclist, endangering his well - being.

With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a constantly fluid place where things change rapidly. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist is this: Never take travel advice from old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their front porches. As the cyclist continued on his journey, the previously flat road was gradually replaced by short, but challenging rolling hills. Up ahead, a sign warned “Rough Road ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit.” The rough road was full of potholes and uneven surfaces, making the ride even more difficult. The cyclist had to be extra cautious to avoid accidents. Many things about the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” have a substantial impact on the cyclist. Not to mention that while he is severely dehydrated, and when he finally finds water, it is “tarlike” and “in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees,” making it almost undrinkable. So he asked for directions and was given inadequate information, which made life extremely difficult for the cyclist. In conclusion, the challenging terrain, the lack of proper water, and the unreliable directions all combined to make the cyclist's journey to Yosemite a perilous one.

The setting of “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affects the cyclist in so many ways. A response that explains how the features of setting affect the cyclist by getting the wrong direction from the old man. One feature is when he passed through a ghost town. The features of the setting will affect the cyclist because the roads are steeply hilly and he is an elderly man, so it will be extremely hard for him to ride up them. Well, some features of the setting like the intense hotness are affecting the cyclist. The character in this short story has a mood that changes with his surroundings. There are many ways the features of the setting affect the cyclist. For instance, the desert is not a humid environment, making its lack of water a bigger deal than normal. The features of the setting affect the cyclist, and one important aspect is to never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven’t left their porches since Carter was in office. In the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, he accepts directions from old men for a shortcut to Yosemite National Park. He ends up cycling in a desert with no water, barely able to push the pedals of his bike. The setting affects the cyclist severely as it is extremely hot, he has nothing to drink, there is nowhere to get water or food, and he might be seeing mirages. In the essay, it states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke.” This clearly shows that the lack of water and the harsh surrounding environment with nowhere to go is making him give up hope to survive. It also says in the essay, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited.” The cyclist is admitting that the desert has him doubting his own senses, and having false hopes when he sees something that might not be real. The desert setting of this essay affects the cyclist in many ways other than just one, all of which are detrimental to his journey.

In “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, I think that the setting affected the cyclist because he was extremely thirsty and he thought he was going to die. The features of the setting have a big impact on the cyclist. One feature is the hot weather and the area he is in. He says he is in the “high deserts of California in June.” With June being a hot month in California, and the cyclist being around deserts, the heat is intensified. “I could drop from a heatstroke,” he says. The sun is beating down on him relentlessly, taking away the cyclist’s energy that he needs for riding his bike. Another feature that affected the cyclist was his lack of water. “Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This affected the cyclist by making him extremely tired. Being tired from no water, the cyclist had great trouble going up hills on his bike. The last feature that affected the cyclist was all of the hills in his path. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” These hills made it hard to go up on a bike, especially considering his lack of water and the intense heat. All of these features affect the cyclist by making him lose energy, get tired, and become frustrated because of their combined negative impact on his cycling journey.

Nature has an impact on everyone, even when they don't realize it. This is especially true for cyclists traveling far and wide. In “Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, it serves as a perfect example of how settings affect people like cyclists. When you're riding your bike as a means of cross - country transportation, you need to be well - informed about what you're doing and where you're going. The cyclist in this story decided to take advice from older fellows and ended up on the wrong route. At these so - called “towns,” there was no water because they weren't proper towns anymore. Without water, like this cyclist, the hills could be life - threatening. For instance, “I gathered a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. If he had gone all that way without dealing with his thirst and the challenges of those hills, he probably would have suffered some kind of stroke. Some of the features of the setting that affected the cyclist were quite challenging. The seal on his equipment was starting to give way, but he only truly noticed it about twenty miles up the road when he came to a sort of park. The cyclist was riding through the sweltering high deserts of California in June. He got down on his hands and knees, working on the heated handle of the rusty pump. The pump began to shoot out a tar - like substance, and the water was around two hundred degrees. After two more miles, he noticed the terrain changing from a flat road to short, rolling hills. He said tumbleweeds crossed his path and a large snake slithered across the pavement. He gathered some pebbles and stuck them in his mouth, having read that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst. After reading about these experiences, it's clear that these settings had a significant impact on the cyclist, making his journey arduous and full of obstacles.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. First, the “town” the cyclist first comes upon is described as a desolate ghost town. In the story “Rough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting had a more negative impact on the cyclist. The desert - like land affected the cyclist by making him extremely tired and causing a significant loss of body water. As a result, he desperately needed water to continue his journey. In the cyclist’s outlook on his journey through Yosemite’s park, readers can get a vivid good feel of how it might be to be riding right alongside him. In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” there are many distinct features of the setting that greatly affect the cyclist. Many of these features impact him in a negative way. Many features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, the intense heat was the main part of nature that threw him off balance. The setting affects the cyclist in many ways. First is that it is extremely hot in the desert, with the sun shining brightly and the temperature soaring. The setting affects the cyclist in almost every aspect of what he does and what he encounters. The setting is a sweltering hot day in June in the desert. The features of the setting in the story affect the cyclist by vividly describing that he is in a desert - like area in Lodi, California.
