The features of the setting have a large impact on the cyclist. If a cyclist would happen to be cycling in the snow, he or she could eat snow to keep from dehydration as snow can provide a source of water in that cold environment. If the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” was cycling in winter time, he would have been constantly so thirsty all of the time because the cold air can cause increased water loss through respiration. Also, if the whole ride was downhill, he would be extremely tired as the constant braking and control of the bike to maintain speed can put a strain on the muscles. In conclusion, different settings can bring various difficulties and physical demands to the cyclist.

The conditions for the cyclist in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” are pretty dangerous. “a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement balance my dehydrated state bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips” (kurmaskie, @NUM1). There was a rather large snake right in his path, coiled menacingly. You can tell he isn't an expert on snakes because he couldn't even begin to identify what kind of snake it was. Because he is in the arid desert on a long bike ride, he is severely dehydrated. His water supply is almost completely gone, with only a few drops left in his bottles. The cyclist feared many dangerous challenges in his journey, such as this snake encounter and the threat of further dehydration. In the end, the harsh desert setting and the unexpected obstacles make his journey a perilous one.

The features of the setting that affect the cyclist are the terrain, the lack of provisions and the power of self - determination. The terrain affected the cyclist by having him/her ride through rough and uneven paths in order to reach their destination. For example, if you walk on sharp rocks, you are bound to reach some rough spots where it seems you can't move forward easily. But that is where self - determination kicks in. The power to keep yourself moving even though there might be obstacles in your way; you know there will be a better path or a reward at the end. Another example of a feature is a lack of provision on your trip. When you don't have the right provisions, like enough food and water, to keep yourself energized, you can't get over your obstacles or even push yourself to do anything. This is why the features of the setting, including the difficult terrain, insufficient provisions, and the need for self - determination, have a significant impact on the cyclist.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the harsh terrain has a notably negative effect on the author. He claims that “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie). This clearly shows that he has been drinking his water too fast due to the intense heat from being in the desert during summertime. After traveling for a long time with no water in sight, he lets out a few chuckles, thinking of how he shouldn't have ignored the old men's advice. He explains that “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” This is a prime example of how badly the unforgiving terrain had affected him. It's gotten to him so much that he even applauds himself for having the mere energy to feel sorry for himself, highlighting the extreme toll the journey has taken on him.

The features of the desolate setting significantly affect the cyclist because the cyclist is already extremely tired and desperately thirsty. The features include a vast desert - like setting of California, where it is swelteringly hot. There are absolutely no signs of civilization in sight, giving an overwhelming sense of isolation. The roads are like never - ending hills that stretch throughout the arid desert. On top of those harsh facts, the cyclist is rapidly dehydrating because his water supply has supposedly diminished, leaving him in a precarious situation during this grueling journey.

The setting of the short cut affected the cyclist in numerous ways. For example, he came across rusty water, and as he described, "it tasted like battery acid." Due to this repulsive taste, he was not able to drink it, which gradually made him become severely dehydrated. Also, in the story, it says, "flat roads were replaced by short rolling hills." This change in the terrain could have made the journey even more arduous for the cyclist because now he had to exert a little more effort to pedal up the hills. One more example is towards the end when he says, "I began breaking my ride down into distances, I could see the horizon telling myself I could make it there." By the cyclist saying this, it seems like he has almost given up and he realizes that this seemingly never - ending journey will only end when he succumbs to exhaustion. That is how the unforgiving setting in the story affected the cyclist.

Some features of the menacing setting affected the cyclist deeply. The continuous rolling hills, the unexpected encounter with a poisonous snake, and the poor conditions of the road worried her greatly. For example, @CAPS1 said, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and the diary.” @CAPS1 had an overwhelming sense of doubt when uttering that quote. @CAPS1 truly didn't think @CAPS1 would ever make it through this harrowing journey. Finally, after much struggle, @CAPS1 reached another destination and once again found herself asking another older man for directions, still in the midst of this challenging and uncertain adventure.

In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by @PERSON1, the features of the desolate setting greatly affect the struggling cyclist. The first major example is when the cyclist finds that the initially flat road is gradually turning into “short, rolling hills.” These pesky hills are steadily increasing the difficulty of the ride and are causing him to have serious doubts that he will make it to his destination. An additional part of the setting which caused major doubt was that he was in a vast, deserted desert. As he described, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The distant horizon was what kept the cyclist going. He said, “I began breaking the ride down into distances: I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine.” The horizon kept him hopeful and determined. Without the challenging setting he would not have been in such a serious predicament, but luckily in the end, the very same setting helped him muster enough determination to make it through the tough journey.

I guess really safety comes first, and you have to be extremely cautious when you're out in the streets on a bicycle. You never know what might happen. I really don't understand much about cycling safety details, so I can't write much on this topic. But it's clear that being careful is crucial.

When the biker listened attentively to the old folks, he felt a sense of confidence. He pedaled steadily and biked to the first town, but upon arrival, it was like a “ghost town.” After all, a town is a town, yet this one seemed deserted. Soon after that, as he continued on his journey, he did not see anything around. There were no cars passing by, no buildings in sight, or anything of that sort. He was getting increasingly sad and severely dehydrated. The old men had sworn there was a town coming up, so he put his trust and confidence in them once again. He saw a building gradually coming up in the distance, but it was just an old, worn - down factory. He thought he was let down. He was sure he was going to die, right there and then. Then he saw a sign for a fish company! He was overjoyed! The place was really there! He thought of them as his saviors! The settings effect the cyclist tremendously, making his journey a real test of will.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, there were many settings that significantly affect the cyclist. One vivid example would be when he came up to a water pump that looked quite old and rusty. He tried his best to get water out, gripping the handle tightly and working it with all his strength. But unfortunately, water didn't come out. “...working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar - like substance oozed out...” (Kurmaskie). Another example is when he came across rolling hills that seemed never - ending, and the scaring heat that made him sweat profusely. He also came across a snake that took up most of the narrow pavement, which really startled him. These settings clearly had a major impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the settings affect the cyclist significantly. If the environment is just filled with tall buildings on both sides and cars constantly moving around, the cyclist won't be able to break free and bicycle freely. The limited space between buildings restricts his movement, and the presence of cars makes him more cautious. So, it's evident that such settings can have a negative impact on his cycling experience and freedom.

The setting in the story was extremely hot. The biker was sweating a great deal, and his clothes were soaked. The whole town was completely empty. As he rode along, he passed by numerous empty buildings that looked desolate. There were also rivers that he had to cross carefully and big hills that he had to laboriously ride through. As it says about the buildings, “somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” The setting would affect the cyclist because there was no one in the town to offer help or company. Also, the high hills made his cycling extremely strenuous. All these factors combined made his journey a real challenge.

The feature of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. He was in the California desert in the scorching month of June. The vast expanse of the desert had no readily available water sources, so he had to rely solely on the limited water he had carried with him. He says the sun began beating down harder, its rays relentless, and the terrain gradually turned into short rolling hills. These hills made him exert more energy with each pedal stroke, which further dehydrated him quickly. And since there was no water in the arid desert, he was at a high risk of dying of dehydration. In such a harsh environment, every drop of water and every bit of energy became crucial for his survival.

When you're with your family in Ocean City, biking down the bustling boardwalk, your only real obstacle is the throng of people strolling along. However, when you're in a race on winding roads, you could encounter a multitude of obstacles. The weather could prove to be your greatest challenge. You could pass out due to the lack of water and the scorching heat that beats down mercilessly. You could also fall over on the slippery roads caused by a sudden downpour of rain. Along with that, nature could take its toll on you. For instance, a ridiculously large snake once blocked the majority of the pavement in front of the cyclist, just like that, you never know what unexpected thing you could come across in such a situation. In the end, racing on winding roads presents far more complex and unpredictable challenges compared to a casual bike ride on the boardwalk.

Many of the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The cyclist is biking through the desolate deserts. “A ridiculously large snake” – this quote clearly shows that not only is the weather and climate against him, but also the unexpected elements of nature. “I could drop from heat stroke” – another great quote that vividly depicts how sweltering hot it really is where the cyclist is pedaling. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This is a great detailed description of the desolate area where the cyclist finds himself, highlighting just how deserted it is. “The bottle only contained a few tantalizing sips.” This indicates that the cyclist is running critically low on water in the unforgiving desert, and in a desert with no water, that could spell disaster. The above quotes really draw you in and allow you to see the many features of the harsh setting and what it's like for the struggling cyclist. In conclusion, these setting features pose significant and life - threatening challenges to the cyclist.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” affect the cyclist in many ways. First, in the essay when the cyclist says he is in the deserts of California, this setting can have a major impact because it gives people an idea of how extremely hot it most likely was out there and how the lack of water can really harm someone in such an environment. The searing heat can quickly dehydrate the cyclist and sap their energy. Also, when the cyclist describes the water pumps and the unappetizing substances that come out of them, it can give the cyclist a strong feeling of disgust and serve as a constant reminder to always keep a good and reliable water supply. In summary, the desert setting and the state of the water sources in the area create difficult conditions for the cyclist.

Many things in the setting of the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affected the cyclist throughout his arduous journey. One very important part that affected the cyclist greatly is the fact that he was in the deserts without a sufficient and reliable supply of water. The parched desert offered no easy access to water, and the limited water he had was quickly being depleted. Another part of the setting that challenged the cyclist was the considerable length of his journey. Pedaling mile after mile in such a harsh environment required immense physical and mental stamina. Those two factors of his journey to Yosemite combined are probably the worst and most challenging things that affected the cyclist. In the end, these setting - related challenges tested the cyclist's limits in every possible way.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because of the harsh environmental conditions. It was a lack of water, and he was in the high deserts of California. The desolate landscape offered little in terms of resources. For example, in the text, it stated, “when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” That showed clearly when he tried to get water from a pump, what came out was undrinkable. The setting was extremely hot, and the scorching sun beat down on him. This heat made the cyclist miserable in such ways that it sapped his energy and made each pedal stroke a struggle. In the end, the unforgiving setting posed a significant challenge to his journey.

In the story, the features of the setting affect the cyclist because there is not much he can depend on. The desert setting is vast and barren. Usually, there is nothing but sand and heat as far as the eye can see. The cyclist only has a limited supply of what he needs, such as water and food. Riding through the desert does not help him as the long, arduous journey under the blazing sun quickly depletes his resources. For example, the old men who gave him directions made him think he could make it longer before he needed to refill. This affected him because throughout his journey, his lack of water slowed him down and made him feel weak. He started to doubt if he was going to make it. When he finally got to “Gary & Wilber’s fish camp,” he learned a lesson. When an old man asked if he knew the quickest route to Yosemite, he said, “yes, I have a very good map,” realizing the importance of relying on his own resources.

In many real - life situations, nature or a setting can be the biggest hindrance in succeeding, or even surviving. For example, the cyclist withstood the blazing heat of the sun as he pedaled through what seemed to be the desert’s living room: Dry, desolate, and extremely scorching. The hot sand reflected the sun’s rays, intensifying the heat. “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This description clearly depicts the intense heat of the desert. Another feature in the setting was the ever - hanging hills. Though pedaling down the hills was an easier task, traveling up the hill, as well as maneuvering the twists and bends, served as a direct conflict. For instance, “with what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered around a sharp bend.” How the setting affects a situation is ultimately shown when the cyclist reached his destination in great relief. But the biggest hindrance was the harshness of his setting, which tested his physical and mental limits throughout the journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because they made the simplest challenges more difficult for him. The lack of water was a major issue. In the arid desert, water sources were scarce, and his limited supply was quickly running out. This made him constantly thirsty and weakened his body. Another problem was the snake in his path. The snake suddenly appeared on the narrow desert trail, startling him. He had to quickly maneuver his bike to avoid it, which required extra energy and focus. These elements of the setting combined to make his journey a real struggle. In conclusion, the harsh setting significantly impacted the cyclist's ability to complete his journey smoothly.

First, by accepting the old men’s advice, the cyclist was setting himself up for some hardships that he would easily have avoided by using his map. He first encounters a “ghost town,” a place that is completely lifeless. The empty streets and abandoned buildings were a clear sign of its desolation. Most importantly, it was waterless, leaving him parched and worried about his dwindling water supply. Then, he encounters a pump that gives out water tasting like “battery acid.” The foul - tasting water was undrinkable and only added to his distress. Next, he rides past a “Rough Road Ahead” sign; not the most encouraging thing on his already challenging journey. The rough road would surely make pedaling more difficult and put additional strain on his bike. To add to the despair, he has to maneuver his way past a tempting yet empty juice factory. The sight of the factory made his mouth water, but there was no relief to be found. Finally, the parched cyclist arrives at “Gary and Wilber’s Fish Camp.” To him, this simple bait shop was like a beacon of hope, offering him a chance to replenish his supplies and rest his weary body. In the end, the cyclist learned the hard way about the importance of trusting his own map rather than relying on others' advice.

In this story, the enthusiastic cyclist was trying to make it to the beautiful Yosemite, California. In the beginning, full of self - assurance, he decided to ask some old men on a porch. These old men looked as if they hadn't left their porch since Carter was in office for directions. Unfortunately, the old men ended up leading him into the middle of the desolate desert. In the desert, the scorching sun was relentlessly beating down on him, and he had only a limited supply of water. There was absolutely no sign of civilization whatsoever. These sweltering conditions made the cyclist extremely hot, incredibly tired, and desperately thirsty. But his determination didn't waver; he kept pedaling forward and eventually came upon a small, charming town where he could drink cool, refreshing water and take a well - deserved rest, rejuvenating himself for the rest of his journey.

Through most of the story, the various features of the setting affect the cyclist in a predominantly negative way. For instance, he made it to a town that a guy had sworn was there. However, when he arrived, he found it to be completely abandoned. Disappointment washed over him, and he let out a sad, hopeless laugh. Despite his exhaustion, he still had the energy to wallow in self - pity. Another notable feature was the Grape Juice Factory, also in a state of abandonment. When he saw it, he hung his head dejectedly, and the melancholy blues tune “Summer Time” kept rattling in his brain. A third significant feature was his intense thirst. To distract himself, he stuck some pebbles in his mouth. Then he started to think about how lucky he'd be if he checked, realizing that the situation was quite negative for him. All these features combined to make his journey a truly arduous one.

The features from the essay affect the cyclist in many ways. As he pedals along, his body is getting fatigued, and he is drinking more and more water to keep himself going. The roads are becoming increasingly rough, filled with potholes and uneven surfaces. So, he has to slow down his cycling speed. If he slows down, he expends more energy, gets tired more quickly, and thus needs more water. Unfortunately, he is all out of water. On top of that, the old men he asked for directions really didn't know what they were talking about. Their misinformation led him astray, and all these features combined have a profound and negative impact on the cyclist, making his journey a real struggle.

The setting affected the cyclist in numerous ways. For example, the heat was unbearable, like a furnace constantly beating down on him during this long, grueling ride. To make matters worse, there was nowhere around him where he could fill up his water bottle. As a result, he was dying of thirst, his throat parched and his lips cracked. He didn't know where he was going or how far he still had to go. The uncertainty and the harsh conditions added to his distress. The setting was truly crucial in this story, shaping the cyclist's experience and testing his limits to the extreme.

The setting in the beginning of the story is flat and easy, allowing the cyclist to pedal along smoothly. But as the path becomes unfamiliar, it transforms into a terrain full of many steep hills and sharp turns. This change affects the cyclist significantly because he was already low on water and was beginning to show signs of dehydration. The effort required to climb the hills and navigate the turns further depletes his energy and increases his need for water. With his limited water supply, the situation becomes increasingly dire, making his journey a challenging and potentially dangerous one.

The setting significantly affects the cyclist. As he pedals along, he starts to see things that gradually seep into his mind. The desolate scenery passing around him makes him start to feel abandoned and misled because there are no clear signs indicating he is going the right way. Eventually, he realizes he must persevere and trust his instincts to find the correct path.

The cyclist has to overcome a lot of obstacles during his journey. For example, there is a large snake coiled in his path, so he cautiously and carefully rides around it to avoid any danger. Also, there are a lot of steep hills on the route, and he wasn't sure if he could muster the strength to make it up those challenging hills. Furthermore, he is almost out of water, and in the scorching heat, he could die of heatstroke or dehydration. In conclusion, through sheer determination and effort, he overcomes these obstacles and achieves his goal of reaching his destination.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead,” the author goes through many diverse sceneries. All of the places that the author visits, from arid deserts to rocky terrains, make him even more determined because he desperately wants to find water and he just wants to get to the beautiful Yosemite. The unwavering determination pushes him to keep going further and further, no matter how difficult the journey becomes. And then the determination finally pays off after he goes around a sharp turn because he then sees a small, inviting place where he can get something to drink and a place to cool down, bringing relief to his long - awaited quest.

The features of this desolate setting significantly affect the author while he is cycling. They gradually change his initial hope to deep - seated doubt. There were no buildings or cars in sight, which led him to believe he would never get to Yosemite. Also, it had a rough and uneven terrain that made him doubt that he would ever find water to quench his thirst. I'm sure if the setting had buildings, people, even just a hint of civilization, then the cyclist would have been fine and his doubts would have quickly dissipated.

Blazing temperatures, lack of water, dwindling hope—all are the crucial parts of the setting that severely affect the cyclist. Blazing temperatures are a major issue because the hotter it gets, the more the cyclist perspires, leading to a lack of hydration. As the water in his body evaporates, he can't replenish it fast enough, and without water, his body can't function properly. Finally, the dwindling hope takes a toll on him. The cyclist didn't think he was going to live through this harsh ordeal. However, he tried hard, pushed himself beyond his limits, and success was achieved. He lived to tell the tale of his challenging journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he gets tiring easily. The character, in the story, is riding his bike for a long period of time under the sun and he gradually gets tired. He rides alone with nothing or no one around him except the tall trees and wild animals in the forest. The isolation and the long - distance riding take a toll on his energy, making his journey more challenging.

The features of the cyclist's journey are rough because of the hills, snakes, heat, and the limited amount of water. The hills give you a refreshing breeze when going down, which is a small relief, but going up gives you a really hard time as you have to pedal with great effort. The insufficient amount of water can really hurt you by causing you to become dehydrated, which can severely affect your physical performance and even endanger your life. In such conditions, the cyclist's journey is fraught with difficulties.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in several ways. The features of the setting affect the cyclist through the posted speed limits. These speed limits can restrict the cyclist's pace, making the ride less free - flowing. Due to how the setting is, the cyclist has to face a rough hill with a sharp incline. This hill makes it difficult for the cyclist to maintain a good speed, constantly slowing him down. Overall, the setting's features significantly impact the cyclist's riding experience.

The hills and bumpy road slow him down considerably, and he is severely dehydrated. The lack of smooth terrain makes each pedal stroke a struggle, and the dehydration is also slowing him down because he needs water to keep his body functioning properly. There are obstacles in the road too, such as a big snake laying lazily across the middle of the road. This forces him to stop and find a way around, further delaying his journey. He is lost without water and could possibly die of a heatstroke in this hot and arduous environment. His situation is truly dire, and he urgently needs to find help and water.

He knew what he was getting himself into, so if he needed water or anything like that, it was probably his own fault. He should have been more prepared and brought some water with him. Before starting the journey, he should have considered the possible challenges and made the necessary arrangements. By not doing so, he put himself in a difficult and potentially dangerous situation. It's a lesson learned about the importance of preparation in any adventure.

The cyclist and his journey in "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed limit" were significantly impacted by the setting. The scorching "deserts of California in June", with their blistering heat, caused him to be weary very easily as his energy was quickly sapped. The terrain change from the flat, easy - going road to challenging hills made him feel less confident because he felt the road sign was taunting him by saying "DO NOT Exceed 55 mph". He could only manage a slow pace of @NUM1. Finally, a large, menacing snake created an obstacle for him by blocking the majority of the pavement right in front of the cyclist. All of these features affected the cyclist in some way, making his journey a true test of endurance.

The story is basically advocating that more people who currently rely on cars should opt to ride bicycles to work or to school. By doing so, there won't be a large amount of pollution in the air. Bicycles are an eco - friendly alternative, and if more individuals make this switch, it can lead to a cleaner and healthier environment. In conclusion, encouraging cycling over driving cars can play a vital role in reducing air pollution.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The high temperature in the area makes him drink water more frequently, and this excessive consumption leads him to worry that he is going to die because he is running out of water. The "towns" he comes to are so utterly deserted that he starts to think he is going in the wrong direction. All the settings in the story, despite causing these doubts, also serve as a motivation for him not to give up but to keep on going. In conclusion, even though he had to battle through all that self - doubt about whether he was going to be alive in the end, he still persevered and tried. In the end, he did make it, and all his efforts were indeed worth it.

There are many settings that affect the cyclist. One prominent feature would be the rough and uneven terrain around him, which makes pedaling more difficult. Also, the various obstacles faced by the cyclist, such as fallen branches or large rocks on the road, pose challenges. Another feature would be the presence of wild animals and the scarceness of water around. The sight of wild animals can instill fear, and the lack of water is a constant threat. Also, an old man he met gave him unimportant and non - updated information, which added to his confusion. All of these would affect the cyclist because they wear and instill fear on his physical and mental strengths, making his journey an arduous one.

I think that there were many things contributing to the cyclist's state at the end of the story. First, there was the factor of time. He was cycling in June, which is very hot as it is the peak of summer. The sun beats down relentlessly. Second, he was cycling through California, a state that is warm even in early @DATE1. And third, he was traveling through the deserts, where the heat is intensified. So, when you put all of that together, he was cycling on a sweltering hot June day in the deserts of California. These three things all contributed to the character's state. He went through dead towns in his desperate search for water and found an old well pump with extremely hot water that tasted like battery acid. He drank too much water at the beginning, perhaps due to the initial shock of the heat, which left him with just spit toward the end. He was incredibly lucky to find a fish camp in the middle of nowhere and to have found water. The three factors made him drink too much water at first and barely left him with enough to sustain him throughout the journey. In the end, his survival was a close - call due to these challenging circumstances.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because in some ways they throw you off a little with other lines and then you will get confused about what they're actually talking about. For example, the littlest thing that could throw you off is the line when it says "before the last world war". That kind of threw me off a little. This confusion caused by the setting features can disrupt the cyclist's sense of the situation and make it harder for them to fully understand the context.

The setting that was affecting the cyclist was the lack of water he had. As the text clearly states, “the water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips”. Moreover, it also mentions “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing the spit to circulate”. He wouldn’t be trying to get his mind off of thirst if he wasn’t thirsty. This shows that the scarce water supply in the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist's well - being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it was June, a typically hot month, and the cyclist had little water. The cyclist became dehydrated as a result and couldn't find any building or water source for many miles. In this difficult situation, the cyclist took advice from old - timers who, unfortunately, didn't know what they were talking about. Their advice led the cyclist further astray. In conclusion, the hot weather and the remote location affected the cyclist, making his journey extremely challenging.

The cyclist pedaled through all types of different terrain, including steep hills, arid high desert, long flat roads, and dense woods. This cyclist took the advice of a bunch of old men who thought they knew a short cut to the Yosemite national park. However, this so - called short cut turned out to be a nightmare. The cyclist had only brought a limited number of water bottles and was quickly drinking them all due to the strenuous pedaling and the hot conditions. The setting of this story changed a lot, at times making the cyclist have to pedal faster to overcome obstacles and at other times forcing them to slow down. The cyclist was quickly worn out and started to lose hope in himself. The constantly changing terrain made it hard for him not to be thirsty. Eventually, he drank all of his water and knew he would die of dehydration or a heat stroke. As he came up over a long hill, he saw a bait store and stopped inside to have a drink. He then vowed not to listen to a bunch of old guys again, having learned a hard lesson from this experience.

The features of the setting make him happy because he meets some people that tell him of a route that will take a lot of time off his trip. This is evident from what the text says, “what I shouldn’t have done was let them have a peck at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice and launched out at first light along a ‘shortcut’ that was to slice away hours from my ride.” At first, the promise of a quicker journey made him excited. He also talks about not taking directions from old timers later on. As the text implies, he realizes that relying on the advice of these old timers might not be a good idea. This shows that while the initial discovery of the shortcut made him happy, the experience also taught him a valuable lesson.

During the cyclist's journey to Yosemite, many unforeseen things got in his way and significantly slowed him down. For instance, he naively listened to a group of old men who gave him wrong directions to his intended destination. Also, his water supply was steadily getting low, which drained his energy a lot quicker than usual. The blistering heat also played a crucial part in his energy loss. The intense heat made him sweat profusely, causing the water in his body to evaporate rapidly and be of little use. All these factors combined made his journey to Yosemite an extremely arduous one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many detrimental ways. For example, he found himself in the California desert in June, a time when the sun beats down relentlessly. The searing heat and lack of water can cause people to become severely dehydrated, pass out, or even die. There are very few reliable sources of water in the deserts, leaving the cyclist constantly at risk. The terrain didn't help him much either. The numerous hills required him to use a lot of energy and made him perspire heavily, causing him to lose vital fluids from his body. In conclusion, the cyclist was greatly affected by the harsh features of the desert setting.

The rider in the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie has a very analytical mind, which is easily influenced by the things around him. At first, the rider “rode into the morning...with a smile” because of the bright sun shining down, and the refreshing sight of the “cool pines” and “rushing rivers”. He was very confident in the directions given by the old men. The first sign of disappointment came when he came across the “ramshackle shed”. The dilapidated sight of this shed was deeply troubling to him, but he mustered the determination to ride on. As he rode over the “crippling hills”, he started to think that maybe this journey wasn't such a great idea after all. Finally, he came to an old bait shop. The “modern bathroom” that he entered to drink from provided him much - needed relief from the harsh desert he had just been riding through, showing how the environment constantly affected his state of mind.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. The landscape was extremely hard to ride on, with uneven terrain and rocky patches. There was intense heat that seemed to sap his strength away, and there was little water available along the way. As a result, it turned out to be a long and arduous trip, and he faced a difficult time reaching his destination. In the end, the unforgiving setting truly tested his endurance and resolve.

At first, the trip was easy - going and the path was flat. It was a pleasant day out, with the sun shining brightly. However, as he rode on, his water supply was gradually draining. Soon, the path transformed into a series of hills and became rough and bumpy. Even though the tall pines provided some shade, it wasn't enough to alleviate the cyclist's discomfort. Eventually, after enduring a grueling climb and a long cycle trip through the dense woods, he finally reached a somewhat civilized area. His perseverance through the challenging journey was finally rewarded with the sight of civilization.

The essay on "Rough Road Ahead" is about the real and present dangers of excessive speed and aggressive behavior. It's simply a friendly reminder to follow the given instructions carefully and pay close attention to all the signs along the way. You should always keep a sharp eye out for any signs and other important details. By doing so, you can ensure a safer and more informed journey.

The setting that affected the cyclist was the water temperature, rolling hills, and the condition of the roads. Water was a crucial factor because he needed cool water to stay hydrated. After running out of water, he came across a shed with pumps. He started pumping the water, but unfortunately, it was hot. Despite his efforts to let it cool down, it didn't work, so he had to take it as it was. Rolling hills were another challenge for the cyclist. The road started off flat but then ended up with hills. Going uphill can strain the legs and make it much harder to keep riding. Another hardship was the road condition. It was smooth at first, but then it became rough and rocky. These were some of the challenges the cyclist had to overcome to continue his journey.

Setting depends on how you can go or move. The flat parts of the town and some of the hills actually helped the cyclist in certain ways. However, the steep up - hills were a real problem. When the cyclist saw the towns, he got a bad attitude. He was upset and mad because he didn't want to die, yet he thought he was going to. He said he would never trust old men anymore because they didn't seem to know what they were talking about. It makes one wonder how and why he trusted them in the first place. In the end, the setting and his interactions in it really tested his mental and physical strength.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many significant ways. For example, "I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This quote clearly shows that his surroundings were presenting him with difficulty and a real challenge for his travel. By specifically describing the hills as "rolling", it vividly helps the reader imagine the obstacles he was going through. Also, the sign that read, "Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit." gives the reader a strong feeling that the character is in danger. This sign serves as a clear warning of the potential hazards ahead. Lastly, an example of the setting that helps show the character's hardships is, "no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind." If anything were to happen to the character, as the author was foreshadowing, he'd be stranded and all alone to face the consequences. He'd be in serious trouble and there would be no one around to offer help. If the author did not use these well - chosen examples, the reader would not easily get a clear picture of the troubles he had to overcome. In conclusion, these examples added great emphasis and deeper meaning to the text, making the cyclist's journey more relatable and impactful.

Well, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in a lot of ways. When his water was too hot to drink, he got some pebbles and stuck them in his mouth. He had heard somewhere that if you do that, it will dilute your spit and make you feel a bit less thirsty. The terrain of the story was very rocky and hilly. The rocky parts made it difficult for the bike to move smoothly, and the hills required a lot of physical effort to climb. These are the key features of the terrain that presented challenges to the cyclist during his ride.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist as he makes his way through the challenging terrain. The hills, with their steep inclines, pose a great difficulty for him to ride. When he reaches the town, he is desperately hoping to find a source of water and take a well - deserved break. However, upon arrival, he discovers that the town is completely deserted, with no one to offer help or a place to rest. The highway is another obstacle; its rough surface and lack of proper cycling lanes make it hard for him to maintain a steady pace. Moreover, there is no sign of water anywhere around him. All these features of the setting combine to make his journey extremely arduous, leaving him feeling exhausted and discouraged.

The features of the setting gradually contribute to the cyclist's growing anger. At the start of the story, as the cyclist pedals along, he unexpectedly comes across poisonous snakes slithering in the grass. The sight of these dangerous creatures sends a shiver down his spine. He also notices "one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule." All these dismal sights trouble the narrator deeply, and he begins to feel frightened and neurotic. As he continues cycling, his water supply starts to deplete rapidly. When he stops to restock, he is disappointed to find that "the water wouldn't cool down" and "it had the flavor of battery acid." This lack of proper water frustrates him to no end. To make matters worse, the hills he encounters become increasingly steeper, adding to his annoyance. The final straw comes when the cyclist passes by what he initially thought "had been a Welch's Grape Juice Factory." In an outrage, the narrator rants about how he hopes to die out on the road, simply to spare himself from the dreaded features of the unforgiving setting.

The features in the setting most definitely affect the cyclist as he travels on his long and arduous journey. The cyclist is incredibly thirsty, his throat parched, and extremely tired, with his legs feeling like lead. The setting he is placed in offers him no hope of survival. At first, this encounter with isolation in such a desolate place doesn't have a huge impact on him as it is the first place he comes across. However, as the story progresses, the rest of the setting mimics this desolation. As he moves forward, he is met with barren land as far as the eye can see, with no sign of water and no people in sight. It's June in California, and the scorching sun beats down on him. The cyclist fears that he will soon suffer from heat - stroke if he doesn't find water quickly. It only adds to his despair when he comes to an abandoned juice factory, which stands there like a cruel taunt, reminding him of the one thing he desperately needs to survive. All in all, the features in the setting make the cyclist lose hope, and he feels that he will surely die if he doesn't find water soon.

The setting in the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" is based in the hot and dry terrain of California. This particular setting has a significant impact on the character's mood. The features of the setting that affect the cyclist depend greatly on where they are located. In this story, the cyclist is surrounded by a desolate landscape. I think the features of the desolate setting on that long - distance cycling journey affect the cyclist in many ways. I would think even riding a bike for an extended period can be quite uncomfortable for the behind due to the constant pressure. At first, he was extremely mad because he took advice from old men who never left their porch. Their limited perspective led him into this difficult situation. The features of the setting affect the cyclist, in the story Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit, in many ways. The features of the harsh setting affected the cyclist greatly. It made him become severely dehydrated. The setting in this story greatly affects the cyclist. It is extremely hot in California at present while the narrator is aiding his ride. Joe Kurmaskie had a rough time trying to get to Yosemite National Park. First, he received directions from an old man. Because he was told to make it right, he decided to go at night. He was eager to achieve his goal because he was trying to cover a long distance. Each time the author comes to a point where the setting isn't very appealing or helpful, he loses hope for reaching his destination or finding a nice place to rest and get some fresh water. Lots of features in the setting play an effect on the cyclist. Some that @MONTH1 play an effect are the intense heat, which makes the air feel like a furnace and saps the cyclist's energy. This essay is an American tale that expresses how hard it is to do something. But one can achieve it through determination. The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist. First of all, he is travelling through a desert in California in June, so the weather is extremely hot. However, as he is running out of the water he brought along with himself, he cannot find any other water source by himself. Thus, he is thirsty and almost dehydrated. When the cyclist decides to conserve some of his water and go to the next town to get more water, there is another setback. The condition of the road is so poor, full of potholes and uneven surfaces, that the cyclist cannot go more than 12 mph. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. At first, it was a bright shiny day and the cyclist was happy, enjoying the gentle breeze and the clear sky. The once bright shiny day began to beat the searing heat down on the cyclist, making him sweat profusely. But just over the hill was a fishing shop. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, when it says, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” The features of this setting, with the refreshing pines and the lively rivers, are making the cyclist determined. The features of the setting, with the unexpected obstacles like tumbleweeds and the menacing snake, are making him brave and courageous. He has to face these challenges head - on. The last example is when it says, “I hung my head.” The features of the setting, perhaps a desolate and unforgiving stretch of land, are making the cyclist have despair. In conclusion, the various features of the setting can have a wide range of impacts on the cyclist's emotions and mindset.

In the essay “Rough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is affected both positively and negatively by the setting. Setting is the surrounding in which the story takes place. In the story, a cyclist loses his way and is put into danger because of it. The setting of the story can be described as mountainous with many rolling hills. The author describes the setting by saying “@CAPS1 two miles into the next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing.” The change in terrain, with steeper slopes and uneven ground, made it more difficult for the cyclist to pedal. However, he also used the land to give him hope that he was almost there. He told himself that he’d make it if he made it over the next hill. The setting of the story gave the cyclist hope and problems in his journey to survive, making his adventure a complex and challenging one.

The cyclist was affected by the fact that he took advice from some old men whose information was not accurate. These old men seemed confident as they shared the so - called shortcut, but it was far from the truth. Then he cycled along the desert which was extremely hot, with the scorching sun beating down on him all the time. He had a limited supply of water and that also affected him in a very bad way. As the water dwindled, his throat became parched, and his energy levels dropped rapidly. He almost had a heat stroke a few times. He was probably angry that he took these men’s advice and got himself into this difficult situation. Then when he found the fish camp, he was overjoyed with relief. But at the same time, if he had asked someone else for directions, he would not have been in this situation in the first place. So it’s really confusing because he probably felt relieved and mad at the same time. And then the other old man asked him did he know the best way there. He was right to say yes because if he didn’t, the old man would have given him some more messed - up directions and he would have been out there again, about to have another heat stroke, which could have been life - threatening.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist by the exhilarating rush he/she got when speeding down the hill. There are no boundaries, when you can go where you like, when you like. No people to get in the way of you and your need for speed. This sense of freedom and pure thrill that the setting provides truly makes the cycling experience unforgettable.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” it is shown that the features of the setting do affect the cyclist through the story. In the story the cyclist is faced with the mental and physical journey he takes while riding his bike. Being unaware of where he is on his journey, the setting begins to really affect him. For example, as he keeps making his journey, he is affected by the old towns and desert places. These old towns have a desolate and abandoned look, with crumbling buildings and empty streets. The sun beats down relentlessly, making the air feel like an oven. For example, he says, “I got down my hands and knew working the hands of the rusted water pump with all my strength.” The quote shows that because he is biking so long and is looking for water and there is not a town in sight, he becomes weak. “@CAPS1 directions, June, lack of water” all are elements that affect the rider on his ride. He took directions from older people who promised the rider a shortcut. These older people seemed well - intentioned, but it turned out that their shortcut was wrong. When the rider went on this trip, it was June in California. He could have died if he didn’t find the other water source. These were some elements that affected the rider on his trip, making it a perilous and difficult journey.

The feature of the setting greatly affect the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The features in the story changed the speaker’s mood throughout his journey. The town had an eerie silence, with broken windows and overgrown weeds, so he was cautious, constantly on the lookout for any potential danger. Next, he came across a fork in the road. Finally, his determination changed to relief where he reached Gary and Wilber’s fish camp. The sight of the camp, with its friendly faces and a promise of rest, was a welcome sight. In conclusion, the setting in the story greatly affects the cyclist by changing his moods and attitude towards his journey, making it a roller - coaster of emotions from start to finish.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed Limit,” it tells the tale of a man who follows some ill - advised directions. As he pedals on, he finds himself in the middle of a vast, desolate desert, completely stuck without a drop of water. He starts to lose confidence in the directions once the setting undergoes a change. He recalled, “After forty miles of hard pedaling, I arrived at the first town. It fit the traditional definition of a ghost town perfectly.” He had been led to believe this was a bustling, thriving town, but all he was left with was an empty expanse. This was a huge letdown, and the cyclist began to doubt that this had been the right choice. He keeps on pushing himself, riding forward, only to find another disheartening sight. “One rickety ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps that looked like they hadn't worked in ages, and a corral that wouldn't even hold in the tamest of mules greeted me.” @CAPS1 was another place said to be good, but all he got was water that tasted like battery acid. On the last stretch of his bike journey, he was met with rough, rolling hills that seemed to go on forever, a diamondback - looking snake slithering menacingly nearby, and an abandoned juice factory that added to the eerie atmosphere. All of these experiences brought his spirits lower and lower until he felt as if he was on the verge of death. Eventually, the cyclist ended up finding a store, but he was deeply discouraged by the harsh environment he was in. It was swelteringly hot, and he realized he could have easily died out there.

In the essay, the cyclist is significantly and visibly affected by the features of the setting. Under the harsh conditions he faced, he could barely manage to survive and make it to his destination. It becomes abundantly clear that the features of the setting are having an impact on him when he states, “The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water - depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can be so cruel.” In his arduous efforts to keep going, he is slowly getting weaker. The sign he sees only serves to make him feel worse because it seems to him as if it is mocking his slow progress. He also remarks, “I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you had left to circulate. With any luck, I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat.” This statement shows that he is on the verge of giving up completely and wouldn't really care if he died. From the author's despairing tone, it is evident that the features of the setting do indeed have a profound effect on the cyclist, sapping his will and energy.

Features of the setting such as the scorching hot sun, the lack of potable water, and “Gary and Wilber’s Fish Camp,” greatly affected the cyclist. Since the cyclist was traveling through the high deserts of California in the blistering month of June, the temperature soared to extremely high levels. Also, the fact that the only water around felt “somewhere in the neighborhood of two - hundred degrees” and “had the flavor of battery acid” was a major problem. This prevented the cyclist from drinking it and put him in a severe “dehydrated state.” @CAPS1, “Gary and Wilber’s Fish Camp” affected the cyclist in a positive way by solving his problem of dehydration. Upon his arrival, there was cold, refreshing water available for him, which was a much - needed relief after his long, arduous journey through the harsh desert.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. First of all, if the cyclist hadn't listened to the old man's advice, he would have never found himself in this troublesome situation. The features of the setting have a significant effect on the cyclist. The setting makes him feel extremely thirsty, his throat dry as a bone, unbearably hot, and completely lost. In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the cyclist is significantly affected by the setting in numerous ways. The cyclist had to deal with some tough terrain throughout his long - distance ride. First, he was in the “high deserts of California in June”. Snake, searing heat, and steep hills – all are what the biker had to deal with because of the specific settings. In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the harsh and unforgiving setting had a major impact on the character. The cyclist is beginning at what seems a fine idea and place, with the sun shining and the road ahead looking promising. Cycling is a very good sport that offers numerous health benefits. People who regularly engage in cycling are generally in good physical shape. Their bodies are toned, and they have strong calf muscles due to the continuous pedaling motion. The repetitive movement of the legs during cycling helps to build strength and endurance in the calves. However, I think it's also dangerous as well. Cyclists are exposed to various risks on the road, such as traffic accidents, uneven surfaces that can cause them to lose balance, and bad weather conditions. Despite the risks, with proper safety measures like wearing helmets and following traffic rules, cycling can still be an enjoyable and beneficial activity. In conclusion, while cycling has its advantages in terms of fitness, one must also be aware of the potential dangers.

In the story, the author says, “The sun was beginning to beat down, and I was struggling to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This gives you a vivid idea that the intense heat is getting to him and is steadily depleting his water supply. As the sun's rays bore down on him, his body was losing water rapidly through sweating. At one point, he almost gives himself up to despair and succumbs to the threat of dying of dehydration. It seems that he will never reach his goal and he will continue to suffer in the grueling heat that shows no sign of relenting. I could almost feel the sweat trickling down my back and the overwhelming heat that the cyclist was feeling. Also, I could almost feel the lump in my throat when he says, “with any luck Iíd hit a bump and lodge a pebble in my throat,” expressing his extreme desperation. The heat definitely affects this man's cycling in a bad way. He was completely exhausted and could not go on without water. In conclusion, the heat acts as a major obstacle, severely hampering the cyclist's ability to complete his journey.
The cyclist found the journey incredibly hard. Moreover, he was extremely upset that the old - timers provided such bad directions, which made his already tough ride even more difficult.

The setting affects the cyclist in many ways. First, he couldn't get water from anywhere because he was in a vast desert with nothing but ramshackle sheds and rusty, dilapidated camps. Second, there were short, uneven rolling hills, and the rough, unpaved roads made it arduous to ride on. There were tumbleweeds constantly getting in his way and large, venomous snakes lurking around. The intense heat made it extremely hard to keep riding. And there were no buildings, structures, or people around to give him a lift or offer him water. That is how the setting affects the cyclist.

In this essay by Joe Kurmaskie, a young man is lured into accepting outdated information by a group of old men. He pays a heavy price later when, on his bicycle, he is almost killed by heatstroke or dehydration. The setting is an excellent way to portray his feelings of hopelessness, despair, and fatigue. While he is just starting out, the road is flat and smooth, making the ride easy. It is cool and pleasantly breezy. When he begins to run out of water, the terrain becomes bumpier and much harder to navigate. He sees empty, barren plains, cracked, parched dry ground, and the scorching hot sun. He begins to despair even more. After a while when he thinks he can go no more, he sees a shabby store that once held gallons of grape juice. He laughs at the cruel irony. The setting does do a wonderful job of describing his sense of helplessness.

In this passage, the cyclist was affected by the setting because if it had been anywhere else, he would not have suffered or learned at all. Because the setting had both a lack of civilization and the water that he desperately needed, it caused him to almost faint from thirst. This is an example of the setting affecting the cyclist, “With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill.” This shows that had the setting been a paradise, he would never have learned anything.

The features of the setting in the essay caused the cyclist to suffer and yet continue being determined. The essay also says “short, bumpy rolling hills”, “tumbleweeds constantly blowing across” and “long, energy - sapping crippling hill” to describe the difficult terrain the cyclist faced that caused him to be extremely tired and ride at a slower pace. Finally, the cyclist is faced with a “rediculously large, menacing snake” and plants and weeds which keep getting in his way and force him to slow down.

The setting affects the cyclist very much, especially in the very dry climates. In such dry conditions, the cyclist faces challenges like rapid dehydration and increased fatigue. The lack of moisture in the air makes it difficult for the cyclist to maintain normal body functions, and the intense dryness can also cause discomfort in the eyes, nose, and throat. Overall, the dry climate significantly impacts the cyclist's physical state and the ease of the journey.

The setting in the story "Rough road ahead" plays a great role in the character's journey. Gary and Wilber Fish Camp.” The cyclist rushed to the bathroom to drink the refreshing water from the sink. A sense of pride and accomplishment overwhelms her as she realizes she has overcome the arduous journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it gives him the feeling of hopelessness. The cyclist depicted in the essay is greatly affected by his surroundings. First, he vividly described a blazing, beating sun and tall pines and rushing rivers. The environment affected the cyclist violently in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” It seems that all of the harsh conditions of cycling in California, such as the scorching heat and long, arduous miles, had worn down this kid who took some faulty directions from older people at one stop. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen.” This clearly explains how simply exhausted he had become due to the miles of cycling, the beating down sun, and the total lack of water due to the absence of all towns. As the cyclist makes his journey towards Yosemite, the setting causes him much worry and concern. In the beginning, the narrator is content and excited. However, as he continues down the long, winding road, his environment makes him doubt their judgement. The first town he comes to is entirely deserted. Though at first he tries to laugh it off, he later realizes just how much trouble he is in if he doesn't come to a civilization soon. The cyclist runs across “ramshackle shed[s]” and shut - down factories, and as his water supply sinks lower, the road seems to taunt him. He passes a water pump (just what he needs), yet the water is something close to toxic. A road sign reminds him not to go too fast, though he might (@MONTH1) die if he doesn't pick up the pace. He is forced to look at a picture of a happy boy guzzling grape juice as he dehydrates. All these features of the setting, in addition to the overpowering heat and the blazing sun, drive the narrator to the breaking point, making his journey a true test of endurance.

The feature of setting affects the cyclist because every thing that was happening years ago is happening now in today's world, meaning wars, rights, and so on. When riding a bike, it may not seem too hard at first glance. However, for a cyclist, everything becomes more serious. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous different ways. The fact that he was in the vast California desert and the intense heat took a toll on him. Two of the biggest settings in this story are the vast desert and the rolling hills. This would affect the rider because of the dehydration that he would inevitably experience. In the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist experiences severe dehydration on his journey. The setting will either affect the cyclist in a good way or a bad way. In the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, it affects the cyclist in both a bad way and a good way. This shows that the heat made the water warm, so it did not cool him down and was almost undrinkable. But a good way it affects him is through the pebbles. “I read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to moisten your mouth.” This shows that even though he has no water, the pebbles can make him feel less thirsty. In this story, it is clear just how difficult the cyclist's journey is. Early in the crisp morning, the cyclist is brimming with eagerness and fully ready to face the adventurous path that had been mapped out by the older, more experienced travelers. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the cyclist experienced a few life - threatening times during his adventure. Certain features of the setting affected the cyclist. The conditions that the bicyclist faced that affected his trip were a various amount of things that could really mess up your ride. Some of the conditions were the intense heat. The loose gravel makes it tough to maneuver the bicycle smoothly, and you have to constantly watch your speed to avoid slipping. So, he's not going anywhere in a hurry. Running out of water can mean dehydration, which leads to poor judgment and even the risk of heat stroke or exhaustion. Another bad thing is that he was in the middle of nowhere. It's not like he could simply stop somewhere and ask for a drink. There was nothing around for miles, leaving him in a desperate situation. These things clearly show how rough the road was made because these difficult conditions existed.

The setting was very hot, dry, and was a vast desert. The scorching sun beat down relentlessly. This setting affected him as it was making him very dehydrated and extremely hot. The setting affected the cyclist because they were in California in June, a time when the heat can be quite intense. The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. There were steep hills and large rocks, venomous snakes, and not a single building or person in sight. The main features of the setting that affected the cyclist are the fact that it was June, a typically hot month, and the intense desert heat. “ … I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June … ” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist in this story. In this assignment, I will explain how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. The setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” adds significant drama into the story by how it affects the cyclist. In the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the desolate setting affected the cyclist in a harsh way. In the story, "Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist. The setting of a story encompasses the background, the place, and the time when the story took place. In this story, a determined cyclist needs to reach @CAPS1 Park. Along the way, he stops and has a conversation with a group of old men. These men, perhaps a bit out of touch with modern mapping, give him directions. He follows their advice but soon realizes the consequences. “At some point, tumbleweeds lazily crossed my path, and a ridiculously large snake – it really did look like a diamondback – blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I carefully and nervously eased past it.” The desolate desert setting, with its lack of water sources, the presence of dangerous wildlife like the snake, and the confusing directions from the old men all contribute to the cyclist's difficult journey. The setting not only presents physical challenges but also adds to the cyclist's mental stress as he tries to navigate his way to his destination.

The cyclist chose the worst possible time to embark on his ride. It was an “early summer evening” in California. At this time of the day and in this location, the sun beats down mercilessly, making the heat almost unbearable. With little water in his supply and being lost in an unfamiliar area, it was far from the best choice he could have made. Before setting out on a long - distance cycling trip, a cyclist should be well - prepared for the weather conditions. This includes checking the weather forecast, bringing an adequate supply of water, and wearing appropriate clothing. Additionally, they should carefully check a map of the place before going anywhere to avoid getting lost. By not taking these precautions, the cyclist has put himself in a difficult and potentially dangerous situation. In conclusion, proper preparation is key for any cyclist to have a safe and enjoyable journey.

The cyclist ran into a diamond - headed snake. He was out of water and stuck in the middle of nowhere. The features of this particular setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. The setting of this story takes place with a man biking and then taking advice from old - timers to a faster route. The biker knew from the start that he should not have given away his map. The setting had a substantial impact on the cyclist. The terrain was bumpy and riddled with a lot of hills, which meant that he had to exert far more physical effort to keep moving forward. In the story, after the cyclist had been riding for a long time, it says “I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state” (kurmaskie @NUM1). This clearly shows the dire situation he was in. With very little water for his long trip, he was constantly at risk of further dehydration and physical collapse. The combination of the difficult terrain and the heat - induced dehydration made his cycling journey an extremely challenging and potentially life - threatening endeavor.

The way the features of the setting affect the cyclist I think is disregardment. First of all, a reason would be because at the beginning of the story when the warning sign is passed, the cyclist disregards it by going down the hill anyways, showing a lack of concern for the potential risks. Also, it states that “I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” This indicates that the cyclist was overconfident and not taking the setting's features seriously. Overall, the cyclist's disregard of the setting's warnings and overconfidence likely set the stage for potential issues later in the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he went through many ups and downs. At one point, he flowed by blackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. The intense heat was unbearable, and the weather wouldn't cool down. This extreme heat and the challenging terrain took a toll on the cyclist, making his journey even more difficult. In the end, the harsh setting clearly had a significant impact on the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they caused him to need water. He was worn out because the setting was so intense. “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This quote from the text shows that the cyclist's terrain was changing and these changes affected him. The hilly terrain required more effort to pedal, which made him sweat and increased his need for water. As a result, the features of the setting made the cyclist's ride more physically demanding.

The features of the surrounding landscape affect the cyclist both physically and mentally. First, the sun constantly beating down on the cyclist causes his or her body to sweat more, which makes one's body use more energy. The sun rays also add to the heat the cyclist feels, making the ride even more uncomfortable. Also, the rough road forces the cyclist to pedal very hard, which drains him or her of even more energy. For example, when the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” reached the rough roads, he had to pedal harder, which made him sweat more, and caused his amount of energy to decrease. Finally, the lack of civilization can make a cyclist feel hopeless, which is how the cyclist in the essay felt when he had no water or could see no nearby town. This can affect the cyclist's will to keep pedaling, and if they have no determination, the cyclist will not go anywhere. In conclusion, the features of the setting can physically exhaust and mentally strain the cyclist, which makes it harder for him or her to keep going on the journey.

Snake, heat, hills - all are what the biker had to deal with because of certain settings. He had to deal with a diamondback snake, which posed a real danger to his safety. He was going through the desert so it was like @NUM1 degrees, an extremely high temperature that sapped his energy. While he was biking, he had to go up crippling hills, which required a great deal of physical effort. All these challenges made his bike ride extremely difficult. In the end, the harsh settings presented multiple obstacles that the biker had to overcome.

The setting acts as a catalyst in this story. It is the aspect of the story that is constantly challenging the character right until the very end. In the story, it states, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This clearly shows that the terrain is opposing him, making his journey more arduous. Also, in the story, it says, “The speed limit was 55. I was doing a water - depleted 12 mph. Sometimes life can be so cool.” This not only shows how much the elements are overpowering him but also reveals his resilience and how satirical life can be. The ultimate irony in this story is when he stumbles across the Welch's grape juice factory and there was a picture of a boy “pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth.” No matter where the cyclist goes, he is always trying to overcome the elements, and the setting continues to test his mettle throughout the story.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many significant ways. For example, the lack of water begins to take a heavy toll on how fast he can reach the next town. As he pedals on, his body craves for water, and his energy levels start to decline. Another example would be the terrain, which is uneven and full of obstacles, only slowing him down more. The combination of these factors makes the cyclist's journey extremely challenging, and it is evident that the setting has a major impact on his ability to progress smoothly.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him use up the last of his water because it's swelteringly hot, and then there's no one around because he's out in the deserts of California. “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage…” (@NUM1.). This excerpt from the text strongly supports my previous statement about how it's hot because the speaker tells us how he's sweating profusely and that he might be seeing a mirage, which is a clear sign of the extreme heat. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or any structure of any kind” (@NUM2.). This shows that there is no one around to help him if he falls down from a heat stroke or anything like that. So, the setting is severely affecting the cyclist's endurance, putting his life at risk in this desolate environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making it much more difficult to ride. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This sudden change in terrain requires the cyclist to exert more energy. “I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” The intense heat makes the ride unbearable. “A large highway sign jumped out at me.” The sign might have added to his stress. “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed limit.” The rough road further hampers his progress. “Sometimes life can feel so cruel.” The cyclist's frustration is palpable. The fact that it was such a hot day made the ride seem even longer. When out of water, you feel extremely exhausted. You will do just about anything to try to withstand the heat, but the setting continues to make the cyclist's journey a struggle.

Author Joe Kurmaskie learns the dangers of a lifeless wilderness during his experience described in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” As a cyclist riding in one of the most undeveloped areas in California, the lack of water found in this setting proves extremely crippling to his survival. The trails he was directed to had no towns or sources of fresh, drinkable water for days. The combination of constant exercise while riding through the rugged terrain, lack of water and resources, the scorching California summer weather, and the lack of civilization drains the author's energy and causes him to suffer from dehydration. Too much exposure to these harsh conditions could have easily killed him. The modern time - period and year also caused the directions the author was given to be inaccurate, and, thus, causing the cyclist to find himself in such a dangerous area of the country. The setting of “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” places the cyclist in a life - threatening situation, highlighting the perils of venturing into such unforgiving landscapes without proper preparation.

The features of a setting could encompass a wide range of different elements. It could be snowing and extremely cold, with the snowflakes gently falling and blanketing the ground, or raining and of course wet, with the raindrops pelting down steadily. It might be hot and dry, with the scorching sun beating down relentlessly, or breezy and humid, where the gentle breeze carries a hint of moisture. The features could be a busy thoroughfare filled with cars and people bustling about or a solitary country road that winds through peaceful landscapes. There could be rough terrain with uneven ground and rocks, or long straight - aways that seem to stretch into the horizon. The setting of a place exerts pressure on the reality of what will happen to a cyclist. In the essay, a young cyclist takes advice from some elderly man and ends up riding through the searing hot sun and desolate ghost towns, not knowing if he would survive. The intense heat had him feeling as though death were creeping closer with every pedal stroke, and the overwhelming thirst had him becoming more determined to reach the next town so he could stay alive. If the features of the setting had been different, say he was riding on a flat road in a busy town with a pleasant breeze and places to stop for water everywhere, he would not have feared for his life. The features of the setting significantly affect how the cyclist feels and thinks.
