He can feel angry due to the difficult conditions, happy when he encounters a favorable stretch, sad because of the desolation, or scared of the unknown. He can even start to think about his own death. These, I believe, are some of the effects settings have on cyclists, clearly demonstrating the powerful influence of the environment on a cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, when the author says “flat roads were replaced by short rolling hills”, this change in terrain made the author have to ride more safely. The unevenness of the hills required him to adjust his speed and balance carefully to avoid any mishaps. Also, when he says, “the ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement”, it presented a real obstacle. The author had to slow down on his bike, carefully assess the situation, and find a safe way around it so he could get past without disturbing the snake or getting into danger. Finally, when the author says “no one in sight, no building, car, or structure”, he is affected because he is lost and thirsty. Without any people or facilities around, he can't ask questions or find a place to get water. The setting makes it hard for the author to maneuver and get to where he wants to go, highlighting how the environment can pose significant challenges to a cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the person who rode the bike was very tired. After riding on his bike for @NUM1 miles, his legs were aching and his body was in desperate need of a rest. Every pedal stroke was a struggle as his muscles were fatigued from the long - distance ride. Also, it affected the cyclist because of all the riding he had to do, struggling to get where he was trying to get. The terrain might have been hilly or the wind might have been against him, making the journey even more arduous. But he was a strong man and he was willing to finish his forty miles of pedaling. Despite being restless and uncomfortable, he persevered. In the end, his determination allowed him to overcome the challenges posed by the setting, showing that while the environment can be tough on a cyclist, a strong will can make a difference.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” because it goes through many different terrains. The cyclist starts at a town, a place full of life and activity, and he is working his way to Yosemite when he decides to listen to a group of old men. He starts out strong, with a spring in his step and a sense of excitement for the journey ahead. However, when he gets to the first town, which is totally abandoned, the silence and desolation start to set in. The empty streets and dilapidated buildings give an eerie feeling. He keeps going to another abandoned town, and the sense of isolation grows. He decides to keep going until he sees a sign. The terrain is a lot different now, with rolling hills that make pedaling more difficult and tumbleweed rolling by, adding to the desolate atmosphere. And then there's a snake on the road, which makes him stop and be cautious. Through listening to the old men, the cyclist almost died from the threatening heat and lack of water. The setting affected the cyclist even more seriously than he could have imagined, clearly showing how the environment can turn a journey into a life - threatening ordeal.

In the story, the setting greatly affects the attitude of the cyclist. When he starts out, it is an early summer evening, and the warm glow of the setting sun creates a peaceful atmosphere. He is serene while he is talking to the old men, enjoying the friendly conversation. He starts cycling the next morning, and as he pedals along, he is thinking of Yosemite, his destination. He is relaxed and confident, looking forward to the adventure. However, his attitude about the day changes greatly when he comes across the rickety old shed, rusty pumps, and a corral at the park in the road. The dilapidated state of these structures makes him a little worried, but he is not discouraged yet. When the terrain changes from flat to hilly, he has to work harder to pedal, and he is a little discouraged. Then, when he comes across the abandoned factory, with its broken windows and overgrown weeds, he is most definitely a lot discouraged. A little later he comes across @PERSON1’s Fish camp. The sight of the camp, with its warm lights and friendly faces, makes him very relieved and thankful to the owners. The cyclist’s attitude changed depending upon whether the setting was very beneficial to him or not, clearly demonstrating the strong link between the environment and a cyclist's emotional state.

The features of the setting have a great impact on the desperate travels of the weary cyclist. The scenery he passes, which is sometimes disappointing and sometimes uplifting, affects him physically and emotionally. When he passes a portion of the road with nothing but a “ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral…”, he becomes disturbed. The cyclist is running low on water, and he becomes even more distraught at a road with a speed limit posted as 55 mph when he was, “doing a water - deleting @NUM1.” The intense heat of the hot, June sun beating down on him affects the cyclist and puts him in a state of dehydration. In an, “ironic twist”, the cyclist is affected emotionally when he passes a @ORGANIZATION1 factory that has been abandoned. The factory features a picture of a boy pouring a glass of juice into his mouth, which upsets the already thirsty cyclist. This combination of the harsh setting elements continues to make his journey a difficult and distressing one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist more than anything in the reading of “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted speeding Limit.” In the beginning, when the cyclist had just begun his cycling journey, he uses a positive tone to describe the setting. For example, in paragraph four he says “the cool pines and running rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” When he says this, the reader can vividly imagine someone in an excited state, eagerly looking forward to reaching his destination on a dry day. As the cyclist's attitude becomes lower, the reader can make the connection that it is because of the setting. In paragraph thirteen, when the cyclist says, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage and that not to get too excited”, the reader can clearly sense that it is getting quite serious for the cyclist to continue as is. Overall, as the setting changes to a “burning sun” and extremely hot conditions, with a shortage of water, the cyclist becomes more sarcastic and less upbeat. For example, when talking about the rocks in his mouth, he states “with only luck I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat.” This clearly shows a bad mood affected by the features of the setting, highlighting the strong influence of the environment on the cyclist's state of mind.

The rougher the road gets for him, the more determination he has at the beginning. However, towards the end, he had the mindset that, “it didn't matter, it was going to die.” This negative thought took a toll on him, and it was extremely hard for him to go on. He then realized that he didn't want to die that way, so he summoned the remaining strength within him and kept on going. Eventually, his perseverance led him to civilization. His journey shows that even in the face of extreme adversity, the will to survive and the decision to keep pushing forward can lead to a better outcome.

The features of the setting affect the biker a lot because the rough terrain is described, which implies that the biker probably had a hard time. Half - way through the story, he said, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” He said this to specifically describe the difficulty in this race. The change in terrain not only makes the biker work harder but also makes the race seem exciting because it changes things around. It wouldn't be exciting if they simply said that flat roads turned into even flatter roads, or if they didn't show the terrain change at all. The dynamic nature of the setting adds an element of challenge and thrill to the biker's experience, making the race more memorable and engaging.

“Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.”, an essay written by Joe Kurmaskie, is about a solo cyclist going on a journey to Yosemite National Park. He listens to a group of old guys and unfortunately ends up lost on a rough road. He has no water or a reliable supply, and the flat road he was on was replaced by short rolling hills. Large highways loomed ahead, and a sign jumped out at him. It read: “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT.” The rough road forced the cyclist to work harder, made him want more water, and just made things tougher than what they already were. This difficult situation on the road continued to test his endurance and resolve throughout his journey.

The settings of your environment always seem to have a notable impact on your mood. Take for instance the cyclist. In the beginning, he approached the journey with a positive and enthusiastic attitude. But once he arrived at the first town, his attitude started to decline steadily from there. He describes the town as perhaps having been a thriving spot at one point, “but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” Ghost towns typically come across as very old, run - down, and dull. This desolate sight affected the cyclist deeply because, since it was not as the old men had described, he began to feel doubtful. This doubt, in turn, did not give him the same motivation as when he had started the journey. Then, when he expected to find water and instead “a tar - like substance oozed out,” it made him nervous and angry because he was unsure if he would make it to his destination. However, his attitude changes as soon as he sees the store. The setting becomes more positive, and so does his mood. So, clearly, the setting does have a significant effect on the cyclist's mood and attitude, highlighting the strong connection between one's surroundings and emotional state.

Many of the settings' features have a profound impact on the cyclist. One of the prominent features of the desert - like setting is the dry air and extremely hot temperatures. This intense heat made it extremely hard for the cyclist to keep going. In a moment of despair, the author says, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Another feature of the setting was the desolate towns that did not contain any water. This lack of water made his journey truly horrible as he struggled to continue on. The thirst was so excruciating that he had to put pebbles in his mouth. Sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what little spit you have left to circulate. Yet another feature of the setting that affected the cyclist was the abandoned Welch’s Grape factory. This factory gave the cyclist false hope because, in his thirst - stricken state, it would have been so wonderful to have some grape juice. The narrator called the factory an “Ironic twist.” Overall, these various features of the setting combined to make the cyclist's journey a challenging and arduous one.

The effects from the setting that have an impact on me are quite evident. While riding on the bike in hot weather with only a very small amount of water to drink, I would have given up if I had nothing left to drink. The water, having been exposed to the heat, was bound to be hot. In the text, it says “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” I don't think I could have lasted long if I was dehydrated. From the description, it seems that I would have dropped dead of heatstroke. The combination of the hot weather and limited water supply in the setting would have made the situation extremely difficult for me to endure, clearly demonstrating how the setting can have a detrimental effect on one's ability to continue an activity.

Many features of the setting have a significant impact on the cyclist. For instance, in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the lack of water in the dry desert had a long - lasting and profound effect on the cyclist. “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh.” This passage shows the reader how all the heat and the shortage of water have made the cyclist feel extremely hot and dehydrated, to the point that she could pass out at any second. She is also thinking beyond the immediate discomfort, as she is laughing at herself and trying to conserve every bit of energy she possibly can. As a result, the effect from the setting on the cyclist is that the lack of water has not only presented challenges but has also given her a sense of humor and the courage to keep going, determined to reach her final destination point. This shows how the setting can both test and strengthen a person's resolve.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The bumpy roads made his ride extremely uncomfortable, constantly jolting him as he pedaled. Sand kept getting into his eyes, causing irritation and making it difficult for him to see clearly. The thirst hit him hard, exacerbated by the too - hot and humid temperatures. Maybe he got so tired of pedaling that he had to get off the bike and walk for a while. When he got into town, a wild dog chased him, adding to his stress and fear. To make matters worse, he had no money to buy a drink. All these factors combined made the cyclist's journey a truly challenging one, clearly demonstrating how the setting can significantly impede a traveler's progress.

The cyclist of this story is greatly affected by the intense heat of his surroundings. While he is riding to @CAPS1, the scorching heat of the day began to steadily increase. The text reads “I had been hitting my water bottle regularly.” Due to the blistering heat of the day, the cyclist was down to his last bit of water, consuming large gulps of it at a time. He struggled to keep going under the oppressive heat.

When the cyclist vividly mentions how extremely hot, dry, and open the desolate terrain is, it makes me strongly feel like he is right in the heart of the desert. I also know that it’s swelteringly hot because he is profusely sweating and severely dehydrated, which clearly shows the harshness of the environment he is in.

At first the cyclist feels perfectly fine, though he gets a little bit discouraged now and then, but basically he’s in good spirits. “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them” (@CAPS1). He feels completely relaxed, because he is right at home with the clear water and the tall pine trees. They give him a strong sense of comfort and tranquility. He thinks that after the first “tree” not being that remarkable, the others will surely be better. He knows deep down that he has it in him to make it through, but he doesn’t know yet that he will have to travel a long, arduous way to get water. When he sees the sign, “It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT.” he knows that things are going to get tough, because “the speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water - depleting 12 mph”. At that point he starts to get really worried, because he is out there more isolated, and he realizes that he doesn’t have enough water. As he runs out of water, the landscape, and his surroundings, start to get drier and more barren. He states, “tumble weeds crossed my path.” The landscape seems to get more menacing too, “a ridiculously large snake.” The landscape changes in tandem with the state of his water supply, highlighting his precarious situation.

The setting affects the cyclist significantly because the blistering heat and the complete absence of humanity make him utterly crazy. If he was in a place like @LOCATION2, it would be just the heat issue because there are people everywhere in @LOCATION2, which would at least provide some sense of security. If he was in @LOCATION1 it would be the severe temperature drop along with no sign of humanity, and he would probably not be able to survive such harsh conditions.

The features of the setting that the cyclist runs into do have a notable impact on him. For example, when the setting changes from an abandoned town to an empty, deserted road that hasn't been used in thirty years, it gives the cyclist far less motivation to push himself to go on and even saps his remaining strength, making his journey even more difficult.

Joe Kurmaskieís “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” tells the tale of how a cyclist seeks directions from older men sitting on their porches. Unfortunately, these men don't correctly tell him the way to get to Yosemite. As a result, the cyclist ends up lost in the vast expanse with hardly any water left in his bottles. Features of the setting such as the unforgiving terrain and the blazing sun have a profound impact on the cyclist in the story. On that sweltering summer's day, the sun was extremely hot. Without water, it became even more difficult for him to keep moving forward as he was parched and overheated. @PERSON2 remarks, “The sun was beginning to beat down… I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The terrain was also bumpy and rough, making each pedal stroke a struggle. The combination of the sun and the terrain can greatly affect the cyclist when out on a hot summer day, testing his endurance and willpower.

The features of the setting taunt the cyclist with cruel irony. As the cyclist continues down his solitary path, he passes through a desolate ghost town, its empty buildings standing as silent witnesses to the past. Then, twenty miles up the road, he spots a ramshackle shed and some rusty water pumps. Desperate as he is running out of water, he attempts to get water out. With all his might, he works the handle of the pump, but all he can get is muck. What little liquid comes out is what he described as “water feeling two - hundred degrees, it had the flavor of battery acid.” Further down the road, there's a sign that clearly says rough road ahead, and it instructs to adhere to the posted speed limit of 55. Meanwhile, he's only going 12 mph, struggling against the harsh conditions. Even worse, he finds an abandoned juice factory on the way. At that point, he is completely out of water, left to face the arduous journey ahead with a parched throat and dwindling hope.

Do not Exceed posted speed limit. A valuable lesson is also to never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in the office. Twenty miles up the long and dusty road, I came to a confusing fork. Frustration welled up as I realized my predicament. I got down on my hands and knees, putting every ounce of my strength into working the handle of the rusted water pump. The water bottles I had were nearly empty, containing only a few total sips. The person I might have encountered on the way could have been a sad individual. Or perhaps he was just a bum loitering around in this desolate area. In such a situation, it's hard to tell who can be trusted and who might lead you further astray.

The features of the setting could definitely affect this cyclist. In this particular case, it does have a significant impact on the cyclist. According to the text, “Sometimes life can feel so cruel.” This is a fitting example because the cyclist was well - aware that this road was going to be rough. Despite knowing this, he was only able to go at a speed of 12 mph due to the challenging conditions. The rough terrain and other elements of the setting made it difficult for him to pick up speed. So, it's evident that the features of the setting did indeed affect the cyclist, making his journey a difficult and arduous one.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist very much in this trying situation. The scorching hot weather made him constantly have a dry mouth, which quickly led to a critical lack of water. With no immediate source of water in sight, he resorted to an unusual method. He used stones in his mouth and said, “Iíd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate.” He clung to this small piece of knowledge, using it as a survival technique to get through the ordeal. This shows how the harsh setting forced him to come up with creative ways to endure the lack of water and the oppressive heat.

The features affected the cyclist in many ways. One notable feature was the highway sign, "ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT." This sign served as a constant reminder of the challenging road conditions ahead. The terrain was now short, rolling hills, which would make it harder on the cyclist to pedal up the hills. Each ascent required a significant amount of effort and energy, as the cyclist had to battle against gravity. Also, there were roadblocks. At some point, tumbleweeds blocked the cyclist's path, and a ridiculously large snake slithered across the road. These roadblocks posed a danger to the biker, as he'd have to maneuver around them carefully. This not only caused him to lose time but also wasted precious energy, resulting in him drinking more water. No water is a great danger because it was June, a hot day, and he was at risk of getting dehydrated. There was also nobody around, so if he desperately needed water, he couldn't find any. In such a situation, the cyclist had to rely on his own resilience and determination to continue his journey.

After reading "Do not Exceed Posted Limit," I have seen how the scene of an area can affect your mood and attitude around things. In this story, the main character is a cyclist who takes the advice of a few old men sitting in a poseh. They tell him a bad shortcut, which leads him into unexpected difficulties. As he is riding, he comes across some hills. Those hills really affected him physically. He gets tired from pedaling up and down continually. "that mood" was replaced by short, moving hills. The cyclist could not gauge the terrain accurately and tried everything to keep going. The hills did not show how long he would have to continue going up and down. There at one point, he says, "@CAPS1 can feel so cruel." There, he is upset because a road sign came up through the tough roads and told him not to exceed 55 miles per hour when he was only going 12 miles per hour. This can be viewed as metaphorical also. When you take a shortcut in life, there are always consequences. For example, if you decide to drop out of high school and go on with your journey, there is always the possibility of it not working out. You might end up crying with no diploma and struggling to get a job. In the end, this shows that taking shortcuts may not always lead to the desired outcome.

In the short story, "Do Not exceed Posted Speed Limit," the setting affects the cyclist in the story significantly. For example, the dry hot air begins to slowly dehydrate him. As the heat intensifies, it causes the cyclist to lose all sense of reason, and the heat also plays tricks on his mind. He may start to hallucinate or make poor decisions due to the extreme conditions. Also, the rolling hills exhausted him from working hard to cycle up them. Each hill presented a new challenge, and the cyclist had to use a great deal of strength and endurance. This, combined with the heat factor, caused him to use up his much-needed water supply at a faster rate. The setting in this story deeply affects the cyclist, making his journey a difficult and arduous one. In such a harsh environment, the cyclist's ability to persevere is truly tested.

Features from the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The area he was in had a major impact. He was in Cali, which is a big desert. In the middle of the desert, it is extremely hot. The sun beats down relentlessly, and the dry air sucks the moisture out of his body. Bike riding on roads in the desert with no trees or shade of any sort is quite harsh. The lack of shade means that the cyclist is constantly exposed to the scorching heat, which can lead to heatstroke and dehydration. And to be riding around where there is not much civilization, so that you can't get water easily, is a major issue. Without a reliable water source, the cyclist's health and safety are at risk. In such a desolate environment, the cyclist has to be extremely cautious and resourceful to survive.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because there is a poisonous snake out there. It lurks in the grass or behind rocks, ready to strike at any moment. You are the only person riding down those hills all by yourself. The isolation adds to the cyclist's sense of vulnerability. The guy had said that the next town was @NUM1 miles from where he was at. This long distance means that the cyclist has to endure the harsh conditions for an extended period. The lack of water is a critical problem. There were not any streams or rivers around; he was just in a desert with nothing but sand and heat. Without water, the cyclist's body will start to shut down, and his chances of reaching the next town safely become slim. In this situation, the cyclist has to make every effort to conserve his energy and find a way to survive until he reaches civilization.

The setting is mid - summer in the California desert. The sun beats down relentlessly, and the air is hot, humid, and extremely dry. There's hardly a cloud in the sky to offer relief. In his bag, there's a severe lack of water. He's on a solitary trip, making his way down the lost, rough, and rigorous roads, where every pedal stroke is a struggle.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because it was a sweltering hot June day in a desolate desert in California. For instance, you're out in the desert, cycling for many long hours under the scorching sun, and you only have a limited supply of water. This situation affects the author as you have to carefully conserve the water you have to be able to make it to the park. Another example is that you're constantly going up and down the rolling hills, and your legs get so very tired that they simply don't want to move any more. And the most obvious example is the sun is pounding down on you, and you're sweating profusely. You might even start seeing things, but all you desperately want to do is see something that has water. These are all things that affected the cyclist very much.

The cyclist in the story is running into a lot of problems in this story. For example, the cyclist is out in the blistering summer heat in California, pedaling away on a bike. After several long minutes of this, your throat starts to feel parched, and you will become extremely thirsty. The cyclist brought some water, but after constant sweating due to the intense heat, the water supply has nearly run out. Not having enough water can cause a person to become dehydrated, which then can cause them to pass - out and possibly die. So as you can see, the cyclist is affected by the setting in the story. He has been affected negatively by the blistering heat and by the lack of water.

There are many ways that the features of the setting affect the cyclist. For example, the cyclist was in a very hot and arid place. Meaning there was no water anywhere to be seen for miles around. Also, towns were nowhere to be found as it would be extremely hard to sustain life out there. This quote supports that there weren't many towns: ''About forty miles into the pedal I arrived at the first town.'' This clearly shows there aren't many towns in these parts. It was so hot and the cyclist was so thirsty as the text claims, ''I read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst.'' This clearly shows the man was very thirsty. Also, it was so hot out there that the man could see strange visions as the text states, ''As the looks often had been a grape juice factory and bottling plant.'' Why would there be a grape juice factory in the middle of nowhere? Therefore, these statements above show how settings can affect one's mind and physical conditions of the cyclist.

The setting that affects the cyclist is the condition of the road because the road twists and turns in all different ways, and it goes steeply uphill. This makes it incredibly harder to pedal up the road. The cyclist has @NUM1 miles before he gets to a town, and he could easily run out of water. If he runs out of water before he gets there, he might have to make frequent stops so he doesn't make himself sick. When he finally gets to the town, he can replenish his water supply.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making him hot and thirsty for most of his way. As he pedaled steadily along the trail, he started to get tired slowly, and he grew more and more thirsty. He drank his water at first without thinking too much about it, but as he went on, he slowly found himself trying to conserve it carefully. By the time he got to the second wild town, he was so thirsty and exhausted that he thought it might have been a "death" scene. So he wiped the sweat from his eyes gently to make sure it wasn't a mirage. The only time people see mirages is when they are hot, tired, and desperate for some water. After his long journey to Yosemite National Park following the directions given by old men, this is exactly how the cyclist felt.

The features of the setting include “There are no one in sights, not a building, car, or structure of any kind” which precisely describes the desolate trail the cyclist was taking. These stark features of the setting vividly describe how the cyclist is affected because it elaborates on his growing doubt about whether he will survive or not. In this empty expanse, with no signs of human presence, his sense of isolation and fear intensify, making his survival seem increasingly uncertain.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist in various ways. The speed - limit sign, standing there rigidly by the road, makes him feel like life is cruel as it seems to mock his slow progress. His first glimpse of the Welch's Juice factory, with its colorful signage and the sweet smell wafting in the air, makes him feel excited, a brief spark of joy in his long journey. Meeting the deserted fork in the road, with its overgrown paths and an air of mystery, makes him feel troubled as he has to make a crucial decision. When he finally arrives at his destination, he feels a wave of relief wash over him. These are all clear examples showing that features of the setting affected the cyclist throughout his journey.

The many features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist and his performance. For example, the cyclist is riding through a very hot area of California. This is clearly stated at the end of paragraph @NUM1: “and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The high deserts of California are extremely windy, filled with fine sand that gets into his gears, dry as a bone, and scorchingly hot. It's not an ideal terrain for cycling. Had the setting been the mountainous regions of California, the weather would not be as hot, and he wouldn't feel as tired because the mountains are a cool, although still dry place. Had I been cycling, I would rather have cycled in a different setting, such as the mountains, than an arid desert. That way, I would not have to endure the discomfort a cyclist experienced in the desert heat.

The features of the setting in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” are very important to the cyclist. In this story, the setting really affected the cyclist because it was set in California, which is a really hot place during the summer. The cyclist faced numerous problems because of the sweltering weather and the shortness of water. Since there was a shortage of water, he had to conserve it meticulously, which slowed him down as he couldn't ride as vigorously. Although there was a cool wind and a river from Yosemite, he had to pass quickly down the hill, which added even more challenges. This is why the settings of the story really affected the cyclist and severely limited how much he could ride, making his journey a difficult and arduous one.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. In the story, it talks about how the man is pedaling twenty miles here and forty miles there under the scorching sun, and it's very hot outside. He only has a limited supply of water, and he doesn't think he'll make it to his destination because he desperately needs more water. As the narrator says, “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June,” which is extremely hot in California in June. The desert's hot weather made him limited on water supply, and the fact that he was in the middle of nowhere, with no buildings around, makes him lose all hope of making it through. There were snakes in the desert which endangered him, and the bumpy road made it harder for him to hold on and get to somewhere safe. “I began breaking the ride into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself if I could make it there I'd be fine.” This quote shows his struggle because of the area he was in but also his persistence. The features of the setting significantly impact the cyclist in this essay, highlighting how the harsh environment can pose great challenges to travelers.

Many features of the cyclist’s surroundings affect his speed and confidence. He was the only one on the long, empty road. There were no other cars, bikes, motor - cycles, or even buildings in sight. It’s like he’s in the far - reaching countryside where nature stretches out as far as the eye can see. So that makes him want to go faster, because he won’t hit anything. The fact that he’s alone in the wide, open spaces boosts up his energy level and makes him feel more confident, allowing him to fully enjoy the freedom of the ride. In such a setting, the cyclist can experience an unhindered and exhilarating journey.

To be able to have a good bike ride, you must have a good setting. To me, a good setting would be about @NUM1° outside and sunny. The warm temperature and bright sunlight create a pleasant atmosphere for cycling. You can’t go bike riding in snow because there is no way that the tires will move smoothly in the thick snow. You can’t go in rain or hail because the roads get slippery and you could get in an accident that could injure or kill you. If it is sunny outside, you will be able to ride freely on dry roads with a gentle breeze to go through your hair and you could be refreshed. That is why I believe it is important for the setting to be just right for a bike ride, as it directly impacts the safety and enjoyment of the experience.

This story is set in the sweltering desert in June and the character is a cyclist trying to get to a National Park. The setting affects the cyclist because the hotter it is, the more water you need to keep you hydrated, but the man is alone in the vast expanse of the desert. This quote “about forty miles in the pedal I arrived at my first ‘town’.” The place might have been a thriving little settlement at one time. This quote shows how deserted the desert is and how as he rides there is nobody around, no place to re - hydrate, no place to get directions. He was all alone in this desolate environment, facing great difficulties in his journey to the park. The harsh desert setting truly takes a toll on the cyclist's ability to reach his destination.

In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting greatly affected the cyclist. In this story, the cyclist is heading for Yosemite National Park. Thinking it wise, he accepts directions from a group of eccentric old men. He begins his journey confidently on the flat, smooth terrain and with a large supply of water, ready to embrace the adventure. The first of three promised towns had been resigned to that of a ghost town, with empty buildings and a spooky silence. The second offered only water that slightly resembled battery acid, which was undrinkable. The cyclist soon becomes exhausted from lack of water and having to cross the now hilly and challenging terrain. He barely makes it to the third town to realize that the juice factory was out of business. The cyclist becomes sure that he is going to die of lack of water when he stumbles across a bait store. If it hadn’t been so hot, if the “towns” along the way had offered better resources and if the terrain hadn’t been so hilly, the cyclist would have had a very enjoyable ride. All of the aforementioned factors of the setting greatly affected the cyclist, demonstrating how the environment can turn a hopeful journey into a struggle for survival.

Hot, sweltering weather, challenging terrain, and being in the middle of nowhere - all are prominent features of the setting that significantly affected the cyclist. First, the intense hot weather in California, with the sun blazing down relentlessly, made the cyclist extremely thirsty and almost on the verge of dehydration. There was scarcely any place to stop for water and if there was, the water was bad - tasting and warm, offering little relief. Second, the different types of rough and uneven terrain, such as rocky paths and sandy stretches, made the cyclist really thirsty also and physically exhausted. Lastly, the cyclist was in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by vast emptiness. He couldn't get water to hydrate himself or find a proper place to sit down and rest. All these factors combined made the cyclist's journey an arduous one.

The setting for the cyclist is a harsh, hard and extremely dangerous one. He had very little water, and his area was filled with tough, unforgiving terrains. “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June” (@NUM1). The searing heat and lack of water left him severely dehydrated and he still had a long way to go. I once went on a bike ride that was many miles long in @LOCATION2, and we did not have water because we could not take a break due to the continuous stretch of the route. The terrain was tough, just like the author’s terrain, with rocky patches and steep slopes. The extreme heat was affecting his brain, making him disoriented and he just wanted to get it over with. I am just glad I don’t have to bike in that kind of harsh terrain as it can be life - threatening.

The cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed @CAPS1” was riding through the dry, desolate California desert in June. This dry, bare setting made it utterly impossible to find any source of water. The only time that this cyclist found water was when it was a murky, brackish puddle that was dirty and tasting of battery acid. There was nowhere for him to find water for miles, with the vast expanse of the desert stretching out all around. This lack of water and the scorching heat made him travel slow and wearily, as if every pedal stroke was a struggle. He even says that he could only go 12 mph in a 55 mph zone. By taking the advice of the old men and taking a “short cut”, the cyclist passed through ghost towns with no water, the empty buildings standing as silent witnesses to his plight. This “short cut” prolonged his trip, most likely by hours. If he had gone through populated area despite the fact that it is a longer path, there would have been more water to drink, which would allow him to go faster. The dry, hot setting of the old men’s “short cut” made this cyclist’s trip last much longer than necessary, turning what could have been a manageable journey into a grueling ordeal.

When the man began cycling he thought that this was going to be an easy, enjoyable ride. For example in paragraph @NUM1 he says “Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” As he got further along the route, he realized that he was in the middle of nowhere. The scenery was getting more and more empty, with fewer and fewer signs of human habitation. There was eventually nothing but vast stretches of barren land. The desolate scenery was putting down his hope of ever getting out of the desert. For example: In paragraph @NUM2 it states, “a large highway sign jumped out at me. It read: Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” He realized this was going to be hard. He had to travel on bumpy roads, feeling every jolt and shake, and pass snakes without getting bit, constantly on high - alert. The scenery created a sense of hopelessness because it was abandoned, with no signs of life or help. When he saw the bait shop, a small oasis in the desert, his spirits lifted and he was now hopeful and relieved, knowing that he was not alone in this desolate place.

When the cyclist began his journey he was confident in succeeding, with a spring in his step and a determined look on his face. Throughout the story however, the cyclist endures many conflicts to his success in his journey. The cyclist faced his first difficulty once he reached a small, abandoned town. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist realized he had not conserved his water and his “water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips” (kurmaskie @NUM1), leaving him in a precarious situation. On top of his water problem the heat was unbelievable, with the sun beating down mercilessly. He was losing hydration from all the sweat, and he was losing it quickly, his body starting to show signs of distress. The cyclist was also dealing with the difficult roads, full of potholes and ruts that made each pedal stroke a challenge. There were many things this cyclist endured throughout his journey, but he was determined to finish his trip and was filled with deep - seated satisfaction once he overcame these hardships, having proven his resilience and willpower.

The features of the setting put a significant affect on the cyclist. The first notable aspect is listening to old men who seemed utterly clueless about the distance, duration, or the actual condition of the roads where they were sending him. These old men would casually give directions, not realizing the challenges that awaited the cyclist. Another thing that affected him was the road condition. Along the way, there were tumbleweeds rolling across the path, and he even encountered a ridiculously large snake slithering nearby, which startled him. The second major factor that came into play was the sweltering hot weather. The intense heat made dehydration a real threat as his body quickly lost fluids. In conclusion, the combination of misleading directions, poor road conditions, and hot weather took a toll on the cyclist's journey.

One main feature of the setting that significantly affects the cyclist is the blistering heat of the day. When you ride a bike under the scorching sun during the heat of the day, your body is bound to use up a large amount of water at a rapid pace. Another crucial factor is the limited supply of water. The cyclist might have started with a small amount, not anticipating the long and hot journey ahead. The final factor is the wrong directions from the aged men. Aged people aren't always wrong, but their information can be out of date. They might recall roads and places as they were years ago, not considering the current changes. In conclusion, these three elements - the heat, limited water supply, and incorrect directions - make the cyclist's journey a challenging one.

The features of the setting in the essay affect the cyclist because as he was riding his bike throughout California, he entered the hot deserts where the sun beat down mercilessly. Soon, he found himself almost out of water. The cyclist was in a very bad dehydrated state as he pedaled his bike, his throat parched and his body weak. He was constantly on the lookout for water or anything drinkable that would successfully get rid of his dehydration. After a little while, the cyclist found himself completely alone in the vast desert with no one in sight. An example of this desolate situation is “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” Another example to show how the cyclist was struggling and fighting against dehydration is “wise rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades.” This clearly shows how the settings of this essay affected the cyclist greatly, putting his health and safety at risk.

During the author's ride to Yosemite, he didn't have the proper tools to go along the long stretch of the California desert he was to face, and by tools, specifically, I mean water. The California desert is extremely hot, with the sun baking the ground relentlessly. It can be potentially dangerous depending on your situation. The author was describing in detail how the lack of water was affecting him. He used vivid sentences like “Rattled around the dry honey combs of my deteriorating brain” to convey the severity of his condition. The author clearly cannot face the rugged heat with his immense lack of water. As he rode on, he was getting near heatstroke, being passed by desert snakes slithering across the path and tumbleweeds blowing in the wind. The author was clearly in a tough struggle against the unforgiving desert heat, which made his journey to Yosemite extremely difficult.

The settings and features are very important to cyclists. One key reason is that for water and food, cyclists might carry a simple water bottle and a small snack, but they need to have a clear idea of where they are going and if they will need to bring extra supplies or not. In the story I just read, the cyclist didn't bring enough provisions to last him through the journey. He then sought directions, but unfortunately, they were bad. As a result, he was in serious trouble, wandering aimlessly in an unfamiliar area. It's extremely important that a cyclist knows where they are going and what kind of environment is around them so they don't get lost and end up having no access to essential food or water. In conclusion, proper planning and awareness of the setting are vital for cyclists to have a safe and successful journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he found himself in a vast desert in the month of June. The desert heat was intense, with the air being extremely hot and dry. There were absolutely no trees around, meaning there was no shade whatsoever for him to take a relaxing break. As a result, the scorching sun relentlessly beat down on his back. Moreover, there were numerous hills in the desert. These hills were not easy to navigate; for instance, the text mentions "over one long, crippling hill," which required a great deal of his strength to overcome. There was also a large and unexpected twist in his path. To make matters worse, he even saw a venomous snake. All these factors combined made him extremely tired. He had a limited supply of water, and the intense sun caused him to become hot and dehydrated. With no shade available, he had no choice but to endure the sun's rays on his back. Jumping over and riding up the hills consumed a significant amount of his energy. Since all these challenges occurred one after another without any respite, it completely exhausted him.

In the story, it vividly explained the captivating beauty of the night. It also delved into the allure of the outdoors and how it was influencing his trip. The features of the setting had a notable impact on the cyclist. The setting was described as mild, with a warm and calm atmosphere that could be almost felt through the descriptions. It also showed how the setting related to us in a certain way. The characteristics of the setting seemed to mirror those of the cyclist. For example, the calmness of the night might have reflected the cyclist's inner peace during the journey, while the mildness could be compared to his measured approach. In this way, the features of the setting had a profound and multi - faceted effect on the cyclist, enhancing his overall experience of the trip.

The cyclist was in the sunny state of California during the month of June. The blistering sun was beating down mercilessly on him, which made the cycling ride extremely difficult, especially considering his limited and short water supply. As he pedaled along, the man came across several towns that were completely abandoned. These desolate towns offered no source of water, further reducing his already scarce water supply. The terrain he encountered was quite diverse. At first, it was long and straight, which allowed for relatively easy riding. However, it soon transformed into tall and imposing hills. These hills were a real challenge to ride up, requiring a great deal of physical effort and determination. All these factors combined made his cycling journey in California a tough and arduous one.

How the features of the setting affect the cyclist is through the condition of the roads, the presence of rolling hills, and the intense heat. The conditions of the road in the setting have a significant impact on the cyclist because the roads are extremely rough. An example from the text is “I noticed that the terrain was changing. The flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” These rough road conditions and the rolling hills make it very difficult for the cyclist; they present a real challenge. The rolling hills are not only physically demanding but also require great skill to navigate. It is quite easy to lose control on these hills, and they constantly test the cyclist's ability to stay on the road. The heat and the sun also play a crucial role in affecting the cyclist. An example from the text is “I chuckled, checked my water supply and moved on. The sun was beginning to heat up, but I barely noticed at first.” As the sun rises higher, especially in the high deserts, it starts to take a toll on the cyclist. The heat becomes more and more intense, making the ride even more challenging. In conclusion, these features in the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, but his determination was unwavering, and he kept pushing himself to move forward.

In the setting of "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the cyclist is riding a bike at a breakneck speed on a rough and bumpy road. The rough surface of the road makes it difficult for the bike to maintain a smooth ride. Every bump and pothole on the road jolts the cyclist, testing his balance and control. The cyclist has to be extremely vigilant as he speeds along, constantly adjusting his grip on the handlebars and his position on the seat to stay on the bike. Despite the challenges posed by the rough road, he continues to ride fast, perhaps driven by a sense of adventure or a specific goal. This high - speed ride on a rough road sets the tone for an exciting and perilous journey, where the cyclist must use all his skills to overcome the obstacles presented by the setting.

The cyclist had a couple of affects in his journey. One of them was the hills. The steep inclines of the hills were a problem because it used most of his energy and slowed him down significantly. The other one was water, specifically the lack of water. If he had energy - boosting water, he would have gotten a much - needed boost that would have kept him going steadily until he reached his destination.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. Firstly, the cyclist had been pedaling through the “high deserts of California”. The arid expanse of these high deserts made it clear that the temperature was hot and dry. With the sun relentlessly beating down on him, he must've been getting thirsty regularly and exhausted from the intense heat. Second, he began to ride through hills. As common sense dictates, hills are much harder to ride on a bicycle, especially going uphill. The constant need to exert more force on the pedals wears you down. These hills, along with a lack of water, must've tired him out and given him extreme difficulty to make it without much water. As you can tell, the difference in setting plays its crucial part on the cyclist and his precious water supply, making his journey a real challenge.

The setting affects the cyclists because he can not take the searing heat. His water supply is running low and he is severely dehydrated. It says this when the character says, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide wings of sweat circled my shirt and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke”. This is saying he is afraid he might pass out and die before he finds more water. In such a dire situation, the setting's heat and lack of water are clearly taking a heavy toll on him.

The setting affected the cyclist in several ways. The first place he arrived at was a “ghost town”, a desolate and eerie place with an air of abandonment. Then he reached a water pump about twenty miles up the road. The water was extremely hot and tasted very nasty. The text states, “...water heating somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees...when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid”. Then he had to travel without water and became dehydrated. Travelling up and down the hilly terrain, he thought he began to imagine a building that could possibly provide him with water. The building was there but it was completely abandoned. He decided he was going to suck on a couple of pebbles. The text says, “I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst...”. This shows how the unforgiving setting continuously tested his endurance.

It is very hot, so the cyclist is very dehydrated, extremely tired and suffering from a lack of water. “I checked my water supply and headed on” is a good example of this. There are also a lot of sad and deserted places with no cars around. The absence of any sign of life bars the cyclist's hope of finding civilization. Also, not seeing any buildings and when he does see one, it being deserted makes this very hard on the rider. Another event that takes a toll on him is when he reaches the pump that has tar, dirt, and then hot water in it. The unpalatable water is of no help. Also, the road plays a toll on him. I know this because he says, “If I could just make it to that next horizon/hill I'll be alright”. This is how I know the setting and features in the setting are affecting the cyclist mentally and physically, making his cycling journey a true struggle.

Hot, sweltering heat, alone on an empty road, with no water in sight – all are reasons why the features of the setting affect the cyclist. It is extremely hot as the cyclist is riding under the unforgiving sun. This makes the cyclist constantly worried about getting dehydrated and his energy waning. The cyclist is completely alone and there is nothing but vast emptiness in sight. If anything happened to him, like a sudden illness or a mechanical issue with his bike, there is no one to help. The cyclist had very little water left in his bottle and had to conserve it carefully in order to stay active and have enough energy to keep pedaling. With very little water, it is incredibly hard to stay hydrated and keep his body functioning properly. Hot, alone, no water - all are reasons why the features of the setting have a significant impact on the cyclist.

The terrain that a cyclist is riding on has a big and noticeable affect on them. The first clear example of this is when they are riding on steep hills, it makes it much more difficult for them. For instance, when the rider in the story saw that he was going to have to ride on a long stretch of hilly terrain, he was, obviously, disappointed as he knew it would require a great deal of effort. Another thing that affects cyclists is the smoothness of the road they are riding on. In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the main character came to a particularly rough spot in the road, with potholes and uneven surfaces, and was disappointed and didn't want to ride it as it made the journey bumpy and uncomfortable. Another aspect that can affect cyclists is the intense heat. Several times in the story, the cyclists says that he is extremely tired and dehydrated. At one point, when the heat was at its peak, he thinks he is going to die of heatstroke. Those are the effects that the rider's setting have on him/her.

The setting in the essay "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" has a major and profound effect on the cyclist. The setting is the high deserts of California, where it is June and the sun beats down mercilessly, making it very hot. The path of the cyclist suggested by some old men makes the heat even worse because there are no people or water in sight for miles. In the essay, the cyclist starts out the day confident and excited for his ride to Yosemite National Park, looking forward to the beautiful scenery and the adventure. His mood changes throughout the day as after @NUM1 miles he arrives in a "ghost town" that the old men led him to believe would be a settled town where he could get more supplies and cool off in the shade. Soon as the temperature rises to what feels like "two hundred degrees", the cyclist begins to run low on water and feels "sometimes life can feel so cruel" as he realizes the dire situation he is in. The heat and lack of people and water lead the cyclist to desperation and make him feel like as he says "i was going to die". The setting of the cyclist's journey provides the mood of hopelessness and amplifies the feeling of determination felt by the cyclist to keep going at all costs because he knew he was going to die if he stopped. The author, @PERSON1 uses the setting of the essay to help bring across his message that by blindly trusting people instead of trusting yourself, things could end up being hard for you to overcome.

In the story “Do not Exceed Posted Speed limit” the cyclist sees many different settings. When he left, it was early summer and it was already pretty hot outside, with the sun starting to warm up the day. He rode into the morning, the continuous pedaling making him gradually tired. The first town he reaches upon was a ghost town, which means he couldn't rest or get his supplies as he had hoped. Then he arrived by cool pines and a rushing river, the sound of the water and the shade of the trees probably making him feel relaxed and at ease. Then he showed up at a ramshackle shed with several rusty pumps and a carrel that could hardly hold anything useful. Gloomy - looking men around there made him feel uncomfortable, and the pumps did not give him water, so there was no relief in sight. Then he was riding through the California deserts in June, the hot sand and dry air which probably made him even more dehydrated and miserable.

The cyclist should have never taken the advice from the older men. The map would have been a lot safer and easier to follow. People seem to always look for a shortcut, including myself, thinking it will save time and effort. He could have died from heat stroke and lack of water in that harsh desert environment. He did have great perseverance though; he never gave up even when the situation was extremely dire and that is what ultimately saved him. Being in that situation and setting, with the scorching heat and no water in sight, I would have given up as it would have been so hard to keep going. But the cyclist's determination is a lesson that sometimes, even in the most difficult circumstances, we should keep pushing forward.

When cycling, it's crucial to make yourself well - aware of the type of terrain, such as whether it's flat, hilly, or mountainous. Also, make sure to check the weather forecast, like if it will be sunny, rainy, or windy. Additionally, assess the environment, for example, if it's a busy city street or a quiet country lane. Most importantly, ensure you have enough resources, including water, snacks, and a basic repair kit. These things are key before taking any cycling trip. They are very important in determining the type of trip you will have, whether it's an enjoyable and relaxing one, or a long and miserable journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly when travelling very far to his destination. For example, "About forty miles into the pedal I arrived at the first town." It was a good thing that he was carrying water; otherwise, who knows if he would have survived or not. I think the biggest mistake was that he asked probably someone who had never been on the road for directions. When he asked the person, he ended up at a sign that said "Rough road Ahead: Do not exceed." That was the moment I felt sorry for him, and that was probably the most impactful feature of the setting that affected him, making his journey much more difficult.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed” by @PERSON1, the settings of the story affect the rider in many ways. The first and most obvious is the temperature; it is swelteringly hot, therefore the rider is extremely hot and becoming dehydrated, making him desperately thirsty. A second way the setting affects the rider is the fact that there is nothing around him. Since there are no facilities nearby, there is nowhere for him to get water, adding to the effect of dehydration and making him even more thirsty. The rider says “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and the corral that couldn't hold the lamest mule greeted me.” This statement from the author supports the fact that there is nothing around. One more feature of the setting that affected the rider was the hills. The steep hills made the rider extremely tired, requiring more pedaling and wearing him out. The setting features had a great affect on the rider, from heat and dehydration to hills and energy depletion. One thing that the setting didn't have was a positive effect on the rider, as it only made his journey tougher.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affected the cyclist. It was a scorching hot June day, and the water supplies he had were quickly running out. He got the wrong directions from these old men, so he had to ride his bike longer than he originally planned. Pedaling all that extra distance for nothing made his need for water even more urgent. Since he was going in the wrong direction, there were no buildings where he could get water. There were no people around, so he couldn't communicate with anyone, and there would be no one to call for help in case he overheated from the intense heat. This difficult setting really put the cyclist in a tough spot during his journey.

In the story, the rider faced several melancholy sites. For example, the “ghost town” that he ran into at first really put a burden on him because he had no one to ask for further directions or a place to freshen up. Further on down the road, the hill he came up on was a physical obstacle that he had to overcome. With the blazing sun beating on his back and the emptiness of the long, desolate road, he might have begun to want to turn back. However, he kept on persevering, which was how he managed to make it down the other side. The lack of water also made it extremely difficult for him. Traveling with his water running out and starting to feel sick did not bode well for him, but his determination kept him going through this arduous journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a negative way. For example, a tarlike substance oozed from the ground, followed by brackish water that felt scalding, somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees. This affects him because he can't get clean water from the well. So this means he desperately needs water, but cannot obtain it. Also in the essay it says the terrain is bad, with numerous potholes and steep inclines. So that means that the cyclist has to pedal harder to keep moving and he has to work extra hard to not break down. So all this puts a strain on him from just what's around him. The old abandoned factory with the boy drinking juice had the most effect on the cyclist because he was so parched and that was when he was on the verge of giving up. In this essay the setting had a lot of impact on the cyclist to the point where he thought he might die, such a dire situation highlighting the powerful influence of the setting on his experience.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. The speaker tells us that he’s riding his bike in the middle of the desert in June. The intense desert sun beats down on him, which shows the author is probably very hot and uncomfortable. The author tells us that the road turned into hills and bumps, with some hills being quite steep. This would make it more difficult for the author because he would have to use more energy to move up the hill, his legs straining with each pedal. And lastly, the cyclist tells us that the “towns” he came to were abandoned and uncared for, with dilapidated buildings and dry wells. This would not be good for the cyclist because he would be unable to get water for his trip, leaving him at risk of dehydration. In conclusion, the harsh desert setting in June, the difficult hilly road, and the lack of water in abandoned towns all combined to have a significant negative impact on the cyclist's journey.

The cyclist is affected in many ways. The major thing that affects him is the lack of water. Throughout the story he repeatedly mentions the lack of water, his throat parched and his body craving moisture. He also continues to say to himself he should not have taken that route. For example, “I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, which caused me to laugh.” The cyclist says things about the older gentleman throughout the story, expressing his regret and frustration at following the man's advice. In the end, the lack of water and the poor route choice take a toll on the cyclist, making his journey a difficult and regrettable one.

Setting very much affects the cyclist and how he feels. If he was in a bad setting, with harsh weather and difficult terrain, then he would most likely be in a bad mood. Mood is highly affected by the general setting. In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclist feels very confident of himself at the start, and the setting helps to boost that confidence and endurance. The open road, the fresh air, and the beautiful scenery all contribute to his positive state of mind. However, as the journey progresses and the setting becomes more challenging, his confidence may waver. But overall, the initial setting has a positive impact on his mental state, showing the strong connection between setting and mood.

The features in the setting of the essay affected the author greatly. The hills, on a sweltering hot day, with no water source in sight or nearby town, are really rough, especially if you’ve been riding for more than 50 miles. Your body is exhausted and your energy is depleted. The environment of the hot June weather near a desert area can cause serious problems. For example, heat stroke is a real threat, and since he had no water to drink, dehydration set in quickly, causing a lot of fear in the author. He could feel his strength waning with each passing moment. The setting of the essay and the conditions the author was under were extremely dangerous and he's lucky he made it out alive, a testament to his resilience in the face of such a harsh setting.

That the cyclist is steadily pedaling down an extremely steep and winding road when trying to get to his destination, the small town settled out yonder, are the events that took place yesterday. The condition of the road was difficult and he was in a bit of a hurry at times, and this took a toll on his body. In the end, he persevered through the tough journey to reach his goal.

In the short story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting greatly affects the cyclist. For example, in the beginning of the story, the cyclist is highly eager to get to Yosemite National Park. He listens to the advice of old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office, and quickly realized that he shouldn’t have. The author describes the setting of the first “town” as “the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This didn’t bother the cyclist as much as his next sight. “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the largest mule” was what met him there. The cyclist said that “this sight was troubling.” It is obvious that the cyclist has given up hope when he says, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This short story clearly shows how anything can get even the most seasoned travellers worried about their survival.

I think the features of the settings affect the cyclist because the knowledge of the cyclist is limited. For example, “old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” meaning that now it's time for the older people to relax and watch the younger people take on new adventures. The cyclist, relying on their advice, may be led astray due to the old - timers' limited modern - day knowledge, which in turn impacts his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because where he is riding it is very dry and hot. He can initially deal with the heat with his good water supply, but when it runs out he begins to get disoriented. For example, in the text he writes “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage.” That statement shows that the cyclist was extremely hot, and the images around him were making him feel even more hot than what he actually was, and his lack of water made him almost believe that he was imagining seeing a building. Another example is “A sand - blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hang my head.” This quote shows that the cyclist is in complete despair as he looks at the photo and hangs his head. This shows that the cyclist was constantly being reminded how hot and thirsty he was everywhere he would go and he couldn't get a drink. This is how the harsh features of the setting severely affected the cyclist.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affected the cyclist in the story. “Not two miles into this next section of ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie). The cyclist is travelling through hot, dry California in the middle of June without much water left. The fact that he now has to travel up and down short hills is going to make him even more tired, because going over hills requires more energy than flat riding. This energy loss, coupled with the cyclist's lack of water, causes him to become even more miserable. The unforgiving setting of this story, with its changing terrain and harsh climate, significantly affected the cyclist's journey and well - being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist's mood and behavior. First, the cyclist believes that taking the shortcut will help him arrive at Yosemite faster. As he pedals along, he soon realizes it won't. Next, the harsh sun beats down on him, the rough terrain jolts his body, and the lack of water makes his throat parched. This causes the cyclist to give up hope that he will make it to Yosemite and leads him to rethink his judgment and consider taking advice from others. In the end, he understands that being more cautious in choosing routes is necessary.

The setting affected the cyclist in a harsh way. At first, the cyclist was fine and going strong, pedaling steadily with energy. But soon after passing the first "ghost town", he started getting weak, his legs becoming heavy. Then the cyclist had to face a few problems. For example, he was running low on water, and his water bottle was almost empty. Also, he faced rough roads that made his bike shake violently. Last, he encountered snakes slithering on the path and the desolate feeling of abandonment. The cyclist had to face many obstacles, but in the end, he pulled through strong, proving his perseverance.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist for these reasons. It says “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. The sight was troubling.” That shows how the features affected the cyclist because he says the sight was troubling. It troubled him because he was extremely thirsty and wanted water. When he saw the rusty pumps, they reminded him of water, but he knew there was no clean water or it was likely to be nasty. This made his situation seem even more hopeless, and he felt more anxious about his lack of water supply.

The conditions of the environment as well as the road can majorly affect the cyclist. For example, if someone was riding a bike in warm weather on flat land, the gentle breeze would accompany them, and it would not take major determination to pedal. On the other hand, if it is hot and the paths are rough with hilly roads, the biker could dehydrate quickly as they sweat profusely. It takes much more effort to get up and over the hill, and their legs have to work harder with each pedal stroke. These conditions of the environment affect a cyclist greatly, highlighting the importance of suitable conditions for cycling.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist, on his way to Yosemite National Park, is forced to face the rough deserts of California. As is normal throughout all deserts, the sun is blazing hot, scorching his skin, and the sand is so hot that it radiates heat. There is no water anywhere in sight, and dangerous, highly venomous creatures like rattlesnakes are abundant, lurking in the sand. The lack of water almost puts him into a heat - stroke as he is determined to leave the desert, riding his bike all alone. A grape juice factory taunts him with its signs, mocks him with the thought of liquid, but he continues on, with a steady pace, though his energy is waning. The desert roads are rocky and bumpy, and his lousy 12 mph speed is getting him practically nowhere, each bump jolting his body. Until, finally, he reaches a modern area and drinks from the sink in the bathroom, feeling a great sense of relief as the cool water quenches his thirst.

In the story, the setting plays a big role in affecting the cyclist. The terrain was very challenging at times, such as having big hills and winding turns. The steep inclines of the large hills made pedaling an arduous task, and the sharp, windy turns required great balance and control. Also, there was no one around. No houses, buildings, or people were in sight, which made him feel alone as if he was going to die. The desolate landscape added to his sense of isolation and vulnerability. The author describes the terrain in one part of the story: “Over one long, crippling hill a building came into view!” This quote shows how the hills in the setting were very big and hard to get over. It also shows the significance of a single building and how excited he was to see it. In the story, the author described many features from the setting which all greatly affected the cyclist, highlighting the power of the environment on his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist, by putting him in unwanted places. Starting off, this man took advice from many older men, who don't even know the area anymore. These old - timers, sitting on their porches, gave advice that seemed reasonable but was actually quite off - base. So, riding through, this man seems lost. He is trying to follow their advice, but comes across many unknown, unwanted areas. The roads were unfamiliar, leading him through desolate patches and rough terrains. He starts out good, then comes to a “Rough Road” and he even says “sometimes life can feel so cruel”. The rough road was full of potholes and uneven surfaces, making it difficult for him to maintain his balance and speed. Then he comes to this large snake in the middle of the road. Scary enough, he has to slow ride past this thing taking up most of the road. The snake was coiled menacingly, its eyes fixed on him as he slowly pedaled by. Coming over these things was very strenuous and hard on this young man, testing his physical and mental limits.

The desert environment had huge effects on the cyclist. He had been drinking his water regularly and would be running out. Not realizing, there would be no refills because the pump was only giving “tarlike substance” said the text. The thick, sticky substance that came out of the pump was completely useless for quenching his thirst. With the lack of water, dehydration was beginning to hit the poor man. An effect of dehydration is poor balance that would have been useful to pass the “ridiculously large snake” he had seen. His legs felt wobbly, and his movements were less coordinated as he tried to navigate around the snake. A final effect would be mirages that could cloud your judgement. This man double - checked his eyes, when coming in view of a building, by “[wiping] the sweat from (his) eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage”. Through all the toughest desert obstacles, the character was able to take the short cut and survive heat, dehydration, and animals of the desert, showing his remarkable resilience.

I think the features in the setting of the story “Do not exceed the speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie highly affect the cyclist. Some implied information would be that it is very hot out, and the people in towns didn't help him. I know that it is hot because the text says, “somewhere in the neighbourhood of @NUM1 degrees.” This implies that it is swelteringly hot outside, making the cyclist's journey even more difficult. I can tell the people in towns didn't help him because the text says, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This shows that the people in towns didn't offer useful guidance. Some expressed information in this text would be that there is a rough road, and a snake was in his way. I know this is expressed because it tells you right in the text. “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit.” This comes right out and tells you there is a rough road full of bumps and unevenness. You know there is a snake because the text says, “and ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the road.” I think there are many implied and expressed information in the story “Do not exceed the speed limit” that significantly impact the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in a larger way, almost resulting in a very severe situation. The cyclist was in a desert - like terrain, which was not densely populated on his trail. The sparse population meant that help was hard to come by.
