There was a lack of fresh water supplies, and the temperatures were more extreme. The searing heat of the desert sun beat down on him relentlessly. The cyclist could easily have fainted from heatstroke, due to the lack of water and excessive heat and work that he was doing pedaling. The long hours of cycling in the intense heat with little water took a toll on his body. Had the area been more populated, he would have had more chances to stock up on water, greatly decreasing his risk of heatstroke. There was also the snakes which presented danger for him. Had he been bitten, then he would be at least @NUM1 miles from the closest help which could prove fatal. The venomous snakes lurking in the desert were a constant threat. Had the setting been, say a city park or a populated countryside, then the setting would have provided exponentially less problems and dangers for the cyclist, clearly demonstrating the impact of the harsh desert setting on his journey.

The conditions and features of the sweltering desert setting, with its intense heat and lack of shade, caused the cyclist to be extremely tired and severely dehydrated, and he began to think that he was going to die from it. For example, it says “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June”. Also, he thinks he is getting dehydrated when he says “I was doing a water - depleting 12 mph. sometimes life could be so cruel”. In conclusion, this cyclist started this arduous journey without enough water, which made him firmly believe that he was going to die from either heatstroke or dehydration.

The desolate setting affects the cyclist because he’s in the middle of a vast, empty expanse with no water in sight. The cyclist had to laboriously ride his bike for over @NUM1 miles, his legs aching with each pedal stroke, trying to get to Yosemite. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly.” This quote shows that he was just beginning to run out of water. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” This quote shows how he really had nothing to drink at all. Having no water in the scorching high deserts of California while riding your bike for over @NUM1 miles is not a good situation unless you have a car to provide support and supplies.

In the essay, the setting had everything to do with the cyclist because he is riding through the parched desert with barely any water. He is pedaling through the dry, searing heat that is tough even if you had an ample supply of water. Plus, there were steep hills and deadly snakes lurking in the area. It’s dangerous enough without that stuff being there. So, I would definitely listen to the cyclist's harrowing experience and never ever heed the advice of old men without proper consideration.

On the cyclist's ride to Yosemite National Park, he encounters a lot of hardships due to the desolate setting he is in and the potentially misguided advice given by old men. The cyclist riding his bike in the middle of June in the deserts of California is not a good situation to begin with, especially considering his already dehydrated state. He first comes across “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lament mule”. By that description of his location, it seems as if he might be in a ghost town by himself, which almost could strand him. He described the terrain with “short, rolling hills” and “over one long, crippling hill”. This shows some of the obstacles that he had to go through on a bike, just to get to Yosemite National Park. He eventually realized once he encountered these features of the terrain that he was off - track and needed to find help. After his long struggle to survive his surroundings for as long as he could go, he finally gets help at a real camp. That is how the settings of the story play a crucial role in the cyclist's difficult journey.

“Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is an inspiring and almost humorous essay that takes the reader inside a journey in a cyclist's daily routine. In this story, the author battles dehydration as he tries to make it to a national park with shortcut directions from “old timers”. The setting of this story greatly affects the cyclist and the pity the reader feels for him. Half - way through the essay, the biker had already traveled roughly @NUM1 miles; that’s extremely crazy. The fact that he is travelling through the hot California deserts in June is even harder to believe. The first time he mentions the setting, he states he is in a ghost town, and two sentences after he states that the sun was beating down relentlessly. At that point, he wasn't really bothered, but his energy was gradually sapping. Another description of his setting that probably affected his ability to peddle was when he states “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills”. He was already dehydrated and had already traveled so far, the rocky roads and the hilly terrain probably didn't help his already difficult journey much. The setting basically made the story. If he wouldn't have been peddling in the desert, it would have just been another ordinary trip in his life. The setting makes the reader truly see what cyclists really go through in such challenging circumstances.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. This is because the road is in a poor condition, full of potholes and uneven surfaces, and he has to travel a long distance under the bad weather, with strong winds blowing against him. This affects him as he might get dehydrated due to the extra effort required to pedal on such roads and in such weather. In conclusion, there are many elements in the setting that have a notable impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because if there weren't steep hills and rough, rutted roads, he would have been able to get to Yosemite Park faster. The constant uphill climbs and the bumpy terrain slow him down considerably. Also, he wouldn't have run out of water as quickly since less energy would have been consumed. The difficult setting clearly hinders his progress and resource management.

The setting was the main factor affecting the cyclist. He mentioned that it was swelteringly hot, and he was completely lost. The cyclist had no idea where he was going, and the intense heat outside made the situation even more challenging. He seemed very stressed, and this stress only exacerbated his problems. He was thirsty from all the riding and the scorching heat, so he tried to get water from a water pump. The water that was in it was horrible. He called it a “substance” as it had a flavor of battery acid. If he were not lost and if it were cool outside, he would have had enough water and would not be so upset. The setting of a hot and unfamiliar place had a huge impact on the cyclist, making his journey extremely difficult.

In my opinion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, when he was talking about the terrain changing from long, straight roads to sharp, winding ones and the speed limit changing, he said he was doing a water - depleting, strenuous effort, like he is having a hard time, or doesn't want to go on. The sudden change in the road conditions and speed requirements adds to his physical and mental fatigue, clearly showing the negative influence of the setting on him.

Due to the features in the setting, including the sweltering hot summer weather, the cyclist not knowing the area well, and the vast California desert, the cyclist is significantly affected. In the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist is travelling through the hot desert in June when he realizes he's running out of water. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie). This is affecting the cyclist because he's becoming extremely hot and has a low supply of water. Also, the cyclist realizes he should have never taken the direction from the old men and thinks to himself, “...The growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June” (Kurmaskie). This quote proves that the searing heat of the desert is taking a heavy toll on him, making his journey a real struggle.

The setting of this story significantly affects the cyclist. I think the setting was supposed to be most like a run - down, out - of - date town with dilapidated buildings and overgrown weeds. This kind of town didn't help him when he was lost as there were few landmarks to guide him. The town is not only out of date but also extremely hot under the blazing sun. This heat brings another problem: the cyclist was dehydrating rapidly because he didn't have enough water. As a result, he would hallucinate and see things that weren't there, like mirages of cool oases. He became very tired in the hot sun, his energy quickly draining away. So, the setting in this short story affected the cyclist in many ways, making his journey a real struggle.

The features of the setting strongly affect the cyclist due to the harsh conditions he is in, especially without any water. The cyclist would have been fine if he had brought more water for his trip. He ran out of water not long into his journey, thanks to the intense heat of the setting he was in. The high temperatures in the high desert of California in June were unforgiving. The cyclist makes this statement: “I was hitting my water bottle pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high desert of California in June.” The cyclist is saying that since it is so hot where he is, he has to take regular drinks of water so he stays hydrated throughout his trip. It is also saying that in the mountains with less air and the sweltering heat, he is not doing as well as he thought he would on the trip. In such conditions, his lack of water severely hampers his progress.

The cyclist had a hard trail to bike in order to get to @LOCATION1. It is easy to bike if you are on flat, smooth terrain. However, when you get to rolling hills, it makes the journey a lot tougher. The biker said, “I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. It was also very hot.” The intense heat made him sweat profusely and he was getting dehydrated quickly. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst.” he said. He had eighteen miles to the next town without much water. The first deserted town he passed through didn't have any drinkable water, with its wells dry and taps rusted. It was very hard to bike in these conditions, with the combination of difficult terrain and lack of water. It is important to always be prepared and know where you are going to avoid such hardships.

The cyclist has to endure rough terrain and bad road conditions, and a lack of water in the area certainly did not help the problem. There was a high probability he could have suffered from heatstroke as the sun beat down mercilessly on him. However, his hope was still up because of an abandoned Welch's fruit factory. The factory, with its large, empty buildings, stood as a potential source of shelter and maybe even water. Despite the tough situation, the thought of the factory gave him the motivation to keep going, but he still faced a long and difficult journey ahead.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed @CAPS1”, the vivid imagery is what sets the cyclist back. The scorching desert with its parched earth and sparse plant life gives him a sense of seclusion and scares him. The desolate landscape, with its vast stretches of sand and the occasional cactus, makes him feel isolated. Because the cyclist is in the desert, he keeps on worrying about his water supply and the threat of heatstroke. In contrast, if he were in a rain forest, he wouldn't worry about water or heat. I think he psyched himself out just by taking in his surroundings. If the cyclist would have pictured water all around him and arctic - like temperatures in his mind, I think he wouldn't have been so worried. What’s interesting about this story is that if he would have gotten himself prepared mentally for the conditions, he wouldn't have struggled so much at the end. “At some point tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake - it really did look like a diamondback blocking the majority of the pavement in front of me.” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). If the cyclist had concentrated more on the task at hand and less on what was going on around him, I think he would have succeeded without as much stress. In the end, his mental state was as much a hurdle as the physical environment.

The features of the arid and challenging setting affect the cyclist significantly as it made him rapidly use up his water supply and severely tested his determination. The sweltering heat and long, tough terrain forced him to consume water at a faster rate. “Sometimes life can be so cruel” implies that he was having an extremely horrible time coping with the harsh setting he was in. The desolate landscape and difficult conditions were overwhelming. To himself he thought he was gonna die at any moment, as the lack of water and the unrelenting environment took a toll on his body and mind. This experience in the tough setting truly showed the cyclist's mettle and the power of the environment to impact one's journey.

In the essay “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit,” the author is continually depressed by the unappealing features of the desolate landscape he passes. At first, he passes a ghost town with dilapidated buildings and empty streets, but because he has enough water in his canteen, this forlorn sight doesn't bother him too much. However, the next thing he sees is a rundown old shed and a “rusted water pump,” and this troubles him greatly because he is running perilously low on water. Then he sees a huge snake coiled menacingly on the road, which does not help his already gloomy mood, as the snake is blocking his path. After that, he passes an abandoned Welch’s Grape Juice factory with broken windows and overgrown weeds, and despairs that he will never find water. The setting and its uninviting features serve to disappoint and depress the cyclist in his desperate quest to find water, making his journey an increasingly disheartening one.

In the story “Rough Road ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” a cyclist is faced with many daunting problems. It’s really hot out, the sun beating down relentlessly like a furnace, practically a desert and it's in June when the temperatures soar. Just knowing that makes me want some cool water. Also, this cyclist is running short of water in his bottles and still hasn’t got to the place he needs to be. The roads are full of steep hills and are bumpy, filled with potholes and uneven surfaces, which make it much harder for him to pedal. Those are the challenging problems this cyclist is faced with, making his journey a real struggle.

At first, the narrator in “Do not Exceed Posted Speed limit” was energetic and enthusiastic about their exciting journey to Yosemite National Park. After getting some helpful advice from a friendly local about a few short cuts, the cyclist sets out full of anticipation for adventure. The first thing they encounter is a ghost town with crumbling buildings and a deserted main street. The gentlemen they took advice from had assured them it was a booming and prosperous town. This set the first wave of doubt through the cyclist's mind. Then the lack of water became a major issue. They were travelling through the high deserts of California in June, where the sun was scorching, and slowly running out of the precious liquid in their water containers. The flat road was soon replaced by short, rolling hills that seemed to go on forever, which only increased the cyclist's state of deliriousness. After a few more disappointments like a broken - down water source and a blocked path, the cyclist decides there is no hope and they are going to die. The reader is partly drawn in believing that this is the end for the cyclist. All of the disappointments set the stage for the possible end of the cyclist's journey and you can't stop reading because you have to find out what happens. If it weren't for the hopelessness of the setting you wouldn't care as much about the cyclist's fate.

When the cyclist is going on his trip, he is riding through a barren desert. All he sees the entire journey is a flat, dusty road stretching out endlessly and nothing but dirt as far as the eye can see. He is riding on the road, hopelessly hoping for some form of life. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The author is trying to stay positive but it’s hard, because all this desolate scenery is doing is bringing his hopes down. How would you like it if you were riding a bike and had no water in the middle of a blistering - hot desert? Now, if the setting had been a nice, green forest with tall trees and a babbling brook, he wouldn't be that worried, as there would be water and shade. He has none of that in the desert. This whole journey was all mental. He always kept in his mind that everything would be ok, repeating positive thoughts to himself. That is what helped him survive. This is an inspiring story, to anyone who needs a push to stay optimistic in the face of adversity.

Poor directions, intense heat, and lack of water significantly affect the cyclist in the story. At the beginning of the story, the cyclist is overly confident in the directions which he believes would, “slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park.” As the story progresses, the cyclist's initial confidence fades. The sweltering “heat of the California, June day causes him to guzzle water rapidly.” He admits, “I had been hitting my water bottle pretty regularly, and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” This severe lack of water becomes a huge problem for the cyclist, so much so that he was on the verge of heat stroke. “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Despite the harsh conditions, he braved the elements and forced himself forward, with hopes that any source of water would reveal itself to him. His perseverance finally paid off. “Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.” The cyclist had found a barst shop and received much - needed water, which allowed him to continue his journey.

The features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist. I say this because the setting is in the scorching hot deserts of @LOCATION1, where the sun beats down relentlessly. The cyclist is drenched in sweat and extremely tired, and he has almost no water left in his bottles. This dire lack of water makes the cyclist not only desperate for a drink but also yearning for food to regain his energy. Clearly, the setting has a lot to do with how the cyclist reacts to what happens, as these harsh conditions test his physical and mental limits.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. First, since there was no one in sight for miles around, he couldn't ask for any help or get proper directions. Also, due to all the poor road conditions, it was an arduous task to ride a bike through all the rocky roads. He was already very tired and dehydrated, and these rough roads only made his situation worse, tiring him out even more. Another reason is the presence of poisonous snakes in the area. If he accidentally disturbed them, they could harm him severely. Also, if he were to fall off his bike, a snake could easily bite him, and then he wouldn't be able to make it anywhere because of the venomous bite. These are the features of the setting that had a detrimental impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting in the story affect the cyclist both physically and mentally. It affects him physically because of the numerous rolling hills he has to laboriously trudge over and the acute lack of water he endures. The continuous ascent and descent of the rolling hills make him extremely tired and weak, especially when combined with the rough and uneven terrain. The lack of water only exacerbates his situation when he's parched from climbing the hills. The features affect him mentally because the farther he goes, the more dangerous his situation becomes. With each additional mile, he keeps reassuring himself, “if I can just get there I'll be fine.” He also blames himself for heedlessly listening to the old men's advice. Along with this self - blame comes doubt. He starts doubting that he can make it alive. In the story, it says, “it didn't really matter: I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Mentally, the pressure and despair were becoming too much for him to bear.

When the rider was riding his bike in such a sweltering day setting, he soon started to desperately need water as he was running out. So, his whole adventure then transformed into a desperate search for water. Being extremely thirsty was incredibly hard for him because it made him lose all motivation to keep going. He was so tired that every pedal stroke felt like a herculean effort. The thirst made the journey even more difficult on him. But at the same time, it also instilled more determination and strength within himself. He decided to keep on pushing forward, refusing to give up, and this inner resolve helped him continue his arduous journey in search of water.

îDo not Exceed the posted speed limitî tells a compelling story of learning and determination. A single cyclist embarks on a challenging journey, biking through the vast deserts of California. Along this arduous path, the cyclist encounters various obstacles, like venomous snakes slithering across the road and a dire lack of water in the parched landscape. The descriptive features of the setting, with its endless sand and sweltering heat, greatly impact the protagonist during his journey. The essay is set in the early summer. As the cyclist prepares to rest for the day, he takes particular note of ìthe serenity of an early summer evening,î with the gentle breeze and the soft glow of the setting sun. He ends the day feeling calm, finding solace in the quiet of the desert night. The next morning, he wakes up excited and rejuvenated, his spirit ready to take on another day of biking. However, as the day progresses, the heat rises steadily. By mid - day, the cyclist starts to worry about his dwindling water supply. Undeterred, he boldly continues forth, reaching new terrain of rolling hills. Here, his energy begins to wane, and he starts to lose hope. He is deeply disappointed when the ìtownî he hoped to find turns out to be an abandoned juice factory, with broken windows and rusted machinery. The cyclist thinks he is going to die due to the blistering heat and lack of hydration. But he gathers his last bit of strength to turn the final bend and reaches a bait shop where he can stop and get water. Finally, he is relieved, and his journey continues. In conclusion, as the cyclist pedals through the California desert, the change in both weather and terrain coincide and affect the cyclistís physical and mental strength, yet he perseveres to keep traveling.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. For example, the story specifically states, "I gathered up a few pebbles and stowed them in my mouth." This quote clearly explains that the setting was arid and rocky, with pebbles scattered across the ground. The availability of these pebbles in the desolate setting benefits the cyclist by diverting his attention from the intense thirst. In that harsh environment, if there weren't any pebbles near the cyclist, he might not have made it through the difficult part of his journey. In conclusion, in the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the cyclist was significantly benefited by the features of the unique setting, which provided a small but crucial means of relief in the face of adversity.

The features of the setting affect any cyclist in a significant way. When a cyclist spends a great deal of time on the bicycle, they often encounter problems with their back. As they sit in the same position for long hours, the constant pressure on the spine can cause strain. When they become an older person, having spent so much time cycling, they will likely face serious back problems. These problems can be so severe that they may not be able to walk properly. The sedentary - like position on the bike, combined with the vibrations and the uneven terrain, takes a toll on the body over time. In conclusion, the setting of long - distance cycling, with its physical demands on the body, can have a lasting negative impact on a cyclist's health as they age.

The setting in the essay ìRough Road ahead; Do not Exceed the speed limitî affected the narrator in multiple ways. The first and most prominent factor that influenced his ride was the intense heat. At the beginning of his journey, he didn't really notice the heat as much, perhaps distracted by the excitement of the ride. But as time went on, the sweltering heat began to slow him down, sapping his energy and making each pedal stroke a struggle. Then, the nature of the roads started to affect his ride. The roads transitioned from being flat and smooth like a sheet of glass to short, rolling hills. The constant up - and - down motion on the hills required more effort from the narrator, further exhausting him. The combination of the road change and the heat made him utter the words ìI could drop from heatstroke.î Moreover, because of the old and deserted towns he passed through, he faced a serious problem of getting water. The water pumps in these towns were so old and had been unused for such a long time that the water they provided was of very poor quality, making it almost undrinkable. In conclusion, the challenging setting of heat, difficult roads, and lack of clean water significantly hampered the narrator's cycling experience.

The complex features of the setting affect the cyclist negatively throughout this story. His trip takes a turn for the worse as he progresses towards Yosemite. After seeking directions from the ìold codgers,î the author decides to take the shortcut, hoping for a quicker and easier route. However, he is deeply disappointed when he arrives at the first town. It is completely deserted, with empty buildings and overgrown weeds. He tries to brush it off though, and keeps ìthe cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,î firmly in his mind as his motivation to keep going. He pedals on with determination, but as he continues, he begins to run out of water. When he arrives at a well, he discovers that the water is inedible, full of sediment and an unpleasant odor. Undeterred, he presses on. Just when it seems like things couldn't get any worse, his trail becomes rougher, with potholes and uneven ground, and his water supply is critically low. The cyclist is becoming dehydrated, and his hope starts to fade. His pessimism deepens when ìa ridiculously large snake - blocked the majority of the pavementÖî He has to carefully navigate around the menacing reptile. He keeps pushing forward and excitedly pedals toward a building in the distance, only to find it abandoned. In a desperate attempt to alleviate his dehydration, he even puts rocks in his mouth. Finally, when he finds the fish camp, he is filled with relief. All the obstacles he endured and overcame were worth it in the end, as he is one step closer to his destination.

The journey of a solo cyclist is a lonely one. The cyclist in “Do not exceed posted speed limit” had a particularly hard journey, as it was made even worse by the desolate setting. His main opponent in the battle of staying alive was the blistering heat. In the vast California deserts on a sweltering day in June, it was no surprise that the sun would be beating down particularly harder than it would at another place at any other time. Also, as the terrain gradually became hillier, his journey became even more arduous. There is nothing hard about biking in a flat straight line. But constantly pedaling yourself up steep hills and around winding roads is no picnic. Just like the dilapidated buildings around him, the cyclist’s water supply deteriorated, as did his state of mind, as his trip which started out very joyful became increasingly more somber. “It didn’t really matter, I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This cyclist was fighting against the strong forces of nature, and the odds seemed stacked against him.

In the short story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting plays an extremely important role. The story takes place in sunny California, where the cyclist was pedaling at a slow pace of around 12 mph. The scorching heat made his dehydration situation much worse. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” The cyclist was losing hope, yet he was still determined to find water. This setting was very important to the story, for if it had taken place at a cooler, more populated location like a forest or a coastal town, it would not have made sense. The setting contributes to the story by raising the intensity of the situation, making the cyclist's struggle for survival all the more real and desperate.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they started to mess with her mind. She didn't know where she was and on top of that, she got lost. Whether you see nothing around you or a lot around you, you're going to feel scared. They have the same effect. In the author's case, she was cycling and couldn't find any water. This is an overwhelming feeling because you can die from dehydration. She then kept cycling and saw nothing. “No one in sight; not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” That is alarming, having no water or people around, as if you are going to be just left to die. These settings would affect anyone who came across them. They definitely affected the cyclist because she was by herself, all alone on her journey. Plus, all she had was a tattered map, her trusty bike, and an empty water bottle, which made her situation even more dire.

The features of this story tend to affect the cyclist very much. Because he took a shortcut in an attempt to save time, he had an even longer and more difficult journey than before. He found himself in the middle of nowhere, with barely any water left in his bottle. On top of all that, he was utterly exhausted from all the steep hills on the rough terrain. So, because he took a shortcut, it ended up costing him dearly in the long run, as he now faced a much greater struggle to complete his journey and stay alive.

The features of the setting in the essay affected the cyclist because first of all, he listened to old folks that hadn't left their front porch in about ten years. He blindly followed their advice without considering other options. Then he didn't ask someone else's opinion on where to go and how to get there. His worst mistake, though, was not trusting the map he had with him the whole time. If he would have just trusted his map and not gone with what the old fella said, he wouldn't have almost died of heat stroke. In the end, his lack of judgment and trust in the wrong sources put his life in serious danger.

In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects him negatively because he was on his bicycle, pedaling under the scorching sun. He was in a hot, arid area with absolutely no water whatsoever. As seen in this quote, “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar - like substance oozed out.” In the quote, the cyclist finally thinks he has found a water pump but he really gets nothing. Also, another negative thing is that he thought he was never going to get to where he was going, feeling lost and hopeless in the vast expanse. But in the end, he persevered and got there, and he finally got some water, which was a great relief after his long - suffering. This shows how the harsh setting had a significant and initially negative impact on his journey.

The setting in the story affects the main character greatly because of the intense heat. The main character is biking through a vast, desolate desert in the sweltering summer with only a meager supply of water. The searing heat of the setting provides a serious problem because the main character is at high risk of dehydration and heatstroke. The main character knows that if he passes out in the barren desert, where there is no one around to help, he will surely die. The main character says, “The growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.” The main character is faced with a problem of man versus nature and the heat is winning. The blistering heat and the threat of dehydration sap the main character's energy while he is biking through the desert, pedaling desperately trying to make it to the next town. In summary, the main character's biggest problem is undoubtedly the heat of the setting, which makes his journey extremely challenging.

The setting around the cyclist affected him in one main way. “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town’” (Kurmaskie). The cyclist put the word “town” in parentheses because it was actually a Ghost town. There was no one living there; it was completely abandoned. Around the cyclist was a vast expanse of deserts, and more empty, forlorn towns. As the cyclist got farther along, the more we realized the old men were wrong. The cyclist was running low on water and there was nowhere to stop, no place to replenish his supply. He cycled on, growing more and more anxious. Finally, he found some water and vowed to never listen to old men's directions again, having learned a hard - earned lesson from his difficult journey.

All the features of the area have a big affect on the cyclist. It is a hot June morning, and he is on his bike, pedaling hard, covering many miles under the blazing sun. He can't find any water, because all the towns along the road are deserted, their streets empty and buildings dilapidated. He is getting dehydrated, and his strength is gradually ebbing away. It seems like he might have collapsed if he hadn't thought he was going to reach his destination and if he hadn't gotten some water at that store. The thought of reaching his goal kept him going. All in all, the setting seems to have the intention of defeating him, with its lack of resources and unforgiving heat.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road: Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie affects the cyclist in a very negative way. It begins slowly with the “ghost town”. The narrator “chuckled, checked my water supply and moved on”. He wasn't especially worried at that moment, but the fact he checked his water suggests that he'll need to ration it carefully for a while. The decline continues when he reaches the rock and the “ramshackle shed”. From the detailed description of the place, it clearly shows you he did not like it, and he confirms that with the words, “this sight was troubling”. He could tell right away that he would not be replenishing his water here. If this kind of situation continued, he would be in great danger, either from dehydration or from the overwhelming pessimism that the desolate setting brought. Eventually, he reached the road sign which declared that going over 55 mph was a bad idea. This is ironic, as he is only going 12 mph, struggling to move forward. As he put it in his own words, “sometimes life can be so cruel.” He quite obviously hates the setting, and it's all the fault of the harsh, unforgiving setting that made his journey so miserable.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he had a very limited supply of water. He had to pedal harder to get up over the numerous hills, and he was getting severely dehydrated from the intense heat. For example, he had limited water because he had taken the directions from the old men, who perhaps underestimated the journey. As a result, he probably didn't bring as much water as he would have if he had taken a longer way. Furthermore, to get up the rolling hills, he had to pedal faster and with more force. That affected him because he would have been more exhausted from this strenuous pedaling. Moreover, it was a June day, and in June, the days are extremely hot. With the lack of a sufficient amount of water, the cyclist would have started to get dehydrated rapidly. This is how the setting affected the cyclist, significantly impacting his cycling experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For one, his body heat raised a good bit. They don't come out and say it directly, but they do mention, “The sun was beginning to beat down.” We all know that when you're outside on a hot day, your body temperature rises as well. This increase in body heat also probably added to his dehydration. As a long - distance runner, I know from personal experience what the sun can do to you during a hot day. It can make you feel fatigued and cause you to lose a large amount of water through sweating. That is how the setting affects the cyclist, clearly showing the influence of the environmental conditions on his physical state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a major way. For one, if the desert was not a deserted mountainous area in California, with its harsh and arid conditions, then the cyclist would not have the same problems. By changing any one feature of the setting, such as the terrain or the climate, you would change how the cyclist would behave in the setting. Thus changing the entire plot of the story. If the cyclist was, say, in an urban or a more developed area, then he would not face the same dangers as if he were in a mountainous region. In a developed area, he would have easier access to water and assistance. The settings features have a huge affect on the cyclist, determining the challenges and outcomes of his journey.

In the story “Rough Road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting seem negative to the cyclist. The setting seems to start worrying the cyclist two miles after he confidently said that he could make the next @NUM1 miles easily. For example, the cyclist says, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” At that point, the cyclist seems worried that things aren't going to be as easy as they seemed they were going to be. His tone becomes more cautious and concerned. From that point on, the setting seemed to get worse for the cyclist. Later on, the cyclist ends up saying, “It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” That was when the cyclist began to notice his intense fear of dehydration. The cyclist ended up making it through the difficult journey, and he realized what a big effect nature can have on you, both physically and mentally.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by unexpected things happening. His water supply got drank quickly, leaving him parched. He couldn't find a town near, and he was in the desert - like California, where the sun was beating down mercilessly on him. When he did reach one town, it was more of a “ghost town,” with a desolate and abandoned look. It had rusted pumps that had a battery - oil tasting liquid, which was completely undrinkable. Every person he asked told him water was near, but due to dehydration, his movements were sluggish, and it took him longer to reach potential water sources. The roads got windy, making it difficult to maintain balance, and small hills occurred frequently. There was a large snake in the middle of the road, adding to his sense of danger, as the tumbleweed blew by. Finally, he saw a town that had a bait shop and was able to get water and cool down, ending his ordeal in the challenging setting.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit” definitely affected the author. The cyclist states, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (Kurmaskie @NUM1). These sudden changes in the terrain from flat stretches to hilly areas meant that the cyclist probably found it more difficult to navigate through the "hills" as opposed to the "Flat roads," making him more quickly tired. The speaker states, “I could drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie @NUM2). The speaker is implying that it is so swelteringly hot outside that he could faint from a ‘heatstroke’ which could slow him down significantly. The speaker also states, "water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees" (Kurmaskie @NUM3). The author did not have any good water to drink, because it was so hot outside, which affected him in that he was dehydrated. Many aspects of the setting affected the cyclist, ultimately making his journey a challenging one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because if the old men didn't give the boy advice then he probably wouldn't have run into all the trouble he ran into. The advice might have led him astray from his intended path. At the same time, despite the difficulties, the boy made his way to where he was going. However, the experience was terrifying for him. Next time though he will just use his map so he doesn't have to go through the scare of death again, ensuring a safer and more straightforward journey.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist by the road’s condition being rough as the cyclist rides further along the road. The rough surface of the road makes it difficult for the cyclist to maintain a steady speed and balance. Every bump and uneven patch on the road jolts the cyclist, causing discomfort and increasing the risk of an accident. This rough road condition clearly has a negative impact on the cyclist's journey, highlighting the significance of the setting on the cyclist's experience.

The setting of this short story has a big affect on the cyclist. Since the story takes place in the desert, the temperature is extremely hot, with the sun beating down relentlessly. The cyclist only packed enough water for the intended trip. Since he made a few wrong turns, he ended up needing more water than he had planned. There were no signs of civilization so he could not stop anywhere and buy water. He came to a “run-down” rusty fauret and tried to drink water from it, but it was hot and tasted like battery acid, which was of no real help to his dehydration. If this short story had a different setting, then the story would not make much sense. For example, if the story would have taken place in @LOCATION1 he could have just stopped and bought water easily. The setting is one of the most important elements in a story as it shapes the challenges and experiences of the characters.

The features affect the cyclist in many ways. For example the road, the rocks everything close by can pose a threat. The cyclist needs to know everything about where he's going, because if not then he can run into some problems along the way. For example like snakes hiding in the grass, rough terrain that can damage the bike, and rocks in the way that can cause him to lose balance. That's why it's important for a cyclist to never listen to anyone but themselves and rely on their own judgment. That's why when you see cyclists you often see them around a road where there are cars around, just in case they get into trouble and need immediate assistance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they give the story more life, add more meaning, and make it fun to read. This enriches the overall experience for the reader as they can better understand the cyclist's journey within the described environment.

At times when the features of the setting are bad, it can have a great impact on the cyclist. For one, if it’s too hot, the cyclist is going to need plenty of water if he/she doesn't want to be dehydrated. There are also the dangers of heat strokes and deadly snakes, which cyclists might want to avoid. When you're a cyclist, times can be hard, so it's essential to be prepared for the long run to ensure a safe and successful journey.

The setting in the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” really goes against the cyclist and his journey. This is because in the places he goes, there is no water, and if there is, it is really hot or bad water. For example, on page @NUM1 it says, “a tarlike substance oozed out, but the water wouldn't cool down,” which clearly explains how bad the water was when the cyclist was there. This poor water situation significantly hinders the cyclist's progress and well - being during the journey.

During this essay, the author is talking about his journey, sharing details of the experiences, challenges, and discoveries he made along the way. Through his descriptions, the reader can get a sense of the unique aspects of this particular journey and the impact it had on the author.

The features of the setting included nice cool pines and then a ghost town, with it being hot out, the danger of @CAPS1, poisonous snacks, and hills that were getting harder to go up. When he first started, the pines were nice and cool, but when he scanned the ghost town, he got discouraged. Then it started to get hot, and when he saw the snake, he thought that it was a deformed baby and was nervous. Then he was afraid of dehydration, and then the hills started to make it harder and harder. This combination of difficult setting features made his journey a real struggle from start to finish.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he has to use more energy to pedal up the steep hills and navigate through the rough, rocky terrain. As a result, his body works harder and loses more fluids. Therefore, he drank more water to stay hydrated. When he couldn't find any water sources along the way, his situation became quite desperate.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in several ways. The first was the terrain, which started out as a smooth, flat road, then gradually turned to a series of short, rolling hills. The cyclist was steadily growing tired from all the continuous pedaling. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This change in terrain tired him out faster, since going uphill is significantly harder than riding on flat terrain. The intense heat definitely affected him, because it made him extremely thirsty. He was “travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” This is a very hot time of year, and when a person gets lost without conserving water properly, which he had not done, that person gets extremely thirsty. Not to mention the “sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth,” which would constantly remind the body of its thirst. So, overall, the setting most definitely affected the cyclist in a negative way.

In the story, the cyclist is greatly affected by the features of the setting. For example, the setting has nothing but desolate ghost towns for miles on end, which makes it absolutely impossible to find any water. Also, it’s a harsh desert - like setting, with the scorching sun beating down, adding to his intense thirst. Another example is the numerous hills that he had to pedal up, which made him even more parched. It was June in California, so it must have been pretty swelteringly hot. Moreover, the town that he arrived at had no water because it seemed completely deserted. Another example is the salt that he put under his tongue. It’s a simple yet effective trick that lets you survive a lot more effectively in such conditions. Therefore, the settings affected his journey significantly and made him wish he hadn’t taken the old man’s advice as it led him into this difficult situation.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. Three key features I found were the lack of water, the intense heat, and the poor conditions and limits of the road. The lack of water really affected the cyclist. When he was dead - tired, he didn't have anything to drink. The essay stated how he/she would say they would save the water until the end. But he/she was so exhausted that the lack of water really took a toll on him/her. The conditions he/she was in really affected the cyclist also. From the very beginning, he/she was given the wrong directions. That was the main reason why he/she was lost throughout the entire journey. Finally, the limits of the road affected the cyclist. The steep hills and uneven different grounds did not help the cyclist at all. In conclusion, the cyclist had many factors affecting him such as the lack of water, the limits of the road, and his/her difficult conditions, which made his journey extremely challenging.

I think that the features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. First, I think the harsh weather conditions affect him severely. I think this because in the passage it says, “I could drop from heatstroke.” Meaning, it's really swelteringly hot! The high temperature makes it difficult for him to keep going. Also, I think the fact that he has no water left is affecting him badly because it says in the passage, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This has a big impact on him, because he's very thirsty and his body is not functioning properly. Also, I think the fact that there is nothing around him is affecting him mentally. I think this because in the passage it says there were no cars, which means no help or signs of civilization. I think all these things combined affect him to the point where his journey becomes extremely difficult and his well - being is at risk.

In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the desolate and harsh setting significantly affects the cyclist. The cyclist, seeking guidance, takes advice from some old guys at a small roadside stop, and soon ends up wishing he never did. He finds himself on an empty, flat, and dry road stretching as far as the eye can see. As he pedals steadily, he consumes all of the water he has in his bottles, and soon realizes he desperately needs to stop for more. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” he laments. He stops at an old rusted pump to get more water, but once, all that comes out is some tar - like stuff, leaving a foul taste in his mouth. Then, he can't find another place to refill for quite a while. The flat road gradually gives way to short, rolling hills, and he comes across a sign that says “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit”. Along the way, he passes tumbleweeds that seem to dance in the hot wind and a large, menacing snake coiled on the side of the road. All of these things impact his journey, filling him with fear and forcing him to exercise caution. When he finally reaches a small diner with a working water tap, he is finally satisfied. Because it is swelteringly hot and the landscape is empty, he is more thirsty, clearly showing that the setting affected the cyclist and made his journey a challenging one.

He feels utterly alone as there is no one around him to offer a push or a word of encouragement. Yet, he keeps going, gritting his teeth and trying to push himself to the very end with the sole aim of winning. The fast - paced roads are not only rough but also full of small potholes that jolt his bike with every turn. The hills he encounters are tall and steep, their slopes seemingly endless. But he is a man of determination, his resolve unwavering. Despite the physical and mental challenges, he continues his arduous journey, knowing that the finish line will bring the sweet taste of victory. In the end, his determination keeps him in the race, driving him forward until he crosses that long - awaited finish line.

Heat, the desolation of abandoned roads, and the presence of snakes are all significant reasons that affected the cyclist's journey. The intense heat in the arid landscape made him get dehydrated at a much faster rate while he was expending energy on the bike. The long, empty, and abandoned roads seemed to stretch into infinity, further increasing his doubt about surviving the whole bike ride. With each passing mile, his anxiety grew as he realized how isolated he was. He used up all of his water in no time. So, when he finally reached an old pump, hot and dirty water with a strange, metallic smell came out. The snake in the story, a large and venomous - looking one, slithered across his path, making the journey for this guy perilous and deadly. This entire series of unfortunate events happened because he listened to the old guys at a small rest stop. When another old guy was about to tell him where to go, he arrogantly said no, sealing his fate with a difficult and dangerous journey. In conclusion, his choice to follow the advice of some and ignore others, combined with the harsh setting, made his bike ride a nightmare.

The features and the setting affect the cyclist a great deal. One crucial reason is that he was in the vast desert. As seen in the quote “through high deserts of California,” this indicates that it was extremely hot, with the sun beating down mercilessly. In such conditions, he could easily pass out from a heat stroke, a very real and terrifying possibility. Then, to make matters worse, he could not even get any clean water. As described in the quote “of the rusted water pump,” it was a clear indication of how old and dilapidated it was. When the cyclist managed to get some water out, it tasted like old battery acid, a foul and unpleasant flavor that made him gag. The heat of the desert, the lack of clean water, and the dilapidated infrastructure all contributed to a difficult and dangerous situation for the cyclist. Therefore, the features and setting clearly affected the cyclist, turning his journey into a battle for survival.

The features of the setting intensely affect the cyclist over a period of time. Destined to reach Yosemite National Park from Lodi, California, a determined cyclist rode strongly through the gentle evening, the cool breeze caressing his face. His initial journey was smooth, his legs pumping rhythmically as he made good progress. However, when the setting changed, so did the effect it had on the cyclist. When the man reached the first town, which was completely deserted, with boarded - up shops and empty streets, his energy began depleting rapidly because the sun began to come into the picture, its harsh rays beating down on him. Next, he came to a shed, his throat parched and his body desperate for water. Only to find rusty pumps with water that was clearly tainted and unsafe, a murky liquid that he dared not drink. When the flat terrain gradually turned to rolling hills, the man was entirely exhausted. “With what I believed to be my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill,” he wrote. That quote directly describes what the man was feeling and how the hills affected him, sapping his remaining strength. When the man stumbled across a fish camp with a clean water source, he became reloaded and replenished with the confidence he had before when he “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile”. The changing setting, with its various challenges, had a profound impact on the cyclist's journey, but his encounter with the fish camp gave him a new lease on his quest to reach Yosemite.

The setting affected the cyclist in many ways. For example, he was riding in the vast, arid desert where all the towns he was going to were completely abandoned, with dilapidated buildings and empty streets. The month was June, a notoriously hot month, and the intense sun was beating down mercilessly on him. And he was cycling with very little water, just a meager bottle that was quickly running out. With the lack of water and the scorching heat, his journey became extremely challenging, but he still pressed on, hoping to reach a better place.

In the essay “Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit”, the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. When the cyclist arrived at the first town, he described it as a desolate ghost town with broken windows and overgrown weeds. This affected the cyclist because he started to have serious doubts about the directions he received, but he was eagerly looking forward to the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite, so he mustered the determination to persevere. The setting of the next landmark was similar to the last. There was a dilapidated shed, a few rusty pipes that were barely holding together, and a corral that “Couldn’t hold in the lamest mule.” This made the cyclist more wary of the path ahead because he was running critically low on water. The next place was also similar. There was an abandoned @ORGANIZATION1 with faded signs and a crumbling facade. The cyclist was running out of water and now thought he was going to die because everything was deserted. Then, finally, the setting changed. There was a store that was actually opened, with a welcoming sign and a few customers inside. The cyclist then felt a wave of happiness and relief wash over him. That is how the different settings affected the cyclist.

The author’s setting described a difficult terrain and harsh weather for bike riding. The author said that it was early summer, which means it could be hot and sweltering weather for the cyclist. The author also mentioned that when the cyclist reached the first town, the sun began to bear down intensely. That means the temperature is going to rise significantly since the sun is getting stronger. Riding a bike in hot weather is very difficult because it takes a great deal of effort and makes your body dehydrate faster because the heat makes you sweat profusely, which lowers your water retention rapidly. Another feature of the setting that the author described was the cyclist’s location. He was traveling through the high deserts of California, where the sand was hot under the wheels and the air was dry. This gives you a sense of how much hotter it is since he’s traveling through deserts during early summer while the sun is high. After the first couple of towns, he starts to ride on short, rolling hills that seemed to go on forever. Hills take a bigger toll on a person’s body because it takes more effort to pedal up a hill, and his legs were starting to ache with each push. Overall, the setting made the cyclist's journey an arduous one.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly. From the desolate ghost town to the small bait shop, it was all a formidable challenge for him. A misleading challenge, but a challenge nonetheless. In the desert, where the sand stretched as far as the eye could see, water grew scarce and he tried everything to push himself forward. From staring intently at the distant horizon to get from one place to another, to sucking on a smooth pebble stone to not focus on his parching thirst. And when he arrived at the bait shop, a wave of relief washed over him, like that shop was his safe haven in the vast expanse of the desert. But yet he would never get directions from any old - timer again. Luck was not a factor in this story. Rather it was his inner drive and the overall harsh climate of the story. When it was still two - hundred degrees of heat left and no water left in his bottles, he pushed himself towards the glimmer of hope. And also when he saw a building in the distance, he was determined to get to it, knowing it might be his salvation. In the end, his perseverance through the tough setting was truly remarkable.

The cyclist was trying to make it to Yosemite National Park. The cyclist was in Lodi, California when he decided to ask for directions from old codgers sitting on a bench outside a store so that he could take a short cut. He followed their directions and little did he know that he should have stuck to his original directions. The cyclist was traveling through the high deserts of California in June, where the heat was almost unbearable. The cyclist became very hot and extremely thirsty from traveling in the desert. It says in the text “when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid” This shows that he had no clean water left to keep him hydrated throughout his travel. His throat was dry and scratchy, and his lips were chapped. Also in the text it says “with what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill” this shows that he had no energy left, his legs were like lead, and he was barely able to keep his balance on the bike. Despite these hardships, he still held onto the hope of reaching Yosemite.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, he traverses all sorts of settings where the situation could either improve or deteriorate. “I noticed the terrain changing; flat roads were replaced with short rolling hills” (Kurmaskie). This clearly shows that the going is about to get a bit more arduous as he will now have to pedal uphill, and to make matters worse, he is almost out of water. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or any kind of structure” (Kurmaskie). This indicates that the cyclist cannot obtain water or a ride from anywhere nearby because there is simply nothing in the vicinity. These are the ways in which the setting features have an impact on the cyclist, ultimately affecting his journey and his ability to continue.

Almost all the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. For instance, the sweltering heat causes him to consume a large amount of water and constantly be in need of more. In the story, it elaborately describes how extremely thirsty and sweaty he is. “The water bottles contain only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of sweat circled my shirt.” These vivid descriptions strongly suggest that he is extremely hot as he is sweating profusely and has been drinking so much. Another prominent feature of the setting is the numerous rolling hills that make him feel as if he will never reach the next town. “I began breaking the ride down into distances I could make it tests for.” He is essentially dividing the long ride into a series of short rides so that he can mentally and physically endure it. In conclusion, the setting features, such as the heat and the hills, have a profound and negative impact on the cyclist's journey.

The setting described by the author was extremely challenging for three main reasons: distance, water, and the heat. All of these factors only served to multiply the effects of one another. As time passed, the cyclist gradually grew exhausted from the scorching heat. In one particular sentence, the cyclist clearly described the severe effect of the heat. The long distance he had to cover made him more and more fatigued, and the lack of water exacerbated his situation. The heat, on top of everything, made his journey even more unbearable. In summary, the combination of these three factors in the setting made the cyclist's experience extremely difficult and challenging.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The scenery gradually makes the cyclist turn worried, unconfident, and ultimately, in an ironic twist, hopeful. When the cyclist first came upon the so - called “town,” he described it as having only “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral.” I firmly believe this is the moment when the cyclist realized things were not as expected and began to worry. Moreover, since he couldn't refill his water supply, the fear of dehydration also set in. Already tired from the journey, the cyclist became unconfident when he saw the sign reading, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” Knowing that this would be a long and slow journey, the cyclist started to doubt his ability to make it. Finally, when passing the sign saying, "Gary and Wilber's fish camp – If you want bait for the big ones, we’ve your best bet," the cyclist reached a hopeful stage because he knew he had finally found civilization again. This clearly shows that one's atmosphere and surroundings can indeed have a significant impact on their general mood, just as it did with the cyclist.

The way the features of the setting affect the cyclist is by either making the ride effortless for him or extremely tough. In the essay, it mentions “No Town,” and without a town, there is no access to water. The lack of water can easily lead to dehydration, which is a serious threat to the cyclist's well - being. It also states that the flat roads gradually turned into “short, rolling hills.” This implies that the path ahead became more difficult, making it hard for the cyclist to stay focused on his ride. These are prime examples of how the setting can have a direct and substantial impact on the cyclist. In conclusion, the setting features play a crucial role in determining the ease or difficulty of the cyclist's journey.

The setting affects the cyclist because the path is on a road with many hills. These numerous hills make the cyclist tired as he has to pedal harder to ascend them. Also, if the cyclist is in a place with extremely cold or hot weather, it would affect his body temperature and attitude. In cold conditions, he might shiver and lose dexterity, while in hot weather, he could become overly fatigued and irritable. This shows how the setting can significantly impact the cyclist's physical and mental state.

The settings in this article affect the cyclist by forcing him to bike a long distance, perhaps 50 miles or more, to get to the next town. There's nothing in sight for miles and miles, no shade, no signs of civilization. This desolate and harsh setting makes the cyclist's journey extremely challenging and exhausting.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in that he shows his frustration to other people. He shouldn't reveal to others where he has to go because it might put him in an uncomfortable situation. By sharing his destination, he could attract unwanted attention or face potential risks. In the end, keeping his route private would be a wiser choice for the cyclist.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” many features of the setting affected the cyclist. And these settings could be easily identified in the middle part of the essay. These settings caused the cyclist to become exhausted on his journey. First, the cyclist noticed a road change from flat to short, rolling hills. He had to exert more energy to pedal up the hills, which gradually depleted a certain amount of his energy reserves. Then, his lack of water, perhaps having only a few sips left in his bottle, caused him to enter a dehydrated state. He could lose another large amount of energy due to this. Out of this stage, he mostly needed someone to support him or be by his side, but he was riding alone. There was no one in sight, not a single building, car, or structure of any kind. The setting affects the cyclist because it can provide clear landmarks and precise directions. These landmarks, such as a distinctive old tree or a unique rock formation, can serve as reliable guides for the cyclist during his journey. In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed posted speed limit”, the cyclist encounters some very rough obstacles on his arduous journey to Yosemite National Park. With his lack of water and the intense dryness, he runs into a big snake that he thinks is a diamond black. He calmly and easily passes the snake and then moves on. Being in the intense heat and having no water, he never gives up and firmly knows he can make it to the park safely. The reason why he goes this way is because of those “old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in the office”. These guys gave him wrong directions. In the end, his determination will hopefully see him through to his destination.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist on different occasions in different ways. For instance, when arriving at the first town, the author calls it an average ghost town. Despite the desolate appearance, he continues on with unwavering confidence. The next building he saw was an abandoned Welch’s Juice bottle factory. On the building was a sign with a boy drinking a cold glass of juice. This sight intimidates the reader and makes the cyclist begin to question the wisdom of the old men. Continuing on his journey, he reaches another building. To his great relief, it’s a bolt shop that was still in business. He quickly goes to the sink immediately to drink the water. At this point, he is relieved to have water and to be near civilization instead of being in the dessert without a sight of life or a building. Therefore, his surroundings throughout the story make him feel indifferent at times, confident at others, and finally relieved, which all contribute to the overall experience of his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the roads are rough and uneven. He has to push out more energy to pedal his bike on these rough, uneven roads than on nice, paved, even roads. Moreover, he is out of water. So, he is using all his energy without any means of refreshment. This lack of water and the difficult road conditions put a great strain on the cyclist. As a result, his progress is slower and he has to work much harder to keep going. In the end, these factors clearly show how the setting can have a significant impact on the cyclist's journey.

The setting's effect on a cyclist can be pretty complicated. So many things have to be prepared for you to be a successful cyclist. First up, you have to be prepared for the weather. For example, when there are serious weather conditions like rain or snow, you have to be careful of slippery roads. Also, what they have to be prepared for are long rides. Some rides might be from @NUM1 miles, so they have to bring plenty of food and water to sustain themselves. Another factor that a cyclist has to face is the condition of the bike. For instance, he/she has to make sure the bikes are in good condition and will cooperate smoothly. Also, if work needs to be done to the bike, then it can be worked on promptly. Another effect on a cyclist is whether the cyclist is in shape. For instance, if the cyclist is in good shape, he/she is able to ride for a long period of time without getting overly fatigued. Finally, another important aspect is that the cyclist has to know where he/she is going. For instance, the man in the story didn't know where to go, so that's an important keypoint. Overall, all these aspects need to be considered for a successful cycling journey.

The setting of where a cyclist takes their journey significantly affects the cyclist. The sweltering heat made his journey extremely difficult, and his lack of proper preparation due to the setting added to his struggles. The setting in the short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed speed Limit” greatly affects the cyclist. The rough, uneven terrain and the blazing, unforgiving sun test him and make him suffer in ways he never imagined. At one point, after the cyclist has been going for hours on end, he notes, “Over on long crippling hill, a building came into view.
