The cyclist is well - aware of the dangers of the setting around him. As you can see, the setting has a very strong impact on the cyclist, influencing his physical and mental state throughout the journey.

The cyclist was affected by long hours of strenuous bike - riding into the unfamiliar areas where he had never been before. The unfamiliarity of the roads, the changing landscapes, and the lack of known landmarks all took a toll on him. As he continued, fatigue set in, and he began to question his ability to keep going. In conclusion, the long - distance ride into uncharted areas had a significant impact on the cyclist, both physically and mentally.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist is affected by the setting mentally and physically. For example, the setting affected the cyclist mentally because it was all arid desert and shifting sand with no sign of water. He was filled with despair and thought he was going to die, saying, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” If he had some water to quench his thirst, he would not have had such dire thoughts. Also, the cyclist was affected physically because the rough, bumpy road seemed as if it could go on forever. He was gradually losing energy and was getting extremely tired from riding up all the steep hills with little water left in his parched body. It was swelteringly hot, and the situation seemed hopeless. But if he was riding through the lush evergreen forest, with its cool shade and possible water sources, I don't think he would have felt this way. In conclusion, the cyclist was affected by the setting physically and mentally. If he had not been riding in the desert, he would not have endured such distress.

In the essay, “Rough Road ahead” the character sees many settings through his ride, all of which affect his mood and physical condition. For example, when the author describes one place he came to as, “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mute greeted me. This sight was troubling,” this was the turning point where the cyclist began to worry deeply. He was running out of water, “The sun was beginning to beat down mercilessly,” and he was probably exhausted from hours of pedaling. But, to make matters worse, he came to a series of rolling hills. This affected him because he had to exert more energy and had less water to rejuvenate himself. When he finally got to a “modernized” town with its proper amenities, his spirits were lifted, and he was able to get water to cool his overheated body down. This gave him more strength and will - power to continue his trip to Yosemite park, showing how settings can have a profound impact on his journey.

The setting of the story has a huge affect because it was such an empty, desolate terrain that made him rely on only himself because of the lack of other people to help. For example, if he was riding through a bustling city for hours, he could easily stop and take a well - deserved break in a store or get water from about anywhere. But being in the vast, silent desert, it really tested his inner strength to keep going and reach safety. The isolation and the harsh conditions forced him to dig deep within himself and find the determination to overcome the challenges. In conclusion, the desolate desert setting had a profound impact on the cyclist, highlighting the importance of self - reliance in difficult situations.

In the essay, I can conclude that there were numerous features of the land that had a significant impact on the cyclist. For example, in the text it states “ridiculously large snake…blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” If you have an intense fear of snakes, this could completely ruin your entire trip. The cyclist was initially scared but managed to overcome the fear and continue moving forward. Also, another factor that affected the cyclist was the shortage of water. Not having an adequate supply of water can be extremely detrimental. As stated “I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” There are indeed many features that affected the cyclist and his journey, highlighting how the land's elements can pose challenges during travel.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s, “Rough Road Ahead Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” there are several notable features that impact the cyclist. “...and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie). Deserts in June are notoriously extremely hot and dry, which caused the cyclist to become dehydrated at a rapid pace. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” The transition from flat lands to hilly terrain made the ride far more strenuous on the cyclist, requiring more effort and energy. These conditions directly affect the cyclist, making the journey more difficult and challenging.

The cyclist was attempting to reach Yosemite National Park. He was riding through the deserts in June, a time when the heat is intense. By the end of the journey on the stony path, the cyclist barely had any water left. To make matters worse, when he desperately needed water, a large number of buildings in the area were abandoned, offering no source of relief. This clearly shows how the setting, with its harsh climate and lack of resources, had a negative impact on him, demonstrating the challenges one can face due to the environment during a journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead” the setting does have a profound effect on the cyclist. He has been pedaling for an extended period, and as a result, he is becoming severely dehydrated. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly. I was in the @LOCATION1.” The long - distance pedaling in the particular setting is taking a toll on his water supply. Another reason the setting affects him is that he is starting to see mirages. “A sandblasted picture of a boy pouring a refreshing glass of grape juice into his mouth could still be seen.” These mirages are a sign of his deteriorating physical state due to the harsh setting, emphasizing how the environment can impact a cyclist's well - being.

The features such as insufficient water and a poor sense of direction have a significant impact on the cyclist. He needs water to maintain the energy required for continuous pedaling. He also needs maps to accurately determine the direction and know where he is going. Due to the lack of water, he said “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a lost entry in place of old men, their wisdom, and their sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph.” This statement implies that the old man’s sense of direction was outdated. They seemed to be in a large porch but had no idea where anything was located. These features clearly hinder the cyclist's progress and well - being during his journey.

The features of the setting are that it is extremely hot and parched. The way that it affects the cyclist is that he gets swelteringly hot and he drinks almost all of his water rapidly. He only has about @NUM1 sips left when he finally reaches the other town. It also affects him because he had a minor advantage. The advantage that he had was he left well before the sun came up. So then he had a brief time to stay cool. Another part of the setting that affects the cyclist is when he ascends some of the hills, he gets a little bit of the wind on his face. Also, when the cyclist was desperately thirsty he put pebbles into his mouth to moisten his dry throat. This challenging setting truly tested the cyclist's endurance.

Setting plays a crucial part in the cyclist's mood and energy. For example, on a pleasantly cool @DATE1 day, while riding gently downhill with a light breeze, the rider is visibly happy and full of energy. However, “traveling through the high deserts of California in June is not the best environment for laughs and ease.” The cyclist in the story was extremely hot, completely exhausted, and struggling to stay hydrated. He thought, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” The harshness of the desert sun and the lack of comfort in such a setting clearly took a toll on him. Where the cyclist rides can have a huge effect on the cyclist himself, as these two scenarios vividly demonstrate.

The cyclist was riding his bike steadily, with the goal of reaching Yosemite. He was well - aware that he had a lack of water, but he decided to press on anyway. As he continued his journey, he had to go past a large snake lying in the middle of the path. The sudden sight of the snake made him jump in fear and his heart raced. Despite this scare, he managed to compose himself and kept pedaling towards his destination, showing his determination in the face of difficulties.

All the features of the settings, such as the uneven terrain, the strong winds, and the changing weather, affect his rhythm, determination, and will to win. It sets him off his goal a little bit when he should just try to ignore these distractions the best as he can, instead of dwelling on them. If I was him, I would just focus on riding my bike and keep thinking about the sweet taste of victory! By not letting the setting get to him, he can stay on track and increase his chances of achieving his goal.

To a cyclist, the surrounding setting can either cause triumph or despair. The cyclist was unfortunately given very old and inaccurate directions. He was directed to back roads that are now completely abandoned. These towns usually had no people in them, and under normal circumstances, that would not matter. But he “was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” (@NUM1). If there was shade to protect him from the scorching sun, a refreshing breeze to cool him down, and @NUM2 mild weather, he would be fine. However, he is pedaling a bike in a blistering desert during the summer. A “ghost town” with no access to good water could have easily killed him. A cyclist needs to know their surroundings thoroughly and be well - prepared for what nature throws at them to avoid such life - threatening situations.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. First of all, when the cyclist came across the “ghost town,” he felt utterly alone and deeply discouraged. The desolate streets and empty buildings around him made him feel like he was in a forgotten place. He felt like he was never going to find his way and there was no one there to offer him even a shred of help. Also, the long hilly highway with nothing but arid desert on either side basically gave him the discouraging feeling that this endless road was never going to end and there was no way out of the situation he had started. The heat from the sun beating down on him made the journey even more torturous. The dry air and lack of shade made it seem like the desert was sucking the life out of him. It was so dry that there was no water in sight, and it made him feel so much thirstier than he actually was. Overall, it had really significant physical and psychological effects on him, wearing him down both physically and mentally.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist runs into a couple of tough obstacles and they affected him in many ways. All throughout the story, he ran into many problems or obstacles but overcame them very well, showing his remarkable determination and resilience.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist. Some of these features include: the intense heat, dangerous animals, the lack of much civilization, and the challenging terrain. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. First, the intense heat made the cyclist overheated. For instance, the weather was sunny in June, with the sun shining brightly and the temperature soaring. The heat radiated from the ground, making the air around him feel like an oven. For instance, the cyclist had trouble finding a place with water to drink, and his throat was parched. Features of the setting affect the cyclist in the way that it is so hot that he is quickly becoming dehydrated. The sun is shining brightly, and the heat is almost unbearable. The dry air is sucking the moisture out of his body, and he can feel his throat getting drier with each passing minute. Another feature is that all the buildings seem to be either abandoned or in despair. The cyclist was on a bike and couldn't really protect himself, and he was dehydrated and tired, making his situation extremely difficult.

Throughout his journey, the protagonist in the story encounters obstacles in the setting. First off, he is cycling in the hot, dry, desert. There is no civilization or natural water source, so he faces dehydration as his body loses water rapidly in the scorching heat. Additionally, the terrain he was riding on proved difficult. He encountered rolling hills that took a lot of energy to ride up. There were even signs for ìrough road aheadî. Another obstacle was a mental obstacle. He came across an abandoned juice factory when he needed an occupied building. These were ironic and mentally frustrating. The cyclist must have lost hope in [CAPS2] civilization after he found [NUM1] abandoned examples of civilization. This discouragement must have made his journey more mentally challenging, adding an extra layer of difficulty to his already arduous cycling trip.

The features in the setting would significantly affect the cyclist because they would strongly desire towns with accessible water sources so they can restock their water supply. They would want water even more after strenuously going up hills. They would also want a proper place to get something to eat and maybe take a short rest to regain their energy. This shows how the setting's features play a crucial role in the cyclist's journey.

The feature of the setting affects the cyclist because of the intense heat and the lack of available water. Also, the roughness of the road ahead was a major concern. Another problem was the dry air that made breathing difficult and the snakes laying out everywhere in the desert, which added to the cyclist's fear. Also, the hills were a big problem too because of the heat and the lack of water. Finally, the other problem was that he knew he was going to die and the birds would peck at him and there would be nothing left of him. This is how the harsh setting affected the cyclist and put his life at risk.

The hot, dry, desert setting affects the cyclist in many different ways, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (@NUM1). The cyclist is extremely hot, feeling the scorching sun on his back. He was thirsty but, “A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of 100 degrees” (@NUM2). The water was barely even drinkable, so he didn't have much to drink until the next town. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (@NUM3). Flat road is much easier to bike on than hills. He was thirstier and more tired after biking on hills. “A sand - blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth could still be seen” (@NUM4) on an old Welch's grapefruit factory. This makes the cyclist envious of the young boy. It also discourages him. In conclusion, the water being bad, the terrain change, the picture of the young boy, and the fact that the cyclist drinks a lot makes him tired, hot, envious, and generally exhausted, making his desert cycling trip a real struggle.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because when he has an ample supply of water and plenty of it, the setting seems to be smooth, easy riding. This means that he doesn't have to use much water, but he still uses some because anyone that rides @NUM1 miles on a bike will need plenty of water no matter what the terrain is like. The features of the setting affect the cyclist toward the middle and end of his trip greatly because it gets rough and hilly and so he needs more water that he doesn't have. And since he was planning on being able to get water at the first stop he didn't conserve it as well, so this left less water for him to have when he really needed it. He then became dehydrated after his first stop, and he didn't get any more water there so it caused him to dehydrate further. So it seems that the features of the setting affect the cyclist because when he has plenty of water and doesn't really need it the terrain is smooth and easy to ride but as he drinks his water the terrain gets rougher and worse. So the features of the setting affects him greatly in that they don't help him; they just get worse when he needs it to get better, ultimately making his cycling journey a challenging and potentially dangerous one.

There are many ways that the features affect the cyclist. One is that he is already extremely scared to go up this really big hill. Another is that as he is going up this big hill, it's swelteringly hot, there are snakes around, he's scared and completely tired. Almost all of his energy is gone. He just wants to stop, yet he is determined to go up this hill. He also knows that it can't be that bad because he can just relax all the way back down, which gives him a glimmer of hope to keep pushing forward despite the difficult situation.

After reading, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” I noticed that the setting of this adventure significantly affected the narrator. First of all, the intense heat in the desert environment caused the narrator to be extremely uncomfortable and thirstier by the minute. While on the move, he refers to the trip as a “water - depleting” one. This quote clearly shows that he was severely lacking water, and this water shortage was a major and pressing problem. Also, the description of the road as “rolling hills” gives the reader a sense that these hills seem to go on without end. The never - ending nature of these hills lowers the narrator’s hope of reaching his destination quickly. Moreover, the vast and desolate desert gives the author a feeling of despair and low hope of ever reaching his goal. In conclusion, the setting affects the narrator both physically, through the heat and lack of water, and mentally, by diminishing his hope and determination.

The setting of the story had a profound impact on the cyclist as it played a crucial role in keeping him going, mainly because he was all alone and had no external help. First, the mere fact that he was by himself on this arduous journey kept his determination at a high level. If he would have had a partner, they could have easily stopped and taken a well - deserved break or shared the limited supply of water, which might have weakened his resolve. Next, the complete absence of buildings, houses, or any signs of civilization in sight affected him deeply. He got a sudden bolt of strength just from the distant sight of a building ahead. If there had been buildings along the way, he could have stopped and asked for more water and taken a rest. The fact that he was in a desert in California in the middle of June, when the sun beats down mercilessly, really affected him. He had no determination there because there was absolutely nothing he could do to improve the dire situation. He even at one point felt that he might die due to the harsh conditions. In conclusion, the setting really affected the cyclist because it was the determining factor for his endurance and will power.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. For example, he approached the older folks who, as he described, “haven't left their porches since Carter was in the office,” to ask where the next place to get water was. This shows how desperate he was for water. Also, he was out in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by vast emptiness with no immediate help in sight. It was also in June, a month when the weather is warm and the sun shines brightly. With the warm weather, his body was losing water rapidly, and he didn't have a lot of water to begin with. All these factors combined made his journey extremely difficult. In conclusion, the setting features severely hampered the cyclist's ability to have a smooth and comfortable ride.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. First, he was in the “high desert of California in June.” This particular setting affected him in numerous ways. The scorching heat of the desert sun made him become very dehydrated. He had to be extremely careful with his limited water supply and resorted to chewing on pebbles to get any spit to collect in his dry mouth. Also, the road became very rough as he moved through the desert terrain. The new, uneven terrain made him have to push himself harder with each pedal stroke, causing him to lose energy at a much quicker rate. The last feature, the long distance he had to cover, added to his troubles. He had to travel a lot further than he had originally planned to. This unforeseen distance again affected his energy levels and spirits, filling his mind with thoughts of possible death and the fear of not being able to make it. In conclusion, these features of the setting had a detrimental impact on the cyclist's physical and mental state during his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. Since the cyclist was in the middle of nowhere, far from any sources of water, he was in a desperate situation. He couldn't get any water to quench his growing thirst. “I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst,” he said, indicating that he was so thirsty that he had to resort to such an unusual method. The intense thirst drained him of energy, and he barely had the strength to keep going. “The growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke,” he thought. It was extremely hot out, and with no water to cool his body, this heatstroke threat severely affected his energy. The lack of water and the sweltering heat in the desolate setting made it a struggle for the cyclist to continue his journey. In conclusion, the setting features were a major obstacle for the cyclist, sapping his energy and putting his life at risk.

The features of setting significantly affect the cyclist. The harsh terrain, with its uneven ground and rocky patches, proved a formidable challenge, especially when his water supply was running critically low. All the towns along his route had been abandoned, leaving him with no option to refill his water bottles. The sweltering heat was also a major factor, quickly sapping his energy and making him feel weary and extremely tired. On the long bike ride, he had a glimmer of hope when he spotted an old water pump. However, his hopes were quickly dashed when he took a sip of the hot liquid, which tasted horribly of battery acid. The unforgiving setting set the stage for the conflict and effectively helped achieve the tone the author was aiming for, having a profound impact on the cyclist.

The settings have a notable effect on the cyclist, primarily due to the roughness of the ride. First, as they pedal along, they have to go over a large bunch of sharp and jagged rocks. This poses a real risk as the tire could easily puncture at any moment. Next, the terrain could suddenly become smooth and easy, providing a brief respite. Also, the cyclist might find themselves far away from towns, making it difficult to get back in case of an emergency. There could be a severe lack of water sources in the area, gradually making the cyclist dehydrate. In conclusion, these aspects of the setting around the cyclist can have a significant and sometimes dangerous impact on him.

The setting described in the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” would undoubtedly be a nightmare for any biker. This biker is riding in the middle of a vast and arid desert on a scorching summer’s day. The sweat is steadily dropping down his body, and this is just speeding up his dehydration at an alarming rate. This is clearly shown when the narration states, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie). This vividly portrays how incredibly hot the desert was, and how he was at real risk of dropping dead from the heat. The desert is also completely deserted, with rolling tumbleweeds and giant snakes slithering around. As he rides along, he passes by numerous abandoned towns and factories. The level of dangerousness for a biker in this desolate area is very high. In the end, the biker was truly lucky to have made it out of those perilous surroundings alive.

The desert area of California was rapidly making him dehydrated. The trip was quite long, but he had initially thought he had enough water to get him there, only if he took the route shown on the maps. A group of old men, who “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” gave him advice about a shortcut. He, unfortunately, followed their advice and ended up in a life - threatening situation. He almost died due to heat stroke and severe dehydration. If the cyclist would have stuck to following the map, he could have easily stopped off at a store for more water if the setting became too harsh. In conclusion, the wrong advice in this unforgiving desert setting nearly cost him his life.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many significant ways. The setting was a dry and desolate California desert. If it had been a bustling city, the events in the story would have never happened. The author, in his eagerness, asked a group of old men for directions to Yosemite National Park. And, “like a foolish youth,” he blindly followed their advice. Everything started out fine at first, with the sun shining and the road seemingly clear. However, things took a turn for the worse when he reached the second town. He was almost completely dehydrated, and “in an ironic twist,” he reached an abandoned grape juice factory. Almost all hope was lost for him as he struggled to stay conscious. But then, he rounded the bend and came across his new hope: “Gary and Wilber’s Fish camp - if you won’t bait for the big ones, we’re your best bet.” In the end, he learned a valuable lesson to stick to a map instead of relying on old people who “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.”

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because first he realized that getting advice from people who no longer drive or even leave their porches would be useless. When the author says “old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” that's what he is explaining. He then says “I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face”; he was referring back to how he's on the road alone, riding the bike, and there isn't a car in sight anywhere around. The curbs of the turns were so sharp that only a bicycle could make them as safely as he did. “He whipped the sweat from his eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage and tried not to get too excited.” In this situation, being on a long, lonely cycle by himself would have made many people excited. This solitude and the unique challenges of the setting truly shaped the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making his way to the Yosemite National Park a longer, more difficult, and dangerous way to go. He takes the advice of going that way from some old folks that he says “haven’t gotten off their porches since Carter was in office.” I think that there would be a reason to not listen to them, though they might have wisdom. Their limited experience of the outside world in recent times could mean their advice isn't fully applicable to the current situation. Still, the cyclist's choice to follow their advice will likely impact his journey to the park.

In the setting, there are no cars and no buildings, meaning there is no help readily available. The cyclist is tired and dehydrated because he ran out of water. No one was around because it was the desert. The cyclist, despite being dehydrated, kept going towards his destination. The road was straight, but almost at the end, there were many hills. Along with having to bike up the hills, he almost ran into a snake. The weather was hot, he had no water, and he could have died. However, his determination kept him going, and he managed to persevere through these tough conditions.

The features in the setting in the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affect the biker. For example, the heat is constantly drying the biker out. Also, at the first town, the old water pump proved to be a hopeless cause, with the water tasting like “battery acid.” Even after that, there were more problems. There was a sign that posted a max speed limit, and the biker was doing about one - fifth of that speed. This affects his mood, and he realizes that it will be a long ride. The pebbles that he found help him out. He remembers reading that sticking pebbles in your mouth calms your thirst. Finally, the bait store gave him the relief that he needed at the end of his trip. In conclusion, the setting makes the rider's journey a challenging one, but in the end, the bait store had just what he needed to overcome the hardships of the journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist. For example, there were no towns close by. One reason this affected the cyclist is because if the towns were near each other, if he ran out of water, there would be stores close by. In addition, he could have a heatstroke, and there would be no one around to get help from, and he could easily die. In my point of view of the reading, I believe where he was located is what affected him mostly. The isolation due to the lack of nearby towns put the cyclist in a vulnerable position, greatly influencing his cycling experience.

The hot weather is steadily dehydrating the cyclist, who desperately can't find more water to quench his thirst. The hills with their rough terrain are continuously draining the energy he has left in his body. The heat is so intense that he has to break the road down into small points he wants to reach. He gets drained physically as his muscles ache and emotionally as his spirits dampen. He has a truly hard journey ahead, but he keeps pushing on, hoping to find relief soon.

The features of the setting, such as the intense sun and lack of water sources, significantly affect the cyclist in terms of whether he is hydrated or not. On the posts with the warning “Do not exceed posted speed limit” is placed after the description “wide rings of dried sweat clinched my thirst, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June”. This clearly shows that he is severely dehydrated from the scorching sun, which is a prominent feature of the setting. The description “a tarlike distance surged out, followed by cockish water feeling somelane in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees” further emphasizes the harshness. Cyclists can tell that there is no available water in this desolate place, which is another crucial feature of the setting that negatively affects the cyclist. In conclusion, the setting's features pose a great threat to the cyclist's well - being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist from the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, had numerous obstacles to overcome. When he first showed the old men his map, he was probably thinking to himself, “Oh my gosh, what did I get myself into?!” His face might have shown a hint of unease. Because the cyclist trusted the shortcut the old men told him about, he experienced a lot of doubt, anger, and determination later on during the day. It was extremely hot, and he was rapidly running out of water, making him worried that he was going to get dehydrated and die as he started to think he was getting lost. The steep hills also affected the cyclist by making him extremely tired. In conclusion, the cyclist, in the end, found a little store by all the determination and effort he put in, finally getting the relief he so desperately needed.

The setting where the cyclist is at is a vast, barren desert, and it can have a serious impact on him because he could easily get a heatstroke. The text clearly states that he is lacking water, and if one gets too dehydrated, it's extremely unhealthy and can even lead to death. However, when the gentle wind blows against his face, it can cool him down, along with the evaporation of the sweat on his skin. As long as he has some liquid left in his water bottle, it should be somewhat manageable. But he needs to find a proper water source soon to avoid the worst - case scenario.

The setting of this story is a dry, sweltering hot desert in the middle of June. These features of the setting, like the intense heat and arid conditions, significantly affect the author, because it shows how he starts off strong and determined with a spring in his step and his left weak and doubtful as his body gives in. In the beginning of the story, the author says, “Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a bright smile on my face.” This vividly shows the readers the high level of confidence he has with himself before starting his trip. Later on in the story, he describes the setting as “the high deserts of California in June,” precisely depicting the heat and what challenges he is facing. It goes on to tell how he is severely dehydrated and completely worn out. But he finally comes to a town, and “cool water drips from my head as I slumped against the wall.” Clearly, he is greatly relieved. As the setting changes from the harsh desert to the town, the author's attitude changes as well, from despair to a sense of relief.

Different features of the setting have a significant impact on a cyclist. For example, temperature truly changes everything. If it's extremely hot, like the sweltering heat in a desert, you're going to get tired really easily as your body has to work hard to cool down. Then again, if it's too cold, the cold air makes breathing really hard as it constricts your airways. The biker in the story was in a desert area in June, so it was really hot and tiring under the scorching sun. Also, the terrain affects a cyclist. If the road is filled with hills, getting up those steep hills requires a great deal of strength and energy. If it's all downhill, it's really easy as gravity does most of the work, but all uphill is extremely hard. Level terrain is fairly easy as it allows for a more consistent pace. The cyclist in the story was on level terrain initially, then it turned into a lot of hills which gradually tired him out. Clearly, features of the setting really affect a cyclist.

The setting affects the cyclist in multiple ways. He is faced with roadways that are unfamiliar and full of uncertainties. The weather is hot and dry, with the sun beating down relentlessly, sapping his energy. Moreover, there are wild animals lurking around, which adds an element of danger to his journey. The text states that these factors combined make the cyclist's situation quite challenging. In such a setting, the cyclist has to constantly be on guard and adapt to the harsh conditions, demonstrating how the setting can have a profound impact on his experience.

The setting has a great impact on the condition of the cyclist. First, it is very hot and dry in June, with the sun shining brightly and the air parched. The cyclist is maneuvering his way through “high deserts in @LOCATION1” where he comes across many steep hills that he must laboriously climb over and carefully maneuver his way down. These hills require a lot of physical effort and concentration. With all of these obstacles and the intense heat slowing him down, he will need water but is already low on supplies. In this difficult setting, the cyclist's condition is clearly being affected, highlighting the significant role of the setting in his journey.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the narrator is faced with the challenging and perilous desert he must cross. He wasn't traveling in a car; instead, he was riding a bike. Crossing a desert on foot is tiring enough, let alone on a bike. “The speed limit was @NUM1. I was doing a water - depleting @NUM2. Sometimes life can be so cruel.” In the horrible @NUM3 degree heat, which is like an oven baking the ground, the narrator gulps down his water bottles at such a rapid rate that he's at high risk of running out. Not only that but he's been pedaling for such a long time that he might pass out from exhaustion or suffer from heatstroke. “I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades.” So, it's evident that the narrator was pretty hassled by his surroundings.

The setting affected the character in ways that would usually affect people. When he got into the first town, he had run out of water to drink. The town's water he was in now tasted like battery acid, with a strong and unpleasant chemical - like taste, so that's not safe to drink. As he started to head out, the scenery changed. “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This is hinting at the fact that maybe this town he is going to might be abandoned or not used. He saw a huge rattle snake slithering across the path and tumbleweed blowing in the wind. Which are usual signs of a desert. It was hard for him to keep his balance as he says, “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” He ended up getting to the point where he had to put rocks in his mouth to trick his mind into thinking that he wasn't thirsty anymore. All these show how the challenging setting took a toll on the character.

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist because at first he had to constantly watch out for the snakes that usually slithered across the roads. These snakes were a real hazard, as a sudden encounter could startle him and cause an accident. Then, the streets were not only crooked but also extremely bumpy. The uneven road structure jolted him around on his bike and threw him off a bit, making it difficult to maintain a steady pace. He was riding his bike in June, and the sun was blazing hot. The sweltering heat was almost unbearable, and he had a severe lack of water. As the heat took its toll, he began to feel dizzy and weak, and he thought he was going to have a heatstroke. These things significantly affected how the cyclist performed on his bike, making his journey a real struggle.

The cyclist is riding through the vast high deserts in California. In this desolate environment, as far as the eye can see, everything looks the same for miles. The landscape is a monotonous expanse of sand and rocks. The cyclist is already dehydrated, and the situation is getting worse because he has no protection from the scorching sun. There are no trees or shelters to provide shade. It is extremely hard for the cyclist to keep in good spirits because he is not even coming across any towns or sources of water. The cyclist says “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town.’” This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time - say before the last world war - but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. There were dilapidated buildings and no signs of life. This made the cyclist doubt the old - timers' directions. In the wide open desert, the cyclist was only coming across something after at least twenty miles. The intense heat, lack of water, and lack of civilization made the cyclist think he was “going to die and the birds would pick [him] clean.” When the cyclist spots the abandoned Welch’s factory, the cyclist says they used what seemed to be their last bit of energy. Clearly, the harsh conditions affected the cyclist in a very negative way.

The setting affects the cyclist by showing that he is a little angry. He states that “don’t remember the saying don’t take candy from strangers.” This off - hand comment indicates that he is upset about something. He is particularly mad about the fact that this one older man tells him directions on how to get somewhere, and it’s completely wrong. The man only figures that out halfway through the story. He also said that “the old man hasn’t been off his porch since Carter was in office,” meaning that the old man has been out of touch with the current state of the roads and landmarks. So, he needs to get his directions up to date. All these factors contribute to the cyclist having a negative attitude at the beginning.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the settings affected the character because he thought he wouldn’t make it to the park because of the way things looked around him. The rolling hills were a major obstacle. They were steep and required a great deal of effort to climb, sapping his energy. And the snakes that slithered across the path added to his sense of danger. With these hazards around, he didn’t think he would make it anywhere and started to panic. He was convinced that he was going to die out there. That’s how the menacing setting affected the character, filling him with fear and despair.

While the cyclist was trying to get to Yosemite National Park he listened to some old men who gave him directions for a shortcut. When he began his trip, the weather was pleasant and the road seemed promising, so everything was fine. But then he found that along the “shortcut” there was not a single building in sight. The landscape was just a barren expanse. By the time he figured out that the old men were mistaken, he had almost run out of water. There was nothing around that he could drink, not even a small stream or a puddle. He was getting very thirsty, and his throat was parched. The fact that he was in the deserts of California in June didn’t make his task any easier. The sun was beating down mercilessly. About halfway through his ride he ran into rolling hills. These hills were steep and difficult to climb, which made his trip even harder. Towards the end he found a building and he used all of his remaining strength to get to it just to find that it was an abandoned juice factory. As he entered, he gazed at the picture of the boy who was drinking juice, which made going without water much harder. In the end he finally made it to a paint shop where he guzzled all the water he possibly could, relieving his intense thirst and finally getting some much - needed relief.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly. For instance, when he was riding on the road, he would carefully pick a specific destination and then steadily ride towards it. After reaching that destination, he would take a short break to regain his energy. If this destination was a building, he would be full of strong will and determination, pushing himself forward. However, if it looked like there was nothing ahead but a series of hills, he would just keep riding aimlessly and wait to fall over dead without a care in the world. This shows how the setting's features had a significant impact on his cycling experience.

One rickety, ramsackle shed, several extremely rusty pumps, and a dilapidated corral that couldn't even hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This dismal sight was truly troubled. There was not a single soul in sight, no building, no car, or any structure of any kind to be seen. With any bad luck, I'd hit a bump and lodge something in my throat. There was a rough road ahead. If he didn't take the old man's advice, he would have enjoyed his bike ride, but he definitely needed a new map to find his way better.

The features in the story affect the cyclist by leaving him without anything to drink. The person was embarking on a journey to a place far away, with absolutely no food or water available for miles. He was in a very precarious situation and could have easily died. There is another feature that affects the cyclist, and that is the fact that no one is around for miles. If he died out there in the desolate area, no one would know for days. I know this because in the story he said, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind.” That statement says it all. The last feature is that it was extremely hot. I know this because it says, “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” It is well - known that it is hot in June, and it is even hotter in the deserts of California, which made the cyclist's situation even more difficult.

People who travel will almost always encounter difficulties. For the main character in this story, this is very true. His first big mistake was when he took directions from the “old - timers”. By doing that, he ended up travelling extremely far out of his way. In the story, he talked to the old men sitting on the porch. He said, “What I shouldn't have done was to let them see my map”. Another problem he faced was when he began to gradually run out of water. This caused a serious problem for him because of the threat of dehydration. In the story, he said, “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Additionally, another problem he encountered was the vast desert area that he was riding through. This caused a problem for him because there wasn't anybody around to offer help if he needed it. In the story, he says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, cars, or structure of any kind.” By reading this story, we've realized that people encounter problems everywhere, however, any problem, no matter what size, can be overcome with the right mindset and effort.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because on page @NUM1 it talks about how the cyclist had to first go down a steep hill and then search for a factory to get some juice. If the cyclist didn't find any building, he would have continued going down the hill and wasted the little bit of energy he had left for no good reason. This clearly shows how the setting features can have a negative impact on the cyclist's journey and energy levels.

Since the cyclist was really thirsty, parched from the long ride under the scorching sun, the setting was not very appealing considering it was a vast, arid desert with nothing but sand stretching as far as the eye could see. You could tell she was stressing because she was sweating profusely, and having a tough time trying to pedal her heavy bike through the soft sand. Eventually, she hoped to find an oasis where she could quench her thirst and rest.

The setting affects the cyclist in a way that most people can't tell. Cycling forty miles on maybe just a single gallon of water is incredibly hard, especially in the blistering heat of California. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, sipping small amounts to make it last, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June, where the sun beats down relentlessly.” The effect on his body would be rather devastating, potentially leading to dehydration and fatigue.

In the story, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in that when he is riding, he has very little water, just a few sips left in his bottle. Also, he takes advice from old men sitting under a shady tree by the roadside. Then he meets up with a venomous snake slithering across the path, which startles him. He then goes down a bumpy dirt road, and at that time, he has no water left at all. The conclusion is that he comes off the dirt road and rejoins the main road that he travels. Also, he promised to stick to it in the future. That is how you should stick to things in the future, learning from the challenges and making better choices.

The biker has many features in his story. For example, he uses descriptive words that vividly put pictures into my head. When he says “One long, crippling hill,” I can clearly picture a steep, never - ending incline that seems to go on forever. And when he states “There was no one in sight,” I can imagine the empty, desolate landscape around him. All of these parts of the story put detailed pictures in my head. That's a good thing, for example, you want the reader to fully understand the situation, and by having descriptive words, it helps the reader to be more immersed in the story.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. One way is that the “rolling hills” in the hot month of July let the rider get more tired as he has to constantly pedal up and down. Another way is the loss of water from severe heat, as the sun evaporates the sweat from his body at an alarming rate. And finally, the path you take along the way and how many stops you make along the way can also impact the cyclist. The heat, lack of water, rolling hills, and the advice you get can result badly by affecting the outcome of the ride. A rider should make a plan, like mapping out water stops and rest points, and use determination to get to where they need to go, no matter the challenges posed by the setting.

The setting in the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” reflects upon the cyclist. In the story, a cyclist is riding his trusty bike along the road and takes directions from a group of old men sitting on their porches. Later, he realizes that these old men probably had no idea that things change over time. He says, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven’t left their porches since Carter was in office.” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist takes the old - timers’ so - called “shortcut,” and it seems to take an eternity to reach his destination. At the end, he finally reaches his campsite, and another person asks him for directions. This time, the cyclist says, “Yes, sir! I own a very good map,” and “I’d always stick to it in the future.” The cyclist’s message is to follow a map, something you know is right, not a person that might be lying or irresponsible. In conclusion, relying on a reliable map is a wiser choice than trusting the potentially outdated advice of others.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him extremely dehydrated and unbearably hot. He was cycling in the vast deserts on a bicycle, and his water supply was steadily running low. The road was rough, with plenty of steep hills that made it extremely hard for a bike to navigate. He kept going, even though the heat was outrageous, and dehydration was beginning to overcome him. Despite the harsh conditions, he persevered, but it was clear that the setting was taking a heavy toll on him. In conclusion, the unforgiving desert setting severely impacted the cyclist's physical state.

I think the boy should ask you directions for the place where he is going. He might be able to reach the place without water, but that is definitely not a good thing to do. Traveling without water can lead to dehydration, which can cause various health problems and make the journey extremely difficult and dangerous. So, it is crucial for the boy to ask for directions and also ensure he has an adequate supply of water. In conclusion, asking for directions and having water are essential for the boy's safe journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist’s mood throughout the essay. Joe @CAPS1 starts with being happy and confident, full of enthusiasm as he begins his journey, to determined yet feeling helpless, and then to relief. Joe writes, “Things began well enough… flat roads…” This quote suggests that in the beginning, everything was okay. He started out with a “smile on the face.” (@NUM1) However, things start to change when @CAPS1 hits the changing terrain. He writes, “…I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This quote states the changing terrain. He starts to lose water to keep him going, yet he pushes himself to the next “town.” Finally, when the author reaches “Gary & Wilber’s fish camp,” he is relieved when he sees an old guy sitting. The two men say, “Know The best way to get There? “Yes sir! I own a very good map.” This reveals that Joe didn't ask for more directions, which was his first mistake. In addition, changes in setting can change a person's mood and attitude. In conclusion, the ever - changing setting had a profound impact on Joe's emotional state during his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it is in the desert during the scorching summer. This setting affects the cyclist because he is riding a bike under these harsh conditions. For example, in the story, he is running out of water rapidly. He is starting to get dehydrated, feeling weak and light - headed. The intense heat of the desert and the physical exertion of cycling make the lack of water a serious problem. In conclusion, the desert - summer setting has a detrimental effect on the cyclist's well - being.

The setting affected the cyclist because of the mood it created and how each change in the setting occurred. For instance, when the setting changed, the cyclist's emotions shifted, and it truly had an impact on him. Like if the setting was a sunny day in a charming town, with clear blue skies and friendly faces, then he would feel elated. But if he was in a dark, gloomy town with a cold, damp atmosphere, he wouldn't feel very happy. So, in conclusion, the setting really affected him in a profound way.

After some time into his trip, he mentioned, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” I believe that this arid and expansive setting had spurred him on, getting him determined to keep on pedaling so he could survive. But then, as the heat intensified and the miles seemed endless, he started to think he might die. However, he wasn't sad or upset; instead, he was oddly happy. He had sort of let out a soft chuckle to himself, because of the fact that he might die simply because he listened to some old men's advice. In my opinion, I think he was having the time of his life pedaling through this desolate yet mesmerizing setting of California, experiencing a unique kind of adventure.

Where the cyclist was gave him more disadvantages than advantages. The advantages were that there were hills to go down, allowing him to gain some speed and rest his legs briefly. However, the disadvantages were numerous. There were hills to go up, which required a great deal of energy. His water was running out when he was in the middle of nowhere, with the blistering sun making the heat unbearable. He was very hot out and was lost in the desert, with no clear sense of direction. He didn't have much hope until he saw the factory in the distance. The biggest disadvantage is that he was on a bike, and not in a car. So he had no air - conditioning and had to pedal to keep going. But being in the desert on a bike with no water, and being last in the group, is quite dire. He is very lucky that he made it up the hill or else he would've died out there. And he thought he was seeing things; good thing he checked it out. In conclusion, for future reference, it's wiser to ride in a car and not use a bike in the desert, as it's not a smart choice.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because when all the cyclist is worried about is finding a place with water, all he's doing is getting scared and panicking. In other words, when he's looking around, the setting he sees is a vast expanse of desert with no buildings in sight. The story says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” When he sees this desolate landscape, with the hot sand stretching as far as the eye can see, he panics and thinks he's not going to make it, which affects him mentally. This mental distress further hampers his ability to continue the journey effectively. So, the setting's features have a significant negative impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in different ways. The woman who had listened to the older men to get where she was going had made a fateful decision that led her to run out of water and almost die of thirst. As she was making her way to this place, in the desolate expanse, she had an encounter with a snake. “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake; it really did look like a diamondback” (@NUM1). The sight of the snake added to her already high - stress situation. As the dehydration set in, she started to see things that weren't there, her mind playing tricks on her due to the harsh setting. In conclusion, the unforgiving features of the setting had a detrimental effect on her journey and well - being.

He was affected by the acute lack of water, the steep hills, the menacing snake in the way, and the poor condition of the road. The water bottles, which were supposed to sustain him, contained only a few tantalizing sips. “This quote explains how the lack of water was a problem. The hills affected him as they were “crippling,” making each pedal - stroke an arduous task. The snake, which was lying across a long stretch of the road, left him in a fix as he didn't know how to get past it safely. Finally, the roads were rough and bumpy, and it was unwise to go over the speed limit of 55 mph. So, he was affected in a lot of different ways, not just one, and these challenges made his journey extremely difficult.

The features of the desolate and barren desert path make the cyclist quite nervous, but they also stoke his determination to escape them. As he pedals along, he passes “ghost towns” with their crumbling facades, “abandoned buildings” that stand as silent witnesses to a bygone era, and diamondback snakes slithering menacingly. These are images traditionally associated with being lost in the deserts, and would be enough to instill fear in most anyone travelling alone. The author even remarks that sadists are probably finding his story pleasing, perhaps relishing in his struggles. He often mentions fears of “dropping” dead from exhaustion, being eaten by vultures circling overhead, and, at one point, even wishing death upon himself via choking, albeit jokingly. And yet, he was determined to live. In spite of the odds stacked against him, he moved on, even after losing “what (he) believed to be (his) lost burst energy.” He even maintains a sense of humor throughout, writing of a diary entry that would be left behind, which remarks on the wisdom of old men. In the end, when he finally finds a place to rest, he turns it all into a lesson he’ll surely abide by: follow the map, as it is his guide through the treacherous unknown.

The cyclist is affected by the scorching heat, the daunting hills, and the eerie lack of people. For example, the cyclist was growing short on water, and there were “wide rings of dried sweat on his shirt,” a clear sign of his intense perspiration. He was in such a dire situation that he “could drop from heatstroke.” The hills, with their steep inclines, must have forced him to use more energy with each pedal - turn. Lastly, the desolate land was devoid of people. If the towns still had people, the cyclist wouldn't have been as affected by the setting, as he could have sought water, rest, and assistance. In conclusion, these factors combined to make his cycling experience extremely challenging.

Features of any setting affect what you do and how you do it. Features affect the cyclist by depriving him of water, help, and safety. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirsty by allowing what spit you have to circulate.” This quote shows his desperate need for water, as he resorts to sucking on a rock to make use of his own spit. The rough terrain and the abandoned road that the old men sent him on, which was out - of - date, made him unable to ask for directions, and he had no way to even know if he was travelling correctly. Along the road, he meets a snake, a menacing presence in this desolate landscape. Being so far away from civilization, if he was to have gotten bit, then he would have no one to help save him from dying on the side of the road. Also, if he was to have a heatstroke, he has no water and no help. Safety, help, and water are all factors which contribute to the features, and how they affect the cyclist, making his journey fraught with peril.

The features of the setting make the ride for the cyclist very hard. It has a lot of steep hills, which would make him exert more energy with every pedal - push. Also, it is a desert, so it is extremely hot and dry. The blistering sun beats down on him, making the author need more water than he normally would. The author said “…I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” a time when the heat is at its peak. The author knew that it was very dangerous to travel there without water, as he said “…I could drop from heatstroke…” If the setting had been cooler, there would not be so much danger, and his journey would have been far more bearable. In summary, the harsh setting was a major obstacle for the cyclist.

The cyclist's surroundings affected him negatively. He was cycling through the sweltering high deserts of California in June, as described by Kurmaskie (@NUM1). His water bottle was gradually running out, and the only town he reached that had water had water that tasted like battery acid. Events seemed rather dire, until the speaker became elated when they spotted a @ORGANIZATION1 factory. The author was extremely thirsty, and on the side of the building, there was a sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth (Kurmaskie @NUM1). However, the building was abandoned. The speaker then states, "Somehow I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope" (Kurmaskie @NUM3). After that disheartening landscape, he lost hope and pretty much gave up. The landscape and features affected the author very negatively due to the severe lack of water, leaving him in a desperate situation.

The setting significantly affects the cyclist as there are numerous steep hills that make pedaling extremely challenging and very little available water. The hills require a great deal of energy to climb, exhausting the cyclist, and the scarcity of water leaves him constantly parched and at risk of dehydration. This combination of difficult terrain and limited water supply makes the cyclist's journey arduous and dangerous, clearly demonstrating how the setting has a detrimental impact on his experience.

The cyclist in the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmashie is heavily affected by the features of the setting in the story. First is the "shorecay" route that is suggested to get to @CAPS1. This path naturally just ends up isolating him, separating him from all other people and putting him in the middle of a desolate nowhere with a limited supply of water. His water shortage is the second crucial thing that affects him because it makes him despair deeply and feel that he is on the verge of collapsing and dying. In the story, he says: "It really didn't matter. I was going to die and the lards would pick me clean." This vivid statement clearly shows that the features of the setting made him feel utterly hopeless, trapped in a situation with no easy way out.

Many features of the setting affected the cyclist in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie. One prominent feature that affected the character was the intense heat of the sun. The narration states that "The sun was beginning to beat down" (@CAPS1), baking the cyclist as he rode. This intense heat made the cyclist uncomfortable, sapping his energy and increasing his need for water. The heat added to the overall difficulty of his journey, clearly demonstrating how the setting's feature had a negative impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist in the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit". In the story, it says, "I was traveling through the high desert of California in June." This description is clearly telling the reader that the weather was extremely hot, and one needs a large amount of water here to survive, especially if you are riding a bike or doing physical work. Later on in the story, it says, "I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." This quote provides the reader with information and reveals that the cyclist is struggling to survive through the harsh features of the setting. In California deserts, as I know from prior knowledge, it is hot and dry, especially in the summer. If you are working outside, like the cyclist in this story is, and you do not have enough water to drink, you will quickly get dehydrated, which eventually leads to life - threatening situations. The author effectively shows the readers how the setting affects the cyclist by painting a vivid picture of the cyclist's difficult circumstances.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the various aspects of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist. One notable factor is the water situation. There is only a scarce amount of water available, and it is boiling hot under the scorching sun. Out of desperation, the cyclist took a small sip of it. He exclaimed, “It tasted like battery acid.” In my opinion, if the water is that hot, it's best not to even attempt to taste it. Another significant element is the land. The terrain transitioned from flat, straight stretches to hilly areas. As he pedaled up those inclines, the change in the land started to gradually slow him down. Lastly, the issue of daytime came into play. The day started turning dark, yet he was still determinedly biking along. He was eager to cover as much distance as he could before having to stop. This shows how the setting's features combined to pose challenges for the cyclist throughout his journey.

The features in the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist, causing him to get tired very easily as he was biking in the desert during the sweltering month of June. In this particular desert, there are no rivers whatsoever, which means he had no natural source to replenish his water supply. The heat was so intense that he could barely see clearly because the copious amount of sweat that poured down his face kept getting into his eyes. Moreover, due to the extreme heat, there were no people around in the vast expanse of the desert. This isolation and the lack of resources made his cycling experience extremely difficult. Overall, the harsh desert setting in June presented numerous obstacles for the cyclist, making his journey a real struggle.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting had a notable influence on the cyclist. The setting affected the cyclist both mentally and physically. When the setting was pleasant, with clear skies, smooth roads, and a gentle breeze, he had a positive outlook on his journey and was brimming with energy. He pedaled with enthusiasm, enjoying the ride. However, later in the essay, as the setting grew less appealing, with rough roads, strong headwinds, and perhaps even a threatening sky, and more treacherous, the cyclist's spirit started to wane. He grew weary from the physical exertion and distressed by the worsening conditions. This clearly demonstrates how the setting can have a direct impact on a cyclist's state of mind and physical capabilities.

A cyclist always has to face a multitude of problems during their rides. For instance, the weather can be a major hurdle. Rain can make the roads slippery and cold temperatures can sap their energy, while extreme heat can lead to dehydration. The condition of the road is another significant issue. Potholes, uneven surfaces, and gravel can make the ride bumpy and increase the risk of accidents. Additionally, factors like traffic and road signs also add to the challenges. Despite these difficulties, cyclists persevere, showing their determination and love for the sport.

The features in the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. The first way the features in the setting affected the cyclist is that the whole trail was completely deserted, leaving him all alone with no access to water. In the story, it vividly describes, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time – say, before the last world war – but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This description clearly explains that he was alone and that the first town he visited was a desolate place. The lack of human presence and water in this deserted setting made his journey even more arduous. As he continued on, the setting's features continued to shape his experience, presenting new challenges at every turn.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist as the lack of available water made him extremely tired and a bit delusional. The glaring lack of shade under the scorching sun increased the rate of his dehydration. The rough, uneven road made it incredibly hard to balance on his bike. And the heavy snack he had slowed him down significantly. In his exhausted state, he thought that he was going to die, his hope slowly fading away.

The setting of the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," is very important to the events that occurred in the story. For example, the story was set on a long, desolate highway with a speed limit of @NUM1, while the cyclist was only able to maintain a speed of @NUM2. This is significant to the events of the story because since he was doing @NUM2, which by the way is a lot for a cyclist pedaling under such conditions, it led to him almost suffering from dehydration. Plus, the highway was hilly, making his journey even more arduous. This difficult situation ultimately led to the unfortunate execution of the cyclist. So, one could clearly see that the setting is very important to the outcome of the story as it directly influenced the cyclist's fate.

The setting is in a part of California which isn't really the coolest of places to be. With the sun beating down relentlessly, the temperature often soars, making the air feel thick and oppressive. The heat lingers, making it uncomfortable for anyone in the area. In such a setting, it becomes quite clear why it isn't the most appealing place to spend time.

At the beginning of his journey, the cyclist is relaxed and appreciative of the features of his environment. He says, “I enjoyed the serenity of an early - summer evening.” The gentle breeze and the soft glow of the setting sun added to the charm. At a campground in @LOCATION1, the setting is calming and relaxing. The tall trees provided shade, and the sound of a nearby stream was soothing. At the first town, the setting is shocking, but humorous to the cyclist and he starts to get nervous. After looking around he says, “this sight was troubling.” The dilapidated buildings and the eerie silence were unsettling. The cyclist's trip gets worse when he reads about the next town. “The flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This part of his journey affects him the most. His environment and the features of the land have made him tired and thirsty. The setting has a major role for a cyclist, dictating his mood and physical state throughout the journey.

In the essay "Rough Road Ahead; Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting is integral to how the cyclist feels and behaves. The cyclist feels a growing desperation as the setting around him gets progressively more bleak. In the beginning of the trip, the cyclist encounters a ghost town. "I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on." At this point, he is still full of hope and thinking positively. A while later, the cyclist comes across another abandoned set of buildings. He feels that this sight is "troubling." Although @CAPS1 the cyclist is worried, he is not yet depressive and pessimistic. Farther down the road, the terrain of the road changes, and he sees the sign that gives the essay its name. "The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water - depleting @NUM1. Sometimes life can feel so cruel." The cyclist's surroundings get progressively worse as he rides on, with the heat intensifying and the road becoming more challenging. But eventually, he finds a place with working water. He is so overjoyed by this building that he wants to find the owners and kiss them, as it represents a glimmer of hope in his otherwise difficult journey.

Some features of the setting that affect the cyclist is that he is riding a bike through the desert. He says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” So, under the scorching sun, he was pedaling a bike, feeling the intense heat. The road became bumpy and curvy. A sign had said, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted Speed limit.” The speed limit was @NUM1 and he was going @NUM2, so it must have been quite hard for him to get over all the bumps while trying to maintain control. Lastly, he comes across a poisonous snake that blocked the majority of the pavement in front of him. So, being dehydrated and trying to get around a snake would be truly terrifying. So, on his @CAPS1 journey, the setting doesn't help him much, making his cycling experience extremely challenging.

The cyclist ran into many issues in his/her travel to @LOCATION1. They had to dismiss many hardships such as a severe lack of water, getting lost in the vast expanse, the immense desert heat that seemed to never end, plus minor things like encountering snakes and dealing with poor road conditions. The setting of the California desert in June was the most intense hardship. That and the lack of water were like a double - edged sword. The heat started pounding at the cyclist's brain, causing them to see mirages and feel disoriented. The heat and the entire setting made the cyclist's travel much harder, testing their endurance to the limit.

The setting affects the cyclist because in the sweltering heat of California in June, which is a time when nobody wants to be outside for long. First, it was the heat which took a great deal out of his body as he struggled to keep it cool, his body sweating profusely. Then came the factor that he had very little water when he reached the first town. In the story, it said, “A tar - like substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” So now, he has no cool water to drink. When he says, “Not two miles into the next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” So the cyclist, with very little water, now has to endure the hardest part of the ride. Later on, he makes a mention of changing a paragraph if he loses consciousness. Also, he talked about the possibility of getting a heatstroke. This all hints to the fact that the setting he was in was affecting him in many different ways, both physically and mentally.

The setting of the essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit” is very dry, sandy, hot, and deserted. On his way to Yosemite, he takes a “short cut” so he goes through the desert. When he first leaves, it is in a hot and flat part of the desert. His mood is high and he has confidence. “Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” With this positive state, he arrives at the first “town”. But he isn't worried as he has plenty of water, so he moves on. The terrain starts working against him in his search for water. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. A large highway sign jumped out at him. It read: Rough Road Ahead : Do not Exceed posted speed limit.” This lowers his confidence, especially because everything is deserted and if he has a heat stroke, no one would be around to find him. He keeps up his determination when he sees the factory yet he moves on. When he sees the first camp, he is overwhelmed with relief and the terrain flattens out again. When asked if he needs directions, he says he has his own map so he can stick to the terrain he knows is restful. He can keep his hopes up for himself and follow a true set of directions to reach his destination.

Anyone who has ever ridden a bike knows how relaxing it can truly be, but when you are forced to ride miles and miles on @CAPS3 rough terrain without any water, relaxation feels like an unreachable oasis. @CAPS1 Cycling through beat - up roads with dryness all around you really puts a damper on your experience. @CAPS2 Moreover, it extends your need for thirst by enhancing the amount of dryness in the air and the amount of energy you are expending. The ability to block all of that out and trying to focus on something easier to handle is exactly what you want to do in these situations. @CAPS3 Such challenging terrain can really build character into a cyclist, but adding the fact of the limited amount of water he had and the dryness around him, it sounds like pure torture. I can only hope that if I ever become a cyclist, I never have to endure this kind of situation, as it would surely test my limits.

The cyclist, Joe Kurmaskie, had a truly rough time traveling to Yosemite National Park. Granted, he was misled by some inaccurate directions, but if the conditions of the terrain and the climate were working in his favor, it would've made his journey a whole lot easier. Not only was it extremely hot, being in the arid desert of California in June, but he only had a single small water bottle. That one water bottle might have lasted a little longer if it was a straight, flat shot through, but the reality was far from it. The roads went up steep inclines, down sharp declines, there were numerous hills to climb, and scattered along the way were towns - some of them ghost towns at that. The only water he could pump from the rusty pump was scalding hot and tasted strongly acidic. Also, he wouldnít have lost as much energy if it was a straightforward path. Itís easy to say that he literally roughed it, having to resort to putting small, smooth rocks in his mouth to try and circulate saliva. All in all, he was very determined to work through the very unfortunate conditions he had working against him, and he was very lucky to survive that grueling journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many profound ways. For example, the fact that he is pedaling a bike slowly through the vast high deserts of California in June, with the sun beating down mercilessly, make the intensity level of the story very high. The sweltering heat adds an extra layer of difficulty to his journey. If it would have been a cooler day, say in early spring, and there was a nice, refreshing breeze gently blowing across the landscape, it would be a completely different scenario. In such a more favorable setting, the cyclist would likely face less physical strain and the overall experience would be far less challenging.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by lack of water, the presence of a poisonous snake, and the poor condition of the road. For example, the lack of water affected the cyclist severely because he couldn't make it very far without water. In the scorching heat, his body was rapidly losing fluids, and he could of passed out if he didn't have access to water. Another example of how the setting affected the cyclist would be the poisonous snake slithering around in the underbrush. If he would have gotten bitten by that venomous snake, he could have died because there would be nobody around in that desolate area to help him. And the last example of how the setting affected him would be the condition of the road. The road was full of potholes and had many steep hills and windy bends.
