This made it tougher for the cyclist to get to his destination as he had to constantly adjust his speed and balance. This is how I think the setting affected the cyclist, making his journey a perilous and arduous one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that if itís hot and you're riding a long way under the blazing sun, you need a large amount of water so you donít get dehydrated. The heat causes you to sweat profusely, quickly depleting your body's water reserves. Also, it can affect your vision because you're constantly looking directly at the bright sun, which can cause glare and make it hard to see clearly ahead. Another way cyclists can get affected by the setting is because what if the road is all bumpy, full of cracks and potholes, and just not in good shape. Such a rough road surface can affect the way they ride their bike. It can make it difficult to maintain a steady speed and balance, and may even cause damage to the bike's tires and components. In conclusion, the setting can have a significant impact on a cyclist's journey, both physically and in terms of the ride itself.

The story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by the author @PERSON1 had some statements that seemed kind of pointless to put in. One of the sentences in the essay had a couple of words that donít need to be used. In the sentence, “about forty miles into the pedal, I arrive at the first ‘town’”, I donít think “into the pedal” needs to be in there because it's not really describing anything relevant to the context. It doesn't add any useful information about the distance, the journey, or the town. Removing those words would make the sentence more concise and to the point, improving the overall flow of the story.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is the harshness of the setting. The cyclist is out in the desert, under the scorching sun in two - hundred degree weather. With very little water, he struggles to keep himself hydrated. Also, the cyclist didn't have a map and he asked someone who hasn't left their porch since Carter was in office. That person, living in isolation for so long, had no real - time knowledge of the area. "Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades." This quote talks about how the setting (two - hundred degree weather, desert) can endanger him. Also, he listened to someone that didn't know what they were talking about. In conclusion, the extreme heat, lack of resources, and unreliable advice due to the setting all had a detrimental impact on the cyclist.

The setting of the story is very desert - like. What I mean by that is it's a vast, arid desert where the heat is intense. The cyclist really had to push himself to make it through this unforgiving environment. The condition of the road is very rough and it has a lot of sharp turns. These turns require the cyclist to be extra cautious while riding. At one part in the story, he gets a boost of energy and pedals as hard as he can down a hill. Then, he relaxes for a bit, taking advantage of the momentum. This is the setting and a summary of how the cyclist navigated through it in the story.

The setting affected the cyclist because the condition of his surroundings was extremely hot. The sweltering heat made him dehydrate more rapidly, so he needed more water to stay hydrated. There were a lot of hills on the route, and to get up these hills, he had to pedal harder and use more energy. The landscape was devoid of cars, buildings, and smog; there was just pure nature. It was a peaceful and relaxing ride on the bike in some aspects, but the heat and the hills added to the challenges. Overall, the combination of the hot climate and the hilly terrain, along with the serene natural setting, all had an impact on the cyclist's journey.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist in a great way. His journey would not be as difficult if these factors had not crossed his path. Climate, location, and population all have an effect on the cyclist. In the story, it is told that the cyclist is in the dry climate of California, in the sweltering heat of June. There is also a lack of water, so he must pace his sips carefully to make the limited supply last. There are few towns in the area, making it hard to get good advice and essential supplies. The cyclist also comes across a snake, making him affected by native wild life. The dry climate and lack of water make him have self - doubt. The cyclist is constantly worried about passing out and dying of dehydration. The cyclist also gets doubts when he sees the road signs reminding him how slow he is going. The snake also has a depressing effect as it highlights the dangers on his journey. All of these things in the setting affected the cyclist. His journey does teach you though, that through determination you will be rewarded. You have to want things bad enough and put the effort into it. The author also teaches you to always have a positive attitude to achieve success, even when facing difficult circumstances in the journey.

The features and settings affected the cyclist because of all the dangers associated with his journey. He took advice from old people to embark on this cycling trip. At first, it started out good, but as is often the case, almost nothing lasts forever. He's riding in the middle of summer, with little water, in the vast expanse of the desert. He runs into towns that are abandoned, and the next town is only @NUM1 miles away, with literally rough roads ahead. The desolate landscape and the lack of resources make his journey extremely challenging. But when he did reach the abandoned town, his spirits were low until he found hope in the form of seeing a man in a chair. This small glimmer of human presence gave him the motivation to continue his arduous journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist as he is cycling outside of town. I say this because the cyclist mentions “old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This indicates that he is in an area where the locals are quite sedentary and perhaps out - of - touch. So, it means he doesn't know exactly where he's at, which makes his journey more challenging.

In the cyclist's journey to Yosemite, several factors hinder him from reaching it. The first is obviously the false information given to him by the elders. These elders, perhaps set in their old ways, provided directions that were inaccurate. The second is that because the information wasn't true, the cyclist had an insufficient amount of water. He planned his water supply based on the wrong directions, which made him dehydrated. The last is the fact that the route given to him included obstacles such as snakes, rocky roads, and old ghost towns and abandoned buildings which made the cyclist less confident. These features of the setting combined to make his journey extremely difficult and ultimately affected his ability to reach Yosemite.

The setting affects the cyclist because, first of all, he should have stuck to his own map. His own map was based on more reliable data, and by deviating from it, he got into trouble. He should have also packed an extra bottle of water. In an unfamiliar setting, having an extra supply of water is always a good idea. Moreover, he should not take any advice from people that haven't left the porch in years. These people may not be aware of the current conditions of the area, and their advice can lead him astray. By not following these precautions, the cyclist faced difficulties due to the setting.

The setting affects the cyclist's mood in the story. The cyclist takes a short - cut with many abandoned towns and buildings, as well as a bumpy terrain. This desolate and rough setting immediately sets a somber tone. When he came to a fork in his path that had a water pump, he was hopeful. He immediately began to pump it, but unfortunately, the water was not good for drinking. Despite this setback, he was determined to make it to the next town. “I could make that,” he said. Because of the ghost town and the old, non - functioning pump, he had to continue on with a heavy heart. When the cyclist came to a sign in the road warning him about the road ahead, he began to get depressed. “I was sad,” he said. Finally, when he reached @CAPS1 and @CAPS2 Fish Camp, he was thankful and wanted to show his gratitude. The setting can affect a cyclist by his mood. At first, the cyclist is determined, but as the setting gets worse with more desolation and obstacles, his mood and hopes go down the drain. At the end when the setting is bright and he reaches his destination, so is his mood.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was thirsty and it was hot. The sweltering heat made his thirst even more unbearable, and he was almost out of water. He was in a dire situation and almost died because when he was drinking the water, he hit a bump and a bit of spit got lodged in his throat, causing him to choke. On top of that, there were tiring hills that seemed to never end. The continuous uphill climbs in the hot and dry setting sapped his energy. All these features of the setting combined to make his journey a life - threatening struggle.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. Right from the start, he is ill - prepared. The cyclist gets directions from an old man who hasn't left his porch in years. With such a long period of inactivity, the old man has no idea about the recent changes in the area. Then, the cyclist begins his journey with a meager supply of water. When he reaches the second town, he notices a notable change in the terrain. The previously flat road is now replaced by short rolling hills. As the quote “I notice the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” indicates, he was completely unprepared for these hills and assumed the route would be flat all the way. Moreover, in the scorching @NUM1 - degree weather and with limited water, pedaling up and down the hills becomes an arduous task. However, going down the hills offers him a brief respite. In conclusion, these various features of the setting have a substantial impact on the cyclist's journey.

A lot of factors have a significant effect on the cyclist. The temperature, terrain, and directions all instill doubt in the cyclist's mind. The high temperatures in the deserts of California leave the cyclist feeling extremely hot, desperately parched, and highly irritable. Throughout the story, he is left with just a few sips of water. The realization of running low on water makes him “feel sorry for himself”. As the cyclist pedals on, the terrain starts to change from flat ground to “rolling hills”. This change can be a major challenge for someone who has never biked on different elevations before. Lastly, the feeling of hope, or rather the lack of it, might affect him the most. Doubting oneself is indeed the most difficult obstacle to overcome. Carelessly taking instructions from an old man has cost the cyclist hours of suffering. The author skillfully uses hyperbole to exaggerate the cyclist's sense of lost hope. Additionally, the detailed descriptions in the text paint a vivid picture for the reader. These literary elements effectively help the reader understand the impact that temperature, terrain, and hope have on the cyclist. In essence, they make the story more relatable and the cyclist's struggles more palpable.

The features of the setting truly have a profound impact on the cyclist. The immediate surroundings mislead him into having false expectations. Little does he know that this seemingly harmless situation will soon put him in serious danger. When he encounters a large rock in the road and discovers that the water pumps are in poor condition, his peril becomes evident. As the text states, “The sun was beginning to heat down, but it hardly noticed. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” The idyllic setting allows the cyclist's mind to wander so much that he fails to even notice the increasing heat. In conclusion, the setting's features not only deceive the cyclist but also lead him into a precarious situation.

In the short story, “Do Not Exceed Posted speed limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting, such as the lack of water and the inability to find help, have a profound impact on the cyclist in the story. During his time of dire need, the cyclist despondently remarks, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise old men their wisdom.” The lack of essential necessities in the surrounding environment makes him lose his pride and abandon hope. However, when the cyclist finally finds hope, he exclaims, “And drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait.” He is utterly astonished by what he has stumbled upon and is deeply grateful to be alive. The cyclist should not have taken the advice of the old people for granted. From this experience, he will now be more discerning when relying on others' sense of directions. In conclusion, the setting's features in the story have a life - changing effect on the cyclist, teaching him a valuable lesson.

Setting plays a crucial role in stories as it can affect many aspects. In this particular story, the setting has a significant impact on the cyclist. The sweltering heat of the setting slows him down considerably. For instance, he mentions that he was supposed to cover 55 miles, but the intense heat makes it a herculean task. The heat drains his energy, making each pedal stroke a struggle. In conclusion, the hot setting in this story has a clear and detrimental effect on the cyclist's ability to complete his journey efficiently.

The setting in the story was the “high deserts of California in June.” At first, the cyclist, full of energy and enthusiasm, had seemed really confident and excited about his journey. However, it was during the journey that something had changed his mind. The cyclist was running low on his water supply, so he stops and pumps water from this old - fashioned water pump. But all he gets is this unpleasant acid taste. So he is on his way to the nearest town which is @NUM1 miles away and he firmly thinks he can make it. As he is heading towards the nearest town, the terrain starts changing. It gradually changes from a flat, easy - going road to short rolling hills. During this arduous time, the cyclist starts losing hope. He vividly imagines that he is going to die of dehydration and the birds are going to pick him apart. Then, when he thought he couldn't make it, he saw a sign that said “Gary and @CAPS1 fish camp.” He rushed into the shop and took long, refreshing drinks from the sink in the bathroom. When he went out of the store, an older gentleman asked him if he needed help and he said no, “I have a really good map.” The hot temperature and rolling hills have a negative effect on the cyclist. I mean he goes from being confident to thinking he is seeing mirages and dying. It states in the story “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage” and “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” So this brought self - doubting behavior, which clearly shows how the harsh setting can shatter one's confidence.

The features of the setting where the cyclist is located affect them very drastically. Cyclists need a reliable water supply, and if they don't have one, they might dehydrate or even face the risk of death. Shade trees are also essential as they act as a shield, keeping the intense sun from beaming down on them so hard. They should also plan their cycling when it's not as hot outside. This way, just in case their water gets low, there is a better chance of survival. It would be great if there was someone accompanying them on the journey to offer help if they get hurt. There should be buildings nearby just in case of an emergency, such as sudden illness or mechanical problems with the bike. It might even be good to carry a cell phone to call for assistance in difficult situations. In conclusion, a well - equipped and favorable setting is crucial for the safety and success of a cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in more than one way. The first features were a dilapidated ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps that looked like they hadn't been used in ages, and a corral that could hardly hold in the lamest mule. These items gave the cyclist a strong feeling of doubts. They made him begin to think he had taken the wrong route when he saw these things were so outdated. Then, he struggled desperately but couldn't get any cold, clean water out of the pumps to save his life. This was the first obstacle which affected him severely. The next features of the setting which caused a problem were the tumbleweeds that rolled across his path menacingly and “a ridiculously large snake.” They made the cyclist extremely scared and caused him to go around these things cautiously. You can tell he was scared because he quoted “I eased past.” When the flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills, the cyclist's journey became exhausting, never - ending, and difficult. Two more things affected the cyclist. These two things consist of the signs. One of which read “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” and the other “GARY AND WILBER'S FISH - IF you want bait for the big ones, we're your BEST BET.” The first sign affected him in a negative way and caused him to become a little angry and frustrated because he was tired and dehydrated and the rough road ahead gave him no hope. The second sign led him to water which was the one thing that would make things better so it had a positive affect. These are features that had a significant impact on the cyclist, highlighting how the setting can shape a journey.

The setting affected the cyclist due to the changes in terrain. A rough spot for the cyclist was when the terrain changed from a flat, smooth stretch to rolling hills. The author wrote, “I tolled on” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist was pushing through the rough and it was not an easy stretch to get through. With each pedal stroke, he could feel the strain on his muscles. Another place in the cyclist's trip that was difficult was when he saw the abandoned juice factory. The narration states, “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The context clues that provide information that it wasn't easy are the words “long” and “crippling.” Both of those words provide feelings of being dragged on through the rough setting of the cyclist's trip. In conclusion, the changing terrain and the sight of the abandoned building in the setting added great difficulty to the cyclist's journey.

The cyclist had experienced some hard obstacles on his ride to Yosemite. He had gotten directions from a group of old men who hadn't gone the places they told him about in a long time. Where they said there would be a town, it turned out to be more like a desolate ghost town. The day that the cyclist was riding was extremely hot and he was riding through the desert, which made the situation worse. Because of the scorching heat, he was drinking his water regularly to stay hydrated. This meant he was running out of it fast. Since the old men had given him directions through places that were no longer open, he couldn't get more water. The cyclist also had to go over roads that were in bad condition, full of potholes and uneven surfaces, which slowed him down even more. Those features of the setting affected the cyclist a lot on his trip, making his journey to Yosemite a real struggle.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. In the beginning, as he pedals along under the scorching sun, he cannot get water and gradually becomes dehydrated. His throat feels parched and his energy starts to wane. Then, he encounters a rough stretch of road filled with potholes and uneven surfaces. The constant jolting and effort to maintain balance on this rough ride cause him to lose more energy. His legs ache and his body grows tired. Then he spots the bait, which turns out to be a small water station. He rushes over and takes a long drink, replenishing his lost fluids. All of these greatly affect the cyclist's condition, making his journey a challenging one.

The setting of the cyclist's journey affected him because he was in a vast desert in California. The intense heat of the desert sun beat down on him as he had to ride his bike through it. The heat took a lot out of him, making him sweat profusely and feel extremely fatigued. He didn't have a lot of water because there were no rivers or water supply due to the arid desert surrounding him. His water bottles were nearly empty, and he could feel the effects of dehydration setting in. At the end, he spots a small store in the distance. This affects him because he quickly rushes inside, gets a cool drink, and some essential supplies which helped him regain his strength. So in the end, his surroundings first destroyed his energy and well - being and then relieved him.

The bicyclist was riding to Yosemite National Park, excited about the beautiful scenery that awaited him. But on the way, he ran out of water. "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." His throat was dry, and he could feel his energy draining. Then, hills came into play. As he started climbing the hills, he could feel the extra effort in his legs. The short rolling hills made him more tired and thirsty. "Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills." The rider's desperation grew, and he didn't think he would live. "I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean." But then, by chance, he found a place to get water. He rushed inside, "drank deeply from the sink," and with new - found energy, he finished his ride to Yosemite.

In the story "Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affected the cyclist a lot. At first, when the cyclist set off in the morning, the conditions were great. A gentle breeze blew, providing a refreshing feeling, and there was shade from the tall trees lining the road. The sound of nearby rivers added to the pleasant atmosphere. Then, after a few hours of riding, the cyclist found himself in the desert with bumpy hills. In the story, the speaker states, "Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." The poor condition of the roads and the lack of water really affected the cyclist. It took more energy to get up and down the hills without any shade, which meant that he needed more water, but he didn't have any. His body was struggling in the harsh conditions. The condition of the setting really affected the cyclist, and if it was easier to bike, they might not have been so dehydrated.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by disturbing them to ride on the road, limiting their speed, and making their distance longer than the original travel plan. For example, the features at the setting disturb the cyclist to ride on the road because they clearly tell them where they can go and where they can't. There are signs like "no entering" or "one way" that restrict their movement. These signs force the cyclist to change their route, which can be quite frustrating. Second, it limits their speed. If the features of the setting state that the limited speed is @NUM1, the cyclist can only ride about @NUM1 and go no further. This means they have to pedal at a slower pace, which can make the cyclist take a longer time to reach the place that they want to go and they can't travel as fast as they'd like. Third, it makes their distance longer than the original travel plan. For instance, a sign like "Rough road ahead, do not exceed posted speed limit" makes them slow down and take a more cautious approach. This can add extra time and distance to their journey. Therefore, the features of the setting affect the cyclist during the journey, making it more complex and time - consuming.

The features of the challenging setting significantly affect the cyclist as they constantly make him doubt and greatly lessen his chances for survival. However, the cyclist remains incredibly determined, and it is this unwavering determination that ultimately enables him to survive.

In the essay, the various features of the desolate setting have a profound impact on the cyclist. One prominent feature that affects him severely is his acute lack of water: "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." This scarce supply of water made him extremely desperate, especially when he came across the Welch's grape juice factory. The dilapidated building, which had been abandoned years earlier, was once a bustling Welch's grape juice factory and bottling plant. This initial dispersion, after he had come to the abandoned factory, was quickly followed by intense disappointment and a vague sense of hopelessness, clearly expressed by the phrase, "I hung my head" after he had found the long - deserted factory. These are some of the key features of the setting that have a detrimental effect on the cyclist.

No water, rough terrain, and bad information - all are valid reasons why the boy isn't doing so well. I mentioned no water because he is severely dehydrated, yet he has to ration his scarce water supply carefully. Also, he is at high risk of dying from heat exhaustion due to the lack of proper hydration. I also pointed out the rough terrain because on such uneven ground, he could easily fall and get badly hurt, with no one around to offer immediate help. And to make matters even worse, he took advice from old people who clearly didn't know what they were talking about. These are all examples from the essay that support my writing.

In the story by Joe Kurmaskie, it vividly tells about a cyclist's arduous challenge through the sweltering deserts of California in June. The cyclist had initially started out with great confidence, which was then followed by unwavering determination, and later a brief sense of relief. The harsh setting affected the cyclist both physically and mentally. First, listening to the old men was a foolish decision, then taking the trip without being certain if he would have enough water was a major risk, and lastly, traveling through the desert in June was an extremely unwise choice. He started getting a little doubtful about himself as well, and this self - doubt won't help much in ensuring the success of the trip. Once he had made it to a fish camp, an old man even older than the men who gave him the false information told him he knew how to get to Yosemite, but the young man did the smart thing and told him he already knew how to get there. He didn't need to be out in the scorching desert heat for hours as it's simply unhealthy.

A cyclist is affected by numerous factors when riding, with most of them being features of the setting. One crucial feature of the setting that can have a substantial impact is the terrain. If the terrain is rough, then the cyclist could face a much more difficult time maintaining firm control of the bike, especially if he is not a professional rider. For example, the author of the essay on page @NUM1 titled: Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit, had a tough time on the rougher roads partly because of his limited level of experience. Another important aspect of the environment that can affect a cyclist is the climate. Most people who are well - versed in cycling know how to dress appropriately to keep their body at a comfortable temperature, but sometimes the unpredictable weather plays tricks on us. The cyclist could unexpectedly get caught in a sudden heat wave or a rapid drop in temperature.

The features of the desolate setting significantly enhance the cyclist’s desperate spirit. Throughout the entire solitary journey, the cyclist is completely by himself, with no signs of people, cars, or buildings in sight. The utter isolation made him much more desperate because if he were to collapse from dehydration, there would be no one around to offer help, and he would simply perish alone. Also, he unexpectedly came upon things such as the “Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant,” which initially got his hopes up as he imagined finding water or assistance. However, it would soon crush his spirits when he realized it was abandoned. These events intensified his desperation as he had no support from anywhere and nothing to fall back on in this life - or - death situation, leaving him in a state of utter despair.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. First of all, as he was riding about @NUM1 miles up the long, winding road, he noticed that the terrain was gradually changing. The once - familiar landscape was morphing into something unknown, and that truly scared him. He says, “This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly” (Kurmaskie @NUM2). He is expressing that as the things around him began to transform, his fear grew steadily. And he kept gulping down water just to try and calm his nerves. Another example is after he had passed the sign that told him not to pass. He says, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM3). This is yet another instance of fear starting to overcome him when he saw even more alterations in the road. Despite the road changes and the fact that his water supply was almost depleted, he still had the inner courage to press on. The setting brought him a great deal of fear, but he managed to persevere and make it through.

In the story, the cyclist had completely run out of water. He had mentioned that the little water he had left at the end tasted like battery acid, a foul and unpleasant taste that only added to his misery. The surroundings had a profound impact on him. As he looked around, he saw nothing but vast stretches of empty land with no sign of human presence for miles. This isolation brought a deep sense of despair. He was in a desert where the scorching hot sun was relentlessly beating down on him. All around were the endless sand dunes and prickly cacti. Just envisioning this scene, one would immediately think of a lack of water and the absence of any shade. The desolate desert setting with its harsh conditions compounded his desperation, making his situation seem almost hopeless.

The features of the setting, in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” have a profound impact on the cyclist. The setting affects him both physically and mentally. Physically, in the story, the arid setting provides no water source for the cyclist. As a result, his body becomes weak, his energy levels drop, and he struggles to pedal forward. Mentally, he is severely affected by the features of the setting. An example of this is when he comes across the abandoned Welch's factory. As he sees the picture of a boy “pour a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth,” it fills him with a sense of longing and disappointment. He hangs his head dejectedly as he continues to ride on. He is constantly thinking to himself that he might die out in this desolate place. These physical and mental effects clearly show how the features of the setting have a detrimental impact on the cyclist, leaving him in a vulnerable and desperate state.

I believe the first photograph closely relates to the story “As Worry” because the author’s son suffers a great deal in the narrative. The photograph vividly shows what he and his friends look like in @MONTH1, capturing their expressions and the essence of their situation. It also prominently features the surfboards, which strongly emphasize that they are surfers, aligning well with the story's context. That is my perception of the first picture. The second photograph only has a slight relation as it simply depicts a surfer surfing. It lacks the depth and connection to the main themes of the story like the first one does. So, in conclusion, the first photograph is more accurate and relevant to the story than the second photo, as it better captures the essence and details related to the events and characters in the story.

When the bicyclist was trying to find Yosemite, he unexpectedly stumbled into a million - dollar setting. In the beginning, as he was seeking directions, he found himself talking to a group of old men sitting on a rickety porch. After their chat, he set off into the vast expanse that seemed to be nothing but an endless desert. “One rameshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me.” It was just him, all alone in this desolate landscape. At some point, dry tumbleweeds lazily crossed his path, and a ridiculously large snake – it really did look like a diamondback – blocked the majority of the pavement right in front of him. Tumbleweeds usually mean desert, a clear sign of the harsh environment he was in. He also passed by the @CAPS1 grape juice factory, which stood abandoned and forlorn. Finally, he reached a bait store where he was relieved to find someone else who could give him directions.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead,” the cyclist is significantly affected by the setting in numerous ways. Since he was cycling through a desert in June, the sweltering heat was intense. The high temperatures made him constantly thirsty as his body lost a lot of moisture through sweating. Moreover, due to the extreme heat, he was at a high risk of dehydration or even heat strokes. The hot sun beat down on him relentlessly, sapping his energy. Lastly, because it was a desert, there were wild animals like snakes and lizards. These creatures could potentially hurt or poison him, and if that were to happen, he could die. This is how the harsh setting of the story had a profound impact on the cyclist.

The cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by @PERSON1 endures some hardship while riding through the arid desert. The features of the desolate setting affected the cyclist severely as there was no water to drink. Being a desert, there was a lack of vegetation, and without vegetation, there is usually no accessible water source. As a result, he was gradually becoming dehydrated, his throat parched and his energy waning. The towns he passed through were also desolate, having no living organisms or people. So, he couldn't quench his thirst there either. In one town, there was a spigot, but when he tried to get water, it was gross and had clearly not been pumped in a long while. Then he came across the Welch's juice factory, which was completely abandoned. From there, he thought he was in a hopeless situation. But then he finally reached a shop that had bathrooms, and he was able to drink water from the sink, which brought him great relief. Additionally, the rocky roads took a toll on him. Since he barely had any water left, and rocky roads tend to require more strength and endurance to navigate, it made his journey even more difficult.

In the passage “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the desert's features had no positive impacts on the cyclist. The desert was filled with “rolling hills.” When a cyclist pedals over hills, according to the laws of gravity, it takes a great deal more energy. As the cyclist in the story went over these hills, he used up a large amount of his energy reserves. Eventually, he only had enough energy left to “feel sorry” for himself. The more hills he encountered, the more energy he lost, and the more exhausted he became. The desert was also extremely hot and dry. Obviously, considering he was cycling in the “deserts of California in June,” this intense heat made him incredibly thirsty. He did stop to look for water, but when he tried to get some, a “tarlike substance” came out instead, which was of no use to him. When he stopped again later for water, it was “cool” and most likely refreshing, giving him a brief respite. Riding his bike in the hilly, dry, and hot desert, the cyclist became both tired and thirsty, making his journey a real struggle.

The features of the settings have a notable effect on the cyclist through various obstacles present in the surroundings. An obstacle is an object that stands in the way between you and your destination. In the story “@CAPS1 Road Ahead @CAPS2 Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” there are several such obstacles. For instance, there are hills that the cyclist has to pedal up, which require a great deal of energy. Forks in the road can be confusing, making it difficult for the cyclist to choose the right path. Also, there are rough roads that can slow down the cyclist and make the ride uncomfortable. In the story, “a large highway sign jumped out at me it read: Rough road.” This sign was a clear warning of the difficult journey that lay ahead for the cyclist.

In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit”, the desolate setting significantly affects the way the cyclist rides. The setting is a vast expanse of nowhere, with no water in sight, and all that meets his eyes are long, empty roads stretching into the horizon. This desolate environment takes a toll on the cyclist as he is not only hungry and thirsty but also about to descend a really steep hill. Fear grips him as he contemplates the possibility of crashing and seriously injuring himself with no one around to offer help. Clearly, the setting of this isolated place has a profound impact on the cyclist in this story.

The features in the story clearly indicate that it was set in a very dry and sparsely - populated area. The text specifically mentions that there were rolling hills in the desert of California, and the air was parched. These elements strongly suggest a harsh environment. I believe those factors affected the cyclist by rapidly dehydrating him. Cycling up and down the hills can be extremely tiring, especially when he doesn't have an ample supply of water and has to ration what little he has left. The quote “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” reveals a great deal about the story. Venturing into a desert in California during the summer month of June is both a very brave and rather foolish thing to do, as it is twice as hot during this period, exacerbating the cyclist's struggle.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by depriving him of reliable directions from the old - timers. In the text, it clearly states, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in the office.” This statement implies that the cyclist did not receive good directions. The road conditions might have changed over time, but the old timers are unaware of these changes because they have been sitting on their porches for so long. As a result, the cyclist is at a disadvantage, and this is precisely why I think the setting has a negative impact on the cyclist.

In the essay entitled “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” it tells the story of a gentleman who is riding a bike to “Yosemite” but has no clear idea of how to get there. So, he stops and asks some old folks for directions. He then remarks, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This means they are not well - informed about the current road conditions and changes. After leaving the old folks, he resumes his long and sweltering journey. As he progresses, he starts to run out of water, and panic begins to set in. Next, he comes across a sign that said “Rough,” which foreshadows more challenges on his arduous trip.

The features of the setting have a detrimental effect on the cyclist. The scorching heat forces the cyclist to constantly drink water, only to lose it rapidly through sweating. As a result, he is severely worn down by dehydration and fatigue. Moreover, the sense of insecurity in this desolate place weighs heavily on him. For instance, he spots a ridiculously large snake, which sends a shiver down his spine. And to make matters worse, the temperature just keeps rising steadily. All these factors combined make the cyclist's journey an extremely difficult and perilous one.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the distinct features of the setting had a profound impact on the cyclist. The setting and its features affected him not only physically but mentally as well. The desolate expanse and harsh conditions caused him to doubt himself and the advice of the men he had encountered. Moreover, it sapped him of the energy needed to reach his destination. Where the cyclist was riding, in the arid regions of California, affected him physically. The scorching heat beat down on him relentlessly, and he had no water to quench his parched throat. This caused him to become extremely tired and increasingly frustrated. The setting affected him emotionally as well. He started off full of determination, but as he went on, and as the initially flat road slowly changed to a series of challenging hills, he began to get frustrated and angry that he had listened to the men. As he saw no buildings in sight for many miles, with only the empty, barren landscape stretching out around him, he began to lose his determination as well as hope. Lastly, when he finally saw the sign “Gary and @CAPS1 Fish Camp,” a glimmer of hope returned, and he started to regain his spirits and become less frustrated. The setting and features of the essay affected the cyclist not only physically but mentally as well. He started off determined, then as the setting changed he became doubtful and frustrated. In the end, he turned out satisfied as the setting seemed more hopeful, perhaps indicating that he was nearing the end of his trying journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The text first mentions that, “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or a structure of any kind.” This desolate sight shows that the cyclist felt insecure, and the eerie emptiness began to upset him deeply. Another example from the text that describes the cyclist's state is, “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me.” You can clearly see through the cyclist's account that he was frustrated that the water from the pumps was of such poor quality. This also could have sparked a deep - seated fear in the cyclist because he was running out of water. He was terrified that since the water tasted like, “battery acid,” with its acrid and undrinkable flavor, that he wouldn't last much longer in this harsh environment. In conclusion, the features of the setting, including the isolation and the useless water sources, affected the cyclist in many ways, making his journey a constant struggle.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” many of the distinct features of the setting affect the cyclist on his arduous journey. The rusty water pump, highway sign, and abandoned juice factory all seemed to make his trip more difficult than it already was. First of all, when the author stumbles along a “ramshackle shed” surrounded by “several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule,” he is extremely anxious to check the pump for well - needed water. His parched throat and desperate state drive him to this hope. When he finds that he is out of luck and cannot drink the bitter - tasting water, with its unpleasant and unpalatable flavor, his hope droops a little. It is as if the blazing sun were taunting him, telling him that he can't make it through this harsh journey. Secondly, he passes a large road sign reading “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” Once again he begins to feel hopeless, but then he manages to turn his angst into determination to finish his journey. He says “sometimes life can be so cruel” as he notices the speed limit to be @NUM1, but he continues on, pedaling hard against the odds. Lastly, the author sees a lone building in the distance and almost doesn't believe his eyes. It turns out to be not only his last hope for water but an abandoned grape juice factory. He reflects on the irony of his position by saying that his situation “should please all sadists” reading about it. Therefore, the features of the setting affected the cyclist by highlighting the negativity of his situation, which in turn drives him to continue pedaling, showing his indomitable spirit.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affected the cyclist in a few significant ways. One way it affected him was that the temperature was extremely hot, and the sweltering heat made it so that by it being hot outside, his water wouldn't stay cool. This is a major problem because you need nice, cool, refreshing water to stay hydrated during a long cycling journey. Another way was when he hit a fork in the road. He didn't know which way to go. All he saw was one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold the lamest mule greeted him. The dilapidated and uninviting sight was deeply troubling. Last but not least, this water pump wasn't working very well, so he got down on his hands and knees and started pumping with great effort. Despite his efforts, the water would not cool down. He tried a drop or two and the water tasted like battery acid, with its acrid and undrinkable flavor. Those are some features of the setting, such as the heat, the confusing fork in the road, and the non - functioning water pump, that affected the cyclist on his challenging journey, making it a test of his endurance and resolve.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in several notable ways. First, the rolling hills make it incredibly hard to pedal over the land. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” clearly shows that the terrain was changing into a more difficult course, requiring the cyclist to exert much more energy. “One long crippling hill,” also shows how the steep and long hills had a significant effect on the cyclist, wearing him down with each pedal stroke. Another feature of the setting was the desert and the high temperatures. The searing heat in the desert caused the cyclist to become severely dehydrated. “Trying to keep balance in my dehydrated state” and “I could drop from heatstroke” vividly show how hot the cyclist was, struggling to stay upright and conscious. One final feature that had an effect on the cyclist was the old abandoned factory. The sight of the boy with a refreshing glass of juice in front of the factory makes the cyclist lose hope completely, and he doubts he will survive this harsh journey. “I hung my head” and “abandoned factory of juices and dreams” tell how the cyclist lost all hope at the sight of the building, feeling defeated by the cruel circumstances. All of these features of the setting, including the difficult terrain, extreme heat, and the demoralizing sight of the factory, have negative affects on the cyclist, making his journey a battle against the elements and his own dwindling spirit.

The setting of the area where the cyclist was biking significantly affects him, gradually making him weaker. Since the cyclist decides to take the long route, he finds himself in the harsh desert environment for a longer period of time. The intense, unrelenting heat in the desert can cause a person to suffer from major dehydration. We know this was the case for the cyclist because he says, “...but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst...” This action clearly indicates that the cyclist put stones in his mouth to distract himself from the overwhelming feeling of thirst. I think this act precisely showcases how severely dehydrated the cyclist actually was. If he was willing to put filthy, dusty stones in his mouth just to get through his dehydration, it's evident that he was extremely thirsty. Another factor that contributed to how thirsty the cyclist got was the amount of physical exertion. This was also a feature of the setting since, during the end of his trip, he encountered rough terrain. The uneven ground and slopes forced him to exert more energy, which made him sweat even more profusely than before. This excessive sweating led to him becoming even more dehydrated. This story effectively demonstrates how the features of your environment can either make or break you, as the cyclist's experience in the challenging desert setting clearly shows the detrimental impact of the environment on his well - being.

There are several notable features of the setting which significantly affect the cyclist. One prominent factor is the fact that he is traveling on an extremely hot day in June. As he states, “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” The sweltering heat was steadily getting to the cyclist, and he was understandably scared that he might succumb to heatstroke. The terrain was also not very ideal for a cyclist on a hot June day. “I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” The cyclist was already tired from the heat, and these hills made his situation worse. Moreover, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” The cyclist was running out of water at an alarming rate, and there was nowhere close by where he could replenish his supply. These unfavorable aspects of the setting affected the cyclist because it was extremely hot, he was running out of water rapidly, and there was rough terrain to contend with. In conclusion, the setting was clearly not in the cyclist's favor, posing numerous challenges to his journey.

According to the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist a great deal. One significant way the features of the setting affect the cyclist is that the mountains, with their steep slopes and uneven paths, make the cyclist more tired. Especially considering that he has no water, having to constantly go up and down the hills really wears the cyclist out. This strenuous physical activity causes him to lose a large amount of water through sweating, leading him into dehydration at a faster rate. The features of the setting affected him in that sense. Also, the snake that he encountered affected the cyclist. The sudden appearance of the snake caused the cyclist to be afraid, which added to the stress on his body. This stress, combined with the physical exertion, further contributed to the fact that the cyclist was dehydrating. Another way that the features of the setting affected the cyclist was the Welch's Grape Juice Factory. The sight and thought of the factory, with its association to refreshing drinks, caused the cyclist to be even more thirsty and made him think about his dehydration even more. In summary, in the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist in multiple, significant ways.

The features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist because, in the story, the character vividly portrays the weather as being horrible. For example, when he said “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt,” this simple yet powerful description is one clear way the setting affects the cyclist. It almost makes the reader feel as if they are right there in the story, experiencing the same discomfort as the character. The description allows the reader to imagine the intense heat and the cyclist's struggle against it. The dried sweat rings are a visible sign of the cyclist's physical exertion and the harshness of the environment. This detailed portrayal of the setting effectively conveys the challenges the cyclist is facing. In conclusion, the well - described setting in the story successfully shows how it can have a negative impact on the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist because it makes it extremely hard for him to reach “@CAPS1 National Park.” In an attempt to reach his destination more quickly, he took the advice from some old men to take a shortcut. On his ride along this supposed shortcut, he stopped at what he considered to be a “town,” but it was, in fact, a desolate ghost town. The emptiness and lack of resources in this place added to his sense of isolation and hardship. Then he came across a Welch’s Grape Juice Factory, but it had been abandoned years earlier. As he continued his journey, he was becoming increasingly weak and dehydrated due to the long ride under the scorching sun and the lack of water sources. He started to worry that he might drop from a heatstroke at any moment. At the end of his arduous ride, he finally reached a fish camp where he was relieved to find water to drink. A man at the fish camp asked him where he was going, and the cyclist told him his destination. Then the man asked him, “Know the best way to get there?” This man was much older than the other old men that gave the cyclist advice. So the cyclist firmly told the man, “yes, sir: I own a very good map.” Through this challenging journey, the cyclist realized that he would never accept advice from old - timers again, as the advice he received led him into a difficult and dangerous situation.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed posted Speed Limit”, the specific features of the setting significantly affected the cyclist's sense of direction. The cyclist initially had a clear idea of his destination and the route to get there. However, the old men sitting on their porches offered him what they claimed to be a “short - cut”. These “old - timers” had seemingly not left their porches since Carter was in office, and their directions were out - dated. As a result, the cyclist's own well - established sense of direction was ruined. This is precisely how the setting, with these elderly locals and their archaic advice, affected the cyclist in the essay.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. I say that because when there is a peaceful and calm setting, with gentle breezes and perhaps the soft rustling of leaves, it provides a positive and motivating environment for the cyclist. In such a serene setting, the cyclist can focus better on the ride and is more likely to feel energized. On the contrary, when there is a lot of commotion, like heavy traffic noise, honking horns, and a chaotic atmosphere around, it can be a distraction and demotivate the cyclist. Thus, the nature of the setting plays a crucial role in influencing the cyclist's experience.

Steep mountains that seem to touch the sky, rolling roads that wind and curve like snakes, and jagged rocks that stand menacingly on the sides of the path are all reasons why the setting has a significant impact on the cyclist. The cyclist needs to be constantly aware of what is happening around and what might happen next. For example, the warning “Rough Rough: Do not exceed posted speed limit” clearly indicates the challenging nature of the setting. This kind of setting leads to a lot of changes in the cyclist's riding style, speed, and overall approach. So, yes, the setting does reveal a lot about the challenges ahead and also describes how the cyclist might react to it. In conclusion, throughout the whole story, the settings do indeed affect the cyclist in multiple ways.

What I believe is that the features of the setting affect the cyclist in a notable way. In the story, the old guys remember things as they used to be in the past. But as it is said in the book, the world is a fluid place where things change all the time. For the cyclist to find his way forward, he had to carefully try and piece together the information the old guys gave him. He had to sift through their nostalgic and perhaps inaccurate recollections to make sense of the current landscape and find the right path. This shows how the setting, with these old men and their memories, influenced the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in obvious ways. For instance, you wouldn't place the cyclist in a setting where it is pouring rain. In heavy rain, the roads would be slippery, visibility would be poor, and it would be extremely uncomfortable and dangerous for the cyclist to ride the bike. Another aspect is the appropriateness of the setting. You wouldn't have a setting in a city environment when the surrounding area is actually filled with only trees and rivers. The cyclist's experience is highly dependent on a setting that is suitable for cycling, and an inappropriate setting can either make the ride impossible or extremely difficult. Therefore, the features of the setting are crucial for the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting that affect the cyclist are numerous. On his long - winding way, he had to deal with a multitude of challenging things. For example, he initially enjoyed relatively flat roads, but soon those were unexpectedly replaced by short, rolling hills. These hills demanded more physical effort as he had to pedal harder to ascend and control his speed while descending. Then, there was a clearly posted sign. It stated that he could not ride at his normal pace of @NUM1; instead, he had to slow down to @NUM2. This restriction really made him disappointed as it disrupted his rhythm. As if that wasn't enough, a large snake slithered onto the pavement and blocked the majority of it right in front of him. He had to come to a sudden stop to avoid it. The long - distance cycling under such conditions made him severely dehydrated. He started to feel sad and hopeless, but somehow, deep within, he still had a spark of energy that kept him somewhat aware of himself. Despite all these hardships, he persevered, slowly pedaling forward in the hope of reaching a better stretch of the road.

There are several features of the setting that greatly affect the cyclist. One prominent feature is the vast desert he is biking through. In June, the desert heat is extremely intense. The scorching sun beats down relentlessly, and the dry air can easily dehydrate someone. When a person is exposed to this heat for a long time, especially while exercising strenuously on a bike and running out of water, the dehydrating effect is even greater. The cyclist's body starts to feel the strain as he loses vital fluids. In addition, the change in terrain and road surface would have a significant effect on the cyclist. Traveling on a flat road requires much less physical effort compared to climbing hills. If the road is also rough, with potholes and uneven patches, the biker has to work even harder to push the bike up the hill. There is also the added mental effort of carefully balancing and not tipping the bike on the uneven surface. Finally, as the cyclist looks around, there are not any buildings in sight. When someone is dehydrated but has no water, they become desperate to find a source. However, if there is nothing familiar or promising nearby, they will start to lose hope. Once they lose hope, they won't try as hard to keep going, and they will gradually lose some of their physical strength. Considering all of the things negatively affecting the cyclist, it is truly amazing that he managed to push through his exhaustion and reach a source of water, showing great determination and resilience.

The setting in the short story “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie is truly troubling to the cyclist. The description “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the tamest mule greeted me” painted a desolate picture. This made the cyclist deeply troubled as it clearly indicated that he was in the middle of nowhere, far from any signs of a proper settlement. The isolation was overwhelming. The quote, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing, flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” further shows his distress. Going over these hills was no easy task. He had to put in extra physical effort to pedal up the inclines and control his speed while going down. As you can see, the setting, with its desolation and difficult terrain, was very influential to the cyclist, constantly challenging his physical and mental endurance.

In the essays, the features of the setting affect the cyclist by giving him a glimmer of hope. The cyclist, while feeling lost in an unfamiliar area, takes directions from a few old men sitting on a porch. These old men seem wise and experienced, but at first, the directions they give seem incorrect. As he follows them, the landscape around him doesn't seem to lead to any signs of civilization. The remains of a Grape Juice factory stand as a forlorn sight. The broken machinery and dilapidated buildings make it seem like he will never find civilization, as if he is trapped in a desolate area. However, despite these discouraging signs, the fact that he has these directions gives him a reason to keep going, holding onto the hope that there is a better place ahead.

The features of the setting around the cyclist affected him to the point of exhaustion and dehydration. The cyclist, who was already starting to feel tired and thirsty, began to really wear down as the setting underwent a significant change. It transitioned from being a simple flat stretch to a landscape full of many ups and downs. The cyclist explained the change quite vividly by saying, “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). These hills in the Californian desert were like a never - ending roller coaster. As he pedaled up each hill, he had to use a great deal of energy, and the heat of the desert made it even more challenging. His water supply was steadily thinning out. The combination of the heat and the constant effort on the hills was tiring him beyond reason. All this cyclist could hope for at this desperate moment was the blessing of a water refill to quench his parched throat and the shade of a puffy cloud to provide some relief from the scorching sun. Eventually, he continued on his journey, hanging on to the hope of finding respite from the grueling conditions.

The setting affected the cyclist severely. Biking in the sweltering desert while following outdated directions nearly cost him his life. The intense heat and the vast, empty expanse wore him down. Along the way, he also came across several dilapidated factories and deserted towns, which filled him with more dismay. However, he eventually came across a last stop, a small oasis, that saved his life and gave him the strength to continue.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist is significantly affected by his surroundings. At first, the man starts out at a quiet reservoir campground. His confidence is high, and he is eager and ready to continue his adventure. As the day went on and all he could find were abandoned buildings, he began to worry a bit. With his water running low, he came upon “one ramshackled shed, several rusty pumps” with no sign of life. He realized that his trip was going to be rough. The harsh environment and the risk of death gave him the determination he needed to push forward. Although he was fearful of death from dehydration, he knew that “travelling through the high deserts of California in June,” his only chance of survival was to keep going. The man's surroundings were what had pushed him to keep biking until he found the fish camp. If he had not been so aware of his surroundings, he might have given up, but not making it out of the desert to “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite” would have been too devastating.

The setting affects the rider in multiple ways. It is extremely hot, which makes him constantly thirsty as the heat saps his body of moisture. The long, seemingly endless road affects his mental state, causing him to feel fatigued and demotivated. Lastly, the fact that there is no immediate sign of relief in sight affects his morale. All these factors combined make the ride an arduous challenge, but he perseveres, knowing that he must keep going to reach his destination.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they significantly change the cyclist's mood towards the ride. For example, in the essay “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” it states, "There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon." The cyclist had to do this because they were having great trouble riding since they were extremely thirsty and the ride was incredibly boring. This makes the ride seem much larger, so it also makes it harder to ride. Also in the essay, it states, "One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps." This affected the cyclist because after seeing this and later realizing he couldn't drink the water, he became even more thirsty as he was running out of water. When the cyclist notices the Welch's grape juice factory, he becomes determined to get there. In conclusion, in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist's mood towards the ride is strongly affected by the setting's features, which can either discourage or motivate the cyclist during the journey.

The setting affected the cyclist in many ways. When he was going up the steep hill, it was extremely hard for him to pedal as the incline required a great deal of effort. The hot summer day, with the scorching sun beating down, was gradually breaking him down. He was getting dehydrated because he only had a little bit of water left. It was evident that he was trying to keep his balance in his dehydrated state, his movements becoming more unsteady. He felt like giving up, but deep down, he knew he had to find the strength to carry on and overcome the challenges the setting presented.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. One prominent factor was the heat. For example, in paragraph @NUM1 it says, “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” Considering that California is well - known as “the sunshine state,” I can clearly infer that it was extremely hot. The sweltering heat must have sapped the cyclist's energy. Another feature that affected the cyclist was when he thought he could get some water but it was hot and tasted like battery acid. This is mentioned in paragraph @NUM2. These features of the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist, making his journey arduous and challenging.

The setting features affected the cyclist because it presented a conflict. It was a conflict primarily because it was hot and he was lost. It was a major issue that he was hot because he had a very limited amount of water. He couldn't obtain any more water because he was lost in the unfamiliar area. The heat naturally causes people to get thirsty, but he was restricted due to his limited water supply. Another conflict was that he was lost. This was a problem because he had a specific destination in mind and needed to be somewhere. Overall, these conflicts arising from the setting made the cyclist's situation quite difficult.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he rode through the blistering, heat - scorching desert of California. He pedaled his bike over @NUM1 miles to reach the beautiful Yosemite. During this long journey, he almost ran out of water, which was a life - threatening situation in the desert. What kept him going was the thought of the cool pines and the rushing rivers of Yosemite. These natural wonders of Yosemite served as a beacon of hope, motivating him to endure the harsh desert conditions.

There are many ways the cyclist is affected throughout the essay by the setting. As he first enters the “short cut” that the old men give him, he is full of confidence, believing it will lead him to his destination quickly. When he arrives at the first town and sees that it is like a ghost town, with empty streets and abandoned buildings, he does not fret but continues on his journey with confidence. As he got to the second stop, his lack of water began to take a toll on him. “I got down on my hands and knees working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength.” This shows he will work hard and is desperately in need of water. As the cyclist passed another place with no hope of water, he placed stones in his mouth because he once heard it helped get your mind off thirst. When he had just about lost hope from travelling through the hot @CAPS1 desert with no water, he found a new drive in him when he saw a store with water. Though this was a hot and harsh setting, it created inspiration for him to keep going, push through the hard times, and ultimately survive.

The cyclist in Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit was greatly affected by the setting. There were no buildings or people in the town anywhere. This desolate emptiness meant that there was no one around to offer help, and he could die without anyone knowing. Also, the setting seems to be very dry and have desert - like conditions. In such an environment, without water, the cyclist would quickly become dehydrated and could suffer from a heat stroke. Moreover, the setting seems to be intensively hot. The heat not only makes the cyclist physically dehydrated but also makes him mentally consider the real possibility of a heat stroke at the time. All in all, the harsh setting put the cyclist's life at risk.

The features of the setting had greatly impacted the cyclist. The intense heat, wild animals, and challenging terrain had slowed him down throughout his entire journey. The sweltering heat had slowed him down because he didn't have enough water to keep his body moving normally; he felt weak and fatigued. And he said the animals had slowed him down because he had to sneak around them so they wouldn't bite him. The steep hills had affected the cyclist because it takes a lot of energy to go up them, and when he was climbing, he said he could hardly see anything in sight. In the end, these elements of the setting combined to make his journey a much more difficult and time - consuming one.

The arid, bare, and rough terrain of the vast desert affected the cyclist during his long - awaited journey to Yosemite in the story “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit”. The cyclist’s expedition was severely hindered due to many unforeseen obstacles. The extreme dryness was a huge problem during his entire journey. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This excerpt clearly explains the hot, arid climate of the area where he was cycling. This harsh climate significantly decreased the rate of travel the cyclist intended to maintain. Since the cyclist was riding in the desolate desert, there weren't many towns present. When the cyclist did approach a town, it was completely abandoned. “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me” (@NUM2). After riding through the scorching desert for hours, the cyclist would have desperately wanted a nice rest stop, but all of them were ghost towns. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (@NUM1). Cycling for hours in a hot desert with limited water wasn't enough of a challenge; the flat land was suddenly replaced with hills. The cyclist was already exhausted from all the other obstacles that the desert confronted him with; the rough terrain affected his journey since his rate was further reduced. In conclusion, many factors negatively affected the cyclist's expedition to Yosemite. The dry, bland, and hilly terrain of the desert severely hindered his journey, making it a struggle from start to finish.

I believe the setting of an area can greatly affect the mind when put in certain situations. In the reading, the man is cycling in a desolate place. He sees no one around him, he is almost out of water, and as far as his eyes can see, he can't spot a house or a person. This desolate scenario is extremely scary and gives the feeling of utter helplessness. But if he would be in @LOCATION1, a bustling area, and go past cars zooming by, people strolling on the street, and parked cars, he would be much calmer. He could easily get water at any building along his ride. Moreover, the temperature would be cold there, so he would drink less water and could go further. This change in setting would have definitely changed his mood, making him more at ease and less anxious.

Well in the story Do Not Exceed Posted Speed limits by @PERSON1, the setting affects you in a profound way. If you can't see anything for miles and you are running out of water, it has a strong psychological effect on you. You can start to panic, just like he did when he stopped at the old house and all that came out of the pump was battery acid. Also, you don't exactly know where you are precisely, so that also affects you because you don't know whether to go forward, turn back, or what to do. If I was this person, the desolate features around me, like the empty expanse of land and the lack of resources, would have a great deal of effect on me. In such a situation, the uncertainty and the threat of dehydration would make the journey extremely stressful and nerve - wracking.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. In the beginning of the essay, she was elated that she was getting a shortcut. "I followed their device and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park.” She thought she knew exactly where she was going. “I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on." When she entered the first town, the dilapidated sight was troubling. "I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength,” she was beginning to get worried as she was running out of water. The next town was “only eighteen miles down the road.” She was now in a dehydrated state. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Then she saw a building, but unfortunately, it was no longer open. So she got back on her bike, but her thoughts had completely changed; she was now upset and expecting the worst, even to die. Then she saw a store, “Gary and Wilbers fish camp”. She went in, drank the cool water with relief, and then decided to use her own map, rather than relying on the advice of the old guys. In the end, the setting's features had a roller - coaster effect on her journey and state of mind.

There were numerous features of the setting that had a notable impact on the cyclist. One prominent feature was the severe lack of water. This scarcity had led the cyclist to become dehydrated, causing their mind to be clouded and unable to think clearly. Moreover, it had sapped the cyclist's energy, making every pedal stroke a struggle. An example is, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Another significant feature is the intense heat. The sweltering heat had made the cyclist constantly thirsty and drenched in sweat. An example is “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage…” Another instance is, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The features of the setting had affected the cyclist in many ways, making the journey an arduous one.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, there were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. The first feature that affected the cyclist was the harsh desert terrain. It was extremely hot, and there were no trees to provide even a sliver of shade. This affected the cyclist because he got very hot and constantly thirsty. As a result, he drank more water than his normal consumption. Secondly, since he was drinking more than usual, he was running out of water quickly. So, he had to conserve his remaining water, which gradually made him become dehydrated. To make matters worse, all the towns they passed through were ghost towns with no running fresh water. This extremely disappointed him and further exacerbated his dehydration. Just when the cyclist was on the verge of losing hope, he found a small bait shop. He got into the shade and finally got water to drink. So after all those disappointments, he found hope in the small bait shop, which gave him the strength and mental boost to continue on with his journey to Yosemite National Park, showing that even in the harshest settings, there can be a glimmer of hope.

The features of the setting made the cyclist’s journey even longer and more strenuous. The fact that it was in such a remote area did not help at all. For example, the people who still lived in that remote area were probably as old as the cyclist's grandparents, and the directions they gave were horribly inaccurate. Also, there were no new shops or areas for the cyclist to rest. The water pump he found was old and dirty, and the only building he saw was abandoned. Another factor was the rough terrain. Since the cyclist was already very fatigued due to lack of water and tiredness, the long, bumpy, and overall horrible terrain made things even worse. Finally, the last factor was that he was bicycling in California on a sweltering summer day, and the fact that his bike had no proper cooling mechanism (but which bike does) did not help at all. These are how the features significantly affected the cyclist's journey, making it a true test of endurance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the rougher the terrain got, the more the cyclist had to strain to make progress. For example, when the terrain transformed into steep hills, the cyclist had to struggle vigorously to climb the hills, which caused him to expend a large amount of his energy reserves. Also, if the terrain was flat and smooth, the cyclist encountered fewer problems during the long journey. For instance, if the cyclist faced less strain, he would not be as tired and would not need to drink as much water. In conclusion, the nature of the terrain and other features of the setting directly influence the cyclist's physical state and energy consumption, ultimately affecting the overall experience of the journey.

He wouldn't know what challenges he would be facing while riding on the road. There could be something bad that might happen to his bike, like one of his bike’s wheels getting damaged or malfunctioning. Or he might accidentally fall off his bike. He could become so tired that he physically couldn't go any further and might even consider giving up on his journey. However, despite these potential difficulties, the cyclist's determination might still push him to persevere through the uncertainties of the road.

The setting affects the cyclist by the need and comfort of riding down with no infrastructure around or people. This situation allows the cyclist to be in the best mood, with the air being nice and cool, no cars in sight, and just him and the beautiful sky to ride with. In contrast, if there is infrastructure, he must watch for people, cars, and pay attention to street signs and act accordingly.
