So, that's how the features of the setting would affect the cyclist, influencing his overall experience and the way he rides.

In the adventures of the cyclist, the setting is not only what develops the character but also what affects how he pushes himself to not give up, even when he feels helpless. This is one example of how the cyclist is affected. As he says, "I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high desert of California in June." With that information, you can observe how this harsh setting creates problems for him physically because his body needs water. He is extremely limited in his water supply and doesn't savor it very well. These issues create the problem of dehydration, and when mentally you think you're going to die without water, you start to panic and lose control over yourself. Thus, the setting significantly impacts the cyclist's physical and mental state.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist. There were rough terrains that made the cycling difficult, and perhaps a lack of proper facilities like water sources. These elements of the setting put extra strain on the cyclist, influencing his performance and overall experience. In the end, it's clear that the features of the setting had a notable impact on the cyclist's journey.

In ''Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted speed Limit'' by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting most of the time disappoint him. You can tell that the features of the setting disappointed him because every time he got to a town, he couldn't get water. In the text, it states, ''I got down on my hands & knees working the handle of the rusty water pump as a foul - like substance oozed out followed by @NUM1 degree brackish water that tasted like battery acid.'' You know the setting disappoints him when he sees the terrain he has to cross as well. You can tell from what he says, ''At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path along with a ridiculously large snake.'' The narrator was disappointed that he listened to the directions of the elder rather than use his map. Joe Kurmaskie does a great job of showing how the narrator faced these disappointing settings and how he felt about them, making the reader understand the negative impact of the setting on the narrator's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the route that the cyclist was taking had a rough road for him to travel. The cyclist took bad advice from some old men who hadn't left off their porches for decades. Also, as he got into his long journey, he began to notice that the advice the old men had given him was bad. The cyclist was headed to Yosemite and he had gotten some advice that turned out to be unhelpful. This bad advice, combined with the rough road, made his journey more challenging. In conclusion, the features of the setting, along with the poor advice, had a negative impact on the cyclist's trip.

When the cyclist first set off, he was doing fine as he had packed plenty of water in his backpack. As he kept going and sort of got off - course, he gradually began to come into the vast desert region. The scorching sun was beating down on him, and he was sweating profusely. He was hot, and he was quickly running out of water. This was making him severely dehydrated, his lips chapped and his throat parched. Also, seeing the tumbleweeds rolling across the desolate landscape and the lack of any green vegetation probably made him even worse mentally, because he was maybe thinking he was never going to get free from that endless expanse of sand. When he saw the fish bait shop though, he was probably relieved that he was going to be saved, and he could finally replenish his water supply and continue his journey.

There are many ways that a cyclist will be affected and one of these are the setting. The setting affects them because if it is a short, smooth setting like a well - paved bike path in a park, the ride will be easy. The cyclist can maintain a steady speed and enjoy the scenery without much effort. But if it is long, bumpy, and rough roads such as unpaved mountain trails, it will be harder to control the bike. The constant jolts and uneven surfaces require the cyclist to use more energy to keep the bike stable. This means that the cyclist’s job will be hardened. This is how a cyclist is affected by his or her settings, and it clearly shows the significant impact of the riding environment on the cyclist's experience.

The cyclist ran into rough settings on the way to @ORGANIZATION1 park. The first is the town he came to was a ghost town. The empty streets were lined with dilapidated buildings, and there was an eerie silence all around. Then he was running out of water when he ran by tambleweeds, and a large snake slithered in front of him, causing him to jolt in surprise. He had no more water and there were rough, rocky roads ahead of him. As he continued, he came across a juice factory. No one was there, the factory seemed abandoned with broken windows and rusty machinery. He was out of water and he did not know how much longer it would be until he came to another town. That is why I say that how the features of the setting affected the cyclist, as these difficult conditions made his journey extremely challenging.

The features of the setting have a very negative effect on the cyclist. According to the old men, the cyclist would pass by a few towns if he took the route they told him. But every town the cyclist came to was deserted. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The desolate streets were filled with dust, and the empty houses seemed to echo with a sense of abandonment. Because the towns were deserted, the cyclist's water supply was dwindling rapidly because there was no place where he could get more water. He became dehydrated and kept pushing himself, his legs feeling heavy with exhaustion, to find a place where there was fresh water. “Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Once he found some pebble and thought about sucking on them because it helps to slow down dehydration. But he didn’t because he thought he would choke on them. The setting around him also made him have negative thoughts. “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Because the setting was a hot, deserted, desert it had a very negative effect on the cyclist. If he hadn’t been running out of water I don’t think that the effect of the setting would have been as bad. But because he did run out of water it made the effects much worse, highlighting the crucial role of water in such a harsh environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. One reason I say this is because he ran out of water in the middle of a dry, arid area. With no water source in sight, he could dehydrate, which would lead to fatigue, dizziness, and a significant decrease in his physical performance. Also, looking for water slowed him down more as he had to constantly scan the surroundings and deviate from his original path. Another reason I say this is because the man gave him the wrong directions. The incorrect instructions led him into unfamiliar and difficult terrain, which got him lost and confused. He wasted time trying to figure out where he was and how to get back on track. That is how the setting affected the cyclist, as both the lack of water and the wrong directions caused by the setting made his cycling journey a struggle.

It is said that, "experience is a good substitute for natural instinct." This means that if someone knows how to deal with the environment they're in, they can survive even if they weren't born with the animal instincts that come with that particular territory. However, even the most experienced person can be overcome by the extreme weather conditions they live in. In the essay, "Rough Road Ahead," by Joe Kurmaskie, the experienced cyclist decides to take a long, arduous, and dangerous trip. His ride will take him along the long desert paths of California with a limited water supply. This limited water supply is the major element that hinders him in the story. Because he listened to some old men, he went without water for most of his trip. Between his constant exercise, the extreme heat, and the lack of water, dehydration hit him fast. A common side effect of dehydration is hallucination, which the cyclist knew. It says in the essay, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage.” This represents his knowledge and experience in the matter, and shows that he was adapting to his environment through experience. A similar story to this is Jack London's, “To Build a Fire” where the man is also pitted against the extremes of nature through the frigid cold, but the elements still overtook him. Both stories represent man's quest for adventure, and also the constant struggle for survival that people face. In the end, these tales remind us of the power of nature and the importance of being prepared.

The features of a setting can significantly affect a cyclist's energy. When the setting turns into a landscape filled with steep hills, it can exhaust this cyclist completely. The continuous effort required to pedal uphill against gravity drains the cyclist's energy reserves. With each ascent, the cyclist has to push harder, expending more energy than on a flat surface. As a result, the cyclist becomes fatigued, and their performance is negatively impacted. In conclusion, the hilly setting has a detrimental effect on the cyclist's energy and ability to ride effectively.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist most in the fact that it strains him out of the hydrated state. The harsh conditions of the environment, such as high temperatures and long distances, cause the cyclist to sweat profusely. This excessive sweating leads to a rapid loss of fluids from his body, pushing him out of the hydrated state. As a result, it makes him unable to operate at his full power and efficiency. His muscles become fatigued more quickly, and his cognitive functions may also be impaired. It deprives him of the little energy he had in him to begin with. That is how the setting affected him, ultimately limiting his performance and making the journey much more challenging.

The setting affects the cyclist very strongly. The desert environment with its intense heat and the absence of water cause him to get dehydrated rapidly. Dehydration not only makes him feel weak but also impairs his physical and mental abilities. The rolling hills and rough terrain further tire him out. The constant effort of pedaling uphill and navigating the uneven ground requires a great deal of energy. In the story it says “and growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This shows that the combination of the heat and the challenging terrain could cause him to overheat and suffer a heat stroke. In summary, the setting poses a significant threat to the cyclist's well - being and ability to complete his journey.

The temperature of the place that the cyclist was riding through affected him very much. The high temperature caused the cyclist to sweat profusely. This sweating was a natural response of his body to cool down, but it had a significant impact on him. As he lost fluids through sweating, he would get thirsty, and his body's need for water increased. Eventually, he ran out of water. For example, in the text he says “the water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips” and then it goes on to say, “I could drop from a heat stroke.” This showed how it affected him because he was acutely aware that the lack of water due to the high temperature put him at risk of dropping from the heat. In conclusion, the high temperature had a severe and direct impact on the cyclist's physical condition and his ability to continue the ride.

The features of the settling that affected the cyclist were the harsh and sweltering hot climate, along with the challenging terrain. The author clearly wrote about how “the sun was beating down relentlessly on him” and how he almost died from severe dehydration, highlighting the extreme conditions the cyclist endured.

The features of the setting do indeed affect the cyclist. If the road is rough, you have to have the right type of bike that can handle the uneven surface. Then, if you get a flat tire, you have to know to look out for dangerous and poisonous things like snakes or thorny plants. If you were in a real bad accident, you’d have to be prepared just in case they don’t find you in time, perhaps by carrying a basic first - aid kit. You would also have to know what the nights were like. For example, if it got really cold at night, you need to have proper layers to keep yourself warm so as to avoid hypothermia.

The desert and the hills had a huge and challenging effect on the cyclist. The desert in June must have been extremely hot, with the scorching sun baking the ground. Going up those hills had to be incredibly hard, as the cyclist had to pedal against gravity on the rough inclines. The road was also very rough, full of potholes and uneven patches. It says, “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” It also says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The cyclist was very thirsty because of the blistering hot weather, constantly craving for a sip of cool water. I think the setting had a huge and detrimental effect on the cyclist, making his journey a real struggle.

The cyclist’s condition was greatly influenced by his setting because he was lost in the high deserts of California in June. The intense heat crippled him as he traveled in search of Yosemite. He became lost and ran out of water, making his already difficult situation even worse. Being lost in seemingly the middle of nowhere in the searing hot heat, he became exhausted, dehydrated, and feared heat stroke and loss of consciousness. This is shown in the essay by, “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke” And, “It looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time,” clearly depicting the dire circumstances he faced.

How the features of the setting affected the cyclist in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Limit,” were very dangerous to his life. The cyclist was traveling to the Yosemite National Park on a hot day in June. The cyclist traveled miles after miles on his bike only to pass by deserted towns. As described, “This place might have been a thriving little spot...a ghost town,” creating an eerie and desolate atmosphere. The terrain was threatening because after twenty - two miles or so, the cyclist had to overcome “short rolling hills,” which would use more energy and make his thirst for water even stronger. The cyclist was out of water and the blistering hot day was not helping at all. After a grueling journey, the cyclist used all the strength he had left to go to a local bait shop and drank from the sink after the treacherous environment he was exposed to. The features of the setting in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” were life - threatening and almost killed the cyclist, due to lack of water and the difficult terrain he overcame, emphasizing the perils of the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by teasing him. First, the gently rippling streams with their clear, inviting water taunted his intense thirst. Then, an old, rusty faucet stood there, seemingly mocking his dry throat. And last, the dilapidated welches grape factory, with its faint aroma of grape juice, had him almost abandon hope. The streams were the beginning stage, simply provoking his thirst. Then came the faucet, which made him acutely realize that he was severely dehydrated. The setting was clearly affecting his mood, leaving him frustrated and desperate.

In the story, the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. The text states, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. I could drop from a heatstroke.” This clearly shows that in the area where the cyclist was riding, water was extremely scarce and hard to find. He is expressing his fear of dying if he doesn't get water soon. Another aspect is that the surroundings are desolate, with no buildings in sight and deserted roads. There are many hills and long stretches of empty roads. The story mentions, “the terrain changing, flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This indicates that he was mostly all by himself, with no one around to turn to for help. The harsh setting put the cyclist in a very vulnerable situation.

In this story, the features of the setting heavily affect the cyclist. Certain features portray that this “journey” to Yosemite National Park was both dreadful and enjoyable. “I would come to along this breeze jaunt.” The word “breezy” suggests that the cyclist can relish the bike - riding experience as there is a gentle breeze. Another feature of the setting is extremely old and dirty. The water the cyclist drinks is of such poor quality that it dries his mouth out even more. “A tar - like substance oozed out followed by a brackish water feeling.” This vividly shows the dirty nature of the water. Also, this setting demonstrates that the cyclist had to utilize all his strength and resources just to survive. It says “working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength.” Overall, the features of the setting portray the sacrifice and bravery of the cyclist as he endures the difficult journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting greatly affects the cyclist. The arid setting around the cyclist made her drink a lot of water due to the dry conditions. “I was traveling the high deserts of California in June.” This indicates that she was most likely hot, sweating profusely, and there was no nearby source of water. The rough terrain also forced her to rely on her own strength to ascend and descend hills and to navigate around plants and animals. The settings in the story led the cyclist to become dehydrated and weak. She was forced to continue with a low supply of water and avoid numerous hazards, with no sign of living people nearby. “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time, say, before the last world war.” This suggests a ghost town where no people currently reside. There was no one around to assist her. The setting led to a deterioration of her health. Her physical health was at risk because of dehydration and lack of energy. Her mind was also starting to falter. She had to shake her head to ensure what she was seeing was real in one part of the story. In conclusion, the harsh setting took a severe toll on the cyclist's well - being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The man didn't have an adequate supply of water and he was venturing into the hot California deserts in June, where the scorching sun made the conditions extremely harsh. Another reason is that the initially flat road was transformed into rolling hills, and up ahead there was a prominent sign that said “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The speed limit was @NUM1, which added an extra challenge to his journey. One more thing to note is that he should not blindly listen to an old gentleman who hadn't left his porch in decades as his advice might not be reliable in the current situation. These are some of the key factors in the setting that can have a significant impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist since it is directly impacting her physical condition. In this sweltering environment, she desperately needs water to survive, yet the next town is an extremely long distance away. So, if she doesn't take a break, combined with the scorching hot temperatures, she could very possibly pass out. “When I tried a draught, it had the flavor of battery acid” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). Clearly, if she doesn't find water soon, it will severely affect her condition. Also, the features of the setting influence her determination. When she realizes that she urgently needs to find a town, she digs deeper and works harder. "I would conserve my water, go inward for an hour or so at least, or rely on my inner spirit" (@NUM1). She will try her utmost to make smart decisions and reach a town as quickly as possible. She works with extra effort since she knows that without water, her life is at great risk. Now, things could get even more difficult, but she remains determined to overcome these challenges.

During the cyclist's journey in “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, he experiences notable setting changes. Initially, the road is flat, which is a relatively easy - going terrain for cycling. As he is riding, he comments that the road is flat. “Flat road was replaced” indicates that the road he was on was initially smooth and nice. However, as he continues his ride, he notices a distinct change in the land. “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This change in the terrain means that the cyclist will face more difficulties, as climbing hills requires more energy and effort. In conclusion, these land changes have a direct impact on the cyclist's journey, making it more challenging than before.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. The sweltering heat in the setting takes a toll on him. In an attempt to find a quicker way, he takes a couple of tips on some supposed short - cuts from some old men sitting on their porch. Unfortunately, these tips turn out to be false, and the so - called short - cuts are not short at all. Now, he is riding, filled with anger for having followed their advice. Moreover, he is running out of water and becoming severely dehydrated. As he rides on, he spots an abandoned place with a water source. But to get the water, he has to pump it. He starts pumping and is horrified to see black gunk coming out. He pumps for about @NUM1 minutes in hopes of cooling the water, but it remains hot. To his dismay, the water tastes like battery acid. He resumes his ride but then encounters a snake. Fortunately, he manages to get away. At this point, he feels that he is on the verge of death and deeply regrets listening to the old men who haven't left their porch since @PERSON1 was president. What angers him even more is that they seemed so confident in their advice. As he's riding, he spots a place that he thought was a juice factory and heads there. To his surprise, it's now a fishing store, but he is relieved to drink lots and lots of water. He firmly states that he will never listen to old men again and will always rely on the map to avoid such misfortunes in the future.

As the author of the story embarks on her bike trip, the landscape around her gradually becomes less and less inviting. The first obstacle the cyclist encounters is a rusty pump and an old shed. When she attempts to get water from the pump, she describes the water as extremely hot, and it shows no sign of cooling down at all. As she continues her journey, tumbleweeds that resemble “diamond head snakes” cross her path, adding to the sense of unease. She rides for a long time without seeing any buildings. When she finally does come across a building, it is abandoned, which strongly suggests that people left the area because of the harsh landscape. During her journey, she meets another elderly man, but due to the bad experience she had following the advice of the last set of elderly men, she decides not to take his advice. In the end, she realizes that she needs to rely on her own judgment to navigate through this unforgiving landscape.

The features of the surrounding setting have a profound impact on the cyclist's performance. For example, in the essay “Rough Road Ahead. Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the landscape is full of hills that twist, rise, and descend. All these topographical features work against the cyclist's energy reserves, making the ride much more strenuous. Additionally, the scarcity of people in the towns poses a significant problem for the cyclist. It becomes extremely difficult and depriving for the cyclist to find a water supply, which is crucial to prevent dehydration. Thirdly, the weather in the essay plays a major role in affecting the cyclist. The desert of California is extremely hot, and the cyclist has to maintain a high level of hydration to continue the bike ride. In conclusion, the combination of challenging terrain, lack of water sources, and hot weather makes the cyclist's journey a very difficult one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many tangible ways, namely heat, lack of water, and hills. The scorching heat beats down on him relentlessly, sapping his energy. While on his journey, he almost gets severely dehydrated because he does not have a good supply of water. When he does take a sip from his meager reserves, he remarks that they taste “like battery acid.” And he had to laboriously pedal up the road for another @NUM1 miles so that he could finally replenish himself at a place where he hoped to find clean, cool water. After reaching his destination and quenching his thirst, he was able to continue his journey with a bit more ease, having overcome this challenging part of his ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by significantly hurting his ability to keep going. In this story, the cyclist was faced with a series of setbacks or problems. At first, he naively took advice from a very old man who provided out - of - date directions, leading him astray. Then, the cyclist made a poor decision by thinking he could keep going on a very limited water supply. As a result, the cyclist then started getting dehydrated and his frustration turned into anger. The cyclist then spotted an old building in the distance, which raised his hopes of finding water and rest. However, his hopes were quickly dashed once he found out it was closed and rundown. Finally, he spots a store in the distance. He rushes inside, rehydrates himself, and then he is on his way again, having learned the importance of proper planning and not relying on unreliable sources.

I think features affect the cyclist because when you ride a bicycle, you need to consider various elements of the setting. For example, the terrain can make pedaling easier or harder. A flat road allows for a smooth and fast ride, while hilly areas require more effort. The weather also plays a role. Hot and sunny days can lead to dehydration if proper precautions aren't taken, and rainy conditions can make the road slippery and visibility poor. All these features have a direct impact on the cyclist's experience and performance. In conclusion, cyclists must be aware of these features to have a safe and enjoyable ride.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist has a very long and arduous journey that is affected by a variety of things and problems. The cyclist starts off confident with himself at the beginning, believing he can handle whatever comes his way. But after a few moments under the harsh conditions of the journey, he feels really bad, both physically and mentally, and learns a really good lesson about preparation. “I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This quote clearly shows that it is really hard for him to move without water. It demonstrates that he is not only thirsty but severely dehydrated, which is extremely dangerous for a human being. The cyclist also had a really bad time because he resorted to extreme measures, like tasting stones in order to make his thirst go away, one example of that is when he had been without water for hours and was desperate for any relief. Eventually, he learned that proper planning and carrying enough supplies are essential for such a journey.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” a cyclist is confronted with a troubling setting on his journey to Yosemite. He is led away from the steady road as a result of taking mislead advice from an old group of individuals. In this essay, the setting plays a crucial and far - reaching impact on the cyclist. In the essay, the author sets up the story describing the day as, “traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The intense heat of the desert in June is almost unbearable. Because of the amount of heat the cyclist was enduring, he became extremely weary and severely dehydrated. Along with this, the cyclist had to work much harder because the man noticed, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” These hills required him to use more energy to pedal. This setting is a major setback to the cyclist’s journey, and required him to persevere through the pain and exhaustion. In my life, there have been numerous obstacles which I have had to persevere through. One of which had been when I was out camping, and suddenly, as in the essay, the setting changed, and a fierce storm came. The strong winds and heavy rain made our situation difficult. Though the other campers and I did what we needed to, like setting up a proper shelter, to make the best out of it. In the essay, the cyclist is affected greatly by the setting. This was the same in my experience as the setting affected myself. In both situations, perseverance led to a final satisfaction of the journey, as we overcame the challenges presented by the changing settings.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the roads are extremely bumpy, filled with potholes and uneven patches. This makes it difficult for the cyclist to maintain balance and control. The text also mentions that the terrain changed, and he even came across a snake, which not only startled him but also increased his stress and thirst. All these factors made it more difficult for him to continue his journey. From reading the text, it's evident that the environmental features can have significant and varied effects on a person.

The features of the setting have a strong and distinct effect on the cyclist's arduous journey to Yosemite. The characteristics of the land, including its mountains and hills, the fact that it is a desert, and the setting being in the middle of June, all play crucial roles in this story. The dry and hilly landscape is a major hurdle for the main character. Since the land is hilly, he has to exert twice as much effort to pedal uphill, quickly exhausting his energy. Moreover, the dryness of the land leaves him constantly thirsty, and there are no readily available sources of water. As it is a desert, there are no settlements or places where he can seek help, obtain food or water, or find any signs of civilization. He begins to lose hope and believes that he won't be able to make it to his destination. The text in paragraph!! explains, “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh.” This shows his desperation. Clearly, the setting, being hot, dry, and deserted, has a detrimental effect on the main character and his journey.

The cyclist in the essay Rough Road Ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit feels deeply discouraged and suffers from dehydration because of the desolate setting. Near the beginning, after viewing the first stop which consisted of a few broken - down buildings and some rusted pumps, he states, “This sight was troubling.” The dilapidated appearance of the place immediately dampened his spirits. He also feels severe dehydration when he reaches the pumps and finds that “A tar - like substance oozed out, followed by blackish water,” which was clearly unfit for consumption. Also, as he is pedaling along the arid road, he sees a sign that says do not exceed 55 miles per hour. This sign seems like an added burden in his already difficult journey, highlighting the long and arduous road ahead. In conclusion, the harsh setting takes a significant toll on the cyclist, both physically and mentally.

In this quick passage by Joe Kurmaskie, the many conditions of the road and the desolate area around it greatly determine how he acts and what he feels. “The sun was beginning to beat down,” (Kurmaskie). As the sun rises higher in the sky, its intense rays start to take a toll on him. He is starting to get extremely tired because it is becoming swelteringly hot and sunny, so he is feeling less confident about continuing his journey. He was traveling through the high deserts of California in June, a time when the heat is at its peak. (Kurmaskie). Not only is he very tired and hot, but the place where he is riding is barren and open, and there is no one around him to give him help or to find water. Through the passage, you can clearly tell that the temperature and weather around the cyclist can significantly change his state of mind and his ability to keep going. In conclusion, the harsh environmental conditions have a profound impact on the cyclist's experience.

That clearly explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. In the essay, the evidence that supports the conclusion is that the cyclist's actions and emotions are closely tied to the features of the setting. The cyclist is affected by the desolate landscape, the lack of resources, and the extreme weather conditions. For example, the broken - down buildings and rusty pumps at the first stop made him feel discouraged, and the unfit water from the pumps led to his dehydration. All these elements in the setting have a direct impact on the cyclist's well - being and journey. In conclusion, the features of the setting play a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's experience.

The beautiful scenery makes the cyclist extremely happy. He's so overjoyed that he can't contain his excitement! As he pedals along, he is surrounded by a panorama of lush green meadows, clear blue skies, and colorful wildflowers. The gentle breeze carries the sweet scent of the flowers, and the soft chirping of birds fills the air. He lets out a loud “Woohoo!” in pure elation. Every moment spent in this idyllic setting brings a wide smile to his face. In conclusion, the enchanting scenery has a magical effect on the cyclist, filling him with happiness and a sense of peace.

In this story, the setting has a significant affect on the cyclist's trip and his well - being. It is extremely hot, with the temperature soaring over @NUM1 degrees, and the road is going down hill with a lot of sharp turns. The cyclist is getting so hot that his water, which was once cold, is now warm and unrefreshing. Being in this scorching desert is like being in an oven, slowly sapping his energy. The intense heat and the challenging terrain are taking a heavy toll on him, and he is on the verge of having a heart - stroke. All the harsh elements in the desert, such as the high temperature, the lack of shade, and the difficult road conditions, are having a profound effect on the cyclist. In conclusion, the desert setting poses a great challenge to the cyclist's physical and mental endurance.

The setting of a situation can significantly affect a person both mentally and physically. This is clearly evident in @PERSON1 “Do not Exceed Posted speed Limit.” The cyclist remains, for the most part, unaffected until the directions he receives from “a collection of old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office” lead him over terrain that is highly unsuitable for biking. Prior to following the men’s directions, the setting is quite enjoyable and makes for an easy ride. A reader can know this because the cyclist exudes confidence. For example, he says “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” However, this confidence begins to deplete as the cycling becomes more difficult. For instance, after hitting rolling hills and coming across a sign warning of a rough road and not exceeding the speed limit, the cyclist remarks “sometimes life can feel so cruel.” He becomes disappointed and wants to give up because he can't even reach that speed limit. Nevertheless, he is determined and pushes through to reach a shop. This achievement gives him a strong sense of satisfaction and restores his confidence. So, in conclusion, the setting can have a powerful impact on a person's mood or motivation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in various ways, making his journey a challenging one, just like when he rode through that desolate ghost town. The setting is a major part of this story, and much of the narrative focuses on it. For example, details such as when he stops to get water or how the tumbleweeds are lazily crossing the road are described. He is constantly thirsty as he pedals his bike for long distances. The harsh environment takes a toll on him, yet he perseveres. In conclusion, the setting plays a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's experience during his journey.

How the setting changes the mood of the cyclist is that what he sees pretty much describes how he feels. Initially, he starts off with strong legs and a bright smile on his face, full of enthusiasm for the journey. Then he arrives at the first town, which turns out to be a ghost town. This sight doesn't really dampen his spirits because when he sees it, he lets out a laugh. Also, as the setting changes, so does his confidence in the old men's direction - giving. At the first town, he still has full confidence in what they told him. Then he notices that the temperature is starting to rise, but that doesn't change his mood significantly. @NUM1 miles later, he comes to a fork in the road with rusty water pumps and a dilapidated, run - down car. All these elements make him less confident about his water level. Then he realizes that the next town is a long way away, so he loses more confidence and becomes more worried about running out of water. Subsequently, the flat road is replaced with a rough, bumpy one, and his mood deteriorates further. Finally, he reaches a fishing store where he gets water, and his spirits soar. This is how the setting affected his mood throughout the journey.

The features and setting in the story affected the cyclist because they made his arduous journey to Yosemite even more difficult. In the story, it vividly describes that the heat was so intense that he could potentially drop dead from heatstroke at any moment. Also, his limited supply of water made him extremely fatigued as he pedaled his bike. Moreover, the sun was beating down relentlessly. Not only was he tired due to his lack of water, but he was also losing water and energy rapidly through his sweat because of the sweltering heat outside. These factors combined are why the features and setting made his journey to Yosemite a truly challenging and strenuous endeavor.

In the short story, “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist experiences some tough times during his journey. When he starts the journey, he has very little water with him. Given that the weather is hot and dry, his water supply depletes quickly, leaving him with hardly any water for the rest of the trip. Additionally, the rough, uneven roads make him extremely tired. The constant jolting and effort required to navigate these roads make it even harder for him to continue the journey. In conclusion, the lack of water and the poor road conditions set the stage for a difficult and trying journey for the cyclist.

Features of the setting that affect the cyclist are “the cool pines and rushing rivers”. These natural elements affect the cyclist by keeping him cool through the shade of the pines and the refreshing air near the rivers. The scenic beauty of the pines and the sound of the rushing rivers also energize him. Another notable feature is the juice factory, which was old and shut - down. Its dilapidated state gives an eerie feeling, suggesting that he would die alone. The ghost town, which was completely and utterly deserted, with empty streets and abandoned buildings, shows that the place is barren and unlivable. These are some of the features that affect the biker, making his journey a mix of beauty and desolation.

The cyclist is very discouraged by the dry and hot settings around him. A feature is something specific about some thing else. In “Rough Road Ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit”, the cyclist takes the advice of a few old men that seems to be somewhat outdated. Following their advice, he gets lost as he is running out of water and energy. The cyclist says “Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). He is greatly affected by the heat, and the exhaustion from cycling in such conditions makes him so tired that he wants to make sure the building is not an illusion. Also, the changed terrain, with its steep slopes and uneven ground, affected how much water he drank and how hard he had worked just to get up that one long hill. The dry climate and tough terrain greatly affected the cyclist, making his journey a real struggle.

Heat, desert, humidity – all are things that affect the cyclist as on his journey. First, heat because the intense heat is making him extremely thirsty for water that he is running low on. For example, the narrator describes, “… water bottles only had a few tantalizing sips.” This means that the day is hot, and the cyclist is in a critical situation of running out of water. Second, desert because the narrator is the only one around, and deserts are usually deserted. The vast expanse of sand and lack of any signs of life are evident. For example, the narrator exclaims “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, structure of any kind.” This clearly states that he could be in a desert where no one wants to be. Lastly, humidity, because it can be hot but then the humidity comes into play and makes the sky more dry - looking and the heat seem hotter than it usually is. This is why heat, desert, and humidity all are things that affect the cyclist as he is on a journey, making it a challenging one.

The features of the setting greatly affect this cyclist. At first, he is fine riding along the old - timers “shortcut” as he states that “things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” But what he didn't know was this was the beginning of a very rough day. He arrived at the first “town” which was a ghost town. The empty streets and silent buildings gave an eerie feeling, but he wasn't overly worried yet. At about sixty miles in on his journey, he came to a ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a broken - down corral. The cyclist explains how he had drank a lot of his water and was in desperate need of some. He tried the pumps but he explains how “a tar - like substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” A couple of miles later, he came to a highway sign that read ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The cyclist continued on, his throat parched and desperate for water. He even came across a snake, which added to his unease. He was now fearing a heat stroke. He came to an abandoned grape juice factory and hung his head in despair. The cyclist then was almost completely dehydrated from the long, tiring bike ride. The cyclist was sure he was going to die from dehydration or a heatstroke that this terrible ride had caused. He finally came to a shop and drank from the sink, feeling a wave of relief. So this ride was torturous due to the setting, which tested his limits.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in positive and negative ways. At first, there were the two old men who gave the cyclist the out - of - date information. They affected him negatively because if it wasn't for them, the cyclist would have never gotten lost and found himself in a difficult situation. When the cyclist arrived at the first town, the water pump affected him. The cyclist was running out of water, and when he tried the water from the water pump, it tasted like battery acid and was about @NUM1°F. The unpleasant taste and high temperature made it undrinkable, and the cyclist was becoming more and more dehydrated. The small, rolling hills didn't help his dehydration either; he also used a lot of energy in order to go over the hills, further depleting his resources. Finally, he found Gary and Wilber’s fish camp where he was able to get water. This whole experience in a way, affected the cyclist positively even though, at the time, he was affected negatively. The cyclist learned to not take advice from really old people who “haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” The cyclist was affected positively and negatively by the features of the setting, and this experience will likely make him more cautious in future travels.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit”, the cyclist is on an adventurous journey to Yosemite National Park. Along the way, he stops at a small roadside spot to seek advice on a quicker route. When he approaches a group of old men sitting on their porches, he remarks, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” Despite his initial skepticism, he decides to follow their advice. As he progresses, he encounters abandoned ghost towns that the old men had described as thriving spots. The cyclist has to overcome the challenges of the rolling hills of the terrain, the mirages that play tricks on his eyes, and the intense heat of a June day in the California deserts. Finally, he spots a bait and tack shop. When he sees that the men who own the place are even older than the previous group, he just stares at them in disbelief. Based on the quote, it's clear that the cyclist will likely ignore their advice about having the best map, as he's learned his lesson from the earlier misinformation.

The features in the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One significant aspect is that the cyclist can only carry a limited amount of equipment that might be needed during the journey. For example, when it comes to water, you can only take so much with you on the bike. Once you run out, and there are no buildings or water sources around, you're in a tough spot and out of luck. Similarly, food is also restricted in quantity. You can only pack a certain amount of food that can fit on your bike. Finally, when it's time to rest, you can't just pull over anywhere. You have to keep riding until you find a hotel or make it back home. I know that I would not make it under such challenging conditions. So those are just a few reasons on why the setting has a notable impact on cyclists.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him dehydrated, troubled, and relieved. The cyclist is dehydrated because of the horrible, sweltering heat. He says “the growing realie at von that l would drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This clearly indicates that the intense heat is a great threat to him and would cause him to become dehydrated and potentially suffer from heatstroke. The cyclist is troubled by the scarce surroundings. He describes “a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule.” This shows that he is getting worried because there is no one around and his directions are starting to sound wrong, leaving him feeling lost and anxious. The cyclist is relieved by the water from the sink. He had the “overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them.” This means that he is so relieved that he has finally found water and he wants to thank the owners of the bait shop for providing it. In conclusion, the setting's features have a profound and diverse impact on the cyclist's physical and mental state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie. The downhill land format helps him in a way because when cycling downhill, he doesn't have to use as much strength and pedal as hard, especially when he doesn't have as much water in his body. This allows him to conserve his energy. When he comes to a pump, it is in a sorry state. It is rusty, with tar oozing out, and the water that comes out is hot and brackish, flavored like battery acid, which is completely unfit for consumption. The dryness of the desert has a bad effect on the cyclist because he isn't able to get to the Yosemite water until the end of his journey, leaving him constantly at risk of dehydration. On the positive side, the breeze of the wind has a beneficial impact as it helps to cool him down during the scorching ride. Overall, the features of the setting in the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie have a significant and varied impact on the cyclist.

Many things that involve settings can affect other things. In the “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist is affected by the setting as he travels to Yosemite National Park. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day….” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The setting of the day, with its intense heat, is affecting him greatly. He is very tired, his body is struggling to cope with the heat, and he's almost sick from it. The arid and hot setting of this place is taking a toll on the cyclist. He is so uncomfortable that he wants to go home and get away from the heat. The setting of this place has a profound and negative effect on the cyclist, making his journey extremely challenging and unpleasant.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The features of the setting affect the cyclist physically. The heat of the California desert causes the cyclist to become tired and dehydrated. This clearly demonstrates the powerful influence of the setting on the cyclist's physical state.

One part of the setting that is affecting him is the sun, which is mercilessly overheating the biker. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because as the terrain got rougher, things for the cyclist got harder. The features of the setting that affect the cyclist are the conditions of the road and weather. As he was riding, he hit some bad and nasty water that was pooled on the road. Along with other hazardous things, he also tried to ride through a desert where he had already drank all his bottles of water and had nothing left to drink. At one point, a big snake almost took up the entire road and he had to just ease his way on by it. His riding conditions were so bad, he thought he was going to die, and he said the birds were going to eat him. The weather was so hot it was hard to go on. He finally found a bathroom, went inside it, drank water from the sink, and yelled to a man who then told him the direction he wanted. In the end, despite these harsh conditions, he persevered and continued his journey.

The features of the setting do indeed affect the cyclist. The setting affects the cyclist in many ways. How? Because there was not a posted speed limit up there, which caused the cyclist to go right through and over, going faster than he was supposed to. This lack of a speed - limit sign in the setting led to the cyclist taking risks and potentially endangering himself. In conclusion, the missing speed - limit sign in the setting had a direct impact on the cyclist's behavior.

Poisonous snakes, mirages, rolling hills, and dry dead tumbleweed - these features in the setting that the cyclist was going through have the greatest effect of all. They showed the treacherous path he took, the obstacles he had to surpass to prevail. The purpose of including some features of the setting like the poisonous snakes, mirages, rolling hills, no signs of life, and no water all show and impact how bad the conditions were. So, you see, the features in the setting help set the mood and also reveal the context of the story. In essence, these setting features are crucial for understanding the cyclist's difficult journey.

When you do something really too often you get used to it. Well, I think it's the same thing with how sitting affects the cyclist's features. It might make their butt flat or their back have a different shape. With different shape, I don't mean that they are deformed but every person is different. So their back can either have a “C” shape or an “I” shape or a “D” shape. Prolonged sitting on a bicycle can gradually change the physical form of a cyclist's body parts. In conclusion, the act of sitting while cycling over time can have notable effects on a cyclist's physical features.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in these ways. The cyclist was extremely hot under the blazing sun. Wide rings of dried sweat circled his shirt, and he had the growing realization that he could drop from a heart - stroke on this otherwise gorgeous day in June. The towns that he passed through, which were supposed to be bustling with people, were in fact completely deserted. There were no signs of life, not even a single soul on the streets. His ride ended up being even harder than it would have been under normal circumstances. This is how the features of the setting, including the sweltering heat and the desolate towns, affect the cyclist.

There are many features of the setting that would affect the pedalists. “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills” (kurmaskie @NUM1) clearly shows the change of terrain. These hills, with their gradual inclines and declines, must be traveled up to get to the other side, and that takes a significant amount of time and energy, especially for bike riders who have to pedal vigorously against gravity. “High deserts of California in June” (kurmaskie @NUM1) indicates the intense heat. The scorching sun beats down on the cyclists, and this heat makes it harder for most people to concentrate. It also causes people to become overheated when exerting much force at once, leaving them exhausted and drained. These two factors, the hilly terrain and the summer heat, significantly impact the pedalists' journey.

The different settings of the cyclist affected him by how he felt when he rode the bike on the road. He was well - excited and happy as he set off on the ride, looking forward to the adventure. He truly felt a sense of exhilaration as he rode the bike real fast through the short cut, the wind in his face. When he came over a long, crippling hill, he was still riding real fast, driven by his enthusiasm. Unfortunately, he was riding fast non - stop, and as he came through the whole road, he felt a great sense of relief. He felt so free, especially when he came over hills that were tall and large, like conquering small mountains. But he mostly believed he could find his way at the end. He said it himself that he always looked towards the future. So he's keeping his future and his wisdom to himself. He thought he was gonna die at one point, but all he had to do was ask for a little push. Different things did affect the cyclist, yet he managed to overcome challenges and look forward to his very bright future.

One of the biggest problems that the author faced in his essay was his surroundings. The setting of the story in Yosemite provided many obstacles such as the vastness of the park, the intense summer heat, and the fact that many places had been abandoned. The summer heat was the most significant problem for the cyclist. He had to bike many miles under the blazing sun, but he only had a limited supply of water. As the miles passed, his water supply began to run low. The lack of water made his mouth dry and his body weak, which increased his determination to find the next town before he collapsed from dehydration. It is this unwavering determination which moves him from ghost town to ghost town and keeps the story moving forward. Another big problem was the vastness of Yosemite National Park, which he was biking through. The park was so large that any wrong turns (which he took, thanks to the inaccurate directions he was given) could get him lost and thrown off track for a very long time. It was his confusion as to where the next town was that kept him biking, with great difficulty, and made for an interesting story. An example of the vastness of the park was when he quoted, “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town.’ This place might have been a thriving spot at one time - say, before the last world war - but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This quote shows that even after pedaling many miles, he hadn't seen a sign of anyone living, which would have increased his desperation to keep looking for civilization. In the end, it is these challenges that make his journey both difficult and compelling.

In "Do Not Exceed Speed Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the author depicts the vivid details of the setting and how they contribute to the cyclist’s condition. For example, the author wrote “Over one long, crippling hill, a building come into view. I wiped the sweat from my eye.” The way the author described the hill as “crippling” clearly shows how much energy it was taking away from the cyclist. The cyclist had to struggle uphill, his legs aching with each pedal stroke. Another quote that contributed to the cyclist’s journey was, “that smoky blues tune ‘Summer time’ rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain.” This expressed how dehydrated the summer heat was making him. His mind was foggy, and he was in a state of discomfort. I believe the author used modifying details to support the description of the cyclist’s condition. These details, such as the description of the hill and the mention of dehydration, enhanced the reader’s perception of the cyclist’s challenging journey.

The terrain the cyclist faces doesn't help very much considering he is almost out of water. As he pedaled on, he came across a series of steep hills that tired him out a great deal and made him even more thirsty. Each upward slope seemed to sap his remaining energy. Also, when he came across the juice factory, his excitement spurred him on, but he used a lot of energy to get there, which made him even more parched. Therefore, if he didn't have any energy left after all of that strenuous effort, he wouldn't have been able to get to the bait shop and find the relief he desperately needed.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. First of all, he is in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by an unfamiliar expanse. He doesn't know the direction of where he is going, wandering aimlessly on the open road. Moreover, he also doesn't know the people who live in this desolate area, so there's no one readily available to offer him assistance. The other thing is that he doesn't have any food or a drink. Without eating or drinking, his body can't get the necessary energy, and as a result, he can't ride the bike effectively, leaving him stuck in this unforgiving setting.

The features in the setting in the story affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, in the story it said, “At same point, tumbleweed crossed my path.” This clearly indicates that he is in the desert or somewhere very hot because, as common knowledge goes, you usually only see tumbleweeds in extremely hot and arid places. Thus, being in the desert affects the cyclist significantly. He is already low on water, and being in a place as hot as the desert makes him even more dehydrated, his throat parched and his body weak. Another feature in the setting in this story that affected the cyclist is the hills he had to climb. These hills were no easy feat. He was already dehydrated, and climbing the hills made him have to work harder, causing him to lose more sweat and become even more dehydrated. Those are two examples of how the features in the setting of this story affected the cyclist, highlighting the harsh challenges he faced.

The setting in this story is very hard for the cyclist. His main problem is the lack of water. If you deprive the body of water, all of your major organs will struggle under the blistering heat of the hot sun. Without an adequate supply of water, his body functions start to deteriorate, and he becomes increasingly fatigued. Another problem was the condition of the terrain. The ground was bumpy and dry, making it very hard to cycle on. Every jolt and uneven surface required extra effort from the cyclist. These are just a few problems the cyclist encountered, which collectively made his journey an extremely difficult one.

The feature in the setting affected the cyclist a lot. It was a sweltering hot summer day, and the sun beat down relentlessly. He was running out of water, his water bottle nearly empty. With all the heat, he was at high risk of having a heat stroke, his body struggling to cope with the extreme temperature. Another problem was the hills. He didn't have a lot of energy to begin with, and the intense heat of the sun was sapping it from him. Climbing the hills became an almost insurmountable task, further draining his already depleted energy reserves. In such a harsh setting, the cyclist faced a difficult battle to continue his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cycles because it was extremely hot, with the sun beating down relentlessly, and it was a rough terrain like a bumpy and uneven train track. This harsh environment made it difficult for the cycles to maintain a steady rhythm and progress smoothly.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because as he gets closer to the nearest town, the ground gradually becomes rougher to ride on. The features of the setting in, “Rough Road Ahead” negatively affect the cyclist. In the vast California desert, where the sun beats down mercilessly, water is everything. If you run out of water then you might as well have run out of life. Without water, dehydration kicks in quickly and it affects not only your body, making you weak and fatigued, but your mind too, causing confusion and disorientation. The cyclist only had a limited amount of water with him when he started. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” Through the deserted towns he came across, he searched diligently for a source of water but found none that were useable. “When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” Another feature was the heat. The scorching heat began to mess with his mind and take a toll on his body quickly. “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage.” He worried about heatstroke and his body's desperate need for water throughout the entire trip. Finally, in the deserts of California, wildlife can affect you. The cyclist was using a path that nature had claimed and was not traveled often by people. “A ridiculously large snake crossed my path and blocked the majority of the pavement.” As you can see, the cyclist was negatively affected by the features of the setting in, “Rough Road Ahead”.

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist because if there is a rough road ahead, you're just going to have to be able and ready to handle the up - and - downs, the sharp bumps that can jolt you out of your seat. The uneven surface makes it hard to keep balance and control. The author was so scared that he was gonna die and that the birds were gonna pick his bones clean, imagining a tragic end in this harsh environment.

In the story the cyclist faces many issues that could stop him from finishing his journey. First, his water supply, which is limited, could cause him to become severely dehydrated and he could pass out due to lack of fluids in his body. Another issue is the hot weather in June, when the sun is at its peak, which could cause him to suffer from a heat stroke and literally die. The rough terrain, filled with large rocks and deep ruts, could stop him from finishing the trip because he could pop a bike tire. If that happens, he would have to walk the rest of the way, which would be extremely difficult in the desert. The cyclist faces many problems that could end his trip and maybe even his life, but he pushes through with determination and survives, showing his strong will and resilience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist really does not like the setting of the road. The rough, uneven surface and the arid, desolate surroundings are messing up his cycling experience big time. The setting is a vast, barren desert in California in June. This severely affects the cyclist because it is extremely hot, with the sun shining mercilessly. Some features of the setting in @MONTH1 that have affected the cyclist was the fact that he was rapidly running out of water. When he came across a well and tried to pump water, he said he pumped with all his might at first. A thick, tar - like substance oozed out slowly, followed by brackish water. The flat road suddenly turned into short, steep hills, and then, to his horror, he encountered a snake that looked like a diamondback, adding more danger to his journey. In the essay “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” By Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist because he was on a bike and the sweltering heat was almost unbearable. He ran into bumpy, rutted roads and numerous hills. For example, he says, “Not even a few June miles into the next section of the road, he noticed the terrains changing. The once - flat land was gradually replaced by short, rolling hills that demanded extra effort to climb.” Another example is “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that he could die from heatstroke was constantly gnawing at his mind.” These examples clearly show that it was not an easy journey and how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. In conclusion, this story shows that you should never blindly take directions from an old person, especially if it's swelteringly hot and you are riding a bike, as it can lead to a very difficult and potentially dangerous situation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. To start with, the terrain of the road turned from flat to bumpy, which made the cyclist's initially easy trip become more challenging. In the story it said, "Rough Road ahead do not exceed posted speed limit." Since the cyclist had to use a lot more energy on the bumpy roads and his water supply was limited, he became very thirsty. When he finally saw an old town ahead, he stopped. It looked like it was abandoned. He began to pump water out of the water pump, but no matter how long he pumped, the water that came out looked like battery acid. These are some features of the setting that affected the cyclist throughout his journey, making his ride much more arduous.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in this story greatly. The cyclist is cycling in a desert, as the story states, "I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June." The features of the setting affect the cyclist's attitude towards the old men. Since the cyclist listened to the old men's directions, he was furious with himself. The cyclist in "Rough Road; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" starts off in the "serenity of an early summer evening" taking road advice from old - timers. The setting in the reading affected the cyclist because it was hot, dry, and there was nothing around. The features mentioned in the sweltering summer settings of the story made it notably harder for the cyclist. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The beginning of the story is set at “a reservoir campground outside of @CAPS1, California” during the early summer. The cyclist decided to ride to Yosemite National Park on a sweltering hot summer day in California. His initial thought was to rely on a perfectly good and up - to - date map. Then he struck up a conversation with some old men who, out of goodwill, decided to tell him a shortcut they had taken back in the day. The cyclist, perhaps a bit too trusting, decided to take the old men's shortcut through the arid desert with just one messy bottle of water. It was extremely hot outside, and the scorching sun was beating down on his back as he pedaled his bike. This made him even hotter than he had anticipated, and there was no shade or place for him to stop and get some water. This situation made the trip much harder for him because now his mind was solely focused on finding water rather than enjoying the ride. The settings of the course affected the cyclist in many ways he was not prepared for. The route he took was not biker - friendly. If he would have taken the route that was on the map, then he would have known exactly where he was, and his ride would not have been affected by thoughts of slowing down to put rocks in his mouth to reserve water or constantly thinking about finding water. In the end, he learned a valuable lesson about the importance of sticking to reliable routes.

The cyclist had a truly rough time. The elements were completely against him. It was extremely dry and swelteringly hot, and he had almost no water. The weather can significantly change the course of action a cyclist will take. If it is cold outside, then the cyclist will surely bring warmer clothes to protect himself from the chill. On the other hand, if it is hotter outside, he would most likely bring lighter, breathable clothes to stay cool. If he was planning to ride a long distance, he'd bring more supplies like an ample amount of water and some energy - boosting food. However, if he was going on a short ride, then he wouldn't need to bring so much stuff. The way the weather is plays a crucial role in how a person will prepare for a cycling trip. In essence, cyclists must always take the weather into account to ensure a comfortable and safe ride.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the different aspects of the setting have a profound effect on the cyclist in several ways. When he first starts his journey, he is so caught up in the excitement that he doesn't even notice how hot it is. He says, "The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it." His spirits finally start to rise when he stumbles upon a store and is able to drink a good amount of refreshing water, which gives him the much - needed boost to continue his ride.

The cyclist in this short story was greatly affected by the desolate setting. The cyclist was utterly exhausted as he struggled to pedal his bike up the steep hill. The setting of the story affects the cyclist a great deal. The setting of the essay greatly affected the cyclist. These desolate settings constantly discouraged him, although he valiantly tried to keep hope alive within him. Being a cyclist is not as easy as it sounds. Sure, casually riding a bike around the neighborhood might be easy, but being a serious cyclist is so much more difficult. Cyclists have many obstacles to overcome while riding. One major obstacle would be a rough terrain. Cyclists are typically used to riding on smooth, well - paved roads where they can glide along effortlessly. However, going off - road or riding on a bumpy dirt road might be a real challenge as it requires more strength and balance. In the short story “Do Exceed posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, there is another example for an obstacle cyclists have to be careful of, and that is running out of water. The cyclist went on in telling how he needed to try to keep his balance but it was extremely hard because he was severely dehydrated, and maintaining balance is crucial when riding a bike. A dehydrated cyclist can easily lose control and end up in an accident. In conclusion, when it comes to the seemingly simple act of riding a bike, you need to take precaution in what might lie ahead on your journey.

The setting affects the cyclist in many profound ways. It makes him feel a roller - coaster of emotions, including hopeful, determined, alone, and completely exhausted. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, “not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he saw “short, rolling hills” that seemed to go on endlessly, “tumbleweeds” that blew across his path unexpectedly, and “a ridiculously large snake” coiled menacingly on the road. Each area the author entered changed what he felt and experienced. At first, he is lent courage by his surroundings. When he passes through the first town, which is completely abandoned and empty with dilapidated buildings and overgrown weeds, he is still confident he can go on, spurred by the lush green trees that provided patches of shade and the cool rivers that flowed gently around him, which belied the hot sun overhead. The third “obstacle” he ran into was that he was so parched and finally had what seemed like a chance for a drink. To his great disappointment, he found an old, abandoned Welch's grape juice factory. As nerve - wracking and upsetting as it was, he continued to move forward, still determined to reach his destination. He finally came up to a fishing supply store where he was able to take a well - deserved break and have a nice, refreshing drink! Even though the setting was tough, full of teasing challenges, and ironic in many ways, the man made it through and still had a smile on his face, showing his indomitable spirit.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist because of his endurance. The amount of time he can continuously ride without taking a break, whether it's a short rest or a longer halt, is influenced by the setting. Also, how long he can pedal uphill, struggling against gravity and the terrain, is a test of his endurance. Moreover, the number of bumps he rides over on a rough road can wear him out. And, of course, how long he can ride without a drink of water in a hot and dry setting is crucial. In the end, his ability to endure these challenges determines whether he can complete his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by the changes that occur while he is riding his bike. At the start, the cyclist began his journey with a big, smiley face, full of enthusiasm. But then, things started to change. The condition of the road became rough, filled with potholes and uneven surfaces, making it difficult to pedal smoothly. The weather was extremely hot, with the sun beating down on him, sapping his energy. Also, there were no clear signals to show him where he was going, and he was constantly unsure if the way he was taking was the correct one. To make matters worse, his bike's flat tire needed to be replaced immediately. Despite all these difficulties, he persevered, learning that he had to adapt to the ever - changing setting to reach his destination.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist as the rough roads and scorching heat took a toll on him. He was cycling through a desert in June, and the intense heat made the journey extremely arduous. Moreover, the road was bumpy, which meant he had to pedal harder with every stroke. The cyclist had to put in extra effort because the roads were long, but he had the spirit and determination to reach Yosemite. Along the way, he ran into a snake, which was a clear sign that he was getting deeper into the desert. This encounter added to the challenges he faced, but his resolve to reach his destination remained unshaken.

The setting of the cyclist clearly influences his mood. From the very start to the end, the outside world mirrors the turmoil in his head. This is evident right from the beginning with the reservoir, the empty desert, the hills, the Welch factory, and finally the fish camp. The reservoir is like a haven, a safe ground that contains everything the cyclist needs. He is feeling optimistic, fully ready and eager to follow the advice of the old men. As he first hits a ghost - town, it acts as a foreshadowing of a dangerous future. However, he passes through it with a level head. Then he comes to a water pump that, to his dismay, gives him battery acid. This is where the mood takes a sharp turn. He suddenly describes his setting as “the high deserts of California.” The sun is beating down mercilessly, and his water supply is running low. His hopes start to plummet. When the “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” it perfectly reflects the turmoil in his head. The terrain becomes harder, and the chances of his survival diminish. When he crosses a snake, it suggests even more despair. It finally reaches a climax at the Welch factory. How ironic it is, an abandoned juice factory. This represents lost hope. When he finally arrives at the fish camp, he is deeply relieved to be alive and his spirits are uplifted. The cyclist has made it. It is clear that the setting has had a profound impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He is riding his bike steadily along the road when he encounters a dilemma. “Wild weeds crossed my path, and a ridiculously large snake blocked the entire pavement in front of me.” He had to come to a sudden stop and was startled by the snake, which not only slowed him down but also freaked him out completely. He was already struggling with thirst and now had to deal with a snake that “really did look like a diamondback.” After this encounter, he sees a building up ahead and discovers that it’s a walrus Grape Juice factory. He thought that it might have some water, but to his disappointment, he realized it was abandoned. Relating to his thirst, before he left the area, he grabbed some pebbles. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate.” Eventually, he came across a fishing camp and received instructions on how to proceed. This affected him because he finally got to a secure place, got proper directions, and will learn from his mistake of blindly listening to the older men at the beginning. The features of the setting have significantly influenced the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by giving him a glimmer of hope that the finishing line is not far away. As he pedals along, there is nothing in sight - no cars passing by, no buildings in the distance, and no structure of any kind. The vast expanse of empty space around him makes the hope of reaching the end seem both close and yet so far. Despite the desolate surroundings, this hope keeps him going, pushing him forward on his arduous journey. The setting, in its emptiness, both challenges and encourages the cyclist, and it continues to play a crucial role in his cycling experience.

The author was affected in many ways by the conclusion of his journey. He was completely exhausted from the blazing heat that seemed to sap all his energy. He didn't have much water left, and to make matters worse, he got lost. Water was simply scarce, and as he went farther and farther, it seemed like things would only get worse for him. A man had given him the wrong directions, and as the author said, that man probably hadn't been off his porch in decades.
