This misinformation led the author into more difficulties, but through it all, he learned valuable lessons about relying on others and the importance of being self - sufficient in challenging situations.

In the story, the cyclist explains how the road conditions change from good to bad. For example, there's a sign that warns, “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed limit.” Also, the road surface becomes dry and uneven, which makes the cycling experience quite challenging.

In the story, there are many elements that affected the cyclist in his journey. The first notable feature of the setting that affected him is the old water pump. This dilapidated water pump hardly worked at all, and when it did manage to sputter out some water, the water had a truly horrible, unpalatable taste. The next significant obstacles on his journey were the rough terrain. “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills,” was how he described it. These hills made pedaling much more strenuous. When the narrator finally finds a building, it turns out to be an abandoned, desolate structure. Eventually, he finds a town and takes a well - deserved rest after his long and arduous journey. He then learns his lesson from before, realizing not to take advice from people he doesn't know.

Well, the features were rough desert - like features with sandy stretches and rocky patches. For a cyclist, this kind of terrain is extremely difficult. For example, there is a severe lack of water sources, and when he did manage to find some water, it had a battery - acid flavor. These factors affected the cyclist in a major way, making his ride extremely challenging and uncomfortable.

'Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. The previously flat road was gradually replaced by short, rolling hills' (Kurmaskie @NUM1). When the cyclist realized the terrain was becoming more difficult, he became more ignorant and hopeless. 'Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt; and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh' (@NUM1). He wasn't going to die, but even though he was struggling, he made a big deal out of it. He kept muttering to himself in frustration. Unfortunately, the man lived. He would live on, telling people not to listen to old men. 'Never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office' (@NUM3). He was on a long, hot road, and he started taking stabs at the old men. 'I made a mental note to change that paragraph' (@NUM4). The man was not forced to take direction from the old man. In his selfishness to cut back on the trip and avoid only a few miles of rough terrain, heat, and dehydration caused him to be hopeless, angry, and he felt sorry for himself.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that the cyclist is traveling through the high deserts of California in June, where the sun beats down mercilessly and the heat is intense. Another effect said in the story was that the cyclist made it to a town where the water pump was all rusted. With all his strength, he worked the handle, and first, a tarlike substance came out, followed by brackish water which he couldn't drink as it was foul - tasting and likely unhygienic. Also, the cyclist had been hitting his water bottles regularly to combat the heat, but his water supply was dwindling fast. Lastly, the old - timers said the towns would be close when really they were far apart, which left the cyclist exhausted and in a difficult situation.

There are many things that can affect a cyclist's journey. This cyclist seemed to have bad luck. He starts off mentioning that he is planning a trip to Yosemite and the men sitting on the porch that hear this give him a tip. The cyclist is pretty confident in what they tell him, so he follows their suggestions. He ends up getting lost in the vast expanse of the desert. The cyclist is also travelling in the “high deserts of California in June.” That means that he is travelling in summer with dry, scorching air. When he gets to the first “town” he sees, he can't get the water he needs to rehydrate his body as the place seems deserted. He also runs into a venomous snake while travelling through the desert, which makes him extremely cautious and slows him down. Because it’s hot, and he’s tired, he begins to see mirages that mess with his mind and affect his judgment. All of these features cause the cyclist to take one long, tiring journey through the desert. These features also taught him the lesson to not take advice from old men who have not left their porch because their information might be out of date.

Well the setting was that the little boy was on his shiny bike, pedaling along the road. He meets this old man sitting on a rickety bench by the roadside and the man tells him about a short cut. So he took this road, which seemed narrow and overgrown at first. I guess something went wrong as the path soon became rough and full of potholes, and he ended up getting stuck in a muddy patch and couldn't find his way back to the main road easily. This experience taught him to be more cautious when taking shortcuts suggested by strangers.

In the “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the main characters, the cyclist. After he first journeyed from the house where he met the old men, he rode over much flat desert terrain, where the intense sun beat down relentlessly and dehydrated him quickly. The dry, arid air made every breath a struggle. Soon, though the terrain changed. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” These hills were not only a physical challenge but also a mental one as he has to maneuver down the hills while dehydrated and ready to collapse from exhaustion. The uneven surface of the hills made it difficult to maintain balance and control, further testing his cycling skills and endurance.

Hot, dry, desolate - all are the features of the setting that affect the cyclist. First, the hot days with not a lot of water to drink. The sun beats down mercilessly, and he will get dehydrated rapidly. Also, there is no one around to help him if he gets lost. Joe Kurmaskie explains “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The vast emptiness of the place makes him feel extremely isolated. Finally, a large, menacing snake came along on the road. So he had to move around it carefully, which made him even more nervous and wasted his precious energy. All these factors combined made his journey a real ordeal.

Setting is one of the most important needs for a cyclist. If the terrain or weather are bad, it can pose significant challenges. For example, the hotter it is for a cyclist, the more quickly he will get dehydrated. A rough terrain with lots of bumps and slopes can make it difficult to pedal and control the bike. Bad weather like strong winds or heavy rain can also make the journey extremely uncomfortable and dangerous. In such conditions, a cyclist needs to be well - prepared and cautious to ensure a safe and successful ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the cyclist faces a challenging problem, which is also the problem faced by the author. For example, I notice the terrain changing. The initially flat road was gradually replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had pedaled over the first few inclines, there loomed a large highway. That shows when he arrived at this point, the road conditions were not good, and the large highway presented a significant hurdle, like a high jump to overcome. This difficult setting made the cyclist's journey much more arduous.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a severe way. It is so incredibly hot outside that he could have easily passed out and died due to heat exhaustion. Also, he suddenly saw a snake slithering across the path, which scared him to death. However, he managed to muster his courage and passed the snake. Then, he spotted a building that could probably help him. But upon closer inspection, he found it was abandoned. It turned out to be an old Welch factory. As he continued to cycle further down the road, he saw a fish - related place. He went to the bathroom there to get some water. Then, somebody asked him where he was going and tried to mislead him. But he still had his map in hand, so he decided that he was going to use it instead of listening to other people, relying on it to guide him to safety.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead,” a cyclist takes some outdated information from a couple of old guys. As he went along, following their directions, he soon found out that their directions were outdated and, at certain points, dangerous. Also, the setting didn't help him at all. He was in a vast desert filled with ghost towns, and the scorching heat made the situation worse. It didn't help him believe that he was going to make it out alive. For example, in the story when he reaches the fork in the road, it describes that he found “several rusty pumps,” and “one ramshackle shed.” This probably didn't help him because he didn't have a lot of water left, and it was really hot. He was losing confidence in himself that he would get out. Moreover, the rusty pumps meant he couldn't get any good - quality water. Also, in the story, it says that “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This setting affected him deeply because at this part of the story, he has cycled for a long while, has no water left, and is getting very exhausted and almost has no energy. It also decreased his hopes because it was described as an almost empty desert that he was stuck in, and he thought he wouldn't get out of the desert alive. In conclusion, in the story “Rough road ahead,” the setting in the story didn't help the cyclist in his hope or confidence of getting out because the setting was very abandoned, and it was extremely hot. The desolate desert environment was a major obstacle to his journey.

Well, since the cyclist is in a vast and arid desert and is out of water, he is probably extremely unhappy. The so - called “ghost towns” he encounters are just empty, dilapidated places that aren't really a boost of confidence either. The sight of these abandoned towns only adds to his sense of desolation. The rugged hills along the way made him angry too. Each steep incline and rough descent required a great deal of effort from him. However, the heat affected him the most. The sweltering desert heat was like a relentless enemy, sapping his energy and making every pedal stroke a struggle. All these factors combined made his cycling journey in the desert a truly miserable experience.

The features of the land affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the first two buildings that he came to were completely abandoned. When he approached them with hope of finding food or water, he was deeply disappointed. He couldn't get any food or water from these desolate structures. Also, he noticed that the terrain was gradually changing from a flat expanse to rolling hills. This change in terrain put more strain on his legs. With each uphill climb, his leg muscles ached, and his energy was rapidly depleted. Finally, the land was hot and dry. The scorching sun beat down on him, and the lack of moisture in the air made him dehydrate quickly. His throat was parched, and his body was weakening. This is how the features of the land affected the cyclist, making his journey a difficult and challenging one.

In this story, the setting significantly affects the cyclist in numerous ways. He attempts to get directions, but the people he asks seem really confused and clearly don't know what they're talking about. This shows that you must be cautious about whom you seek directions from. Then, he desperately needs a drink, but his attempt doesn't go well at all because the water he finds ends up tasting horribly like battery acid. After that, the cyclist starts on his way again and encounters the same difficulty on the road. The road is in such a bad condition that he has to ride slower than the speed limit. At this point, he feels like he's on the verge of death. Fortunately, he finds a bathroom and drinks water from the sink, which gives him a bit of relief and allows him to continue his journey, albeit with caution due to the harsh setting.

The features of the setting have a notable impact on the cyclist in a few distinct ways. Early in the essay, the cyclist states that he “enjoyed the serenity of an early - summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers.” He was truly relishing the moment and the pleasant atmosphere around him. However, the mood changes rapidly to doubt when he disregards the advice of the “collection of old - timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” Moreover, his depleting water source quickly becomes a major cause for concern. This doubt is soon followed by relief when he sees the sign for Gary and Wilber’s Fish camp and is able to get a drink from the bathroom faucets. After that, relief is succeeded by satisfaction as he “promises himself right then that he'd always stick to [the very good map] in the future,” realizing the importance of reliable guidance in such a challenging setting.

The setting had a detrimental effect on the author in many ways. One significant reason is that the intense heat of the setting causes the author to become severely dehydrated. Dehydration occurs when your body begins to shut down gradually due to a lack of sufficient water. The setting also affects him by draining his confidence and compelling him to search desperately for water. When he says, “I hung my head,” it clearly indicates that he was deeply depressed. This incident proves that no matter who or what guidance you follow, there is always a possibility of facing life - threatening circumstances such as death. Therefore, this is how the author was affected by the harsh setting he was biking in, highlighting the vulnerability one can experience in an unforgiving environment.

I think the settings made it a little more challenging to not give up. The difficult conditions presented by the settings constantly tested the cyclist's willpower. For example, the rough terrain and extreme weather made each pedal stroke a struggle. However, this also shows that you do better in life when faced with challenges. Overcoming the difficulties posed by the settings can lead to personal growth and a stronger sense of self - confidence. Just like the cyclist, when we persevere through tough situations, we learn valuable lessons and become more resilient. In the end, the experience in these challenging settings can be a stepping - stone to achieving greater things in life.

The setting significantly affects the cyclist because it is in a warm and dry climate. This causes him to sweat profusely, and as a result, he needs to drink a large amount of water to stay hydrated. When no one else is around, it becomes even more difficult for him to continue his journey. There is a constant nagging thought that he might be on the wrong path, and with no one available to tell him otherwise, he has to rely solely on his own judgment. With only abandoned buildings in sight, if there are any at all, water is nowhere to be found. This makes the journey extremely tiring and physically straining on his body. If the setting were different, say a cooler and more populated area, this story would not have been as traumatic. The harsh setting truly adds a layer of difficulty and danger to the cyclist's journey, making it a memorable and arduous experience.

THERE ARE VAST FEATURES IN THE SETTING THAT AFFECTS THE CYCLIST. IN SEVERAL WAYS, ONE PROMINENT FEATURE WOULD BE THE “SUN BEGINNING TO HEAT DOWN”. AS THE SUN POURED ITS INTENSE HEAT, IT MADE THE CYCLIST SWEAT PROFUSELY, BECOMING HOT AND THIRSTY. THE OVERWHELMING THIRSTINESS FORCED HIM TO USE HIS LIMITED SUPPLY OF WATER, GRADUALLY DRAINING HIS RESOURCES. SO THE SUN WAS ABLE TO AFFECT HIM IN A COUPLE OF WAYS. ANOTHER FEATURE THAT CAUSED SOME PROBLEMS FOR THE CYCLIST WERE THE RUN - DOWN “GHOST TOWNS” THAT CONSISTED OF “RAM - SHACKLE SHEDS” AND “SEVERAL RUSTY PUMPS”. THESE DESERTED AND DILAPIDATED FEATURES LED THE CYCLIST TO FEEL A DEEP SENSE OF HOPELESSNESS. AS WELL AS THE PROBLEM THAT THEY DIDN'T HAVE ANY USABLE WATER FOR HIM TO REFILL WITH AS HE BECAME DEHYDRATED. OBSTACLES SUCH AS “TUMBLEWEEDS” AND “PAVEMENT BLOCKING SNAKES” ALSO PLAYED A ROLE IN AFFECTING THE CYCLISTS AS HE MOVED ON THE “@NUM1 ROAD” ONLY DOING “12 MPH”. ONE FINAL, AND LAST OBSTACLE WAS THE TERRAIN HE RODE ON. THE OBSTACLE BEING A “LONG CROPPING HILL”. THIS MADE THE CYCLIST EXHAUSTED, AS HE USED MUCH ENERGY TO CLIMB THE HILL, STRUGGLING WITH EVERY PEDAL STROKE. ALL THESE SETTING FEATURES TOGETHER POSED A FORMIDABLE CHALLENGE TO THE CYCLIST'S JOURNEY.

Topic: The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The features of the setting that affect a cyclist or the major problems that a cyclist encounters are some rough roads, the inspection of the bike to ensure it's in proper working condition, putting on necessary safety equipment like a helmet and knee - pads, and not exceeding the posted speed limit. For a cyclist to be doing all this, I don't think there won't be any features of the setting that affect a cyclist. For a cyclist to maintain the speed limit of @NUM1 or deal with a water - depleting @NUM2: sometimes life can feel so cruel. At some point, tumbleweeds are caused by too much of speed, but if they are using the necessary equipment, they won't get seriously injured. Forget that old saying about never taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be “Never accept a ride from a stranger without proper caution”. Overall, the cyclist has to be vigilant against both the setting features and external risks.

The features of the setting really affected the cyclist. The author wrote of rough terrain and isolation. “Flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills; tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake”. After reading this information and the detailed descriptions, I inferred that the author was alone in the vast desert with awful conditions. The lack of any human presence and the harsh natural elements added to the sense of isolation. I could also infer a tone of resentment. He seemed to wish he hadn't taken the “shortcut” that landed him in the desert. The hot weather was another factor that affected the author. Trying to keep his balance in a dehydrated state was extremely difficult. He seems to have not really planned how long the ride would be and how to conserve water properly. The rough terrain, desolation, and hot temperatures all combined seemed to have a significant and negative impact on the cyclist / author, making his journey a real struggle.

The features of the setting that most affected the cyclist were the water pump, the Welch’s Factory, and the fish camp. The pump affected him because he was very thirsty, and at first, he thought he would have a chance to get water. He was excited and he pumped the water out, as he wrote, “with all my strength”. Unfortunately, he had to go on thirsty, (a very risky thing to do while cycling) because “it had the flavor of battery acid”. Next, the Welch’s Factory affected him by killing his spirits. He was already feeling bad from the lack of water, but seeing the mocking, ironic image of “a sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice”, made him feel even worse. It vividly reflected his own desperate situation, all the refreshments in the past, and now there was nothing left. I had a similar experience once. I am allergic to peanuts. One time, on a long car trip, I had slept through lunch, so I was starving, and we were on a long stretch of highway with no buildings to be seen. After two hours, we finally saw a sign for a nearby restaurant: @CAPS2’s peanut shade. I nearly cried. The last thing that affected the cyclist was the fish camp. It saved his life. He arrived and “drank deeply from the sink”. He was so happy that he wanted to kiss the owners of the camp. This also relates to the car trip I mentioned, because after hours of hunger, we found a very good sushi bar, and sushi is my favorite food. These setting features had a profound and diverse impact on the cyclist's journey, from despair to relief.

The story that I am going to talk about the most was about what happened in the story. I wasn't sure at first, but the name of the story sounded pretty good. If I was in the story, I wouldn't be in a good situation because the story is really crazy. It would be really challenging to start and write about it. However, the story seems to have a lot of interesting elements that could potentially draw readers in. Even though it's a bit wild, it might have a unique charm. Overall, despite the initial uncertainty, I'm looking forward to exploring and sharing more about this story.

In the setting they are in Lodi, California, which is a part of the arid desert. The harsh desert environment affects the cyclist really badly. For one, the intense heat beats down relentlessly. Second, the sweltering heat is making him extremely thirsty and he is quickly running out of his limited supply of water. Then, to make matters worse, he is in an area with no nearby towns, so he can't get any more water. Clearly, the setting has a significant and detrimental impact on the cyclist.

The cyclist is most severely affected by the intense heat. He is pushing himself, exerting all his energy and willpower to reach Yosemite. The blazing hot sun and the lack of water make him incredibly tired and cause him to use his energy in an inefficient way. At one point, he has to carefully determine whether the building he sees is a mirage. It is so swelteringly hot that his mind could easily be playing tricks on him, which further hampers his progress and morale.

The conditions that the cyclist was in were very horrible. As he continued on his ride, the heat became more and more oppressive, and he got hotter and hotter. He was desperately hoping to find water after finishing off his last bit. Taking advice from an old man was the last decision he made, perhaps in the hope that it would lead him to some relief from the harsh conditions.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because sometimes, it made him lose some courage and optimism. “and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day” This is a clear example of how he lost courage. He initially wanted to be brave and be strong. But the scorching hot day and all the sweat pouring from his body made the author feel physically and mentally weak. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear” This is an example of how the author lost some optimism. He didn't want to die, but he kept telling himself that he was going to. He should have thought to himself that he was going to make it, but the setting was just too rough. There were bumps along his ride, and the sun beating down increased his thirst. As a result, he became less courageous and less optimistic, which made the journey even more challenging.

The features of his journey are cruel. “Rolling hills” make him work much harder to get over them. The more effort he expends, the more he sweats, and therefore he needs an adequate supply of fluids. However, the lack of water he has does not help at all. Poisonous plants don't really bother him if he leaves them alone. The condition of the roads adds to the difficulty presented by the hills. The rough roads force him to work hard to get through and then over the hills. So, this cyclist is really having a tough time on his journey.

Some of the features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the rough terrain and the hills. As described in the reading, “a flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” These hills would gradually wear a person out, especially without a good supply of water. Moreover, the cyclist was also unsure in what direction he was travelling, which added to the challenge. And another factor that affected him was the hot June weather in California, which made the already strenuous ride even more difficult. All these elements combined to make the cyclist's journey a tough one.

Throughout “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. The cyclist was traveling through a very dry area in the deserts of California in June, where it was extremely hot, dry, and dangerous. There was no water to be found, and the terrain was rough and bumpy, filled with uneven ground and small rocks. The speaker stated, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake...” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist faced land blockings and dangerous animals, which caused him to slow down a little bit. It was extremely hot out in the setting he was in. The speaker also stated, “Rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June...” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist was experiencing the high temperatures of the setting and witnessed the intense features of the harsh desert environment. In conclusion, the setting's features had a profound impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He becomes delusional, as evidenced when he said that if he were lucky, one of the stones would be lodged in his throat. This shows the extreme mental stress he is under. Also, he is dehydrated because he has used all of his water and is having to push hard to make it to the next town. The lack of water and the physical exertion are taking a toll on his body and mind, making his situation increasingly dire. In conclusion, the setting's features are severely hampering the cyclist's well - being and progress.

The features of the setting started out easy, like a flat road with cool lines to keep him cool and not hot. The flat surface allowed the cyclist to ride smoothly, and the cool lines, perhaps in the form of shade or a gentle breeze, provided a comfortable environment. Then it got harder. There was a lack of water, the road was no longer flat, and snakes appeared. The cool pines that might have offered some shade and a sense of calm were gone. This change in the setting made the cyclist's journey much more challenging and dangerous. In conclusion, the shift in the setting's features had a significant negative impact on the cyclist's ride.

In the story "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit," the features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. As he was riding, he was passing through a desert during June, an extremely hot month. There is not much water present in a desert (which is part of the very definition of a desert), and so, particularly in the even - hotter - than - normal June sun, he was at high risk of running out of water. Had he been driving through, say, a forest with its lush vegetation and natural water sources or perhaps rolling grasslands with small streams, he might not have been in such danger. In those areas, he could have merely looked for a river or creek for water if he was desperate. Another thing that might have affected the cyclist would have been the psychological impact of the desert on his mind. When people think of deserts, they often think of dry, barren wastelands, complete with buzzards circling in the sky and maybe a dead cowskull, as commonly depicted in movies. Deserts are intimidating and have a bad reputation. So, as he was riding through and was low on water, thoughts of death, like how he was “going to die and the birds would pick (him) clean,” ran through his now - terrified head. Had he been in a city with its infrastructure and people or in rolling farmland with its human settlements, he might not have been as terrified. There are people in those places, and places to be safe there, but in his desert, he had neither, allowing him to give way to despair. Setting does a lot to influence stories, so it is important to keep that in mind when reading, as it can greatly shape the experiences and emotions of the characters.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist as he found himself out of water in a desolate, desert - like environment. For most of his journey, there was no one around, leaving him entirely on his own. In the story, the cyclist described his struggle when he said, "I got down on my hands and knees, working the water handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar - like substance oozed out followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees." This incident affected him deeply because before reaching this point in his trip, he had been drinking a lot of water to stay hydrated. As he was almost out of water, he desperately needed to refill but had no proper place to get more. This challenging aspect of the setting clearly had a significant impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in multiple ways, such as getting dehydrated, getting tired, and getting lost. After the cyclist had been on the road for a considerable while, he had drank almost all of his water. However, he still had a long way to go before reaching his destination. He intended to find a place to stop and pick up more water, but unfortunately, there was nothing around for miles. He also got tired as he was constantly exposed to the harsh sun, had barely any water to keep his energy up, and didn't know where he was going. Another problem was that he was lost. There were no cars passing by, no buildings in sight, and no people around. So, if he were to get hurt or sick, no one would have been able to come to his aid. In conclusion, being dehydrated, tired, and getting lost were the features of the setting that affected the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he runs out of water while trying to traverse the challenging terrain. In the setting, there is a desert in California that he is attempting to cross on a bike. As he mentions, "I was travelling through the high deserts of California." The word "high" here indicates that there were hills, which would make the journey even more arduous. Later in the story, the cyclist said, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." When the speaker uses the word "replaced," he is clearly showing a change of terrain. Another feature of the setting is the tumbleweed that he encounters as he crosses other hills. He stated, "Tumbleweeds crossed in path." The presence of tumbleweeds made him vividly remember that he was in the desert, as tumbleweeds are strongly associated with deserts. This brought up disturbing thoughts of dying and being picked apart by birds. Overall, these features of the setting significantly impacted the cyclist's journey.

Well, if the setting relates to the theme, then the story will make perfect sense. For instance, if it's a sad story and the day is an ugly, rainy one, then the mood of the setting matches the story's tone very nicely. The dreary weather can enhance the sense of sadness in the story, making the emotions more palpable to the reader. This is how the setting makes the story better, by creating a harmonious connection between the backdrop and the underlying message.

If it is hot out, you can dehydrate quickly. Moreover, if the terrain is long and hilly, you use a great deal of energy. This kind of environment can be rough on your equipment, body, and mind. So, make sure you dress appropriately and carry lots of water to stay hydrated. Next, ensure that your tires are properly inflated and all your equipment is working in good condition. Then, plan a good route where you can stop at places to catch your breath and refill your water supply. Also, make sure you eat well because food provides a lot of energy to keep you going. By taking these precautions, you can better handle the challenges posed by such a setting.

In the setting of the essay; "Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit." had a profound impact on the cyclist. It made him even more resolute to finish because the terrain was extremely difficult to ride through. For instance, "At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake - it really did look like a diamondback - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I carefully eased past, struggling to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." The author fully elaborates on how no matter how severe the obstacles he encounters, he keeps trying to move forward. The challenging terrain affects the character by sustaining his determination. This phenomenon occurs to many people in their sports. For example, in football, players take any problems they face and use them as motivations to push themselves harder to complete the game. This shows that difficult situations can inspire individuals to persevere and achieve their goals.

In the story, the cyclist was significantly affected. The cyclist was influenced by the directions given by the old man. It was stated that the old man provided the directions to assist him, claiming it was a shortcut. I believe the cyclist thinks the directions are outdated. The reason I think this is that in the second sentence of the story, it says, "never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." The features of the setting also affected him because he had to ride up and down through what he regarded as rough, uneven terrain. This rough terrain made his journey more arduous and tiring. That is what I think affected the cyclist, and it clearly shows how external factors can have a major impact on a person's experience.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the features of the setting affect the cyclist a great deal. The terrain and the heat play significant roles. First, the terrain affects the cyclist. It has a major impact because there are numerous hills. The text says, "With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill." In order to go down a hill, one must have first gone up a hill. So, having to expend the energy to pedal up these steep hills affected the cyclist greatly, leaving him exhausted. Next, the heat affected the cyclist. I know this because the text says “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.” This clearly proves that it is extremely hot outside. The heat would affect the cyclist because it prevents a person from functioning at their peak ability, quickly draining their energy. That is how the features of the setting in ‘Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit’ affect the cyclist. The terrain affects the cyclist due to the challenging hills, and the heat because it rapidly depletes your energy.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed posted speed limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. One way it impacts him is that the towns were old and deserted. In the story, he said, “This place might have been a thriving little spot… but at that moment, it was a ghost town.” As a result, he could not obtain any water or get any directions, which made his journey even more difficult. The features of the setting also affected the cyclist because the roads were bumpy and there were many hills. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” Consequently, the cyclist had to exert all his strength to maneuver over the hills, which was physically demanding. The third reason why the setting affected the cyclist was the weather and the fact that it was a desert. “I was traveling through the deserts of California in June.” He was hot, sweaty, and extremely thirsty. He was also tired and desperately seeking water and a town that was not deserted. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit,” through the rough roads, deserted towns, and the lack of water, all of which combined to make his cycling journey a real struggle.

In the story “Rough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limits,” the setting is a long, desolate road with “no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The cyclist could be severely affected by the rough, uneven road that he has to ride down. The rough surface of the road makes it difficult for him to maintain a steady speed and balance. Every bump and pothole on the road jolts him, causing discomfort and potentially slowing him down. This challenging road condition can also put extra strain on his body and the bicycle, increasing the risk of fatigue and mechanical problems. Overall, the rough road in this desolate setting has a significant impact on the cyclist's journey.

In the essay by Joe Kurmaskie, he vividly describes his experience of bike riding in the vast desert. The unique setting affects the cyclist in numerous ways throughout the writing. At first, Kurmaskie is full of confidence as he listens intently to a group of old codgers sharing their advice with him. The setting is calm and happy, with a gentle breeze blowing. Kurmaskie writes that he “enjoyed the serenity of an early - summer evening”, where the soft glow of the setting sun painted the desert in warm hues. The word “serenity” truly gives the effect of calm and peace. However, as Kurmaskie proceeds further into his journey, the setting undergoes a significant change. He is troubled by the dilapidated “ramshackle shed, several rutsy pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold the lamest mule” in a desolate ghost town that he encounters in the desert. Even later, the terrain becomes more challenging, and he sees a sign stating “Rough Road Ahead”. Kurmaskie’s confidence gradually turns into even deeper doubt and worry as his water supply steadily runs low. Finally, Kurmaskie sees a sign for a fish camp. Here, his hope returns as he finds a “rather modern bathroom” where he can stop to get a much - needed drink. As the setting changes, Kurmaskie’s confidence is first followed by determination and then finally relief, showing how greatly the desert setting influenced his emotional state during the ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a negative way because he is in a desert - like place during the scorching summer. With a scarce water supply and few places to refill, he could easily become extremely tired. The arid environment saps his energy rapidly. I would never have asked old people for directions. He should have asked someone who was in charge of a store because those people are often asked for directions and are more likely to give accurate and useful information. Also, he was in great danger as there were snakes in the area. He could have died if that snake had bitten him or, as he said, from “heatstroke”. The harsh desert setting with its lack of resources and potential hazards clearly had a detrimental impact on the cyclist's journey.

The story begins as the author, an enthusiastic cyclist, has taken directions from several very old men to reach his bike - ridden destination of Yosemite National Park. He starts out confident enough, with a spring in his step and a gleam in his eye. Then he reaches the first town the gentlemen described. It is a ghost town, a place filled with empty buildings and a sense of abandonment. It amuses the author, and still believing he’s perfectly fine, he sets out again. This time, he arrives at a place with “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule”. The dilapidated state of this place is a clear sign of trouble. It is at this point that the author starts to worry as his water supply is alarmingly low. He proceeds past rolling hills that seem to go on forever, slithering snakes that send shivers down his spine, tumbleweeds that roll aimlessly across the road, and different land - marks. Each one rips his confidence and excitement to shreds. Especially the juice factory, as the author is currently very dehydrated and losing all hope. The sight of the factory, which could have been a source of refreshment, only serves to remind him of his desperate situation. Finally, he arrives at the water he seeks in the form of “Gary Wilber’s fish camp”. He refreshes himself and his dried - out hope. Each time the author passed a land - mark, his confidence took a beating. And even though he was in dire physical health, not having any hope for his sunny breezy vacation can drain a person even more from the inside out, highlighting the powerful impact of the journey on his mental and physical well - being.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist negatively because he was in the desert in the sweltering summer. With little water and no accessible places, like stores or water fountains, to get a drink, he was in a precarious situation. For example, he says “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind”. This statement clearly explains how his setting affected him because he had nowhere to go or get a drink. The vast expanse of the desert with its barren landscape left him isolated and vulnerable. The lack of resources in the setting made his journey extremely difficult and dangerous. That is my reason why the cyclist's settings were negative, as they severely hampered his ability to complete his ride safely and comfortably.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in bad ways. The rocky road, full of uneven stones and bumps, and the steep hills made him pedal harder with every turn. His legs ached as he struggled to make his way up the inclines. The old people, perhaps not fully aware of the current conditions, made him go through the rocky way. The blistering temperature from the desert made him incredibly thirsty, and he ran out of water fast. He said “When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid”, indicating the poor quality of the little water he had left. The heat was so intense that it could have killed him at any time. For example, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from the heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June”. This shows the extreme physical stress he was under. This ride this man took to Yosemite was a very dangerous ride, with the unforgiving desert setting posing numerous threats to his well - being and making the journey a true test of his endurance.

The setting can greatly affect the cyclist. The specific place can change what happens and how it happens. For example, if the story had taken place in Alaska, the cyclist would not have had, "Wide rings of sweat circling my shirt." Instead, they would have been constantly fighting off hypothermia. The setting is very important because it affects all of the details in the writing, making the story's atmosphere and events unique to that particular place.

At first, the terrain was fine and he felt confident. But when he reached the first town, it looked exactly like one of those ghost towns in the movies, with dilapidated buildings and an eerie silence. The next town didn't come up when he was told it would. The terrain was that of a harsh desert, with no water for miles in any direction. But he stayed determined. And he finally made it to some water though, a small oasis that provided him with the much - needed relief.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” For example, he spots a “ramshackle shed” in the desolate area and immediately tries to find water there. It affected him significantly, because it says, “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” The quote shows that he was so determined to find water and perhaps anything that could quench his thirst or help him in his difficult situation.

The setting affected the cyclist by depriving him of hydration and gradually weakening him. The large, steep hills and rough, bumpy roads ebbed away every bit of his strength and wore him down. The narration states, “Over one long, crippling hill” (kurmaskie @NUM1). This word choice reflects the writer’s feeling about his adventure. Words like “long” and “crippling” clearly show that the trip was a truly horrible experience for the cyclist.

Pride, determination, relief – all are things that the cyclist felt during his long bike ride. First, the cyclist started off riding on fresh legs and with good directions. But after a while down the road, he started to doubt the old men. As he thought, “a diary with my last entry in place of old men, their wisdom, and their sense of direction, I made a mental move to change it.” After feeling that the direction might be rough, he rode out of pride to reach his destination. Next, the rider had great determination to get to his destination and did many things. For instance, “I gathered a few pebbles and stocked them in my mouth to take my mind off of thirst.” This quote shows that he would do almost anything to keep going. Finally, the cyclist was fatigued when he arrived at the @CAPS1 shop. He then knew the old men were right and that he would reach his destination. As the text says, “As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink.” This quote shows he was not only polite naturally to get water but also relieved to know the men were right, and his long - awaited journey had finally come to an end.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist when he was thirsty. As he pedaled along, "A sand - blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth could be seen." This vivid image clearly proves that the rider was thirsty. In the paragraph before this, it details him having a last burst of energy going down a hill. During this effort, he was also sweating a great deal, constantly wiping sweat from his eyes, which further indicates his physical state and the impact of the setting on his thirst. In conclusion, the setting's features effectively conveyed the cyclist's thirst through these details.

I work better when I can fully feel the environment around me. I think the same principle applies to cycling in the mountains. When there is fresh air and no worries on your mind, cycling can truly become a fun activity. The pleasant climate makes the ride easier, and the fresh air, the fine trees, and the overall environment make the cyclist feel better. For cyclists, the environment plays a vital and undeniable role in enhancing their experience. In conclusion, a favorable environment is key to making cycling an enjoyable and fulfilling activity.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a major way. The setting has a profound impact on the cyclist's performance. For example, the harsh temperature, which was extremely high, started to make his pedaling sluggish as his energy was quickly sapped. The settings also made the cyclist a little frightened. For instance, while cycling on a narrow path, the cyclist came across a snake that he was terrified of, causing his heart to race. Again, the settings affected the cyclist by tempting him. The clear, cool river tempted the cyclist to stop riding and go get a drink of water to quench his thirst. In conclusion, the setting had a major and multi - faceted affect on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For one, a lot of the settings discouraged the cyclist. "This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time - say, before the last world war - but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town." As soon as the cyclist hit this "town", he realized that the old men's advice might not have been so great. The dry desert affects the cyclist the most. This hot climate, with the sun beating down mercilessly, makes the cyclist extremely thirsty, hot, and sweaty. "Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke..." The cyclist's tune here is sarcastic but he is still deeply concerned about his health because of the heat and lack of water. The fact that there is nothing living around the cyclist also affects him. Since he talked to the old men for directions, he hasn't seen a glimpse of life, or buildings or anything. This definitely discourages the cyclist and makes him lose his will to continue his journey. In conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many and often demoralizing ways.

The cyclist tracked through a barren land trying desperately to get to a land of rivers and valleys. While tracking through the first town, the cyclist saw a ramshackle shed, rusty pumps, and a corral located in the desolate desert of California. The cyclist was very angry that the old men led him into this barren town. However, he kept a glimmer of hope and traveled to the next town. There, he found an abandoned fruit juice factory and bottling plant. This sight so discouraged the cyclist that he started to give up. "I was going to die," he claimed with all hope lost. The man feels like there is nothing left and it's the old men who caused this unfortunate situation. Then finally, he came across a bait shop on his own, which gave him a huge relief. The features of the setting affect his attitude because in a barren land, one easily loses hope, as did the cyclist. Therefore, what's around us affects us in various aspects such as education, friendship, and survival. In conclusion, the surrounding environment can have a powerful impact on our mindset and our ability to persevere.

In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,'' the cyclist is deeply affected both emotionally and physically by the features of the desolate setting. At the start of his journey, when he came across a deserted shed with rusty, dilapidated pumps, an overwhelming sense of discouragement began to seep into his mind. ì[The] sight was troubling,î(page @NUM1) As the ride progressed, the terrain gradually changed from flat land to short, rolling hills, and tumbleweeds started to pass by in the dry wind. The cyclist is definitely affected by this change in terrain. He is now completely exhausted but continues to doggedly pump his legs and ride on. Before the end of his arduous ride, the cyclist reaches an abandoned @ORGANIZATION1. The setting now includes a large picture of a young boy drinking a refreshing glass of juice. The author seems almost defeated by this sight. ìI hung my head'' (page @NUM2) he confessed. In the end, once he spots an old fisherman's store in the distance, he is relieved. The sight of the store from afar excited the author, because he could finally have a long - awaited drink. The author's mood and body were greatly affected by the features of the setting, which made his journey a real test of will.

The features of the desolate setting in ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie clearly show that as the long day goes on under the scorching sun, the cyclist becomes extremely tired and worn - out from his long and arduous ride through rough and unforgiving terrain as he tries to find his way back home. Then, he catches a glimpse of some buildings down a hill and said ìWith what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hillî (kurmakie @NUM1). After the rider finally gets home, despite the hardships, he says he is going to do it again, showing his love for cycling and the challenge it presents.

The main and most pressing affect on the cyclist is the lack of water. It is in the sweltering month of June, while he is riding his bike in the arid expanse of California. Therefore, itís going to be extremely hot, and heíll need a large amount of water to stay hydrated. When he sees that Welchís Grape Juice factory, with its enticing images of cool beverages, it just makes him acutely aware of his thirst even more. Also, the terrain he is riding on is far from easy. He starts out riding on flat ground, but then he has to tackle hilly and not - so - flat terrain. This strenuous riding on uneven ground only exacerbates his dehydration. Thatís why you should always carry an ample supply of water with you if youíre riding a bike during the hot summer months to avoid such discomfort.

The affects of the settings on the cyclist were mainly how blisteringly hot it was and the poor condition of the cyclist road he was on. The rider said it was June in the peak of the summer time, and the sun was beating down mercilessly, making it very hot. And the roads were not smooth at all; they were very old and ragged, full of potholes and cracks that made the ride bumpy and difficult. These factors combined made the cyclist's journey a real struggle, highlighting the importance of proper conditions for cycling.

In the short story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî a cyclist is bravely going against the intense heat of the summer sun, the severe lack of water in the arid environment, and the challenging rough hills as he tries to skillfully maneuver around them. His journey is fraught with difficulties, but it also showcases his determination and resilience in the face of adversity. Despite these challenges, his cycling adventure is a testament to his love for the sport and his will to overcome obstacles.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is trying to bike up steep hills and down equally challenging hills, which can be extremely tiring. The continuous effort required to pedal uphill and control the speed downhill takes a toll on his energy. Also, the sweltering hot air can rapidly dehydrate him, which can cause him to pass out. Along with the dry air, the arid land means there is no readily available place to stop for water or take a short rest. The rough, uneven terrain makes the biking more difficult because it involves more energy than biking on a smooth path. Finally, the snake lying in the middle of the road made it hard for the cyclist to go around. If the snake would have bitten him, he could have died from the poison. In such a challenging setting, the cyclist has to constantly be on high - alert and conserve his energy to make it through.

The setting in the essay "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" was extremely hot and dry, with very little shade or moisture available. At some points along the journey, there was perhaps not a single spot of shade or a drop of moisture in sight. This harsh weather affected the author severely because he had no water at all. As he continued to move forward, he was getting more and more dehydrated. The lack of water combined with the intense heat made his situation quite perilous. Eventually, this challenging setting highlighted the importance of proper preparation when venturing into such environments.

How the features of the setting affected the cyclist. The feature was that one should never take advice from old people who never get out of the house. For instance, in the story it says, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This advice affected the setting because if it weren't for his map and he let those old people take a peek at it, that would have saved him a great deal of trouble. By relying on his own map and not the unhelpful advice, he could have avoided the difficulties that came with following their suggestions. This shows that in unfamiliar settings, it's crucial to trust reliable sources of information.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting of the terrain was hot and water - draining. In the text it says “Followed by blackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two - hundred degrees.” This clearly proves that the cyclist is exaggerating about the very hot temperature of the high deserts of California. The intense heat made the journey extremely challenging. The setting is also water - draining, and the cyclist had to stop in the desert town to refill his water bottle. As in the text says “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of a rusted water pump with all my strength.” This proves that the cyclist had to stop for water and use a great deal of power to pump it out. In conclusion, always prepare for the worst but hope for the best, especially when venturing into harsh terrains like the high deserts.

In the story, there are many features of the setting that affect the cyclist. One setting feature is the rolling of steep hills. The long and steep hills make the cyclist completely exhausted and even more desperate for water. For example, in the story it says, “Over one long crippling hill, a building came into view.” This shows that the hill was very hard and strenuous to get over. By using the word crippling, it informs us that the hill was brutal and extremely difficult to conquer. Another setting feature that affects the cyclist is the complete absence of any civilization on his cycling path. While he was riding, he notices that there is not a single person around to help him if he gets in trouble or needs water. The lack of people makes him feel highly stressed and worried about his journey. It shows this in the story when he says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” Also, it says in the story “I was going to die and the bird would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry on the parse of old men.” This shows that there was nobody around to help him and he was fully aware of it. He thought he would die alone and that birds would eat him. He was obviously extremely worried about the absence of people. In such a desolate setting, the cyclist's situation becomes increasingly precarious, emphasizing the importance of preparedness for solo adventures.

Usually, the features of the setting have a major impact on the cyclist. The features of the setting relate to and describe the harsh, and eventually the relief, conditions of the cyclist. The setting is connected to the person and plays a role that the cyclist can observe. One reason how the features of the setting affect the cyclist is that it shows the various problems the cyclist is facing. For example, surrounded by cool pines with no one in sight, I am all alone. This situation conveys a clear meaning: as the cyclist, I need help to get home, and during the journey, I need water to quench my thirst. Prior to this, the features show the weakness of the cyclist. For instance, I believed it was my last burst of energy as I constantly maneuvered down the hill. The features and settings affect the cyclist by showing how he was dealing with his troubles, thirst and fear, which were all left behind in the end. These features and settings develop a clear understanding for the cyclist and what is to be expected by him.

The features of the setting had a big impact on the cyclist. When he started that ride, he was confident that the “old timers” were right about which directions and roads he had to take to get to Yosemite National Park. Even though the scorching sun was bearing down relentlessly, he refused to give up, just as he says “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I hardly noticed.” He came across places that were worn - down and completely deserted, so he knew that he was all alone if anything happened. The intense desert heat had made him consume his water pretty regularly, so he tried to get more. As described in the text, “I got on my hands and knees. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid” (paragraph @NUM1). He was so extremely thirsty that he would even drink hot water. Then he thought he only had @NUM2 miles to go, so he kept pushing forward. He was weakening as he pedaled along the ever - changing terrain while “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” With what little energy he had left, he passed an abandoned Well be Grape Juice factory, which probably severely tested his patience and sanity. He had resorted to “gathering up a few pebbles and sticking them in my mouth” just to take his mind off his thirst. He was losing hope when he came upon “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp best bet,” and then he felt relieved after he was able to get cool water. By then, he had learned his lesson: to stick to his map and not rely solely on others' advice.

In the author's recollection of his long and tiresome bike ride, he talked about the numerous struggles he had to face. When he set out that morning, he asked some old guys sitting on a porch for directions to @CAPS1. They told him that they knew the way and that they knew a shortcut. He chose to take their advice but later regretted it. When he reached the places they mentioned, all he found were dilapidated and deserted ghost towns. He realized he was all alone if any trouble occurred. As the author said, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I hardly noticed,” showing his initial determination. The desert heat was intense, and he had to drink water regularly. He tried to get more water, as described when he “got on his hands and knees” and found that the water “had the flavor of battery acid.” He was so thirsty that he would have drunk hot water. He thought he only had @NUM2 miles to go, so he kept going. He was weakening as he pedaled along the changing terrain, “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” With his last bit of energy, he passed an abandoned Well be Grape Juice factory, which surely tested his patience. He resorted to “gathering up a few pebbles and sticking them in my mouth” to distract himself from the thirst. He was losing hope when he finally came upon “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp best bet.” After getting cool water there, he felt relieved. By then, he had learned his lesson: he should have stuck to his map instead of relying on the advice of those old - timers.

A cyclist can only travel as fast or as slow as he pedals. If the setting is a humid sunny day, he can't go too fast due to his limited lung capacity. The thick, humid air makes it difficult for him to breathe deeply, thus restricting his speed. If it is a warm but windy day, he has to watch his speed carefully to keep from getting hurt. Strong gusts of wind can easily unbalance him, especially when taking turns or going downhill. Basically, unless the weather is nice and safe enough, he won't go fast. But safety comes first, so it mostly depends on the weather, but also the time of the day. If it is night (dark), reflectors must be put on the bike to keep from getting into an accident. The lack of visibility at night makes it crucial for the cyclist to be visible to other road users, and reflectors are an essential safety measure.

The features in the setting affect the cyclist because of the heat and the terrain. I say this because in the story it describes all the steep hills that he has to laboriously go up and down while the horrendous heat beats down on him mercilessly. The heat also makes the situation difficult because it makes the cyclist drink more water. Throughout the story, he was constantly trying to find some water. The water he did find was about “two hundred degrees and tasted like battery acid.” If you have no water, it becomes extremely hard to bicycle such a long distance in that much heat. The combination of the challenging terrain and the sweltering heat drains the cyclist's energy and makes the journey an arduous one. Without an adequate supply of water, the cyclist's physical condition deteriorates rapidly, making it almost impossible to continue the ride. In conclusion, the heat and terrain in the setting have a significant and negative impact on the cyclist's ability to complete the journey.

The cyclist is affected by numerous features in the surrounding setting. The long, arduous hill is one prominent example. The slithering snake that crosses his path and the bumpy dirt road he traverses are two more. The intense heat of the desert, which beats down relentlessly, is another factor. Also, his gradually depleting water supply, which becomes a constant concern, are all examples of features that affected him. These elements combined made his cycling journey a challenging one.

There were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. On one page @NUM1, in paragraph @NUM2, there is a clear sign that states "rough road ahead". This warning indicates the difficult terrain he is about to face. On the same page @NUM1, paragraph @NUM4, it says "over the long on - piling hill". This shows the physical challenge of the uphill ride. He also has to deal with the temperature as described starting on page @NUM5. At the top of page @NUM1, paragraph @NUM7, it says "I was traveling in the high desert of California in June". These conditions of the setting all have an impact on the cyclist, making his journey more arduous.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in this story. First of all, in the story it says "…and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke…" (@NUM1). This quote clearly shows that it is extremely hot, and this sweltering heat is directly affecting his ability to ride. The narrator also says, "I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state" (@CAPS1 @NUM2). This quote is indicating that he is dehydrated and, as a result, is having significant trouble keeping balance on the rough terrain. In conclusion, the setting, with its heat and rough ground, affected the cyclist in this story by posing physical challenges to his cycling.

The setting affects the cyclist by motivating him to go longer and keep riding the bike. His curiosity drives him to see what is up ahead. However, riding a bike in the intense heat can lead to serious consequences. You can have a heat stroke and die from dehydration and the searing heat. That's why it is crucial to have a sufficient amount of water with you when you are riding a bike in such conditions. Failing to do so can turn an exciting ride into a dangerous situation.

THE CYCLIST'S SETTINGS HINDER HIM IN THE ESSAY "ROUGH ROAD AHEAD." THE CYCLIST IS IN THE DESERT DURING THE SUMMER TIME, WITH HARDLY ANY WATER TO QUENCH HIS THIRST. HE IS ON A QUEST TO FIND HIS WAY TO YOSEMITE, BUT HE ENCOUNTERS TROUBLE. SOME OLD MEN GAVE HIM BAD DIRECTIONS, AND HE GETS LOST ALONG THE WAY. DURING THIS TIME, HE IS RIDING HIS BICYCLE FOR MILES AND MILES IN THE SCORCHING HEAT OF THE SUMMER. HIS CONSTANT THOUGHTS OF THIRST GET IN THE WAY OF HIS CONCENTRATION, MAKING IT DIFFICULT FOR HIM TO CONTINUE ON TO FIND YOSEMITE. I BELIEVE THAT IF THE CYCLIST WAS IN A COOLER ENVIRONMENT THEN THINGS WOULD HAVE BEEN DIFFERENT BECAUSE HIS SETTINGS WERE SORT OF A DISTRACTION TO HIM, IMPEDING HIS PROGRESS ON THE JOURNEY.

The cyclist became extremely tired, and the area he found himself in was of no help whatsoever. He was in the vast desert in June, on a swelteringly hot day. Every town he reached was completely abandoned, with not a drop of water to be found. Moreover, the terrain was very hilly, which made his cycling work even more arduous. In such harsh conditions, his journey became an uphill battle, and he struggled to keep going.

The features in the setting of "Rough Road Ahead, Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" significantly affect the cyclist because they determine how easy or hard his ride is. For example, the land being extremely hot would put him at risk of dying or suffering from heatstroke without an adequate water supply. The dry land means he doesn't have a convenient place to refill his water bottle. And the barren land implies that if he doesn't succumb to heatstroke, there's a high chance he won't be found and won't survive. Another instance of how the features of the setting impact the cyclist is in the story when the road turns rough and he sees the speed limit sign. His thoughts are about how he's going at a water - depleting 12 mph. This clearly shows that the features of the setting, namely the contour of the land and the roughness of the road, make the journey a great deal harder on the cyclist. The features of a setting could possibly be the biggest hindrance to a cyclist, and whether they have a long, hard journey where they have to push themselves to the limit, like in this story, or a nice, leisurely ride depends largely on these features.

The cyclist in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" was definitely affected by the setting. He was cycling in California, which is known to be a hot place right from the start, and it was June. This made the weather even hotter as he was approaching a searing hot desert. When you're engaged in a physical activity like cycling, the last thing you desire is to be in such intense heat. The narrator only brought one small bottle of water, and at first, he was sipping from it regularly. Then, as the heat intensified, he quickly ran out of water. This affected his body, making him extremely tired, and his mind as well, as he started to doubt his ability to continue. Then there was the abandoned juice building where they used to make juice. He said, "In an ironic twist, the building abandoned years earlier had been a Welch’s grape juice factory and bottling plant." He was on the verge of dying of thirst when he found the bottling plant. The cyclist was definitely affected by his surroundings both mentally, by constantly thinking "I'm going to die," and physically by becoming severely dehydrated. In the end, the harsh setting took a heavy toll on his well - being.

The cyclist was riding in some extremely rough, dry, and desolate abandoned terrain that made his journey perilously close to being fatal. He described it as, "In the high deserts of California in June." The environment was bone - dry, completely lifeless, and swelteringly hot. The scorching sun was relentlessly beating down on him, and he needed to drink water frequently, but his supply was rapidly running out. The empty towns were what he was desperately hoping to find fresh water in, but they had been long - abandoned. This made his journey extremely dangerous. He could've toppled off his bike at any moment because of heatstroke and would've perished right there in the desert. His sweat was evaporating instantly in the intense heat, and there was no way for him to cool off in the desolate, dry, and lifeless desert. He had to endure these extreme and ironic conditions for miles on end, just to search for some water. It was the epitome of what a desert is and what a cyclist should never have to go through. In such circumstances, his survival became a real challenge.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The hills are uncommonly long, making each climb a strenuous task. Every town he passes through appears to be completely deserted, leaving him with no hope of finding essential supplies. The roads are extremely rough, filled with potholes and uneven surfaces that jolt his body with every pedal stroke. The blistering heat also takes a heavy toll on him. He is affected health - wise, as the heat makes him dizzy and weak, and the lack of proper rest and water due to the unforgiving setting puts his overall well - being at risk. In conclusion, the adverse features of the setting make his cycling journey a real struggle and pose a significant threat to his health.

When you're doing any sport or any activity where you sweat, your setting is everything. If you're sweating in an unfavorable setting, you can easily get sick. In the story "Rough road ahead", the cyclist was in a situation where there was no water and the setting was extremely hot. That's precisely why the cyclist became tired and sick because he was sweating profusely and had no water to replenish himself. This clearly shows how the setting can significantly affect the cyclist.

The features of the setting, such as old abandoned towns, hot temperatures, and abandoned buildings, affect the cyclist greatly. These elements make the cyclist think that all hope is lost. As described in the essay, “Over one long crippling hill, a building came into view [...] I hung my head as that smoky blues tune 'Summertime' rattled around.” This shows the cyclist's despair. Then, in an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building, which by the looks of it had been a Welch’s grape juice factory and bottling plant, changed the cyclist's mood. As stated, “As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them.” This demonstrates how the setting can have a profound impact on the cyclist's emotions, from despair to a glimmer of hope.

With no one around, a rough road stretching ahead, and not to mention the onset of dehydration, the cyclist began to feel that he was going to die. Due to this dire situation, he started to doubt himself. However, each time he caught sight of something in the distance, he summoned the will to try and reach it. Despite his growing sense of hopelessness, the cyclist found a small spark of determination within himself, pushing forward in the face of adversity.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. For one, he was biking through the high deserts of California in June, a time when the sun beats down mercilessly. This intense heat caused the cyclist to become overheated and sweaty. As a result, he drank from his water bottles frequently to cool down and stay hydrated. Unfortunately, since there was, “no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” he had nowhere to refill his bottles and soon became dehydrated. To make matters even worse, the terrain changed from a flat road to “short, rolling hills.” Normally, this type of terrain would not cause too much struggle, but since he was dehydrated and overheated, each hill seemed “crippling.” My thoughts are that if the setting had been a bit cooler and perhaps in a time period similar to when the old men had lived, the cyclist would have had a much more enjoyable experience, free from the physical and mental toll of the harsh conditions.

Excitement, desperation, and self - pity are all feelings the cyclist had because of the setting. He was really excited to get to Yosemite Park because of its well - known peacefulness. He vividly said, “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite are calling my name.” The intense heat of his current setting made his desire to reach Yosemite even stronger. As he continued his journey, he started getting desperate for water. In his desperation, he even tried to drink from a hot water hole. He remarked, “I tried a drop or two, tasted like battery acid.” With his water supply running out, his desperation for some clean water grew. Moreover, he started to have self - pity. He lamented, “sometimes life can be so cruel,” feeling sorry for himself because he still had such a long way to go. These are all feelings the cyclist had because of the setting, which had a profound impact on his emotional state throughout the journey.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist’s moods in many ways. The story says, “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town.’” The cyclist is probably already tired from pedaling for forty miles on the long, arduous journey. Then he finds out that the town is deserted, with empty streets and silent buildings, which makes him a little frustrated. The next few stops are also deserted and he is almost out of water, feeling his throat parched and his energy waning. He is becoming desperate. The road becomes bumpy, jolting him roughly on the bike, and there is a large snake blocking the way, its menacing presence sending shivers down his spine. He is terrified. Finally, he reaches a bait shop with cool water, and he is relieved as the refreshing liquid quenches his thirst. As you can see, the cyclist goes through many moods caused by the setting of the story.

The way the feature of the setting affected the cyclist is that it’s in June in the middle of the desert. The intense heat of the desert sun beats down relentlessly, baking the sand beneath his wheels. Also, he was given wrong directions, leaving him lost and disoriented in this vast, unforgiving expanse. This combination of the harsh climate and incorrect guidance made his cycling journey extremely difficult and perilous.

The cyclist was affected by the climate, the people, and the surrounding. The climate was the desert in June which was very hot with little water. The scorching sun beat down on him all day, causing him to sweat profusely and quickly deplete his water supply. This made him dehydrated and miserable, with a pounding headache and a dry, cracked throat. The old men that “helped” him accused him of being in the guiding situation he was in, adding to his frustration and confusion. There were no surrounding shops or buildings that were inhabited. The desolate landscape stretched as far as the eye could see, with no signs of civilization or a place to get help. This way there was no place for him to get any water nourishment, leaving him in a desperate situation. All these factors combined made his cycling experience in this setting extremely challenging and unpleasant.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by when the story says “Twenty miles up the road. I came to a fork of sorts.” This statement from the story affected the cyclist because he didn’t know which way to go. Standing at the fork, he looked down both paths, each disappearing into the distance, with no clear indication of which was the right one. Another feature that affected the setting is when the story says “I got on my hand and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength.” That statement shows that the cyclist was dying for water and he didn’t think any was going to come out. He pumped with all his might, his muscles straining, as he watched the dry pump with growing despair. Last feature that affected the cyclist was when the story says “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit.” This shows that the rider had to go under a speed limit but he was earlier tired and he was going way under it and that he could make it up the rough road. The rough road loomed ahead, full of potholes and bumps, and his tired body struggled to keep the bike moving forward. In conclusion, these various features of the setting significantly impacted the cyclist's journey.

The dry, deserted area the cyclist is in has many cautions and dangers. The parched landscape is filled with loose sand that can easily cause the bike to skid and lose control. There are also hidden rocks and uneven terrain that pose a threat to his safety. The lack of water sources means he is at risk of dehydration, and the extreme heat can quickly lead to heatstroke. With no signs of human habitation, he is isolated and alone, with no one to turn to in case of an emergency. All these factors make his journey through this area a challenging and perilous one.

In the text, the author was cycling to Yosemite Park through a vast, arid desert which rapidly dehydrated him and significantly changed his mood.
