As he pedaled through this seemingly endless desert, he soon ran out of water and had to stop. Some of the small towns he had been told about turned out to be completely deserted. Since he couldn't find water there, he quickly became dehydrated. This is the obvious effect the desolate setting had on him. Another effect was that it made him doubt the advice of old people and transformed his mood from confident to desperate. As he was cycling through the desert, desperately clinging to life in hopes he could find water, he realized that old people know more about the past than the future as they don't get out into the ever - changing world as much as they used to. In contrast, at the beginning, he was fully confident in the directions and wisdom of the old men. The harsh setting he was in ultimately made him a little more wise, teaching him the importance of self - reliance and critical thinking.

Because the setting of the cyclist's ride is a parched, dry desert, it makes the cyclist seem even more determined. He is going against all the odds, as if he is pushing himself to the absolute limit. Against the scorching heat and the seemingly never - ending long road he's on, and with no water in sight, all seems lost for the cyclist. Every pedal stroke is a struggle, his body is being tested to its extremes. But in the end, he manages to pull himself together. With sheer willpower, he makes it happen for himself and triumphs over the adversity of the desert, proving that determination can overcome even the harshest of conditions.

From reading the story, I believe the setting of the desert he was cycling through affected him immensely. I believe it affected him in the way the attitude of the cyclist changed for the worse. At first, he was very motivated, determined, and well - hydrated. As time passed and he covered more miles, the scenery remained monotonously the same. That can be really challenging, especially when you're in the heat and need to be as hydrated as possible, particularly when engaging in an enduring physical activity like cycling. As time went on, he was getting low on water and had nothing else to think about other than how thirsty he was and whether this whole journey was worth it. It's a lot harder to stay motivated when there's nothing interesting to look at to keep your mind off the discomfort. The attitude of the cyclist changed for the worse. In my point of view, I strongly believe that it could have been from cycling in the same sandy desert for a long period of time. I have experienced the same when exercising while in a dull environment. It's hard to stay focused on the task at hand. My attitude will quickly shift from “I'm so determined” to “I'm bored” to “what's the point”. But I thought it was great how he never gave up even when things got really bad. It opened my eyes to see how great it is to reach your own goals, no matter the difficulties faced along the way.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by dehydrating him severely. The cyclist said, “I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake slithered by.” The cyclist was in the vast expanse of the desert, and with each mile he rode, he became more and more dehydrated. The intense desert sun was like a relentless oven, drying out his body with every passing moment. He said with each passing landmark, “I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” It was evident that the more he went on, the more the unforgiving desert affected him and sapped the moisture from his body, making each pedal stroke a herculean effort. In the end, the desert's dehydrating effect was a constant and powerful force against his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. One way is that the cyclist deviated from sticking to his map. Instead of following the planned route on his map, he decided to ask a couple of old people for directions. The old people who gave the cyclist directions also suggested a short - cut to take. That's where the second effect came in, as the cyclist started to use this shortcut instead of staying on the main road. This shortcut, likely due to the unique features of the desert setting such as less traffic and a different terrain, led him into unforeseen situations. Overall, these actions, influenced by the setting and the advice he received, changed the course of his journey, demonstrating how the features of the setting can have a significant impact on a traveler's choices and experiences.

Some features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the poor road conditions and the significant road changes with the steep hills. So far, the cyclist had a great and smooth ride for about two miles into his journey. After that, the situation started to change. This is supported when the author states, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing” (kurmaskie). Even though the author started this journey in a nice and comfortable way, it did not take long for things to turn against him. Although the hills became steeper and the road conditions deteriorated, the character in the story still managed to get through his problems without much worry. With all of the problems in the setting, the cyclist still persevered to end his journey successfully.

The features of the setting cause the cyclist two main problems: doubt and dehydration. From the essay, you can clearly infer that the cyclist doubts he will ever make it to Yosemite because of the numerous constant features in the essay that cause him to lose his hope and confidence. For example, near the end of the essay, the cyclist is already extremely exhausted and completely hopeless. But then he sees a building over a hill. He hurries to the building with high hopes, only to find out that it is an abandoned, run - down @ORGANIZATION1 factory. After getting his hopes up, he is forced to get back on his bike and carry on. This feature of the setting causes further disappointment to the cyclist and installs more doubt into his mind. Despite losing his confidence and hopes to make it to Yosemite, the features of the setting also cause him a serious, literal problem: dehydration. The weather is hot and dry, and he has to carry on over steep hills and on rough roads. He is running low on water, and at the one town he finds, the water from the pump is undrinkable. The features of the setting are causing him these problems and are the reason his health is at significant risk. In the end, these challenges severely test the cyclist's physical and mental endurance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is the poor condition of the roads, which are full of potholes and uneven surfaces. Another is the intense heat that makes the air feel like a furnace. Another is the presence of snakes slithering around, posing a real threat. Another is the fact that there is no town in sight for miles. The final one is the lack of information about the route ahead. Maybe the guy made it safely to his destination. Maybe he got hurt on the ride. Maybe a snake bit him while he was cycling. Either way, the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, making his journey a challenging one.

In the essay, the description of the setting was dry, with the parched ground cracking underfoot, hot, as if the sun was directly baking the land, very open with vast stretches of empty space, and deserted with no signs of human habitation. The description could suggest loneliness, obviously. Even though the man was all alone in this desolate setting and didn't know where he was going, he still persisted. While he thought about “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,” this vivid mental image kept him strong, so he kept trying, determined to reach his destination.

There were many land features that affected the cyclist and his trip. First of all, it is a desert, a vast expanse of arid land which greatly affects him as there is no readily available water in deserts. There was also a venomous snake, coiled menacingly on the side of the road, which could have bit and killed him. As the roads were not very well paved and had obviously been abandoned for years, with large cracks and loose gravel, it made cycling much harder for him. And the dilapidated juice factory just taunted him, making him remember his desperate need for water, as did the well that did not pump cold, refreshing water, but instead pumped hot, gross - smelling water. All these land features combined to make the cyclist's trip extremely difficult and challenging.

When the cyclist first starts his journey, he is full of self - assurance, brimming with confidence as if he can conquer any challenge. He sees everything exactly as the old men told him, believing every word they said. As he travels on, he begins to notice that the entire area is desolate, with everything looking abandoned and empty. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The man starts to become extremely unsure of himself. You can clearly tell from his actions. He says, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get excited.” He was very doubtful he’d get to where he was going. In the end, he was immensely relieved when he found a fishing spot with a bathroom and fresh water, which was like a haven in this desolate landscape.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in this story a great deal. Having unreliable directions, which were vague and inaccurate, barely enough water for the long - distance journey, poor road conditions full of potholes and uneven surfaces, and other hazards like the scorching heat and wild animals made this a very difficult journey for the cyclist. Starting the journey, the cyclist received bad information on how to get to his destination. This misinformation led him on a long and arduous journey with not much water to sustain him. He says in the story, “The speed limit was @NUM1. I was doing a water - depleting @NUM2.” This means he was running out of water too fast for the amount of land he was covering. Another feature of the setting that affected him was that the road conditions got worse and worse until he reached a highway late in his journey. He said, “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This means the faster, easy - to - ride terrain was replaced by slower, harder - to - ride - on terrain. These features of the setting could have been very dangerous and maybe even fatal, and they affected the cyclist a great deal throughout this story.

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist, because as his surroundings gradually changed, he lost hope of making it to Yosemite National Park. Such as when he was riding through his first town and it looked completely abandoned, with broken windows and overgrown weeds, he wasn’t so sure if he should keep going. He hesitated, looking around at the desolate scene. As well as when he didn’t see anyone or any buildings for a long time, just miles and miles of empty land, he got worried and was on the verge of losing hope. His heart sank with each passing mile. But as a second road sign appeared, clearly indicating the direction to his destination, he was relieved, as if a heavy burden had been lifted from his shoulders.

The setting in this short story causes the cyclist to doubt his survival. The main problem is water, or rather the lack of it. The cyclist has no water left in his bottles, and the parched throat and dry lips make him think it’s only a matter of time before he dies. His mouth is so dry that it’s hard to even swallow. Another big problem is the rough terrain. The rough terrain, with its rocky paths and steep slopes, is hard for the cyclist to overcome. His legs ache with each pedal stroke. Also, there is no sign of buildings, people, or cars in sight to save him. The vast expanse of emptiness stretches all around. Until he finds the bait shop, if anything would have happened to him, there would’ve been no one there to help, leaving him completely at the mercy of the harsh environment.

The features of the setting of “Do not exceed posted speed limit” greatly impact the cyclist, in a negative way. For example, when the road changes from being smooth and easy to ride on to being rolling and full of hills. The sudden change in the road surface makes it difficult for him to bike. He has to shift gears constantly and use more energy to get over the hills. His breathing becomes heavy as he struggles to pedal uphill. Another example is when it says, “tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” The connection with seeing a tumbleweed is that of being deserted and alone, so this increased his feelings of despair. He feels isolated in this desolate world. Lastly, he sees the Welch’s Grape Juice Factory, which is deserted and has broken windows and rusty machinery. This desolate sight serves to only make him thirstier. All of these things affect the cyclist. The fact that he sees the grape juice factory is also ironic, because he is extremely dehydrated and the factory, which should be a source of refreshment, is abandoned.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways. The first of these is the blazing heat. He is basically in a vast, arid desert where the sun beats down relentlessly, and he is running low on water. As he starts to run out of water, he starts conserving it, but this is dehydrating him, so he is becoming weaker. “I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so - a test of my inner spirit.” Next up is the rough terrain. When you hit the bumpy, uneven rough terrain on a bike, it can get extremely hard to keep going, and the cyclist was already short on water. “A large highway sign jumped out at me. I read: rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit. Sometimes life can be so cruel.” Finally is the structure. First there was the Ghost town with the “battery acid” tasting water that was undrinkable. Also there was the Welch’s grape Juice factory and bottling plant which were both probably dilapidated. “A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head.” As you can see, the features of the settings generally affected the cyclist, making his journey a difficult one.

The author finds the desolate and harsh settings to be not discouraging. Rather, they stand out as a cause of amusement and fun, like quest - like tests. The author writes that after arriving at his first ghost - town, he chuckles, amused by the funny “old codgers” sitting on their porches and their crazy, out - of - date ideas. When he arrives at the second establishment, and realizes it isn’t the least bit established anymore, just a crumbling building in the middle of nowhere, he’s slightly disappointed, but sees it as “a test of [his] inner spirit.” At the third building, an abandoned factory with rusted machinery and broken windows, he still appreciates the irony of the situation. While biking across the vast desert, he refuses to be discouraged by the empty horizon that stretches as far as the eye can see. Instead, he uses it as a point of reference to measure his progress and as a way to push himself forward. Though the author is faced with empty, disappointing views, he keeps his spirits up and keeps pushing, showing great resilience in the face of desolation.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead: do not exceed speed limit”, the reader sees the scenery and terrain get rougher, and lonelier. As the cyclist travels and his limits are being pushed, his outlook is somewhat grim as he only expects the worst. The rough road starts out after a water pump he finds. The water from the pump is piping hot, brackish, and tastes like battery acid. Water in a sense in this story is a metaphor to his life, and is the source for him living. In the beginning, he drank it regularly, quenching his thirst easily. But when he gets to the pump and finds the bad water, it’s just like when things start to turn sour in the story itself. The cyclist in this story is very aware of how his body is and acknowledges his dehydration. At one point he says “and the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke simply because I had listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porches in a decade”. He later said it caused him to laugh sadly, hopelessly. The lack of humans and their technology, like proper water sources, really broke him down, making his journey a struggle.

The desert is the cruelest of nature’s environments. Its lack of water, dry air that sucks the moisture out of everything, and punishing heat that can sear the skin are enough to kill even the hardiest creature. When traveling through a desert, one must maintain a constant water supply and know their path with respect to the power of nature. In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, cycler Joe Kurmaskie must overcome the desert’s intense heat and lack of water to survive. As the author observes in paragraph @NUM1, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, I could drop from heatstroke.” If the human body overheats, it becomes sick and unable to properly function. When in the desert, one must keep cool or perish. In @NUM2, Kurmaskie begins to realize the danger of running out of water in the desert. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” As this water starts to run out, Joe suffers from dehydration, despair that clouds his mind, and a loss of balance that makes it hard to stay on his bike. Water is essential in a desert environment. Without it, as Joe observes, “the birds would pick (you) clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear”. In the end, Joe's ability to overcome these challenges will determine whether he can make it out of the desert alive.

The features in the setting of the essay “Rough Road Ahead Do not exceed the Posted Speed limit” affect the cyclist in a cruel manner. The old man says that the towns are going to be there, but they are just non - functioning towns, mere shells of what they once were. To make the cyclist feel hopeless, the setting puts him in a sweltering California day in June which is extremely hot, and throws in all these unexpected twists. A cruel thing to add in the essay was when it read “The Speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water - depleting 12 mph.” This lowers the cyclist's confidence, making him seem more worried about his slow progress and the fact that he's using up water so quickly. Another cruel thing is the author adding a Welch’s Grape Juice factory that had been abandoned. There was “A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring @NUM1 refreshing glass of juice into his mouth”, totally causing him to lose the last bit of hope he had. These features in the setting are cruel, making the cyclist's journey a demoralizing one.

The features of a setting, such as terrain and weather greatly affect the cyclist who is biking in it. The features of a setting can make the cyclist's trip either easier or harder. The features of the setting in a cycling journey can have a wide - ranging impact on the cyclist. The cyclist is affected by multiple factors during his journey. The change in terrain from flat to hilly makes pedaling more strenuous, requiring more energy. There are many different features that can influence a cyclist's journey, such as the weather, road condition, and how the person is feeling. The weather can have a significant impact. According to the essay, the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” a cyclist was on a mission to reach Yosemite National Park. In “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is significantly affected by his surroundings. He is leaving the old water pump, eagerly heading towards Yosemite. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many significant ways. One prominent feature of the setting was the intense heat. It affected him severely by quickly getting him dehydrated. For example, the text clearly states, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips; I could drop from a heat - stroke.” This meant that the scorching heat was really getting to him, making his journey extremely difficult and potentially dangerous. As a result, his physical and mental state was deteriorating due to the lack of proper hydration in such high - temperature conditions.

The author made the setting seem long and unbearable, filled with an undesirable heat and a lack of water at hand. Specially in the way he kept describing the road with all these challenges that kept appearing. For instance, after @NUM1 miles to a town and then @NUM2 miles passed that, he wrote, “I came to a park of … One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the tamest mule greeted me. This sight was truly troubling.” Then he went into a tirade, “I was traveling straight through the high deserts of California in June. @CAPS1 … imagine, the blistering heat, and the unbearable nature of the … journey still I face. @CAPS1 that bike has seen endless miles. Then with a thrust gaining on him, for example, “I was doing a water - depleting 12 mph; it's clear life can be cruel.” @CAPS1 made him feel his constraint and regret on the journey. It also made me feel his constraint and sorrow for his endless journey he had to go through. Another example is, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure I wasn't seeing a mirage.” Then, reaching this, the building abandoned years ago. @CAPS1 made his journey seem hopeless and long, filled with endless problems as the first wave of issues got stronger. @CAPS1 made his journey seem to be harder and filled with little hope as his strength left to finish his goals, leaving him in a seemingly never - ending struggle.

In the story, “Do not exceed postal speed limit,” many features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist. First and most importantly, he is significantly affected by the people who live there. “Never accept travel advice from a group of old - timers who haven’t left the confines of their porch since Carter was in office.” This quote vividly describes the feelings the cyclist has towards the old men. Because he listened to their directions, he ended up traveling through ghost towns and was on the verge of dying from dehydration constantly. Also, the lack of people and civilization in the area affected the author greatly. There was no one around that he could ask for help from. “… but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” Here, the author is trying to stop for water, but since no one lives in the town anymore, he gets none. Finally, the lack of water has a huge and detrimental effect on the cyclist. “That smoky blues tune ‘Summer time’ rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain.” This describes how the author is really dehydrated and he feels like his brain is drying up. However, his desperate need for water makes him more determined than ever to keep going until he reaches another town or his goal destination of reaching Yosemite National Park, pushing through all the hardships.

The features of the setting affect the man in many ways. One way is that when the man notices the terrain starting to change gradually, he becomes more and more distraught. He sees the sign that says “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit.” It is almost as if he thinks the sign is deliberately mocking him. Also, when the rider says “In an @CAPS1 twist that should please all sadists …” he is clearly telling the reader that this situation is very ironic and that he was expecting nothing good to come from this change in the terrain. The combination of the changing terrain and this ironic situation is really taking a toll on his mental state, making his journey even more difficult to endure.

In the story I read, the setting is a significant factor affecting the cyclist. For instance, it describes how the cyclist spots a sign that clearly states, “Rough road ahead! Do not exceed posted speed limit.” This warning forces the cyclist to be extremely cautious while riding. As a result, the cyclist has to adjust their pace and riding style to navigate the rough road safely. Thus, the setting plays a crucial role in influencing the cyclist's actions.

The cyclist was in a truly horrible and nasty environment for cycling. The terrain was rough, and the heat was intense. However, the thing that really threw the cyclist off was running out of water. There were no houses nearby to refill his bottle, and there was no one around to give him updated directions. The sweltering heat made him drink more water rapidly and also made it harder for him to breathe in the extreme conditions. Without these unfortunate faults, the cyclist would have been able to continue his journey smoothly.

I think that the features of the setting affected the cyclist in numerous ways. For example, he talks about various challenges he had to endure while he was riding. He was severely parched as he had no water. There was a huge snake that took up half of the road, leaving him with limited space to pass. Moreover, there wasn't a building in sight. The desolate setting filled him with doubt, but he maintained the confidence of reaching his destination. When he finally got there, it was a clear sign of relief. That's how the setting affected him.

The setting in the story affected the cyclist physically and mentally. Physically, it took a toll on him due to the rough terrain and the intense heat as he was in a desert and in the mountains. Also, because he didn't follow his plan on the map, he had no clue where he was. The anxiety of being lost and facing such harsh conditions undoubtedly took a toll on his physical well - being. Mentally, every town he passed through or every building he passed was deserted. Not knowing where any people were stressed him out greatly. This mental stress messed him up, and he even thought he was going to die, which is extremely detrimental to anyone. I really think he should just do what he believes is right and not listen to crazy old men anymore. Maps are reliable as they don't go crazy, don't really get outdated quickly, and don't lie to you. So, he has obviously learned his lesson from this experience.

Some of the features, like the change in landscape, significantly affected the cyclist. Transitioning from flat land to miniature hills and then to highways is quite difficult to cope with. This is especially true considering he was dehydrated and had no water. The varying landscapes required different levels of effort and riding techniques. The lack of water further exacerbated his struggle, making it even more challenging for him to adapt to these changes. Overall, the combination of the changing landscape and his dehydration had a substantial impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” affected the speaker by presenting a series of challenges. In the arid environment, dehydration became a real threat as the sun beat down relentlessly. The presence of dangerous animals, like venomous snakes, added an element of peril, and the rough terrain made every step a struggle. All these were designed to teach him a valuable lesson about following the travelling advice from old men. In the essay, he started out confidently on his journey after following “their advice,” reasoning that the men seemed to have “no sense of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off town.” As he progressed, the setting changed from a relatively cool and pleasant area to a dry and barren expanse, with the mention of tumbleweeds indicating the harshness of the new environment. It even turned dangerous when a diamondback snake blocked his path. In the end, the setting changed back to a more comfortable state, allowing him to learn his lesson through the hardship of the setting's features and follow his own map from then on.

The features of the environmental setting are significantly affecting the cyclist. A setting encompasses a specific time and place where an event occurs, and along with the setting, there are features which serve as background descriptions, essentially providing additional information about the subject or idea. The features, combined with the setting, are interfering with the cyclist in multiple ways. The hot temperature in Lodi, California, is making the cyclist, or biker, feel hotter than usual as he heads in the wrong direction, ever closer to the hot, blazing, scorching desert. In addition to this, he is running out of water rapidly and is beginning to get increasingly exhausted from the intense heat. He is starting to lose consciousness and is becoming dehydrated. This is a major problem for the character because he is losing his sense of direction, and as a result, he is getting more panicked as his supply of water is running extremely low. An instance of the environmental setting affecting the cyclist is “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my skirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June” (Joe Kurmaskie, @NUM1). Another example is “This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June” (Joe Kurmaskie, @NUM2). The hotness and heat had also increased the character's panic while decreasing his confidence in himself. An instance of this is “I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it this far, I'd be fine” (Joe Kurmaskie, @NUM1). In conclusion, the hot setting in California had affected the cyclist in a number of ways. It had exhausted his water supply, causing him to become exhausted, dehydrated, and lose his logical sense to make decisions. However, his desperate situation also propelled him to strive towards the roads and a nearby town that was about twenty miles away in order to get water so that he could survive.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie in many notable ways. One significant way the setting affected the cyclist was when the temperature soared and the rider started running out of water. The sweltering heat in the area made the cyclist's situation increasingly dire. Another way the cyclist was affected by the setting was when he mentioned that “he could die of heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because he listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades,” a statement that caused him to reflect on his choices. A third way the cyclist was affected was when he went inside the bait shop and was able to cool down, providing a brief respite from the harsh conditions. Lastly, when he rehydrated himself, it was a crucial moment that alleviated some of the immediate threats. Clearly, the setting was a main factor influencing the cyclist in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie on his way to Yosemite National Park.

The cyclist made the choice to ride through the worst terrain one can encounter on a bike. He bravely rode through deserts and deserted towns. At the beginning of his journey, he wasn't tired or thirsty because in the morning, he was riding past cool trees and alongside rushing water, which provided a refreshing and pleasant environment. However, once he reached the desert part of his route, where there was no water source in sight, he started to feel thirsty and began to drink his water. Unfortunately, his water supply depleted fast due to the high temperatures and the physical exertion. The lack of a water source in the dry desert can make anyone thirsty on its own, but after riding for a while, the situation became even worse. The setting had everything to do with the cyclist's predicament of having no water and fearing that he was going to die from heatstroke. That's precisely how the setting affected the cyclist, highlighting the importance of a suitable environment for a long - distance bike ride.

The setting had a profound impact on the cyclist's mood in the story. The cyclist was riding through rough terrain and over rolling hills, which made the journey seem extremely difficult. This made the cyclist feel like his journey was hopeless, as each pedal stroke was a struggle. When the cyclist arrived at the abandoned @CAPS1 Grape Factory, he experienced a twist of fate. He was extremely thirsty, and since there used to be a @ORGANIZATION1 building there, he had hoped to find some water when he reached the fork in the road. However, when this attempt failed, the cyclist became even less determined. He felt as if the world was against him, with the unforgiving setting constantly challenging his resolve and making his journey an uphill battle in every sense.

The settings affected the cyclist significantly, because wherever he went, it seemed as if the journey would never end. Like when he was riding along the path the old men told him to take. He went through a ghost - town, just as they had said he would pass through a town. The desolate streets and empty buildings added to the sense of endlessness. Then he kept on going, but the road seemed to stretch on forever, and the intense summer heat started to take its toll on him. As he began to dehydrate, he spotted an old juice factory. In his delirium, he started imagining that he was drinking cool, refreshing juice. So, he started seeing things, and his mind wandered in the heat - induced haze. Eventually, his senses returned, and he pressed on, hoping to reach his destination.

As the author cycles through this shortcut, he finds himself in a perilously dangerous setting. As stated in the poem, he is in the high deserts of California in June. A desert environment makes the heat almost unbearable for the cyclist. It's just the blazing sun, the endless expanse of sand, and him all alone. The mention of the month being summer, of course, means that the temperatures for the cyclist soar to around @NUM1 degrees, and it could even be hotter. This extreme heat could cause him to drink plenty of water at a rapid pace, and he almost loses all of his water supply. As the text says, “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Then there is the long distance of his ride. The author is constantly saying “About @NUM2 miles” or “Twenty miles up the road.” All of this strenuous work in the searing heat can cause heatstroke and potentially kill him if he doesn't find help soon.

The features of the setting, like the desert, the sun, and abandoned towns, affect the cyclist a great deal. The dry desert makes him feel as if he were pedaling on an endless loop. He probably often wonders if he is ever going to make it to a town. The relentless sun beats down on him, making him even hotter than he already is. It makes him sweat profusely and leaves him even more parched. The abandoned towns, with their empty streets and dilapidated buildings, make him lose hope in finding water or even reaching Yosemite. The mood of this story shifts from content to sad to happy. He is content after riding to the first town, enjoying the brief respite. But then, as the rest of the towns he encounters are also abandoned and he starts to run out of water, he thinks he is going to die, which makes the mood sad. Then, his spirits lift and he becomes happy when he finds the bait shop and discovers a much - needed supply of water.

In “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist negatively. The story takes place in June in California. This is a particularly hot time of the year in such a desert location. The sweltering heat adds to the speed at which the cyclist becomes dehydrated. It also impairs his ability to think as coherently as he could had he not been in a desert in June. The cyclist is also travelling through desolate, uninhabited land. The author says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This description emphasizes the character's total lack of resources. There is nowhere within his line of sight that he can turn to for help, water, food, or shelter. The road was also rough, being plagued with many rolling, crippling hills. Such challenging terrain is much harder to maneuver, especially when the cyclist is in such a desperate state of despair. Overall, the setting of the story, “Rough Road Ahead,” greatly impacts the cyclist's journey and well - being.

There are a lot of things that affect the cyclist, such as the blistering heat, the lack of water, the rough roads, and the long trip. The cyclist is out in a desert, so it is extremely hot. The narration says, “and the growing realization that I could die drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This clearly means that he or she was very hot and severely dehydrated. The roads were very rough; for example, a sign read “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The roads became bumpy, and there were numerous hills the cyclist had to laboriously go over. There was no water available either. So, he/she was rapidly running out of energy, and it made the journey even more difficult. In the end, after enduring all these hardships, the cyclist survived and drank a large amount of water to replenish their depleted body.

The features of the desolate setting affect the cyclist in a very harmful way. The sweltering hot temperature and the boiling sun beating down made the author feel extremely hot and rapidly took his energy away. The vast emptiness of the setting can easily make a person lose hope of finding any sign of civilization. The narrator said, “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you...” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). That is not the last of the harmful aspects of the setting; the dry desert air has the biggest impact on his life. The parched air makes him more desperately thirsty for water he doesn't have, causing him to dehydrate at a faster rate. The narrator said, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The lonely and dreadful features of the setting the cyclist was in made the situation so much worse as he had no water, which put his life at great risk.

In ‘Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,’ a cyclist follows some ill - advised guidance, which leads him on a grueling ride through the arid desert with a meager supply of water. The setting has a large effect on the cyclist because it causes him to become severely dehydrated, which presents the main conflict of the story. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips,” the author states when his fresh water supply begins to dwindle. Another factor the setting presents to the cyclist is the searing heat of the California desert. This intense heat exacerbates the cyclist's thirst and speeds up his dehydration. The reader can tell it is unpleasantly hot when reading, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt… that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” The rough, uneven roads and the challenging, hilly terrain also present a significant challenge to the cyclist, slowing his advance to Yosemite and making his journey even more arduous.

The cyclist is significantly affected by the features of the desolate setting. The cyclist has been steadily pedaling his bike in the direction that the old men told him to go in order to reach Yosemite. As he continues, soon he runs out of water and becomes extremely tired. He starts to believe that he will die soon as the harsh conditions take a toll on him. But then, to his great relief, he stumbles upon a fish camp. He rushes into the bathroom to revive himself with some water and a moment of rest. When he comes out, a man is sitting on the porch. The author gets clear directions from him and is overjoyed to know that he is on the right track again, giving him new hope for his journey.

There are many effects of the setting in this essay that can be either good or bad. The setting is a solitary, empty mountain road, with no houses in sight, no passing cars, and no other people around. Now, I'm going to detail some good and bad effects. One good effect is that you are by yourself, so while you exercise, you can fully relax and enjoy the natural energy of the surroundings. One bad thing is that what if you pop a tire or encounter some other problem and need help. You'll be stuck because there's no one around to assist you. Another good thing is that being by yourself, you won't encounter any cars. You don't have to worry about getting hit, so you'll be able to just unwind and enjoy the ride. Another bad thing is that there is no readily available water source, so you might want to bring plenty of it with you. So, whatever you decide to do, just be careful and thoroughly think your idea through before embarking on this journey.

The setting or environment the cyclist was in made him feel completely isolated from the rest of the world. He was well - aware that there was no turning back once he started his adventurous journey. There was no one there to offer him any assistance. The desolate environment made him acutely realize the many risks involved in this adventure. The knowledge that there was no immediate help available served as his driving force to continue on his long and challenging journey, as he knew he had to rely on his own strength and determination to reach his destination.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist as he has to cross different types of landmarks. First, he sought information from the old people. When he showed the map to the old folks, they were only familiar with the old short - cuts and not the new ones, which made his navigation more difficult. Second, when he ran out of water, the situation worsened. As the cyclist ran out of water, he still had to climb the steep hills, and this physical exertion tired him out. Moreover, when he tried to get water from a certain source, only hot water came out, which was of no use to him. Last, when he finally reached a store, the old guy had his own map. When he asked the old guy about the place he was going to, the old man simply said “I have my own map”. From this, he knew he was in trouble. In conclusion, these are the ways in which the features of the setting affected the cyclist.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. The setting was extremely hot, and there were numerous hills. The cyclist had been laboriously riding up and down these hills all day, and it consumed a great deal of his energy. When he saw the building that he thought could offer him help, he said, “... last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill.” By making this statement, it clearly showed that the hilly terrain of the area where he was located took up all his energy. That is how the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist.

In the short story Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit, by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting have a notable effect on the cyclist. When at the old codgers' house, he is full of confidence as they tell him about a shortcut to Yosemite. This gives him the self - assurance he needs. As he leaves, he still retains that confidence. However, as the setting changes, so does the mood of the cyclist. After “about @NUM1 miles into the pedal”, the cyclist arrives at the first town. He is filled with despair because it is a ghost town. Despite still having a bit of confidence, the lack of water forces him to continue on. After a couple more miles, he comes to a small fork with a pump. Thinking it would provide cool water, he goes to pump it. To his dismay, he finds out it is @NUM2∞@CAPS1 and tastes like “battery acid”. Now, he is desperate, with no water, dehydrated, and no towns in sight. He begins to pedal and pedal, hoping to find a town around. When he does find a town with water, the setting becomes relieving and better for him as he finally finds water. In the end, the setting causes the cyclist to swing from confident, to desperate as his water supply runs out, and then to relieved when water is found.

This would be a hard risk to begin with, but the cyclist is taking it in the desert. As we all are well - aware, the desert can reach boiling temperatures, so what could have been an enjoyable bike ride quickly turns into a strenuous ordeal. Also, when the only things you see for miles are the long, desolate road, the endless sand, and an empty factory, your morale can easily drain away. It's just an overall desolate setting that makes one feel lost and hopeless. In such a setting, the cyclist's journey becomes fraught with challenges and a constant battle against the harsh environment.

The features of the setting make the cyclist feel utterly hopeless after realizing he is not on a short - cut. As the cyclist rides along under the scorching sun, he has the “growing realization that [he] could drop from heatstroke”. Also, the only building he sees for miles “had been @NUM1 Welch's Grape Juice Factory”. When he spots this building, he is driven deeper into despair and feels that all hope is lost. As he continues to ride, the song “'@ORGANIZATION2' rattled around in the dry honeycombs of (his) deteriorating brain.” At this point, the cyclist firmly believes his own death to be inevitable. When talking about the pebbles he placed in his mouth, he says “with any luck Iíd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat”. Finally, the cyclist reaches a small bait shop, and all hope is restored as he “drank deeply from the sink.” The desert setting, with its lack of water, shelter, and people, was the root cause of this man's concern and later panic about his own life. The hopelessness of this cyclist is much like the hopelessness of those in the @ORGANIZATION1, who, trapped in a blizzard far from civilization, resorted to eating their dead just to survive. While the @PERSON1 @ORGANIZATION1 went to extreme lengths for their survival, their setting caused them to experience the same overwhelming hopelessness as the cyclist.

The effect of cycling is very challenging and trending because a lot of things can go wrong. For instance, you can feel extremely hot, and even drinking water wouldn't cool you down; it simply didn't matter. When you took a drop of water into your mouth, it had the unpleasant flavor of battery acid. On a gorgeous day in June, he or anyone could just drop from a heatstroke. It was so hot that you started seeing things. Even the thought of a townsperson pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still leave you parched and suffering in the sweltering heat.

The features of the setting dramatically affected the cyclist. He set out on his journey in a highly confident mood, full of enthusiasm for the adventure ahead. However, his spirits started to dampen when he arrived at a town that was completely deserted. There were no signs of life, just empty streets and abandoned buildings. His confidence was still relatively high at this point, but it was not as unwavering as it was prior to coming upon the ghost town. Twenty miles up the road after that, he came to a fork in the road. There, he found a ramshackle shed with rusty, unclean pumps, and a small corral that looked like it hadn't been used in ages. The desert was swelteringly hot, and his lack of water was quickly dehydrating him. Paragraph @NUM1 states, “This sight was troubling… I had been hitting my water bottles regularly, and was traveling through the high deserts in California.” With little water left and a short energy supply, he was getting tired and dehydrated at an alarming rate. The land then started turning into rolling hills, which required more effort to pedal through, causing him to become even more exhausted. His mood had completely shifted from confident to hopeless. He even contemplated changing a diary entry in case he died of heatstroke. Clearly, the features of the setting greatly affected the mood of the cyclist. Sometimes disappointment can come from taking the so - called “easy way out,” as this cyclist might have thought this route would be simple, but the harsh setting proved otherwise.

In the story, the setting affected the cyclist all through the story until he arrived at Body and Wilbers Fish Camp. As the man rides his bike for a while, he starts out in high spirits. But as he pedals into the first town, it seems to be a ghost town. There are no people around, and the buildings look abandoned. As he continues to pedal on, “The sun was beginning to beat down but I barely noticed it.” At that time, the weather is affecting him a great deal. The scorching sun is making the air thick and hot, but he keeps the thought of Yosemite's cool pines and rushing rivers in his head, using it as motivation to keep going. He also only has a few tantalizing sips left in his water bottle while going up a big hill. The steep incline of the hill makes his legs burn, and the lack of water makes his throat dry and parched. Despite these hardships, he presses on, driven by the hope of reaching his destination.

The setting of this essay serves the purpose of guiding cyclists on where to go without getting them lost. It provides clear directions and descriptions of the routes to ensure that cyclists can navigate safely. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of not blindly taking advice from old people. Sometimes, the advice they give might be based on outdated information or personal experiences that don't necessarily apply to the current situation. By following the guidance in this essay, cyclists can have a more enjoyable and stress - free journey. In conclusion, this essay plays a crucial role in helping cyclists plan their trips and avoid potential pitfalls.

The features in the setting greatly affect the cyclist. The setting was extremely hot, with the sun beating down relentlessly, and the terrain was rough, filled with uneven ground and rocky patches. The cyclist was not only tired from the strenuous pedaling but also desperately thirsty. The cyclist said, “Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view.” This indicates that he needed water so much that the sight of a building gave him a glimmer of hope. The hill was so big and demanding that it sapped his energy, and his thirst only added to his misery. Also, he says, “Summertime ‘rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain’.” It is summer time where he is riding, and to keep his mind off of his intense thirst, he hums the song “Summertime.” He wants to show that despite the overwhelming heat, he has the mental strength to not let it overtake his body. Moreover, he says, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake.” He is highlighting that the terrain is not only physically challenging but also potentially deadly because of the snake that slithered by him. Despite all these obstacles and objections, he is determined to show that he could overcome anything. As you can see, the setting greatly affected the cyclist, testing his physical and mental limits throughout his journey.

Many things can affect a cyclist. But in the story, three main features of the sweltering setting affected the cyclist the most. While the cyclist was vigorously riding, the scorching sun was beating down, and it was extremely hot. We know this by carefully looking back at the text. It gives us this vivid quote, “That I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” Because it was so hot, the cyclist's body was quickly losing moisture, and this could make the cyclist desperately thirsty. Another prominent feature of the setting was the multitude of steep hills. These hills, with their varying gradients, would create intense exhaustion for the cyclist. We know there were many hills because in the text it clearly says, “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” Going over all those arduous hills can really tire someone out. A third significant feature of the setting would be nature. Nature can affect us in many ways, by weather, by terrain, and as in this case, by animals. In the story, the cyclist unexpectedly comes upon a large, menacing snake lying across the path. This encounter makes the situation extremely dangerous. The setting can affect anything. It would have been a totally different story if the cyclist had been in the summer during @DATE1, not June. The setting's influence on the cyclist's journey is a crucial element that shapes the entire experience.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed @CAPS1,” the setting is artfully used to subtly alter the cyclist's mood and as a clear reflection of his challenging situation. For example, the evocative statement “the cool pines and rushing river of Yosemite had my name written all over them” helps precisely describe the cyclist's desperate situation. The vivid idea of lush, cool water vegetation gives the @CAPS4 a glimmer of much - needed hope during his increasingly hellish trip. The breathtaking beauty of that idyllic setting also reflects on the comforting relief that would come from finally reaching Yosemite; the good setting equals a promising outcome. Later on, the cyclist comes across “one ramshackle shed, several rusted pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest male.” This is a dismal, depressing setting symbolizing a complete loss of hope. And indeed at this point, the cyclist becomes deeply troubled by his dire situation. While laboriously pedaling through the vast desert, the cyclist becomes even more frustrated when tumbleweeds, which are always a classic symbol of a deserted area, come blowing by. The use of setting to affect and mirror mood is nothing new. There are many well - known examples of this literary technique throughout history. For example, in his story “The @CAPS2 of @CAPS3 @PERSON1.” @CAPS4 @PERSON1 was a desolate land filled with wild beasts to symbolize and cause @PERSON2 to change his personality, surrounded by uncivilized people and creating a situation where @PERSON2 tears his clothes and hunts like a dog. The setting of a desert in the uncultured part of colonial times simultaneously causes and reflects on this change. The setting in the essay “Do Not Exceed posted Speed Limit” is used as an important tool for character development, effectively showing how the environment can shape a character's emotions and experiences.

The features of the essay clearly explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist for many compelling reasons. When the author writes “tumbleweeds crossed my path,” it vividly shows that he is most likely in the middle of a desolate nowhere. This is true because tumbleweeds are commonly known as signs in movies and TV shows that the place is deserted. Also, when the author writes “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke” and when he writes “a ridiculously large snake,” it shows the increasing danger that he is getting himself into. This is true because the snakes could strike at any time, or he could just collapse from the severe lack of water and die. Lastly, the name of the store is relevant because it is a fish bait store, and he is extremely thirsty. This is relevant because fish live in water, and seeing the sign briefly relieves him completely. Therefore, the features of this essay explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, highlighting the strong connection between the environment and the cyclist's well - being.

He believes the shortcut will be a pleasant and stress - free way to relax rather than taking the original longer and more mundane way to Yosemite. But the trip he makes completely changes his mind.
