I would conserve my water…” He did indeed conserve his water, but when he reached the town, he found that it was very old and dilapidated, and it didn't have any water for him to drink. So throughout the essay, the narrator went without water for a long time until he finally got to a factory, where he managed to get some water to drink and also got new directions. The trip was very different from what he had expected. It was far more depressing, filled with disappointment and hardship. In conclusion, the unforeseen challenges presented by the setting turned what was supposed to be a relaxing shortcut into a distressing journey.

A response that explains how the feature of the setting affected the cyclist would be that in the setting, the various elements of the setting affected the cyclist because, for one, the features of the setting were based on a particular environment that was distinct from what the cyclist might have anticipated. So that would be a reason how it would be affected. Because there are significant differences in the stories' settings, such as the terrain, climate, and availability of resources. These differences can have a direct impact on the cyclist's physical and mental state. For example, a harsh and arid setting might lead to dehydration and fatigue, while a setting with difficult terrain could slow down the cyclist's progress. In conclusion, the unique features of the setting play a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's experience and can have both positive and negative effects on their journey.

You can always choose your features because your initial idea might change over time. As you gain more experience or encounter new circumstances, your perspective on what features are important can shift. For instance, you might start with a certain set of features in mind for a project or a plan, but as you go along, you realize that other features are more relevant or beneficial. This change in mindset can be due to various factors, such as new information, feedback from others, or personal growth. In conclusion, being open to changing your choice of features based on evolving circumstances is a wise approach that can lead to better outcomes.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist mentally, physically, positively and negatively. For instance, “There had been @CAPS1's Grape Juice Factory and bottling plant. A sand - blasted picture of a young boy by pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen.” This affected the author mentally, vividly making him remember that he had no water. Which in turn affected him physically by gradually becoming dehydrated as moments passed. So overall, that setting feature had a strongly negative directional affect on the cyclist. Another example, “One ramshackled shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling.” This affected the cyclist mentally by making him feel hopeless and think he was never going to see civilization again. It also affected him physically because the water he found there tasted like “battery acid,” which put him deeper into his dehydration state as his body rejected the unpalatable and harmful water. This setting feature had a clearly negative affect on the cyclist. The setting features and how they affected the cyclist is like an environment a person is placed in and how it makes them who they are, influencing their thoughts, emotions, and physical well - being. In conclusion, the various features of the setting in this cyclist's journey had predominantly negative impacts on him, both mentally and physically, highlighting the powerful influence of the environment on an individual's experience.

He is going on an adventurous journey on his sturdy bike. Along the way, he has to deftly go down steep hills and also deal with the troublesome fact that he has no water. That’s basically what the challenging setting of his journey is about.

When riding a bike, the various features around you can significantly affect the cyclist. Some prominent things that can have an impact on the cyclist are the weather and the scenery. If the weather is cold and rainy, with raindrops pelting down and the cold seeping into the bones, the cyclist would not want to be riding. The dangers of riding when the weather conditions are bad, such as slippery roads and poor visibility, will make the cyclist second - guess whether to keep riding or not. If the weather is extremely hot, the scorching sun beats down, causing the cyclist to get dehydrated quicker and even more exhausted. The scenery can also affect the cyclist. When a cyclist is riding and all he/she sees is a vast, desolate desert stretching as far as the eye can see, then they might have doubts on where they're going. If there are abandoned buildings everywhere, with broken windows and overgrown weeds, the cyclist may become frightened and want to head back or lose hope, as shown in the story “Do not exceed the speed limit” when he gets over a hill and begins to think that he will never make it to Yosemite. Many things can affect the cyclist and make the journey a complex experience.

The features of the setting vividly exhuberate the cyclist. The June weather, being the beginning of summer with its sweltering heat, added to the water depletion. When the cyclist “arrived at the first ‘town’”, it was completely deserted. The water there had a disgusting odor and a murky appearance. The author uses verbal irony when calling it a “town” as it was not really a town anymore, just a collection of dilapidated buildings. The large snake slithering across the path presented an air of danger, and another abandoned Grape Juice Factory, with its rusted machinery and broken walls, added to the hopeless, lost tone of the setting. All these elements combined to create a challenging and disheartening environment for the cyclist.

Many things in the setting affect the cyclist. The first thing that affects him is the intense heat. The blistering heat is actually what causes the conflict in the story of the cyclist needing water. If the heat was not present in the story, with its sweltering rays and high temperatures, then the cyclist would not have such a desperate need for water and he would be able to continue on his ride without fear of dehydration. Another aspect of the setting that affects the cyclist are the rolling hills. These hills, with their uneven slopes and long ascents, also exhaust the cyclist and cause him to need more water. If these hills were gone, the cyclist would have tired less quickly, making his journey easier. The setting in this story greatly affects the cyclist, shaping his experiences and challenges along the way.

The features of the setting in, "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” affect the cyclist in many ways. After following the old men's advice, he sets off on his long - awaited journey. After the first town appears on the horizon, the sun really starts to beat down with full force, which really affects the cyclist. In the essay it says “The sun was beginning to heat beat down, but I barely noticed it.” He may have not noticed it yet, but then later on the long, winding road on the new flat terrain, he runs out of water, and that is really dangerous in weather that hot. The text says, “The speed limit was @NUM1. I was doing a water - depleting @NUM2.” In this part of the story, it clearly proves that the cyclist is out of water. In this kind of setting, you can run into dangerous creatures. In the story it says, “I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake. It really did look like a diamondback - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” This entry proves to the reader that there are snakes in this sort of setting. The features of the setting in “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist greatly, making his journey a perilous one.

The terrain setting affects the cyclist in many ways. The fact that he was cycling in a vast desert under the blazing sun made him extremely thirsty. There were no towns and not even a single sign of water to quench his parched throat. The hills he had to cycle up just made him more tired as he struggled to pedal. These are what the harsh setting did to the cyclist, testing his endurance to the limit.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed” by @PERSON1, the cyclist faces problems caused by the setting. The biker was riding on a sweltering day, and the heat was absolutely scorching. As a result, the biker was really getting dehydrated and tired, and he was rapidly running out of water. Because it was so hot, the biker had to drink more water to replenish his body of all the sweat he was losing while biking. The hills of the rough terrain were making it harder on the biker by making him use more energy and liquid to keep going. If it had been cool and breezy, he would have had no problem making that distance. If the surrounding area was full of people and not abandoned towns, then he would have had water to drink, and his journey would have been much easier.

Everybody experiences physical and emotional pain, but most probably wouldn't have survived what the cyclist in this story went through. The man started a bike ride in Yosemite National Park, but when some elderly men told him a shortcut, his arduous adventure had just begun. First of all, every “town” and “building” the men told him he would come to wound up being completely deserted. At first, this wasn't a big deal to the cyclist. In the fourth paragraph, when he came to his first deserted town, he “chuckled, checked his water supply, and moved on.” However, as his journey progressed, his water decreased. He was then in desperation for a town with water. On top of that, in the story he wrote, “the last road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This made his biking harder, and he was then becoming dehydrated. He finally found a town with water, but he learned his lesson from taking advice from strangers and old men, realizing that shortcuts aren't always reliable.

The features of the setting would have affected the cyclist a lot. There is a man who takes the advice of old men and takes a “shortcut” to Yosemite Park. The shortcut only leads him to thirst and no sign of the park. The narration states, “A sand - blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen (Kurmaskie @NUM1).” This feature could affect the cyclist by discouraging him deeply. When the cyclist comes to the first “town,” he only finds yet again no water and a picture of something that makes him even more thirsty. It could also make him be more angry at the old men because they led him on this pointless journey. Another feature that would affect the cyclist is the lack of trees or shade. The only thing he could feel was the intense sun beating down on his back. The narration states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt. (Kurmaskie @NUM1).” This also makes the cyclist firmly believe that old men do not know what they are talking about, and he realizes he should have trusted his own judgment.

There are many features of the setting that affected the cyclist in “Do not exceed the posted speed limit.” The time of year affected the cyclist because it’s mid - June. Moreover, the region affected the cyclist because mid - June in Arizona is extremely hot and dry. If it was in a more northern state in spring or fall, it wouldn't be as bad, and you wouldn't have the danger of heat - related struggles. Additionally, when the terrain changed from flat to hilly, this affected him because it made it significantly harder for him to ride. These are some features of the settings that affected the cyclist in “Do not exceed the posted speed limit,” highlighting how the environment can greatly impact a journey.

In “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting significantly affected the cyclist. Since he was cycling in the sweltering desert of California in June, his water supply was quickly depleted. With the scorching sun beating down, he came across a desolate ghost town. His hope started dwindling as the harsh conditions took a toll on him. He then found a water pump, but to his dismay, it produced a tar - like substance. Due to the unforgiving desert and the lack of water, he even wished he was dead. Eventually, he decided never to blindly take advice from strangers and to always trust his map. This is how the features of the setting had a profound impact on the cyclist.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the features of the setting affected the cyclist in multiple ways. First of all, he was traveling in the arid desert, which meant it was extremely dry. With scarce water sources around, the cyclist could not refill his water and was gradually getting dehydrated. Also, he was biking under the intense heat of the sun. This made him continuously sweat, which not only depleted the water in his body but also started to play tricks on his mind. Finally, the steep hills he had to climb caused him to exert more energy, further exacerbating his dehydration. Moreover, the seemingly endless hills dampened his spirits, forcing him to muster a great deal of inner strength and determination to keep going. This aspect of the setting had a significant emotional impact on him. Overall, the setting had both a physical and emotional effect on the cyclist.

The cyclist is alone, traveling on a flat expanse of land at first, following the directions that the old men gave him to reach Yosemite National Park in California. During his journey, as he cycles over hills and through deserts with the scorching sun beating down on him in the hot June weather, he becomes severely dehydrated. He realizes that without water, he could suffer a heart - stroke. His travels are desolate and lonely, with nothing but vast stretches of barren land around him. When he finally spots some buildings in the distance, he initially gets excited, only to discover that they are ghost towns. However, this sight still gives him a bit of a boost, and he recovers some determination to speed up. Fortunately, the cyclist finds a camp site. This saves him from passing out in the desert. He can rest there, replenish his water supply, and then carry on his journey, relying on his own map from then on.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed Limit”, the cyclist is trying to reach Yosemite using the directions that some codgers, or eccentric old men, gave him. The cyclist noted that the old men looked as though they “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” He decides to take their advice, but about a third (assuming @NUM1 is one - third) along his journey, he gets lost. While eagerly looking forward to the “Cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,” he finds himself traveling through a desolate and barren desert. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This kind of desolate setting can really bring down a cyclist's mood, especially when he is constantly thinking about the beautiful Yosemite. It could make him lose all hope of ever finding Yosemite at this rate. A nice setting can make a trip more enjoyable and the destination even more appealing.

The setting affected the performance and the mood of the cyclist. The rolling, steep hills that the cyclist had to climb most likely made him more tired and thirsty because he had to exert a great deal of effort to get over them. “Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view.” These long and large hills not only made him thirstier but also gave him a sense of satisfaction once he conquered them. Ironically, the building turned out to be an abandoned and rusty grape juice factory. Although the sign featuring a boy drinking a refreshing glass of juice was still visible, it brought his hopes down. But he didn't give up and continued to move on. In my life, I've never had an experience where I had to keep pushing myself towards a goal while facing more distractions the closer I got. However, I can understand the cyclist's struggle in such a difficult situation.

ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî is a short story about a man who is bicycling through the beautiful yet challenging Yosemite. As he pedals along, he encounters some elderly men and politely asks them for directions. They, in good faith, lead him on this so - called ìoldî shortcut. Little does he know, this shortcut takes him through extremely tough terrain with steep slopes and rough paths, and also through an area experiencing extreme famine. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways throughout the story. For example, when the bicyclist came to a deserted area, he said ìthere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kindî. By this time, he was severely malnourished and desperately in need of water. This extreme thirst also led to him passing an abandoned Welchís grape juice factory with an advertisement showing a young boy pouring a fresh glass of juice into his mouth. He says ìIn an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building,î, then he goes into detail about the dilapidated building. The mood and feeling by this time was one of being tired and worn out, and the advertisement didnít help the situation at all. The author's mood did change with the setting, and before it got better, it was worse. Eventually, the cyclist found a way to overcome the difficult situation, and the story shows how the harsh setting can test one's will.

The young cyclist began his day full of confidence, eagerly looking forward to his day of riding across California. Slowly, however, as he realizes he has been directed wrongly, his mood changes, and he begins to feel more hopeless. As he starts his journey, he feels carefree and ready for anything. He writes "I carefully checked my water supply & then moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it at first. The beautiful surroundings seemed to have little effect on his initial enthusiasm. Later on, he realizes his water is quickly going down, and he is getting increasingly tired. His mood changes to one of exhaustion and defeat. Here he writes ìI got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuffed them in my mouth. With any luck, Iíd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat.î He has become sarcastic and saddened by the hopelessness of his journey. Eventually, he finds relief when he gets a drink of cold water, which helps to bring up his spirits and sense of humor, allowing him to continue his journey with a new - found determination.

In the essay, the features of the setting significantly affected the cyclist. In the beginning, the setting was at the old manís cozy place. The cyclist was happy and confident, chatting with the old man and starting his journey with high spirits. When he reached the desolate ghost town and was out of water, he was extremely upset and frustrated. The empty streets and abandoned buildings added to his sense of despair. When he saw a building in the distance, he was relieved, thinking he might find help. But when he found out it was an abandoned building, he was deeply sad. When he finally reached the small store, he was excited and relieved. The store was a haven in the harsh journey, with its stocked shelves and friendly shopkeeper. That is how the setting affected the cyclist during his trip, showing how different settings can bring on a wide range of emotions.

Weather, places, the will to continue ñ all are reasons that explain how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, the weather will affect the cyclist because in the hot, sunny weather, you lose a lot of water through sweating, and this makes it hard to pedal the bike. The intense heat of the sun beating down on him will greatly affect his will to ride. I mean, come on, who wants to ride when it's burning hot outside? The places the cyclist went through, like small, desolate towns and rough, bumpy roads, would also affect him because itís pretty tough to navigate through such areas. The rough roads made his ride uncomfortable, and the lack of facilities in the towns meant he had to face many difficulties. Overall, the combination of weather and the places he passed through tested his endurance and will to continue the journey.

The story ìRough road ahead: do not exceed posted, speed limit ì tells of a biking trip gone wrong. But the story would  not be as terrifying if it had happened in a different place. The setting plays a large role in the story. The story begins on a pleasant present - day summer evening. As the man bikes along, he arrives at a ghost town completely devoid of any living beings. A feeling of unease sets in when he arrives at ìone ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold the lames mule. î Later, we see panic set in as the terrain becomes hilly, with tumbleweeds rolling across the path and snakes slithering around. It's like a scene from a cold western movie. Finally, all hope is lost when he reaches the grape juice factory and finds ìa sand - blasted picture of a young boy. î The desolate and menacing setting is a powerful tool which greatly influences the cyclist's state of mind, making him feel scared and helpless. The story effectively shows how the right setting can enhance the sense of danger and drama in a narrative.

In the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affected the cyclist's physical abilities. The features affected his abilities because the climate and the dangerous environment were extremely hot and very rough to handle. Since he was cycling in the California deserts in June, the conditions were harsh. The passage that supports this is, “Tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake - it really did look like a diamondback - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Also, the features of the setting give him determination. They give him determination because each new horizon he sees gives him a glimmer of hope. They give him hope since he knows he is that much closer to Yosemite National Park. The passage that supports this is when he thinks, “Looking at the distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could move it that far, I’d be fine.” In the story, “Rough road ahead, Do not exceed posted speed limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of his settings affect both the cyclist's physical and mental abilities.

The features of the setting have a huge effect on the cyclist. There was a point in the story where he ran out of water, and he remembered that the old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. He was extremely tired and severely dehydrated, but he thought he could make it along the long, desolate road. So he started off, and two miles later, the terrain changed, and so did his outlook on this entire arduous journey. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” He thought, “Sometimes life can be so cruel.” These hills took a great deal out of him, and he was now on a busy highway. Before this terrain change, the rider was very positive and thought he could complete this journey easily. He said, “I could make that!” But after the terrain change, he lost all hope and almost didn't make it. He despaired, “It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” It is obvious as you read that when the terrain becomes tough, it has a huge negative effect on the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways. Initially, the roads were nice and smooth, but then they gradually turned into hilly stretches. It was a swelteringly hot day in June, and he had only a sparse water supply with him as he was peddling through the vast deserts of California. The last thing that affected him was that there weren't very many suitable places to stop and refill his water. All these aspects combined made his cycling journey a challenging one.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist is on his way trying to find his way to Yosemite National Park, but runs into a little trouble when getting directions from a couple of older men. The one important lesson the cyclist learned was to never listen to short - cuts given to you by old men who are extremely out of date and haven't left their porch since Carter was in office. The cyclist learned this the hard way when he ends up lost and almost died of thirst. The setting takes place in the desolate desert of California or in deserted ghost towns. On his journey, the cyclist says, “...I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” This feature affects the cyclist because the extremely dry and scorching heat beating down on him continuously makes him severely dehydrated. Also, along his journey, the cyclist encounters numerous hills. The feature of the setting affects the cyclist by tiring him out completely and making him believe there isn't any hope of him getting out alive. Features of the setting like hills and deserts dehydrate and exhaust the cyclist, making his journey a life - threatening one.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. It seems to be that the more desperate the situation becomes, the more determined he becomes. On page [NUM1], he thinks, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Right after he has this despairing thought, he climbs away from the abandoned factory of Juices and dreams. He says on page [NUM1], “All troubles, thirst, and fatigue were all behind me.” This shows that after a difficult situation, the cyclist feels relieved of all earthly obligations. Not only does the settings affect the cyclist but also the entire story around him, as it sets the tone and the challenges that drive the narrative forward.

The setting of the story encompasses areas that are extremely dry, with arid stretches where the ground is parched, as well as some humid pockets that seem out of place. The landscape is a mix of flat expanses where the horizon seems to go on forever and hilly regions with gentle slopes. The author clearly noticed the terrain changing, as described: “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Joe Kurmaskie). Being out in the middle of a desert - like surrounding during June, with nothing but vast emptiness around him, is a truly scary thought. The intense heat and lack of water take a toll on him. He might experience mirages, those deceptive images that play tricks on the mind, or he could faint due to the searing heat and the significant amount of fluid he has lost. The hills, with their added effort required to traverse, don't help his situation either. In such harsh conditions, his endurance is truly being tested.

The features of the setting have a profound impact on the cyclist as he pedals through the unforgiving desert in the middle of June while carrying very little water. This situation affects him severely because he is constantly thirsty, yet he has only a meager supply of water to quench his thirst. Being in a desert in June means the sun beats down relentlessly, making it extremely hot. Also, in the story, it mentions that he comes across Welch’s Grape Juice Factory. On the side of the building, he sees a picture of a “young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth”. This vivid image makes the cyclist even thirstier as he imagines the cool liquid. Despite this intense longing, he continues on his journey, determined to find water at a bait shop. His perseverance in the face of such discomfort shows his strong will.

The cyclist in this essay has his sights set on Yosemite National Park. He initially feels confident in his ability to reach his destination, not fully realizing what challenges lie ahead. First, he encounters the windy roads that sway his bike from side to side. As he progresses along his route, his confidence gradually starts to wither away. The desert hits him like a boulder, as he is running short on water and desperately needs to rest. The extreme heat, with the sun shining brightly overhead, just exacerbates his situation. “Not a mile into this heat - section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This clearly shows that the cyclist did not anticipate meeting this kind of terrain and is completely overwhelmed by it. However, the one thing he never does is give up. This is crucial because as he keeps going, just when he is on the verge of giving up, he finds a place to get water and to relax. “Then, as easily as running about, my troubles, thirst, and weariness were all behind me.” This indicates that he was strong - willed and determined to survive. He finally found what he needed, which filled him with happiness and a renewed will to live. Everyone in life needs to be determined to overcome the obstacles they face.

It gives him a hard time, but through these difficulties, he learns a great deal. He realizes that life is not always easy. It might not seem like a big problem at first, but sometimes, some small problems can snowball into bigger ones. Life is like riding a bike; there are ups and downs. Sometimes you face problems, and sometimes you get lost along the way. But that's just the nature of life. These experiences teach him to be more resilient and to face challenges head - on, understanding that every setback is an opportunity to grow.

The features of the setting very much affect the cyclist. He had to ride through extremely tough conditions and became utterly exhausted. I believe the toughest feature of the setting was the blistering heat. He told us, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The sweltering heat made him feel like he was in an oven. He was talking about how he needed to sip from his water more frequently than normally, as the heat was causing him to lose fluids rapidly. Another tough feature of the setting was the hills he had to ride up and down. As he was riding, he said, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” Riding over these hills in the hot June sun in a California desert was an incredibly tough task for the cyclist. The combination of the heat and the hilly terrain made each pedal stroke a struggle. I believe the terrain very much affected him, testing his physical and mental limits to the extreme.

The features of the setting in this story make the ride more difficult for the cyclist. For example, the cyclist is moving through the “high deserts of California” (kurmaskie @NUM1). This shows that the cyclist is at a high altitude, where the thinner air makes breathing more strenuous and requires more effort with each breath, which makes breathing more difficult. Then the cyclist notes that the “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). These undulating hills demand more physical exertion as the cyclist has to pedal harder uphill and control speed downhill. The hills would make the trip more difficult. This is evidenced by the cyclist describing one of them as a “long, crippling hill” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). Clearly, the terrain, which got increasingly difficult, negatively affected the cyclist, making the journey more arduous and challenging.

In the story, the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. For example, the condition of the road was bad. It changed from a smooth, flat road to short, rolling roads with uneven surfaces that jolted the cyclist's bike. Tumble weeds crossed his path unexpectedly, forcing him to swerve and maintain his balance. He had a severe lack of water, and the little water he did have tasted like battery acid, making it unpalatable and hard to drink. In the story it says, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This clearly shows how the adverse setting conditions made the cyclist's journey extremely difficult and precarious.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist like if you have to go up a steep hill or along long bumpy type roads that shake the bike and rattle the cyclist's body. Then in the essay it says “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit: @CAPS1” which indicates that the rough terrain does make things more difficult than average. The uneven surface requires more control and effort from the cyclist. Especially with a lack of water to make things worse, as the cyclist gets more fatigued and dehydrated, the challenges of the setting become even more overwhelming.

The setting greatly affects the cyclist trying to get to Yosemite National Park. First of all, the cyclist says he’s in Lodi, California on a “gorgeous day in June.” It’s very hot in California in June, with the sun beating down mercilessly. So the biker is affected by the weather because he could die of heatstroke as the high temperatures cause excessive sweating and dehydration. Also, he is in the middle of the desert, where he faces tumbleweeds crossing his path and a large snake that is possibly poisonous in the way. The presence of these obstacles and potential dangers puts him in more despair, because he could get hurt by a wild animal, or run out of water with no place to go get more! So the setting mostly negatively affects the cyclist, making his journey to Yosemite a perilous and difficult one.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist; the author says he is in the California desert. This means that the cyclist must conserve water so he can stay hydrated for the long and arduous trip. The dry and hot desert environment causes rapid evaporation of sweat, increasing the risk of dehydration. Also, there are many hills, as the author says, “over one crippling hill…” with a lot of hills to climb, the cyclist uses up more energy and will become dehydrated quickly, if he isn’t careful. The constant uphill pedaling requires intense physical effort and leads to increased sweating. Finally, there are many abandoned towns that are several miles apart from each other. This again affects how the cyclists uses his water. He might think that there is a prospering town coming up, so he drinks his water, thinking he’ll get more soon. However, when he gets there, there is no water, and he must pedal several more miles to the next town with very little water. The setting is a great effect on how the cyclists act especially with no water, making every decision about water consumption crucial for his survival and the success of his journey.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affect the cyclist. Depending on what sort of new terrain or landmark he came to, his determination increases and decreases. For instance, when he first caught sight of a building emerging in the distance ahead of him, a spark of excitement ignited within him. He leaned forward on his bike, gripping the handlebars tightly, and used all his energy to pedal furiously down the hill towards the building. Also, when he finally reached the next building and was pleasantly surprised to find a working bathroom, he rushed inside. He bent over the sink and greedily drank from the running water as his hope (of not dying) was renewed. The man riding the bike in the story had many different changes in his emotions during his long trek in this story that were dependent on the setting. These emotional fluctuations clearly demonstrate how the setting can have a profound and direct impact on a character's state of mind and motivation during a challenging journey.
